abstract: The present condition of military affairs gives us hope that the loyal citizens of Georgia may soon be permitted to return to their homes, and again enjoy the protection of the Government of the United States under the old flag of the Union. We hail the promise of such an event with unmingled pleasure; and desirous of cooperating with all loyal Georgians at home and abroad, to secure the return of the State to her proper and natural relations to the Federal Government, we earnestly request all loyal citizens of Georgia, now in the loyal States, to attend a meeting to be held in the City of New-York at the Cooper Institute, on Thursday, the 16th of February inst., at 2 o'clock P.M., that a public expression of opinion may be had by the loyal refugees in regard to the duty of Georgians at home to take the necessary steps to secure peace by "laying down their arms and submitting to the national authority." Loyal citizens of all the insurgent States and citizens generally are earnestly invited to attend. Distinguished speakers have been invited and will be present.

abstract: Con. Amend. passed by U. S. House, States in favor
snippet: Con. Amend. passed by U. S. House, States in favor
lead_paragraph: In the Senate, yesterday, a joint resolution of the Ohio Legislature against the Bankrupt Bill was presented. Mr. SUMNER reported a bill for the extinction of the Scheldt Dues. A resolution was offered, and ordered to be printed, calling upon the President for information in regard to communications with JEFF. DAVIS. Mr. HALE offered a resolution calling upon the Secretary of the Navy for information as to whether the arguments of the Judge-Advocate in the trial of Mr. SMITH, of Boston, had been printed by order of the Navy Department. The resolution was ordered to be printed. Mr. ANTHONY introduced a bill relative to mail service between New-York and the Pacific coast; it was referred to the Committee on the Post-office and Post Roads. The resolution for the appointment of a Standing Committee on Corruptions of the Government was taken up, and Mr. HALE resumed his remarks on the subject. The Retaliation resolution was then taken up. The subject was discussed by Messrs. HENDRICKS, WADE, SUMNER, SPRAGUE and HOWE. After being somewhat amended, the resolution was adopted, and the Senate adjourned.

abstract: ARREST OF A YOUNG MOTHER FOR CAUSING THE DEATH OF HER INFANT. -- Last evening Officer CODNER, of the Forty-fifth Precinct, arrested a young girl of 17, named ANNIE KELLY, at the residence of her aunt, in Thirteenth-street, New-York, who, it appears, was delivered of a female child on Saturday night last, at the residence of a relative in South Second-street, E.D., and who, to hide her shame, left it exposed in a vacant lot near by, where it was found dead on Sunday morning. The girl, who is still very weak, was sent to the hospital by Coroner BARRETT, who will properly investigate the case.

abstract: THE CAPTURED COTTON OF SAVANNAH. -- Three of the four vessels laden with cotton which were to sail from Savannah for this port last week have been detained by order of Collector DRAPER, cotton agent. It is now announced that ten or twelve vessels will soon sail for this city, in fleet, under convoy of gunboats, and will bring to this city about four thousand bales of cotton. It is expected that Mr. DRAPER will shortly conclude his arrangements for the shipment of all the cotton at Savannah, and that he will soon return to this city.

abstract: Constitutional Amendment, Passage of
snippet: Constitutional Amendment, Passage of
lead_paragraph: Congress has decided to submit to the action of the several States an amendment of the Constitution prohibiting slavery forever within the limits or jurisdiction of the United States. The Senate adopted a resolution to this effect at its last session; and the House of Representatives concurred in its passage yesterday, by a vote of 119 ayes to 56 nays. Of those ordinarily and distinctively known as Democrats, there voted for it, Messrs. BAILEY, BALDWIN, COFFROTH, ENGLISH, GANSON, GRISWOLD, HERRICK, HUTCHINS, KING, MCALLISTER, NELSON, ODELL, RADFORD, ROLLINS, STEELE, WHEELER, YEAMAN. If this amendment is concurred in by the Legislatures in three-fourths of all the States, it will become part of the Constitution. The Union is composed of 36 States; the assent of 27 of these is therefore required for the ratification of this amendment. There is very little doubt that it will receive the prompt assent of the Legislatures of the following States;

abstract: The, again; San Salvador Courts Release Rebel Pirates
snippet: The, again; San Salvador Courts Release Rebel Pirates
lead_paragraph: It is always an ungracious task for a great Power to assert its rights against a weaker neighbor. The stronger party, whether the quarrel be of personal, social or national significance, is invariably expected to "yield," not on grounds of right, but on some ill-defined principle of chivalry. We Americans have been doing this sort of thing of late to an extent which barely comes within the bounddaries of prudence.

abstract: Northern Feeling Toward the South (Savannah Relief); Relief to and Northern Feeling
snippet: Northern Feeling Toward the South (Savannah Relief); Relief to and Northern Feeling
lead_paragraph: The vessels which have been sent by our people with food for the poor of Savannah are beginning to arrive, and naturally make some sensation there. They must remind the citizens of Savannah forcibly of the slanderous charges which have been as persistently made against the people of the North, of bloodthirstiness and barbarity. These charges have been made not alone by the rebels. We should expect them there. The necessity which has been upon them of using every means to keep up the determination of their people, and their unscrupulousness in the choice of means, made such calumnies upon the Northern people one of the most natural and readiest weapons which they could use. That similar charges should be rife among our enemies abroad is also not surprising. They are further removed and have had less opportunity for actual knowledge of facts, while the atmosphere has been filled with misrepresentations almost as persistent and nearly as effective as those which have poisoned the Southern air. But there have been some counter influences also. Light has been thrown in upon the unwilling darkness. We doubt now whether the stone fleet which was to close up the port of Charleston will be cited much more as a proof that we are so given up to the inhumanities of war as to be insensible to the calls of justice.

abstract: The history and personal character of the rebel Vice-President, ALEXANDER H. STEPHENS, as well as his strenuous exertions to preserve the South from the folly and crime of secession, are well known to our readers. A.J. CAMPAELL, of Alabama, formerly occupied a seat on the Bench of the Supreme Court of the United States. It will be remembered that just previous to the capture of Fort Sumter, Mr. CAMPBELL appeared in Washington with Mr. FORSYTHE, of Mobile, CRAWFORD, ex-member of Congress from Georgia, and Mr. STEPHENS, on a mission to obtain the peaceful separation of the South from the Union. Since the commencement of hostilities his name has not been prominently before the public. Mr. R.M.T. HUNTER was formerly United States Senator from Virginia. He served a short time as rebel Secretary of State.

abstract: ACADEMY OF MUSIC. -- The prospects for the coming season are extremely good; a large number of the best boxes and seats have been disposed of for the series of twenty-four performances, and for the opening night, on Thursday next, there is already a rush. Mr. MARETZEK is determined not to lose time. To-day the last performance takes place in Boston, and to-morrow the first is given in New-York. In the first named city "Don Sebastian" was played five times, "Fra Diavolo" four times, and "Don Giovanni," "Martha," "Faust" and "Ernani" twice each. It is curious to observe now completely -- for the time being, at least -- "Don Sebastian" has killed GOUNOD's famous work.

abstract: Upon my word, kind reader, you have no idea of the dismal fate of a newspaper correspondent, who finds himself compelled to remain constantly within army limits, just because that event that "Wilkins Micawber" was always hoping for might happen "for something to turn up." The writer finds himself in pretty much the same position of "Mrs. Toodles'" bargains. He will be very handy to have on the spot if wanted.

abstract: Hudson R Train off Track
snippet: Hudson R Train off Track
lead_paragraph: An accident occurred on the Hudson River Railroad yesterday (Tuesday) afternoon. The 4 P.M. train, from Albany, for this city, ran off the track two miles above Hamburgh, owing to the breaking of an axle of one of the cars. Five cars were smashed, but only one person (SAMUEL SIMMONS, a brakeman,) was hurt, and he was dangerously injured.

abstract: Glimmerings of; Stephens', >amp;c ,Mission
snippet: Glimmerings of; Stephens', >amp;c ,Mission
lead_paragraph: It seems probable, from our advices this morning, that A.H. STEPHENS, of Georgia, R. M.T. HUNTER, of Virginia, and A.J. CAMPBELL, of Alabama, are on their way to Washington to confer with the President concerning Peace. We shall hail their appearance there as indicative at least of their conviction that the attempt to overthrow the authority of the National Government in the Southern States is a failure. What more it will indicate, time only can determine. We cannot believe they are coming with any hope of treating for peace on the basis of separation. They are among the ablest and best-informed citizens of the South, and cannot help knowing that both the Government and people were never more determined to suppress the rebellion and restore the Union than they are at the present moment. They must know, moreover, that upon LEE's army at Richmond rests their sole hope of prolonging the contest, -- and that the chances are three to one that LEE cannot maintain himself against the Union forces that are rapidly and resistlessly combining against him. It is not unlikely, therefore, that they believe they can obtain more favorable terms now, while that army is in the field, than would be granted after its defeat; and this conviction may have prompted them to go to Washington.
headline: {'main': 'Glimmerings of Peace.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'Glimmerings of Peace.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: House Refuses to Count
snippet: House Refuses to Count
lead_paragraph: The House of Representatives is a queer institution. It seems to understand the art of looking one way and rowing another to perfection. Professing to support the Administration, it loses no opportunity of denouncing its action. The Chairman of the Committee of Ways and Means is at loggerheads with the Secretary of the Treasury. The Chairman of the Committee on Foreign Relations presents and passes resolutions denouncing the action of the Secretary of State. Leading members charge the most outrageous corruption on the Secretary of the Navy, and demand votes of censure on the Administration they profess to support. While the House is voting men and money and waging war to restore the Union, it is at the same time trying to pass bills to prevent that result. And now that the people, by an overwhelming majority, have just elected a Vice-President from Tennesee, the House has decided, without discussion, that the electoral vote of Tennessee shall not be counted! What new absurdity will be adopted by the House, we must wait a day or two to ascertain.

abstract: Yesterday afternoon a dozen or more of the clerks who are employed in the Enrolling Bureau, at No. 75 Duane-street, indulged in a very lively knockdown on the sidewalk in front of their office, and for fifteen minutes the neighborhood was favored with an interesting exhibition of calisthenic diversions; but as the vigilant Sixth Ward police were nowhere to be seen, no arrests were made, and consequently it is impossible to print the bullies' names, or the cause of hostilities.

abstract: Winternitz, Max; Fraud on Claflin >amp; Co.
snippet: Winternitz, Max; Fraud on Claflin >amp; Co.
lead_paragraph: PENNSYLVANIA MERCHANT COMMITTED TO THE TOMBS. -- In September last, MAX WINTERNITZ, of Newcastle, Lawrence County, Penn., stated to Mr. JOHN J. DONALDSON, of the house of H.B. CLAFLIN & Co., that he had a stock of goods valued at $10,000 and $3,300 in ready money, and that his entire indebtedness was only about $6,000; and upon these representations Mr. DONALDSON gave him credit to the amount of $10,408. Subsequently Mr. EDWARD W. BANCROFT, one of Messrs. H.B. CLAFLIN & CO.'s salesmen, went to Newcastle, and found WINTERNITZ's store closed and in charge of a Sheriff; and he further learned that WINTERNITZ had confessed judgment in favor of his brother DAVID for $12,000, and that in addition to this he was indebted to New-York firms in the sum of $22,000. Thereupon Mr. DONALDSON returned to this city and secured a requisition from Gov. FENTON upon Gov. CURTIN, and with this document Detective DUSENBURY went to Pennsylvania. He returned yesterday with WINTERNITZ, and appeared before Justice DOWLING, and upon affidavits of Messrs. CLAFLIN & CO.'s employes, alleging that the prisoner had been guilty of obtaining goods under false pretences, WINTERNITZ was required to find $20,000 ball. In default of this he was committed to the Tombs.

abstract: Peter R. Strong vs. Mary Strong. -- This was a motion made on affidavits of a rather exciting nature for a motion to hie a supplemental answer to the complaint, charging on the plaintiff adultery with a Mrs. Electra M. Potter, formerly, if not at present, practicing medicine at the Metropolitan Hospital for Widows and Children, and who figured about a year ago in a letter in the Police Gazette. The affidavits of the usual contradictory character establishes but one point, the utter want of character on the part of some at least of the deponents. Mrs. Potter's particular friend testifying that Mrs. Potter had acknowledged the charge, and Mrs. Potter herself denying the whole matter; and still other witnesses swearing to an attempt at bribery and corruption. Should the case ever come to trial, the revelations will no doubt, be of an interesting nature.

abstract: The peace question has assumed a new aspect. It is now the rebels' turn to send commissioners, and accordingly three such gentlemen, Messrs. A.H. STEPHENS, of Georgia, R.M.T. HUNTER, of Virginia, and A.J. CAMPBELL, of Alabama, appeared on our lines in front of Petersburgh, at the point known as "Fort Hell," on Sunday afternoon, and applied for admission under flag of truce. The request was communicated to Gen. GRANT, who is believed to have communicated with the Government promptly on the subject, but the result is not yet fully known. They had not received permission to enter the lines up to Sunday evening. Dispatches from Annapolis, not very reliable, announce that they are on their way from City Point yesterday, and were hourly expected to arrive at Annanpolis. In this case they may reach Washington to-day.
lead_paragraph: The peace question has assumed a new aspect. It is now the rebels' turn to send commissioners, and accordingly three such gentlemen, Messrs. A.H. STEPHENS, of Georgia, R.M.T. HUNTER, of Virginia, and A.J. CAMPBELL, of Alabama, appeared on our lines in front of Petersburgh, at the point known as "Fort Hell," on Sunday afternoon, and applied for admission under flag of truce. The request was communicated to Gen. GRANT, who is believed to have communicated with the Government promptly on the subject, but the result is not yet fully known. They had not received permission to enter the lines up to Sunday evening. Dispatches from Annapolis, not very reliable, announce that they are on their way from City Point yesterday, and were hourly expected to arrive at Annanpolis. In this case they may reach Washington to-day.

abstract: Tibbetts, L C, vs Baxter >amp; Brothers
snippet: Tibbetts, L C, vs Baxter >amp; Brothers
lead_paragraph: Luther C. Tibbetts vs. Archibald Baxter and sixty-three others, including David Dudley Field, the Editors of the Police Gazette, and James Gordon Bennett. -- Mr. Tibbetts, acting as his own attorney, has brought suits against the members of the Corn Exchange, and various other gentlemen of this city, and in his complaint charges them with combining and confederating to deprive him of his property; to imprison him as a criminal until they can confine him as a lunatic; to anger and enrage him so that they may take occasion to separate him from his wife and children; to defame his character, and induce his children to hate his name; and claims against all and each of the defendants $1,000 000 as damages. He has, being a layman, included in his complaint a copy of a long will, a full account of the fracas at the Corn Exchange, viewed from his own stand-point, and various statements which he has heard were made to his children about him, and slanders of him made to others, slating that he squandered his money on a Mrs. Neal, with whom he lived in a house of ill-fame. (He, however, avers that Mrs. Neal was a godly defender of the truth, and an ornament to society,) and various of other remarkable statements to the same tenor and effect.

abstract: -- This pond was visited by large numbers of the recherche of society during the season of cold weather last week, and who continued to do so, contrary to all expectation, for the past three days. It is true, the surface of the ice on this, as on all other ponds, was a little soft, but the cold northwesterly wind of last night attain rendered the surface hard and smooth; so the lovers of the art of skating are now favored with a continuance of the pleasure they have experienced so frequently during the Winter. A fine band of music was in attendance, yesterday, at this pond, and a number of the best skaters in the city attracted much attention in the afternoon.

abstract: Juvenile Gang of Burglars Arrested
snippet: Juvenile Gang of Burglars Arrested
lead_paragraph: -- Two years ago JUDGE VAN COTT and other citizens of Mount Vernon, having for a long time been annoyed by an audacious band of robbers who conducted their operations so adroitly as to baffle the Metropolitan Police, organized a Vigilance Committee and called to their aid detective policeman SLOWEY, of the Central Department, and officer MONTGOMERY, of Mount Vernon. Strict watch was then kept, and the committee daily conferred one with another until they had gathered information showing conclusively that numerous burglaries which had been committed in Westchester County were the work of a gang whose headquarters were in their midst. The Committee then set themselves to the task of capturing the entire band. It was not desirable to apprehend one or two of the thieves, since their confederates, learning that their den had been discovered, might take flight; and therefore the Committee and officers SLOWEY and MONTGOMERY winked at the thieves' transactions until everything, had been made ready for a descent simultaneously in this city and in Westchester. This was made early in the week, on a warrant which was granted by Judge MEEKS; and AUGUST CHRISTMAN, JOHN FINK, JACOB CUSICK (otherwise "Dutch CHARLEY,") JOHN MULLER, JACK ALDER, GEORGE SLONER, PETER SMITH, and three women named MARY JOHNSON, ELLIOTT and MOOLE, were apprehended and taken to White Plains for trial. Several of the prisoners were committed to prison, and others have been admitted to bail. It is alleged that ROBERT CHURCHILL, who was recently shot by an officer, was leader of the gang, and that they held their midnight councils at the abode of Mrs. ELLIOTT, one of the prisoners above named.

abstract: pardoned by President
snippet: pardoned by President
lead_paragraph: The St. Louis Republican states that Brig.-Gen RODDY, who has earned a high reputution during the war, as a partisan Cavalry Commander, and who has cooperated with FORREST in several important operations, grew tired of the contest a few weeks ago. He found means to communicate with the Federal authorities, and through them procured a full pardon from the President as a condition precedent to laying down his arms. His pardon was forwarded to Gen. THOMAS' headquarters by Mr. LINCOLN last week, and by this time, doubtless, is in the hands of the repentant rebel for whom it was prepared. He will soon be heard of, therefore, as having resumed civil pursuits at his old home, which we believe was in Tennessee. The information upon which this statement is made, comes from a loyal officer, who has just arrived from Tennessee. His position in the army there is such to give him an opportunity of personally knowing the truth of what he asserts.
headline: {'main': 'RODDY SUBMITS.; He Receives a Pardon from the President.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'RODDY SUBMITS.; He Receives a Pardon from the President.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: Brazil and the Perils of Democracy; Our, and the Brazil Settlement
snippet: Brazil and the Perils of Democracy; Our, and the Brazil Settlement
lead_paragraph: There is as great disappointment in London among the Tory writers at the settlement of the difficulties with Brazil, as there would be among a herd of Mackerelville rowdies at the breaking up of a prize fight. Mr. SEWARD's apology is evidently a bitter pill for them to swallow. What they desired, and what the enemies of the United States all over the world desired, was that we should have approved of Capt. COLLINS' act, and have set Brazil at defiance, or that we should have disapproved of the act, but have refused to make any atonement. The sinking of the Florida, too, was hailed with delight, as there was little difficulty in making it appear that it was caused designedly, and was thus a fitting termination to the outrage which was begun in the harbor of Bahia.

abstract: Attempt to Blow Up
snippet: Attempt to Blow Up
lead_paragraph: The United States steam transport Suwo Nada Capt. JAYNE, arrived at this port last night from Savannah, and from Hilton Head Jan. 29. Purser THOMAS reports that on the evening of Jan. 27, a disastrous conflagration occurred at Savannah, destroying considerable property, but without loss of life, and on the morning of the 28th, another fire broke out, destroying two squares in the Third District ground. Buildings were torn down to prevent the spreading of the flames, as the wind was blowing strong from the east. Lieut. T.C. SPENCER, Deputy Ordnance Officer, reports that some fiend had placed a keg of powder at the side of the arsenal, corner of York and Walker streets, undoubtedly to blow up the city, as the arsenal contained some thirty tons of powder. The keg was placed in the s[???]ow of a tree, to avoid discovery, with the top [???]ken out. This hellish design is believed to be the work of the rebels, who are in anything but an amiable mood, in view of their present condition.

abstract: Shelby Defeated and Evacuation Town; Fires, Incendiary, Jan 27 and 28; Great Losses
snippet: Shelby Defeated and Evacuation Town; Fires, Incendiary, Jan 27 and 28; Great Losses
lead_paragraph: The peace business grows in interest, though its aspect this morning is scarcely so comforting to the over-sanguine as yesterday. Our special correspondent, with the Fifth Army Corps, whose dispatch is the very latest news from the army lines, announces that up to Tuesday morning at 8 A.M., the rebel Commissioners had not yet passed our pickets. Several interviews between our officers and the rebel officers had been held under flag of truce, and it was generally understood that the absence of Gen. GRANT from City Point accounted for the delay in granting the so-called Commissioners permission to pass the lines. Our Washington special, however, says that early yesterday morning, Secretary SEWARD, accompanied by no ane but his private Secretary, left Washington on a dispatch steamer for City Point, to decide whether to admit and confer with, or refuse and repulse the white-winged messengers. The Richmond papers of Monday and Tuesday, copious extracts from which we print this morning, are in a state of intense alarm and wonderment over this development on their side. They smell a "snare," warn the peace-longing rebel public, and wisely come to the conclusion that the terms will be submission, emancipation and amnesty, in consideration of future good behavior.

abstract: Southern Statutes of Limitation; Statutes of Limitation in Southern States
snippet: Southern Statutes of Limitation; Statutes of Limitation in Southern States
lead_paragraph: The Senate is daily besieged with petitions from small mercantile bodies, asking that the Bankrupt Bill be made prospective in its operation. We can conceive of no reason on which these petitions can possibly be based, except a prevailing, but ill-grounded fear, that a bankrupt measure which should afford relief to insolvent traders residing in the loyal States would necessarily carry absolution to dishonest and disloyal traders residing in the South. If this were a valid reason in itself for defeating the bill as it now stands, one would think that an easy way of depriving Secessionists of the benefit of the measure would be to make its operation exceptional in their particular case, instead of denying its benefits to the large loyal community among us here whose insolvency, in a vast number of cases, is primarily due to secession. By refusing to make the measure retroactive, a disability upon the Northern trader is maintained. But that in no degree affects the liability or non-liability of the Southern trader for debts contracted prior to the rebellion epoch. Refusing to legislate at all in bankruptcy, or passing a law merely prospective in its operation, leaves the rebel or Southern merchant precisely where he is left to-day, by the old State laws, or by the confiscation enactments of the so-called Confederate Congress, which professed to outlaw all the debts owing to loyal citizens of the United States.
headline: {'main': 'The Bankrupt Bill Southern Statutes of Limitation.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'The Bankrupt Bill Southern Statutes of Limitation.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: In the Senate, yesterday, a petition was presented for public markets in Brooklyn. Notice was given of a bill for the completion of Harlem Bridge. A bill was introduced for the better prevention of fraudulent voting. A bill was passed to perfect the amendment of the Constitution, by providing for the appointment of five Commissioners of Appeals.
lead_paragraph: In the Senate, yesterday, a petition was presented for public markets in Brooklyn. Notice was given of a bill for the completion of Harlem Bridge. A bill was introduced for the better prevention of fraudulent voting. A bill was passed to perfect the amendment of the Constitution, by providing for the appointment of five Commissioners of Appeals. A bill was reported enabling husband and wife to be witnesses for or against each other in certain cases. A message was received from Gov. FENTON, informing the Senate of the passage by Congress of the anti-slavery Constitutional amendment, and recommending that immediate action be taken for its ratification. A concurrent resolution to that effect was introduced, but under the rules lays over one day.

abstract: In the Senate yesterday, after a number of miscellaneous petitions had been presented and referred to the appropriate committees, the House resolution of thanks to Gen. SHERIDAN was taken up and unanimously passad. The General Appropriation Bill for the year 1866 was reported.
lead_paragraph: In the Senate yesterday, after a number of miscellaneous petitions had been presented and referred to the appropriate committees, the House resolution of thanks to Gen. SHERIDAN was taken up and unanimously passad. The General Appropriation Bill for the year 1866 was reported. The House resolution, declaring that certain States were in rebellion, and not entitled to representation in the electoral college, was reported with an amendment which was adopted. It was also moved to amend by striking out the word Louisiana. At this point further consideration of the subject was postponed to give way for the reception of the credential of Messrs. NYE and STEWART, Senators-elect from Nevada. These gentlemen were admitted and sworn in. Mr. STEWART drew the long and Mr. NYE the short term. The consideration of the House resolutions, the question being on the motion to strike out the word Louisiana. After some debate, the Senate went into executive session, and soon afterward adjourned.

abstract: The board met in their hall last evening, President McLEAN in the chair, and a quorum present. Among the communications that were received and referred was one from Mr. WILLIAM B. HUTCHINGS, proposing to teach his system of Arithmetic in the public schools.
lead_paragraph: The board met in their hall last evening, President McLEAN in the chair, and a quorum present. Among the communications that were received and referred was one from Mr. WILLIAM B. HUTCHINGS, proposing to teach his system of Arithmetic in the public schools. A resolution recommending that Colored Grammar School No. 6, of the Twentieth Ward, be recognized by the board as consisting of two departments, namely, grammar and primary, was referred to a committee. An appropriation of $10,988 for furniture in the Sixteenth Ward Grammar School, in West Twentieth-street, was made, and a vote was passed increasing by 25 per cent. the salaries of Messrs. S.S. RANDALL, Superintendent, and HENRY KIDDL E, Assistant Superintendent of Public Instruction; after which action the board voted to make a requisition upon the Comptroller for $300,000 for the payment of current expenses. Mr. WILLIAM D. BOGERT was elected as an additional Assistant Clerk to the board, with a salary of $1,200 annually, and Mr. JOHN DUNHAM was chosen engineer.

abstract: Negotiation Resolution in House; The on Presidential Negotiations
snippet: Negotiation Resolution in House; The on Presidential Negotiations
lead_paragraph: The country will be glad to learn that Mr. FERNANDO WOOD, of this city, has introduced a resolution into the House of Representatives to the effect, that it is the duty of the President, under no circumstances, to proffer or accept negotiations which shall admit, by the remotest implication, the existence of any other Federal or Confederate Government within the territory of the United States. The friends of the Union will feel easy, now that they know that Mr. WOOD has his eye on Mr. LINCOLN. The well-known disposition of the President to acknowledge the Confederacy, renders the vigilance of a gentleman like Mr. WOOD, who has been from the outset the uncompromising foe of that institution, and the firm opponent of all attempts to tolerate its existence, peculiarly necessary at this juncture. We are glad to see, also, that Mr. WOOD is of opinion that it is "the duty of the President, in every legal and constitutional manner, to preserve the integrity of the Union." Should he get this resolution passed, it will then become Mr. LINCOLN's duty, if he retains a proper respect for Mr. WOOD and for the House, to try the only means of restoring the Union which, we believe, is, in Mr. WOOD's opinion, either "legal or constitutional," and that is, asking the revolted States, in a firm and decided manner, whether they are going to come back or not.
headline: {'main': 'The "Single Eye" on President Lincoln.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'The "Single Eye" on President Lincoln.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: AFFRAY BETWEEN SUBSTITUTE RUNNERS.  Sergt. CRAFT and Officer REAGAN, of the Forty-second Precinct Police, arrested two men on Tuesday evening, on the charge of highway robbery, preferred by THOMAS BURT, of No. 102 Cherry-street, New-York. Complainant states that while passing ...
lead_paragraph: AFFRAY BETWEEN SUBSTITUTE RUNNERS. -- Sergt. CRAFT and Officer REAGAN, of the Forty-second Precinct Police, arrested two men on Tuesday evening, on the charge of highway robbery, preferred by THOMAS BURT, of No. 102 Cherry-street, New-York. Complainant states that while passing down York-street, on the night of the 30th ult., he was assaulted, near Gold-street, by three men, who robbed him of a pocket-book containing $30. The two men were examined by Dr. JACOBS, and BURT not being able to identify them they were discharged. Officer REAGAN went after a third party, and found him in New-York, lying dangerously ill from a severe stab received during the assault on BURT. He could not be removed. It is claimed that the affair was the result of a difference in hand-money, the parties being engaged in substitute running.

abstract: Commissioners; Objects Conjectured
snippet: Commissioners; Objects Conjectured
lead_paragraph: The Peace Commissioners, it seems, have not come to Washington at all. Our correspondent with the army gives intelligence of their movements down to the morning of day before yesterday, (Tuesday,) and at that time they had not even reached headquarters. We learn from Washington that Secretary SEWARD has gone to meet them, with what instructions or for what purpose is, of course, open to the Widest possible conjecture. It is perfectly safe to say, however, that he has not gone to tender them peace on the basis of separation; and it is also safe to believe that, if they come prepared to recognize the supreme authority of the Constitution and laws of the United States, they will find the Government disposed to treat every other subject of complaint or of demand which they may make, with the utmost liberality. The President has repeatedly given them and the world the most emphatic assurances on this subject. If they are prepared to talk of peace on the basis of Union they will probably visit Washington. If not, we presume they won't.
headline: {'main': 'The Peace Commission.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'The Peace Commission.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: Bergen County Farmers' Club, Officers of
snippet: Bergen County Farmers' Club, Officers of
lead_paragraph: BERGEN COUNTY FARMERS' CLUB -- A number of the residents of Paramus and adjoining places, met on Saturday evening last at Union Hall, and organized the Bergen County Farmers' Club. The officers chosen were JAMES KELLEY, President; JOHN J. ZABINSKIE, GARRETT H. VAN DIEN, Vice-Presidents; J.W. ENGLAND, Corresponding Secretary; E.J. KEELEY, Recording Secretary and Treasurer. Meetings will be held semi-monthly, at the same place, on the first and third Saturdays of each month, and an annual exhibition of the agricultural, horticultural and other products of Bergen County is to be held in the month of September, at which prizes for excellence will be awarded.

abstract: Petroleum Exchange; Opened in N Y
snippet: Petroleum Exchange; Opened in N Y
lead_paragraph: The Petroleum interest in this city, having solemnly determined that their light should not be hidden under a bushel, have opened a public exchange for barter and sale of Oil Stocks at No. 73 Broadway, corner of Rector-st. The rooms there selected were formally opened yesterday, and consecrated to the service of Oil, and the event was deemed of such interest as to call forth several speeches in glorification of Petroleum. The magnates of this great and growing interest, assembled at the Exchange at noon, and before the meeting was called to order, entered into social converse and discussion concerning oil, wells, derricks, steam-engines, pumping-wells, spouting-wells, gas, &c. From the talk of the members of the new Exchange, a stranger would conclude that the glories of ancient Greece were nothing to the grease of modern times. Some oleaginous HOMER must arise to sing its story, its romance, and its reality. The oil men are largely given to painting in their favorite product bright-clouded pictures of its future. They depict it mounting the throne of the defunct King Cotton, and swaying the sceptre of commerce over the universe. They point to it as an instance of the compensating laws and overruling of Providence, which supplies the wants of man from new and unseen resources when the old ones fall. Three years ago, the world in general and New-Bedford in particular, lamented the scarcity of whales and the decadence of the fisheries. Now, Titusville has taken the place of New-Bedford, and is the centre of light. But however the members of the Petroleum Exchange may be given to praise of oil, it is undeniable that the oil interest has become one of the largest in this country. The capital now invested in this business is enormous, and Mr. JACKSON has supplied a want long felt in opening a public exchange for dealers in petroleum stocks.
headline: {'main': 'Opening of a New Public Petroleum Exchange.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'Opening of a New Public Petroleum Exchange.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: WARD SCHOOL No. 14. -- The committee of the Senate, Messrs. WHITE, HUMPHREY and MUNGER, visited Ward School No. 14, in the Twenty-first Ward, yesterday morning, in company with the President and Clerk of the Board of Education, Commissioner MILLER, of the Seventeenth Ward, Messrs. STEVENSON, BANKS, ALLEN and GOEHEGAN, Trustees and Inspectors, and quite a large number of ladies and gentlemen. The committee expressed themselves highly pleased with the exercises. The declamation in the male department, the singing and calesthenics in the female department, and also in the primary department, were excellent, and reflected great credit on Mr. OLNEY, of the male department; Miss WHITNEY, of the female department; and Miss MEYES, of the primary department. Senator WHITE addressed the children of the primary department, and expressed himself much pleased with the order and discipline of the School.

abstract: Banks, New-York; and Tax on United States Bonds; U S Bonds Cannot be Taxed by State Legislature
snippet: Banks, New-York; and Tax on United States Bonds; U S Bonds Cannot be Taxed by State Legislature
lead_paragraph: The recent decision of the Supreme Court of the United States in the case of the Bank of the Commonwealth against the Tax Commissioners of NewYork, will have a most important bearing on the financial condition of the city. It will be remembered that on the 25th of February, 1862, an act was passed by Congress exempting United States Bonds from taxation, and, availing themselves of the provisions of this law, the city banks and insurance companies refused to pay the demands of the Tax Commissioners for the assessment on such portion of their capital as was invested in these securities. The banks that refused payment of the taxes imposed were the Atlantic, Bank of Commerce, National, American Exchange, Continental, Hanover, Shoe and Leather, Importers' and Traders', Irving, Mechanics', Mechanics' Banking Association, Mercantile, Ocean, Tradesmen's and Union, the total amount of taxes due from these banks being $256,355 86. In the meantime, the Board of Supervisors applied to the Legislature for an act specially empowering them to levy a tax on the capital of Banks and Insurance Companies, and a bill to that effect having been passed by the Legislature, a number of the Banks and Insurance Companies came forward and paid the Tax Commissioner's demands. Twenty Banks however, and fifteen Insurance Companies persisted in refusing payment, and carried their cases to the Court of Appeals.

abstract: Taken near City Point
snippet: Taken near City Point
lead_paragraph: The peace news this morning affords the important intelligence that Secretary SEWARD yesterday morning telegraphed to the President that his presence was needed at Fortress Monroe. The President at once took a special car for Annapolis, which place he reached at 1 P.M., and immediately embarked on the steamer Thomas Colyer for Fortress Monroe, where he undoubtedly arrived before breakfast this morning. From the army we learn that, permission having been accorded, the rebel Commissioners were received into our lines, and escorted to City Point on Tuesday afternoon, and that on Wednesday morning they were on board Gen. GRANT's dispatch boat at City Point, apparently awaiting the arrival of some one from Washington. It is possible that a conference to-day, either at Fortress Monroe or City Point, may be the result of these movements.

abstract: and N Y Chamber of Commerce; Chamber of Commerce and Bankrupt Bill
snippet: and N Y Chamber of Commerce; Chamber of Commerce and Bankrupt Bill
lead_paragraph: -- The committee of the New-York Chamber of Commerce, to which the petition of the Boston Chamber against the Bankrupt Bill was referred, made yesterday a pointed and conclusive report in favor of the measure as it now stands before the Senate. The committee have come to the conclusion -- and in this we are satisfied the great body of our New-York merchants agree with them -- that the bill, in the shape in which it passed the House of Representatives, is so framed as to give ample assurance of protection to the interests of the creditor. The committee do not feel competent to declare in an unqualified manner whether, by any positive enactments of Congress rebel debtors in the South may be prevented from profiting by the proposed law. But they point out that much time must in any case elapse before debts due to our merchants here can be collected at the South -- time at least sufficient to enable the dishonest debtor to place his assets beyond the reach of his creditors.

abstract: Wade Senator and Mr. Blair's Richmond Visit
snippet: Wade Senator and Mr. Blair's Richmond Visit
lead_paragraph: We fear that Senator WADE is falling into a chronic state of discontent. He seems to be especially indignant with the President for having allowed Mr. BLAIR to go to Richmond, and declared his determination a day or two since, to "know how he came to do it, if there is power in the United States Senate to be informed on that subject." We share Mr. WADE's curiosity and his disapprobation to some extent; but so old and so accomplished a statesman as he is ought to know that there are some things which the President of the United States may do without asking consent of the Senate, and without holding himself responsible to the Ohio Senator.

abstract: ACADEMY OF MUSIC. -- Mr. MARETZEK's season commenced last evening, under auspices that were most flattering to the impresario and agreeable to the audience. The house was full, and the weather was fine. We have seldom seen a more fashionable assembly. The boxes were filled, the parquet and balcony crowed, and up stairs the lieges -- who were privileged to hear good music for little money -- cropped out in black but not picturesque masses. "Don Sebastian" was played. Mad. ZUCCHI, as the heroine, renewed the triumphs of last season. She was in superb voice, and threw into the role of Zaida all that subdued intensity which belongs to the best school of Italian art, but is exhibited us but rarely on the American stage. Sig. MASSIMILIANI's rentree is memorable for the fact that it marks a distinct improvement in his style. His manner is no longer indifferent. He acts. In the ritornelli, which are embarrassing to the best dramatic artists, he succeeded last evening in giving a bearable idea of the emotion -- or change of emotion -- intended by the composer, and throughout he exhibited strength, individuality, and even power. We record these facts with pleasure, because the defect of Signor MASSIMILIANI's style, so far, has been a lack of warmness and identification with the character he was interpreting. In every other respect the gentlemen's impersonation was admirable. He has seldom been in better voice. The romanza at the end of the second act was superbly rendered -- the high note flowing easily and melodiously from his well-trained voice. Signor BELLINI -- most conscientious, enthusiastic, and striving of artists -- was excellent as Camoens. The performance, indeed, was in all respects a happy inauguration of a season which, although the last, bids fair to be the most brilliant on Mr. MARETZEK's honorable record.

abstract: At a few minutes past 6 o'clock last evening the streets of our city again resounded with the peal of the fire alarm from the belfry of the Exchange, and at the same time dense volumes of smoke were discovered issuing from the large double tenement four-story brick building on the north side of Broughton-street. The fire, which is supposed to be the fiendish work of an incendiary, originated in the cellar of the western tenement, which was used as a miscellaneous store-room, and filled with cotton, resin, leather, furniture and other combustible material. The upper portion of the building was occupied by several families, and so rapid was the progress of the flames, that all modes of egress and ingress were cut off, the smoke curling up the stairs in dence volumes, bidding defiance to all attempts to enter the building.

abstract: Monitors and Iron-clads in U. S. and England; Military and Naval Improvements
snippet: Monitors and Iron-clads in U. S. and England; Military and Naval Improvements
lead_paragraph: No matter what great national advantages are to be gained by a decided military or naval improvement, there are always those who are unwilling that the country should be benefited except through themselves. The great opposition with which the introduction of the Monitor system has been met is an illustration of this. To prove the uselessness or inferiority of monitors, a long list of iron-clads, belonging to the French and English navies, are quoted, carrying a large number of guns, and it is left to be inferred that as we have not such a number of vessels of this class, with such a large armament, we should have but little chance against these Powers in a naval war. The facts are, however, the very reverse of what they appear on the surface to be.

abstract: Relief; How Received, Meetings, >amp;c.
snippet: Relief; How Received, Meetings, >amp;c.
lead_paragraph: The steamer Rebecca Clyde, which, it will be remembered, was generously given by the NewYork and Washington Steamship Company to carry the New-York supplies to the needy of Savannah, arrived off Quarantine last night, having on board the deputation sent by the Chamber of Commerce and Produce Exchange to superintend the distribution of their bounty, Messrs. ARCHIBALD BAXTER, C. H.P. BABCOCK and FRANK LATHROP. The Clyde brings full details of the meeting of the inhabitants of Savannah, held 25th ult., to express their gratitude for the timely aid furnished by their brethren in the North. She also brings accounts of a great fire which occurred in Savannah on the night of the 27th, resulting in the destruction of no less than 225 buildings, including the Confederate Arsenal, which contained a large quantity of fixed ammunition, the explosion of which added considerably to the damage. The cargo of the Rebecca Clyde consists of 500 bales of cotton, for Government account, and 172 tierces rice, belonging to the City of Savannah.

abstract: Our Relations with; Alien Bill; Alien Bill in Canada
snippet: Our Relations with; Alien Bill; Alien Bill in Canada
lead_paragraph: A bill of more than local interest was passed to its second reading in the Canadian House of Assembly fon Tuesday. It is a measure giving power to the Provincial Government, under certain conditions, to remove such aliens from the country as may have proved themselves unworthy of an asylum therein. In other words, it is an alien act of a most stringent character, framed in part upon various British acts, such as those passed in 1772, in 1802, 1803, 1814, 1815 and 1818; as also in part upon the statute passed by the American Congress in 1838, to prevent incursions hence into the Provinces during the insurrectionary epoch.

abstract: The, Case-- Prize Laws; The Circassian, Chief J. Chase's Decision; Decision in Circassian, Blockade-runner Case; Circassian; The Case
snippet: The, Case-- Prize Laws; The Circassian, Chief J. Chase's Decision; Decision in Circassian, Blockade-runner Case; Circassian; The Case
lead_paragraph: The first of that series of cases before our prize courts which have given rise to so much discussion, oftentimes acrimonious, in England and France, about the principles of prize law and the rights of neutrals, has reached a final decision in the Supreme Court of the United States. We refer to the case of the Circassian, in which Chief Justice CHASE a few days since rendered the decision of the court, affirming the decree of condemnation entered against the vessel and her cargo by Judge MARVIN, in the District Court of Florida.

abstract: Constitutional Amendment, Popularity of
snippet: Constitutional Amendment, Popularity of
lead_paragraph: The Amendment obtained a majority in the House exceeding expectation. Its popularity, as now manifesting itself through the country, is more surprising yet. It is not only hailed with universal joy by the friends of the Administration, but it receives the willing acceptance, if not the positive favor, of the party which heretofore has stood firmly by every interest of slavery. The "Democracy," which always before the war rallied with peculiar spirit upon the slavery-protecting sections of the Constitution, and whose great watchword since the war, has been "the Constitution as it is," now move not a step in earnest, or lift a finger, to save slavery. A certain force of habit causes a portion of them to mouth a phrase or two of dissent, but there is no heart in it. They neither make, nor attempt to make, any serious fight. Whether or not they have the grace to welcome the right, they at least have the sense to recognize the inevitable.
headline: {'main': 'The Popularity of the Constitutional Amendment.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'The Popularity of the Constitutional Amendment.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

lead_paragraph: The Army and Navy Journal for this week contains, in full, the elaborate report of the Naval Committee appointed to consider and report on the subject of rifle cannon for the navy. The committee find that 703 Parrot guns of all calibres, have been issued to the naval service, and that of these twentyone have burst or been otherwise injured by explosion.

abstract: -- Coroner GAMBLE concluded an inquest yesterday upon the body of Mr. HORACE CUSHING, at No. 18 West Thirty-third-street, and the jury found that deceased "came to his death by concussion of the brain, with fracture of the skull, the result of injuries received by jumping out of a window on the morning of Jan. 25, 1865, while laboring under temporary aberration of mind." JOHN T. CRANE, M.D., made a deposition as follows: "I have been the attending physician of deceased for several years past; during the past few months he has suffered at times with great depression of spirits, the result, in my opinion, of a system of persecution, continually followed up, by those to whom he was indebted at the time of his failure in 1861; deceased's mind had become so far depressed that he showed confirmed symptoms of melancholy; and in one of these fits of melancholy, in my opinion, he committed the act which caused his death." Mr. CUSHING was a native of Massachusetts, aged 45 year....Coroner COLLIN held an inquest, at the Sailors' Home, in Cherry-street, over the body of JOHN BEND, a seaman. BEND leaped from the window of his room, on the fourth story of the Home, yesterday morning, white laboring under mania, and was instantly killed. Deceased was 30 years of age.

abstract: The citizens' meeting at the Exchange yesterday noon, to respond to the generous contributions of the New-York, Boston and Philadelphia people for our needy, was one of the most enthusiastic and sympathetic assemblages that has ever convened in the "Forest City." Owing to the very short notice
lead_paragraph: The citizens' meeting at the Exchange yesterday noon, to respond to the generous contributions of the New-York, Boston and Philadelphia people for our needy, was one of the most enthusiastic and sympathetic assemblages that has ever convened in the "Forest City." Owing to the very short notice which was given to the public of the meeting, it was feared that the attendance would not be commensurate with the occasion, but long before the hour announced for the opening of the meeting, the Council Chamber in the Exchange was crowded with a large number of the most prominent citizens of Savannah. From the portico of the Exchange, the superb band of the Second Brigade, Second Division. Twentieth Army Corps, led by Mr. DAVID H. BOWEN, filled the air with harmonious sounds prior to the opening of the meeting. At 12 1/2 o'clock the Council Chamber was filled to overflowing, hundreds being unable to obtain admission, or even standing room within sound of the speakers' voices. We experienced a thrill of delight, as we cast a glance at the audience crowded within those historic walls. We instinctively contrasted the present hour with that of six weeks since, and, as we silently reverted to the dreary pictures of the past, our hearts were filled with deep gratitude for the privilege of being permitted to live to witness such a glorious metamorphosis in the sentiments of so many who, but a few months ago, could find no language strong enough in which to express their denunciation and hatred for the Government of the United states and the Northern people.

If they find them empowered and inclined to talk of peace on the basis of Union, we presume they will be permitted to come to Washington. If their only errand is to insist on independence, probably they will have leave to return at once to their own capital.

abstract: West, Robert Athol, Formerly Editor Washington Commercial
snippet: West, Robert Athol, Formerly Editor Washington Commercial
lead_paragraph: The Commercial of last evening announces the death, in Washington on Wednesday last, of Mr. ROBERT ATHOW WEST, formerly editor of that paper. Mr. WEST's connection with the Commercial was first formed when the late W.L. STONE was its editor. He was assistant editor under Mr. INMAN, and upon the retirement of that gentleman took charge of the paper and discharged the duties of that position for many years with great acceptance. In June, 1863, he went to Washington to edit the Chronicle, and about a year ago became head of the Bureau of Military Justice, under Judge Advocate-General HOLT. Although a foreigner by birth -- Mr. WEST was born in England -- he was an American by choice and conviction. His culture was wide and varied, and his facility in writing fitted him in an imminent degree for the profession in which he did such good service, and which loses in his death one of its foremost members.

abstract: Census of, 1855, Particulars of; Presented to American Geographical and Statistical Society
snippet: Census of, 1855, Particulars of; Presented to American Geographical and Statistical Society
lead_paragraph: A meeting of the American Geographical and Statistical Society was held at its rooms last evening, Hon. CHARLES P. DALY in the Chair. After some routine business, a letter was read from Hon. CHARLES F. ADAMS, the American Minister to England, and a map exhibited, which he presented to the society. The map is known as "Mitchell's Map," was made in 1755, and is the only one of the kind in this country. It is the one upon which the boundary question between the United States and Great Britain was settled. After some further business, the President introduced Mr. F.B. HOUGH, Superintendent of the State Census of 1855, who read a historical sketch of the census in New-York, and a statement of the plan of the census to be taken in this State during the present year. He commenced with a review of the census in colonial times, mentioned the alterations and improvements made since, the introduction of Agricultural Statistics in 1821, the great improvement made in 1850 of giving the name of each person; said that in 1855 the State had adopted the Federal system of taking the census, with additional columns for the material and value of dwellings. The census was then arranged by the Secretary of State and Marshals appointed by him to the number of 1,744, it being the intention to appoint one to each election district. That law is still in existence, and that will be the basis of the coming census, except that large election districts will be subdivided. Each enumerator in the country will have a population of about 2,000 persons, and in the city about 3,000. To do this it will be necessary to appoint about 2,500 enumerators. The most serious obstacle which lies in the way of taking a full census, is, that by many it is believed to be in some way connected with military matters or with taxation. The only remedy for this is an official statement that it is required by the State law, under the constitution, and that it has no connection in any way with either of these matters; and in order to relieve the collectors of information from all, even seeming, connection with draft or taxation, they will be called Enumerators instead of Marshals. The principal improvements recommended in 1865 are as follows: The ages of persons under five years of age will be reported by months; the place of employment, if different from the residence of the family; a separate table of information concerning deaf, dumb, blind, idiots, &c., and all facts connected with them; an inquiry as to all who are now or have been in the army or navy, their original position, promotions and present positions, or if they have left the service, whether wounded, sick, or in what condition; the statistics of marriage, same as in 1855, except that the names of both parties will be given, and how the ceremony was performed, whether by a clergyman or by civil authorities; death statistics, same as in 1855, except to give name of party deceased; agricultural statistics same as in 1855, except that in each crop, the number of acres planted the previous year and now in crop, will be inquired into, and the yield of the present year; a special inquiry will be made regarding epidemics among domestic animals; the manufacturing statistics will be given the same as in 1855, except that particular blanks will be given for great manufacturers, and particular blanks will be given, also, for all institutions, orphan asylums, &c. At the conclusion of the lecture, a vote of thanks was passed to Mr. HOUGH, and a request for a copy of the paper, to be deposited in the archives of the society, alter which the meeting adjourned.

Coroner FARREL took charge of the body, and will hold an inquest to-day.

abstract: New-York City; Quota of
snippet: New-York City; Quota of
lead_paragraph: -- Messrs. ANDREWS and BELL, of the State Senate, have succeeded in securing a suspension of that portion of the approaching draft which was added to the original quota of New-York by the order of Jan. 24. This will reduce the draft at the outset about one-fifth, -- to about 16,000 in this city. The propriety of the increased quota demanded by Gen. FRY is to be made the subject of further inquiry.

abstract: The Steamship Africa, from Liverpool Jan. 21, via Queenstown Jan. 22, arrived at Halifax yesterday.
lead_paragraph: The Steamship Africa, from Liverpool Jan. 21, via Queenstown Jan. 22, arrived at Halifax yesterday. Her news is two days later. The London Globe authoritatively denies the reports of the departure of British troops for Canada. The Captain of the Sea King, now the Shenandoah, had been again arrested, charged with enlisting men for that vessel. He was admitted to bail. It is denied that the Queen will open Parliament in person. The shipping of the Atlantic telegraph cable from the works of Messrs. GLASS, ELIOT & CO. to the vessels which are to convey it to the steamship Great Eastern, commenced on the 19th of January, and will continue without intermission until the end of May, when all the cable will be coiled on board of the great ship. In the Spanish Senate the opposition moved an amendment to the Queen's address, declaring a new electoral law necessary, demanding representation for the Antilles, and the preservation of San Domingo to Spain.

abstract: The enemy's newspapers have falsely reported the Tallahassee as captured. She ran into New Inlet just after the capture of Fort Fisher, when discovering that some important change, he knew not then what, had occurred in the military situation, her commander, Capt. MAFFIT, put to sea and made good his escape. He touched the South Carolina coast, and put ashore a messenger with dispatches, who has reached this city. The news, if any, brought by the messenger, has not been made public.

lead_paragraph: In the Senate, yesterday, a resolution was presented calling upon the Secretary of War for the publication of the record of the court-martial in the case of Col. NORTH. A bill was introduced for a Territorial Government of the Indian country. After an attempt by Mr. SUMNER to call up the resolution relating to the Peace Commissioners, the resolution declaring that the electoral vote of certain States shall not be counted, was taken up. An animated discussion ensued, in which nearly all the members participated, but no conclusion was arrived at prior to the adjournment at 4 o'clock.

abstract: There seems to be a disposition on the part of many of our citizens to conclude that the quota of the County of New-York will be filled in some way. It may be an unpleasant fact, but it is well that all interested in the perspective draft should know that, under the present management of affairs in this city, the chances are exceedingly small to avoid it. At present we have not less than six thousand men to furnish before the 15th inst. to fill our quota, and from that number, if we persist in allowing Supervisor BLUNT to take the course he is now pursuing, we shall not find, on the 15th of February, a deduction of more than 110. For some time it has been a habit to place the most implicit confidence in the management of affairs at the different county recruiting station, our citizens thinking that all was going on right; but a slight investigation will develop the fact that the County Volunteer Committee have been the indirect means of discouraging enlistments in this city, and encouraging volunteering outside of New-York. Mr. BLUNT pays but one-fifth the amount of hand-money paid by licensed brokers. At his office, a recruit brought by an honest broker is frequently badgered into saying that the party introducing him is not entitled to the hand-money, and the result is, the broker leaves in disgust, affirming that he will never be similarly trapped. This fact maybe illustrated by repeating the questions usually asked of the recruit on his application to enlist:

abstract: In the Senate, yesterday, the House bill for the construction of a ship canal round the Falls of Niagara was read twice and referred to the Military Committee. The Senate bill in relation to the enrollment act was made the special order for to-day. Mr. DALE'S resolution calling for ...
lead_paragraph: In the Senate, yesterday, the House bill for the construction of a ship canal round the Falls of Niagara was read twice and referred to the Military Committee. The Senate bill in relation to the enrollment act was made the special order for to-day. Mr. DALE's resolution calling for information in regard to the employment of Government detectives, was taken up and passed. The Senate, upon the motion of Mr. SHERMAN, resolved to insist upon its amendments to the Military Academy and Deficiency Bills. The consideration of the joint resolution to exclude the electoral votes of certain States in rebellion was then resumed, and a long debate ensued upon Mr. TEN EYCK's motion to strike out the word "Louisiana," so as to exempt that State from the provisions of the resolution. The proposed amendment was advocated warmly by Mr. DOOLITTLE, of Wisconsin; but the motion to strike out was disagreed to. An amendment offered by Mr. HARRIS, of New York, was also lost. Pending the discussion of an amendment offered by Mr. COLLAMER, the Senate adjourned.

abstract: Its Importance to Rebels
snippet: Its Importance to Rebels
lead_paragraph: However dim and dubious may be the prospects of peace through the negotiations at Fortress Monroe, the most cheering hopes may certainly be entertained as to the prospects of peace through victory in the field. SHERMAN's South Carolina campaign is, and has for some time been, in active progress. It has not been as rapid as the public expected it would be, when his right wing first moved out from Savannah; but it has been quite as rapid as the local and military conditions would permit. The topography of the country in Northern Georgia made SHERMAN's Atlanta campaign sufficiently difficult; the topography of the country around Richmond makes campaigning there exceedingly difficult, as has been attested by half a dozen Generals, successively, in command of the Army of the Potomac. But we suppose that if we could denote the most difficult locality in the whole land for military operations, it would be precisely the region surrounding Charleston, for a distance of forty miles. It is bottomless swamp, tangled brake, inextricable jungle -- a region of that amphibious character which marks so much of the Southern coast -- the raveled and unfinished ends of nature's web, where sea and land keep up a natural warfare. Military men have always considered it virtually impossible to move an army with its heavy guns and great wagon trains through this section. The small movement made by SHERMAN from Pocotaligo toward Charleston ten days ago, had to be turned back because of the impossibility of getting through the swamp; and we are sure that nothing could more astonish those acquainted with the locality than a successful military march along the railroad to Charleston.

abstract: The rebel commissioners arrived at Fortress Monroe in Gen. GRANT's dispatch steamer on Wednesday afternoon, and found Secretary SEWARD awaiting them, having arrived from Annapolis in the steamer River Queen. The steamers at once proceeded to an anchorage in the stream, side by side, and a conference war held, the result of which was a summons to the President, who arrived on the scene very early yesterday morning. It was understood in Washington last night that the conference closed yesterday, and that the President and Mr. SEWARD were on their way back to Washington, where they will undoubtedly arrive to-day. Of course, nothing further is known.

abstract: THE TOMBS. -- In August last Mr. THOMAS J. HAND, of Port Huron, Mich., introduced himself to Mr. JONATHAN S. CHRISTIE, of No. 35 Courtlandt-street, wholesaler of boots and shoes, and represented that he owned real estate in Port Huron, and had a tannery there, in which he had invested $16,000, and that he owed only $1,000. Mr. CHRISTIE, accepting HAND's story as true, sold him a stock of $5,000 worth of boots and shoes, at ninety days; but before the expiration of that period he learned that his customer had no assets, either at Port Huron or elsewhere, but was merely a sharp adventurer. Mr. CHRISTIE thereupon preferred a complaint before Justice DODGE, and with a warrant for HAND's arrest, Officer SIEBERT, of Jefferson Market Police Court, and Mr. AARON H. DUNCOMB, Mr. CHRISTIE's salesman, went to Port Huron and apprehended the accused; but they were compelled to await the arrival of a requisition from Gov. SEYMOUR upon Gov. BLAIR, and HAND's friends, in the mean time, served a writ of habeas corpus, and thus secured the prisoner, whom they at once carried off to Port Sarnia. HAND did not venture from Her Majesty's dominions until last week, when he crossed to Detroit, and was immediately taken into custody by Sheriff E.K. SULLIVAN, and surrendered to Officer SIEBERT. The accused was committed, yesterday, in default of $10,000 bail.
lead_paragraph: THE TOMBS. -- In August last Mr. THOMAS J. HAND, of Port Huron, Mich., introduced himself to Mr. JONATHAN S. CHRISTIE, of No. 35 Courtlandt-street, wholesaler of boots and shoes, and represented that he owned real estate in Port Huron, and had a tannery there, in which he had invested $16,000, and that he owed only $1,000. Mr. CHRISTIE, accepting HAND's story as true, sold him a stock of $5,000 worth of boots and shoes, at ninety days; but before the expiration of that period he learned that his customer had no assets, either at Port Huron or elsewhere, but was merely a sharp adventurer. Mr. CHRISTIE thereupon preferred a complaint before Justice DODGE, and with a warrant for HAND's arrest, Officer SIEBERT, of Jefferson Market Police Court, and Mr. AARON H. DUNCOMB, Mr. CHRISTIE's salesman, went to Port Huron and apprehended the accused; but they were compelled to await the arrival of a requisition from Gov. SEYMOUR upon Gov. BLAIR, and HAND's friends, in the mean time, served a writ of habeas corpus, and thus secured the prisoner, whom they at once carried off to Port Sarnia. HAND did not venture from Her Majesty's dominions until last week, when he crossed to Detroit, and was immediately taken into custody by Sheriff E.K. SULLIVAN, and surrendered to Officer SIEBERT. The accused was committed, yesterday, in default of $10,000 bail.

abstract: Constitutional Amendment Removes Obstacles to Peace; the Obstacle to Peace, at an end
snippet: Constitutional Amendment Removes Obstacles to Peace; the Obstacle to Peace, at an end
lead_paragraph: Congress, in passing the Constitutional Amendment for the abolition of slavery, has removed what has generally been regarded as a formidable obstacle to the termination of the war. Hitherto, the express abandonment of slavery by the South has always been deemed essential to peace. The country could never consent to leave the cause and root of the rebellion untouched. Until the South would concede the validity of the Emancipation Proclamation, and surrender slavery, it has generally been assumed, the country would not consent to peace. And the President stood substantially pledged to maintain that proclamation by all the Executive power of the Government.

lead_paragraph: FATAL RAILROAD ACCIDENT. -- On Thursday afternoon JOHN FITZPATRICK, of No. 134 East Forty-fifth-street, was at work on the Third-avenue Railroad track, near Forty-ninth-street, when a team ran against him and prostrated him on the track, and car No. 61, which was approaching at full speed, passed over his body. He was taken up dead. Coroner GAMBLE held an inquest, and the jury found that the occurrence was accidental. FITZPATRICK was a native of Ireland, aged 40 years.

abstract: Peace Conference; the; Resumes Seat in Rebel Congress
snippet: Peace Conference; the; Resumes Seat in Rebel Congress
lead_paragraph: For the first time since the war commenced we now have what may fairly be called a Peace Conference. Not a word has ever been directly exchanged between our Government and the rebel authorities concerning peace. The little communication which has taken place on the subject has all been the irresponsible work of private parties, officious not official, tolerated rather than sanctioned. It amounted, and in fact could amount, to no more than what was daily uttered by the public press of the two sections -- simply restating the issues, and reprotesting a determination to fight it out on those issues to the last extremity. Furnished with no discretion, it could do nothing to adjust. Committing nobody who had any power in the premises, it could elicit nothing upon which official action could be ventured. The most it could do was to stir a little dust. It had no more real effect upon the mighty conflict than the frisking of the field mice in the track of our armies.
headline: {'main': 'The Peace Conference.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'The Peace Conference.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: Questions Involved in; Securities, State power to tax
snippet: Questions Involved in; Securities, State power to tax
lead_paragraph: The cases recently decided by the Supreme Court at Washington, arising out of the controversy between the banks and the Commissioners of Taxes of this State, are of so much importance, not only in the amount of money involved, but in the principles upon which the decisions rest, that there ought to be no misunderstanding about the principles, and no ignorance about the facts; and yet there are both. The cases have been spoken of by one of our cotemporaries as being "in regard to the power of the Federal Legislature to exempt certain national securities from local taxation," and others have taken occasion to charge Congress with unwise action in enacting that they should be exempt from State taxation.

abstract: Gas; Family Suffocated by at Brooklyn
snippet: Gas; Family Suffocated by at Brooklyn
lead_paragraph: A shocking discovery was made at No. 228 Washington-street, Brooklyn, shortly after noon yesterday. A family of six persons, who had taken possession of the house the day previous, passed the night in a small room in the rear, on the first floor. The weather being very cold, they put up a Franklin stove and lighted a coal fire. Closing the door and windows, they went to sleep, some on the bed, others on the sofa and chairs, while the infant was placed in the cradle. The gas had not been turned off, and that, together with the gas from the stove -- one of the lids having been removed -- filled the room, from the inhalation of which all became insensible, and the youngest died before their condition was discovered.

abstract: Bounty-Jumper Devlin Shot on Governor's Island; Deserter, Executed at Governor's Island
snippet: Bounty-Jumper Devlin Shot on Governor's Island; Deserter, Executed at Governor's Island
lead_paragraph: Yesterday afternoon, Governor's Island was the scene of a solemn and imposing tragedy. JAMES DEVLIN, a deserter from the army, was executed, in the presence of a thousand persons, in accordance with the findings of a court-martial. The sentence was approved by Gen. DIX, Commander of the Department of the East, for the purpose of checking the rapidly increasing crime of desertion. A perfect system of bounty-jumping has been adopted by recruits, until it has become a serious evil, which the authorities have resolved to stop. The accused, JAMES DEVLIN, was about thirty years of age, of compact, well-built form, and five feet nine inches high. His features were full, and his complexion dark, with a sensual face. He first entered the army under his right name, and deserted. He then entered the army under the name of Patrick Dimond, and having deserted a second time, entered the army under the name of Patrick Sully.

abstract: His Letter; New-York, Gen. Fry's letter explaining
snippet: His Letter; New-York, Gen. Fry's letter explaining
lead_paragraph: In another column we publish a letter from Provost-Marshal-Gen. FRY to Gen. HINCKS, of this city, in explanation of the draft. It is long and somewhat intricate, though this is due mainly to the nature of the subject; but it will be found to furnish a complete vindication of the Provost-Marshal-General from the sweeping charges of injustice and incompetency in which some of our own authorities have so freely indulged. Gen. FRY might, perhaps, have made a still more detailed and explicit statement of the exact numbers in question with advantage, but the leading principles which have guided his action are sufficiently clear from his letter.

abstract: Compromise between
snippet: Compromise between
lead_paragraph: The terms of the compromise between NARVAEZ and Queen ISABELLA, are being fairly carried out. Gen. PAREGA has been dispatched to Lima to offer the Peruvians the alternative of war or submission; while a bill to repeal the law of 1861 incorporating the territory of the Dominican Republic with the Spanish monarchy, has been introduced into the Cortes by the Minister, who, if it passes, will be armed with the power necessary to give the new ordinance effect, and then the Spanish troops will be withdrawn from the island, and the Dominicans will be left to the enjoyment of their former liberty. But though this measure is creditable to NARVAEZ, it is, nevertheless, quite evident from the preamble to the new bill that the Premier abandons the idea of re-annexing San Domingo with the greatest reluctance, and that the natives will stand indebted for their future autonomy and freedom rather to the dangers and difficulties of the enterprise, than to the moderation and magnanimity of Spain.
