abstract: King of, and his Chambers
snippet: King of, and his Chambers
lead_paragraph: The Prussian Chambers are again in session, and WILLIAM of Brandenburg, and the people's respresentatives, are once more face to face. His Majesty opened the Diet in person, and read the speech from the Throne with tolerable distinctness. The tone of this address was more moderate and less offensive than usual. It contained no denunciation of the popular Chamber; no condemnation of its former acts. On the contrary, the King expresses a wish therein "that the antagonism which has prevailed for the past few years between" his "Government and the House of Deputies should find its settlement." But then he gives no indication that he means to do anything himself toward bringing about this desideratum. All the concessions must come from the deputies, for the monarch will not condescend to compromise. He expects that the deputies will set the seal of their approval to every measure of his Cabinet; that they will pass the bill for the perfection of the military organization and sanction the budget of 1865; that they will add to the burdens of the country in order to meet the expenses of the war and develop the naval power of Prussia, and that they will be thus accommodating and subservient while their own wrongs are still unredressed, and the national press muzzled and mauacled.
headline: {'main': 'The Prussian King and His Chambers.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'The Prussian King and His Chambers.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: Bronson, Curious Will Case
snippet: Bronson, Curious Will Case
lead_paragraph: --A will trial of a pecaliar character copies on before the Surrogate today. The maker of Mr. MILES BRONSON, an old man between 70 and 80 years of age, recently died, leaving a wife, but no children. He leaves an estate of about $30,000. To his wife he left $4,000 and the use of the farm during her life. To the family of a soldier who had been killed in war he bequeathed $500. To a soldier who had been wounded in the war he also gave $500. A domestic in the family also received $500, and the balance, comprising about three-quarters of the estate, he left in the hands of his executors to be applied to the benefit of the Indians of this State. The helrs, of whom there are several, contest the will. When the litigation ends the Indians are likely to have a poor look for a benefit. The devisor pinched himself during life, denying himself of necessary comforts in order to accumulate money, most of which at his death is left as a subject of contention. -- Poughkeepsie Press.
headline: {'main': 'A CURIOUS WILL CASE.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'A CURIOUS WILL CASE.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: Proudhon, Pierre Joseph, ???
snippet: Proudhon, Pierre Joseph, ???
lead_paragraph: We receive by the Africa intelligence of the death of the celebrated French writer, PIERRE JOSEPH PROUDHON, who had been for some time seriously ill. PROUDHON was born in Besancon, July 15. 1809, and after receiving a partial education at the college of his native town, was apprenticed to a printing firm, of which he subsequently became partner. In 1840 the Academy of Besancon awarded him a prize of 1,500 francs for an essay on general grammar. This enabled him to visit Paris, where he entered upon the pursuit of his literary career. A work of his on property, which opened with the startling dictum "that property is theft," brought him prominently into notice, and was followed by others of the same character and tendency.

abstract: Hudson R; Simmons >amp; Heffron; 5 cent Fare Case; Hudson Railroad 5 Cent Fare; Assault Case
snippet: Hudson R; Simmons >amp; Heffron; 5 cent Fare Case; Hudson Railroad 5 Cent Fare; Assault Case
lead_paragraph: The People on the Complaint of C.W. SIMMONS vs. PATRICK HEFFRON. Since the 23d of January last the Hudson River Railroad Company have per- sistently refused to carry their passengers and commutors below Thirtieth-street, without an additional fare of five cents for each passenger, which was contrary to their practice, as well as to the understanding with their passengers ever since the road commenced running. Their practice, since Jan. 23, 1865, has been to demand fare from the passenger below Thirtieth-street, and upon his refusing to pay to call in some of their laborers and eject the passenger. Mr. SIMMONS, a commuter on the road, was assaulted, with intent to eject him, by the prisoner, when both Mr. SIMMONS and the prisoner were arrested and taken to the Jefferson Market Police Court. At the suggestion of Justice LEDWITH both parties entered into a personal recognizance to appear before the Special Sessions on yesterday (Saturday) morning for a hearing of their mutual complaint for assault and battery, and the trial came on before Justices DOWLING, MANSFIELD and LEDWITH.

abstract: Farrel and Ward, Wil, Del, 250 Arrested by Military
snippet: Farrel and Ward, Wil, Del, 250 Arrested by Military
lead_paragraph: The fight between FARRELL and WARD, both of the Hibernia Engine Company, for $1,000, which has been under way since Jan.12, came off on Thursday, near Claymont Station, on the Pennsylvania and Delaware line. Hundreds went from this city, as well as a large delegation from New-York. Every means of locomotion was made available to reach the destined spot and about 7:30 A.M. on Thursday, some one thousand or twelve hundred persons had assembled about one thousand yards north of the Philadelphia and Wilmington Railroad, near the Claymont Station. At this time the ring had not been ritched, but was in progress. The ground was bound in Jack Frost's iron grasp, and crowbars failed to make much progress on the icebound earth. At about 8.20 the ring was completed; but still, precious time was wasted, and no attempt was made to bring the men into the ring, although both were present in carriages, and had been on the ground for upward of an hour.

abstract: President LINCOLN and Secretary SEWARD returned yesterday morning to Washington, from Fortress Monroe. They had an informal conference, occupying several hours, with Mr. STEPHENS and his associates, on board the River Queen, in Hampton Roads. The conference is said to have resulted in no change of attitude on either side, although a rumor ...
lead_paragraph: President LINCOLN and Secretary SEWARD returned yesterday morning to Washington, from Fortress Monroe. They had an informal conference, occupying several hours, with Mr. STEPHENS and his associates, on board the River Queen, in Hampton Roads. The conference is said to have resulted in no change of attitude on either side, although a rumor prevailed on board the steamer in which the President returned, that an armistice of thirty days had been agreed upon. This, of course, is mere rumor; and all that is positively known is, that the President and Mr. SEWARD have returned to Washington, and that the rebel commissioners have returned to Richmond. Among the many rumors prevailing in Washington was one that thirteen commissioners had been appointed on either side. A Washington dispatch to the Commercial Advertiser says that "there is a general feeling of satisfaction among those in the President's confidence, and the result of the negotiations is regarded as highly favorable to peace."

abstract: Although the warfare of 1864 has been in favor of the Federals, yet their successes have not been of a decisive character, and vast means of resistance are still left in the hands of the Confederates. Assuming that the determination to conquer is as strong on one side as the determination to resist is on the other, and admitting the superiority of the Federals in resources of all kinds, ashore and afloat, yet there must be in the Confederacy, even if the Richmond Government does not think it expedient to arm the slaves, means of prolonging the contest for several years. By arming the slaves, and subjecting them to the magic influence of military discipline, the Confederates would be in a position to assume the offensive; without arming the slaves, and confining themselves mainly to a defensive war, their position is such that they will be able to sustain themselves for a very long period. But the task is now more difficult than it has ever been, as a brief consideration of the facts will show.

abstract: Failures and Unpopularity; The Problem of the; and Compeers will be known as Polititical Adventurers
snippet: Failures and Unpopularity; The Problem of the; and Compeers will be known as Polititical Adventurers
lead_paragraph: Enraged by their recent defeats, the rebels are engaged in mercilessly pelting their unfortunate chief. There is manifest injustice in the charges brought against DAVIS by his irresponsible opponents. The head and front of his guilt is that he took part in the rebellion at all; that he assumed the principal official position in an organization whose object was to overthrow the Government of our common country; and not that he has failed to conduct the insurrection successfully to its end. History will give him no credit for profound wisdom, neither will it pronounce him a fool, as do the rebel editors. He, in common with all those who instigated rebellion, was unable to forecast its inevitable ruin. He and they alike miscalculated the value of the elements in their favor and the stability of the Government against which they lifted treasonable hands. The foresight which they lacked was within the scope of human reason, and was exercised by that statesman who, in the Georgia Legislature, denounced the crime that was about to be committed and predicted the blight which must follow. Men who thus madly undertake revolutions are known in history as political adventurers. Thus will DAVIS and his compeers be known. But they will also be known as men who well understood themselves and their own aspirations; who knew upon what they might calculate, though they miscalculated, and what they must count out; and who, in an ill-advised war, had yet a remarkably well-advised scheme for its conduct, when considered in relation to the proposed end. Where all schemes must have failed, this was more consistent and promised more than any other. Richmond editors may well be reminded that in a rebellion, as in all things else, the elements involved in the movement, and the end proposed, must shape its ruling policy.

abstract: In the Senate yesterday a joint resolution was introduced to advance PAUL S. FORBES, of NewYork, the sum of $200,000 on the contract for building the steam sloop-of-war Idaho. Mr.  SHERMAN asked unanimous consent to call up the bill to encourage emigration, which was not granted. Mr. WILSON introduced a bill for the protection of travelers, which provides, among ...
lead_paragraph: In the Senate yesterday a joint resolution was introduced to advance PAUL S. FORBES, of NewYork, the sum of $200,000 on the contract for building the steam sloop-of-war Idaho. Mr. SHERMAN asked unanimous consent to call up the bill to encourage emigration, which was not granted. Mr. WILSON introduced a bill for the protection of travelers, which provides, among other things, that no person shall be excluded from travel upon any railroad or navigable water of the United States on account of color, or by reason of any State law or municipal ordinances, or of any rule, regulation, or of any corporation, company or person whatever. Mr. WILSON also introduced a bill, which was ordered to be printed, to prevent the sale of notes, scrip, bonds, or other evidence of debt, issued by the rebel authorities, &c. A resolution was introduced, and laid over till Monday, declaring that the President's approval is not necessary to give validity to the Article of Amendment to the Constitution proposed by Congress. Mr. SUMNER introduced a series of resolutions, which were ordered to be printed, declaring that the rebel States should not be allowed to participate in the ratification of the Constitutional Amendment. Consideration of the joint resolution declaring certain States not entitled to representation in the Electoral College, was then renewed. After the rejection of several amendments, the resolution was passed.

abstract: The Condition of
snippet: The Condition of
lead_paragraph: The news from Savannah, published in Friday's issue of the TIMES, is not exactly of that rose-colored character which marked the reports immediately succeeding the surrender of the city to Gen. SHERMAN. And yet, we think, both the citizens and the military that garrisoned Savannah, may be cordially congratulated on this most important matter, that the former have shown no disposition to thwart the purposes of the National authorities, and that the latter have not only been careful not to infringe upon the rights of non-militants, but have, thus far, endeavored to deal leniently with their prejudices. The city has been the scene of a great disaster, due, no doubt, to incendiaries, prompted and paid by secret rebel agents. A large portion of the city has suffered from a fearful conflagration. Two hundred and fifty houses -- of the smaller class, we assume -- were burnt down almost simultaneously with the arrival of the friendly offering of provisions, sent from New-York and other Northern cities. The calamity, it seems, was further aggravated by the explosion of a rebel arsenal within the city, whose contents, by some unaccountable oversight or neglect, were left undisturbed after the city was surrendered to our troops. No doubt the whole thing was the work of some rebel plotter; but if it could be conscientiously shown that proper precautions were taken by the loyal force now garrisoning the city, against the evil which has befallen it, we could learn, without any excessive alarm, that Savannah, even now, to-day, harbors a large number of professional incendiaries, intent upon reducing the place to ashes. New-York, at this hour, harbors hundreds of the same class. Why should they not be counted by the score in a town barely six weeks released from rebel bondage? Even were the leaders of the rebellion to surrender to-morrow, and peace to be proclaimed before the season of Lent commences, it would be but reasonable to expect that hordes of desperate rebel ruffians would, for a time, have full swing to prey and to plunder in many parts of the South. We are, therefore, not disposed to magnify into undue importance this incendiary plot in Savannah. Its worst feature is, that it does not appear to have been in the remotest degree a matter of forecast by the loyal military authorities. The neglect of all precautions in the matter of the "rebel" arsenal, most assuredly needs explanation.

abstract: Oration on Edward Everett; Everett, Edward; Biopraphy, by George Bancroft; Everett, Edward, by George Bancroft
snippet: Oration on Edward Everett; Everett, Edward; Biopraphy, by George Bancroft; Everett, Edward, by George Bancroft
lead_paragraph: In the death of EDWARD EVERETT I have lost the oldest friend that remained to me. I saw him for the first time in August, 1813, more than a half century ago, on my examination for admission to Harvard College. I was then 12 years old, he 19. He was, at the time, the college tutor of the Latin language, and for one quarter at Cambridge our class read with him the first books of LIVY. A marvelous account of the ability he had displayed in the four years of his student's life, his undisputed reputation as the best scholar that had been graduated within the traditions of that day, a grave, and sedate, and earnest manner, a sanctity of appearance, that made him in youth an object of veneration, gave him over our class an influence such as no other instructor exercised. In a few weeks he was invited to take the place left vacant by the lamented BUCKMINSTER, and at the end of the term he bade us an affectionate farewell. I remember to this day the aspect of holiness which he wore, as he made us a parting speech, full of the best counsels and exhortations. In the pulpit his manner at that time was more sober and calm and solemn than at any later period. Crowds thronged to hear him; he loved occasionally to treat subjects of critical learning; the oldest doctors in the temple were amazed at his skill in disputation; and the young of both sexes hung with delight on his fervid but chaste and modest eloquence.

abstract: The stated meeting of the Board of Managers was held at the Bible House, Astor-place, on Thursday, the 2d instant, at 3 1/2 P.M., WILLIAM B. CROSBY, Esq., Vice President, in the chair, assisted by WM. WHITLOCK, Jr., Esq., and Hon. JOSEPH A. WRIGHT, Vice-Presidents. Three new auxiliaries were recognized; one in Missouri and two in Western Virginia. Communications were received from Mr. ANDREW M. MILNE, Buenos Ayres, with a gratifying account of his labors in Santa Fe and Parana; from Rev. JAMES HICKSY, Monterey, with accounts, not very encouraging, as to the prospect of Bible distribution in Mexico; from Baron, CHAS. DE RIVERONG ST. CYR, Norrkoping, Sweden; R.[???]. WM. GOODFELLOW of Buenos Ayres, and MANUAL METAMORAS, Bavonne, in regard to sending colporteurs to Spanish America; from Rev. W. CLARK. M[???]an, with accounts of the labors of colporteurs under this Society in [???]; from Rev. LEON PILATER, Nice, in regard to establishing a bookstore and Bible depot in that city; from Rev. I.G. BLISS with an account of Bible distribution in Turkey, Grants of books were [???] amounting to 21,907 volumes, including Bibles and Testaments of different sizes and languages. They were to the Missionary Society of the Methodist Episcopal Church for China, and for Montana and Territory; to the Sunday School Union of the same Church, for S[???]-schools where we have no auxiliaries; to the Maryland State Bible Society, to be forwarded to Richmond; to the French Christian Missionary Society; for soldiers and prisoners of war at Columbus Ohio; for hospitals at St. Louis, for distribution among destitute families in the Shenandoah Valley, Va; for prisoners of war at Fort Delaware, &c., &c. In money an appropriation was made of $[???],000 toward the translation of the Scriptures into the Azer[???] Turkish language at O[???]. P[???] and $1,000 for printing Scriptures in the Mandarin C[???]ll[???], in China. The revision of the Spanish Testament was announced complete, and was ordered to be printed. It was a full and very interesting meeting.

abstract: Eulogium by Gen Grant
snippet: Eulogium by Gen Grant
lead_paragraph: We notice that some of the New-York papers are giving circulation to a rumor, to the effect that Maj.-Gen. MEADE is to be removed from command of the Army of the Potomac. The report is entirely without foundation, and does great injustice to an officer who has attained his present posit on by constant service in the field, and whose name is historical as leader in our most important victory, and identified with most of the battles of the army which he now commands.

abstract: Patapsco, Monitor; Loss of and List of Names on Board
snippet: Patapsco, Monitor; Loss of and List of Names on Board
lead_paragraph: On the night of the 15th the Patapsco was sunk by striking a torpedo in Charleston harbor, while protecting a launch that was searching for those nefarious machines. The accident happened when the monitor was about four hundred yards south and east of Fort Sumter. The torpedo struck her at a point thirty-five feet a bait the port bow directly under the wardroom. In twenty seconds from the time the torpedo struck her she went down in five farhoms of water, so that at present all that remains visible of her is two feet of the smokestack. All who were on the deck watch and in the engine-room were saved. Acting Ensign BASHFORD had the charge of the deck watch at the time. All, with a few exceptions, of those below were lost. A boatswain's mate escaped by passing through the berth deck into the engine-room, thence out through the hatch to the deck. Three men escaped by climbing out of the turret chamber. The Patapsco had passed over the same water several times that night. She would drift down with the tide, and then steam back to her original position. At the time she was struck her engines were going under four b[???]s.

abstract: There were in this institution yesterday 240 patients. During the week 43 were admitted, 64 were discharged as cured or relieved, and 8 died. The hospital library, of which Dr. JOHN L. VANDER VOOET is librarian, has recently been enriched by the addition of about six hundred rare old medical works, the bequest of the late Dr. JOHN WATSON, who was for many years an attending surgeon in the institution.
lead_paragraph: There were in this institution yesterday 240 patients. During the week 43 were admitted, 64 were discharged as cured or relieved, and 8 died. The hospital library, of which Dr. JOHN L. VANDER VOOET is librarian, has recently been enriched by the addition of about six hundred rare old medical works, the bequest of the late Dr. JOHN WATSON, who was for many years an attending surgeon in the institution. The library now contains about eight thousand volumes. One thing further is needed by the institution to make it one of the finest hospitals in the land, namely, the appropriation of from $12,000 to $20,000 which the Legislature annually made toward its support before the beginning of the war, or rather, before certain gentlemen of a speculative turn cast longing eyes upon the hospital lots. It is alleged -- and there would appear to be a degree of plausibility in the allegation -- that a number of gentlemen, who are desirous of purchasing the eligibly-situated hospital property with a view to the erection of extensive warehouses, have interposed objections to the annual appropriation by the Legislature, hoping that by withdrawing State aid from the institution they might compel the Board of Governors to sell their edifice of revolutionary memory and erect a new building on one of their lots up town. And so the Legislative appropriations have been withheld for several years past. But the Board of Governors, with public spirit which ought to endear them to every New-Yorker, resolved that there should be a hospital down town, where it may be, as it has so long been, useful; and they have thus far made their resolution good by contributions of from $5,000 to $10,000 annually from their private means. The city, also, formerly contributed liberally; but the same influences which are said to have operated in withdrawing Legislative aid stepped in between the hospital and city government; and the result has been that hundreds of pauper patients whom the hospital admitted in other days have necessarily been sent, at great expense to the city, far over to Bellevue Hospital, on the east side of the town. The hospital records show that four-fifths of the accidents that are reported occur south of Broome-street. Nearly all of the Broadway stage accidents are reported below that street. Our stages, prolific of accidents, centre below Canals and the railway lines, which are supplanting the stages, and which promise to yield more hospital cases than the stages ever yielded, all centre not half a mile from the New-York hospital. And here it occurs to us that the railways, which enjoy very valuable franchises at the hands of the city, and which may do so much toward filling our hospitals, might not improperly be called upon to aid in supporting a hospital institution down town. Suppose that gentlemen of the Sente[???] Assembly, when our city railroads apply for those privileges which the Legislature alone can grant, required the directors to appropriate a small percentage of their surplus profits toward sustaining the New-York Hospital.

abstract: On Wednesday, Jan. 25, the funeral of Lieut. B.H. PORTER, who fell while leading hie men in the assault on Fort Fisher, took place at his native village of Skaneateles. Although he died so young, being only twenty years of age, his conspicuous gallantry at Roanoke, Fort Sumter, and elsewhere, and ...
lead_paragraph: On Wednesday, Jan. 25, the funeral of Lieut. B.H. PORTER, who fell while leading hie men in the assault on Fort Fisher, took place at his native village of Skaneateles. Although he died so young, being only twenty years of age, his conspicuous gallantry at Roanoke, Fort Sumter, and elsewhere, and his frank, manly character, had won for him much personal affection and general public respect, which was touchingly manifested at his funeral. The pall was borne by Col. BENEDICT, of the Seventy-fifth Regiment, N.Y.S.M., with the officers of his staff, and Company E, of the same regiment, volunteered as escort, in testimony alike of affectionate regard for the deceased, and good will toward the naval service, which could not possibly be fully represented on the occasion. Capt. MATTHEWS, of Gen. LEW. WALLACE's Staff, and Lieut. LA RUE P. ADAMS, U.S.N., were also present.

abstract: Police Trials; Description of Court and Proceedings
snippet: Police Trials; Description of Court and Proceedings
lead_paragraph: Many fine descriptive sketches have been made of the ornate marble pile at No. 300 Murberry-street, the lair of the Metropolitan Police; but, if we mistake not, no special mention has been made of the Police Trial Chamber. The fact is more remarkable, since this hall is the only place which this city can boast that is in any degree adapted to the purposes of a public tribunal. The court-rooms in and near the Park are cramped, dingy, cheerless, and surrounded by busy streets, from whose unremitting uproar there is no escape, and to this must be added the occasional thunder of a monstrous fire-bell which our astute authorities have hidden behind the Hall. The Trial Chamber at the Central Department of Metropolitan Police is a court-room of quite another kind. It is lighter, loftier, purer of atmosphere, than any of the down town, dust-begrimed seats of justice, and once within its walls, the visitor is as remotely removed from the din of the town as though he were in the centre of the African desert.

abstract: Atlantic, Plans and Prospects of
snippet: Atlantic, Plans and Prospects of
lead_paragraph: On Thursday, the somewhat tedious process was commenced of shipping a portion of submarine cable which has been made for this great undertaking, from the works at Greenwich on board the hulk Iris, for transference to the Medway, and final stowage in the tanks of the Great Eastern. The shipment was began early in the morning, and will continue without intermission now until nearly the end of May, by which time it is hoped all will be coiled away snugly on board the great steamship. The total quantity of rope required to connect Valentia with Bull's Bay, Newfoundland, allowing for the "slack" which must run out to prevent too great a strain on the cable, is about 2,300 nautical, or nearly 2,700 statute, miles. With this length a liberal margin is given of nearly 600 statute miles of rope for slack caused by currents, possible rough weather and the avoidance of anything like unusual strain on the cable in the deepest water. Over one part of the route the depth is as great as from 2,000 to 2,500 fathoms, or nearly three statute miles -- a depth, however, which is only considered of moment in case of rough weather in paying out the mere strength of the cable being sufficient to bear its own weight in eleven miles of still water. In this respect, as, indeed, in all others, the new cable has an enormous superiority over the old and ill-used rope which was first laid, and which, to the amazement of all those who knew its real condition, nevertheless remained in fair working order for a few days. If such unexpected results were obtained from the old cable, which the advancement of electrical science since then shows to have been thoroughly ill-adapted for its purpose, it is not over sanguine to enterprise, every step in the conduct of which has been marked with the most jealous care, not only to guard against the dangers known to exist, but against other emergencies which experience shows may arise, but which five years ago were unknown. In size, in strength, in better condition, better insulation, and better outer covering, the new rope is never less than three times as good as the old one, while in many cases, and these the most important, its superiority is four or five times greater. Though a much larger cable, its weight in water per mile is less than half that of its unfortunate predecessor, its breaking strain is 7 3/4 tons, against 3 1/4 tons, the maximum strength of the old rope. The method of joining up the two-mile lengths in which it is constructed is also a great improvement upon the soldered joints in the wires of the first cable, while the standards for insulation and "conductivity" are as high as those devised for the Persian Gulf cable, and the tests are continuous in every portion of the manufacture. Nearly 900 miles of the cable have already been made, and are beautifully coiled away in the large tanks in the Telegraph Construction Company's works, lately those of Messrs. GLASS & ELLIOT. Fifteen hundred nautical miles have yet to be manufactured to complete the tale, exclusive of the shore ends, which will be most massive, and in length some 30 miles. The factory now turns out 14 miles a day of completed rope, which in four months' time will give 1,350 miles, at the present rate of working -- though, of course, as the days grow longer, so in proportion will the hours of labor. It is considered, therefore, that the work would be well advanced if 2,000 miles had to be completed, instead of 1,500. Two hulks have been placed at the disposal of the company by the Admiralty -- the Iris and the Amethyst. As soon as the Iris, now off the works, is filled with her quantum of 250 miles, she will be towed down to the Great Eastern, and the Amethyst will take her place, and in this manner, for the next four months, the shipment of the cable will be continuous. The cable is wound on board these hulks at the rate of a little over two miles an hour, and, as the days are short, and there is little night work, the rate of shipment is not much ahead of the rate of manufacture. During this winding on board the hulks, as during every other process, the tests for insulation and "conductivity" are continued with the same scrupulous care.

abstract: Notwithstanding the foul state of the weather on Saturday, there was an unusually large attendance at the operatic matin e. The upper regions of
lead_paragraph: Notwithstanding the foul state of the weather on Saturday, there was an unusually large attendance at the operatic matin e. The upper regions of the Academy were invaded by the fashion and beauty of the city. DONIZETTI's opera of "Il Poliuto" was given, to the complete enjoyment of those present, and will, doubtless, bear repetition. To-night, VERDI's opera of "Il Trovatore" will be played, for the benefit of the floating population; to-morrow, "Faust;" on Wednesday, "Norma;" and on Friday, "La Traviata," with Mme. CAROZZI-ZUCCHI as Violetta. It is the first time the lady has assumed this role in America. Mr. MARETZEK announces that "La Forza del Destino" is in active rehearsal, and will be produced on the earliest practicable day.

abstract: Negotiations and the Logical End of the War; and San Domingo Compromise between; Negotiations and Foreign Precedents
snippet: Negotiations and the Logical End of the War; and San Domingo Compromise between; Negotiations and Foreign Precedents
lead_paragraph: Those whom the coming and going of Peace Commissioners make so sanguine of a speedy, not to say immediate, cessation of hostilities, are evidently under the influence of analogies drawn from negotiations between two belligerents, whose independence is established. When two separate nations quarrel, it is very rare indeed that the avowed object of either of them is the complete subjugation of the other, and its annexation to the domain of the conqueror. However the war may end, it generally begins in a dispute about a boundary, a failure to observe the terms of an existing treaty, an injury to some private citizen, a real or alleged encroachment on the territory of an ally, or some infringement of neutral rights; and the party which first takes up arms simply declares his intention to do the other as much damage as he conveniently can, or, as it is commonly called, "obtain satisfaction" for the injury from which he has suffered, or thinks he has suffered.
headline: {'main': 'Negotiations for Peace The Logical Termination of the War.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'Negotiations for Peace The Logical Termination of the War.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: Our Detective Police, to whom on the morning of the 26th of November last, Gen. DIX and Superintendent KENNEDY intrusted the work of ferreting out and apprehending the conspirators who plotted the burning of New-York on the night of the 25th, took their task in hand at once, but they carried in in the city, taking notes here and there, at their
lead_paragraph: Our Detective Police, to whom on the morning of the 26th of November last, Gen. DIX and Superintendent KENNEDY intrusted the work of ferreting out and apprehending the conspirators who plotted the burning of New-York on the night of the 25th, took their task in hand at once, but they carried in in the city, taking notes here and there, at their own time and in their own way, and half of December had passed before they were ready and went hence. On the morning of the 18th, Chief YOUNG and Detectives MCDOUGALL and BENNETT and two of Gen. DIX's officers, whose names are withheld by request, started for the frontier, there to join Detectives MCCORD, RADFORD and WILSON, who had been sent to the Canadian line in advance.

lead_paragraph: Our correspondent who, two months since, accompanied Lieut-Col. MULFORD's exchange-fleet to Savannah and Charleston, obtained from one of the released prisoners, whose duty it was to keep the roster of his comrades, the following list of officers confined at the prison-pen at Columbia, S.C. Probably one-tenth of the officers named have been exchanged since the 8th of last December, the date to which the record was made up, but the remainder, unfortunately, still languish in their terrible captivity. To many of our readers this list will convey valuable information as to how letters and parcels may be addressed to the prisoners:

abstract: The, on Quorums; Mr. Sumner and the Constitution; Resolutions on Ratification Amendment
snippet: The, on Quorums; Mr. Sumner and the Constitution; Resolutions on Ratification Amendment
lead_paragraph: Senator SUMNER has introduced resolutions into the Senate which, if adopted, will recognize as complete the dissolution of the American Union. They relate to the ratification by the States of the amendment to the Constitution just passed by Congress. They declare that this amendment will be valid, and will become part of the Constitution, whenever it shall be ratified by three-fourths of the States actually exercising the functions of States under the Constitution; in other words, by three-fourths of the loyal States of the Union. They embody the reasons for this position, and those reasons are:

abstract: The dispatch of our special correspondent at Washington gives this morning a reliable report of the leading points discussed at the recent conference of President LINCOLN and Secretary SEW
lead_paragraph: The dispatch of our special correspondent at Washington gives this morning a reliable report of the leading points discussed at the recent conference of President LINCOLN and Secretary SEWARD with the rebel commissioners, it will be seen that the rebel ultimatum was recognition of the independence of the Southern States, as a preliminary condition, absolutely indispensable to any negotiations whatever concerning peace. President LINCOLN, on the other hand, distinctly informed them that the United States could stop the war and arrest even temporarily the movement of its armies, only on the condition that the authority of the National Government should be recognized and obeyed over the whole territory of the United States. This radical difference of view was found to be irreconcilable, and the conference resulted, therefore, in failure.

abstract: Success no excuse for Inaction; Success; Danger of; Conference, a Reason for New Energy
snippet: Success no excuse for Inaction; Success; Danger of; Conference, a Reason for New Energy
lead_paragraph: A false security seriously threatens the loyal cause. Gen. SHERMAN'S recent successes and the peace conference which so soon followed, have produced a general impression that, at worst, but little more fighting remains to be done. No requisition for more soldiers ever yet issued has been responded to so dilatorily as that now pending. Everywhere, in city and country, there is a general flagging of effort in every operation for reinforcing our armies in the field. Nobody can deny the fact. Nobody can impute it to a loss of hope, or to any decline of patriotic spirit. The purpose to maintain the Union, and the consciousness of the ability to do this were never more settled. This new laxity can come from no faint-heartedness. It springs from exactly the opposite condition -- from over-confidence. For all that, it is none the less dangerous. It must be remedied.
headline: {'main': 'New Energy Demanded.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'New Energy Demanded.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: A joint resolution was introduced in the Senate on Saturday to advance PAUL S. FORBES, of NewYork, the sum of $200,000 on the contract for building the steam sloop-of-war Idaho. Mr. SHERMAN asked unanimous consent to call up the bill to encourage emigration, which was not granted. Mr. WILSON introduced a bill for the protection of travelers, which provides, among
lead_paragraph: A joint resolution was introduced in the Senate on Saturday to advance PAUL S. FORBES, of NewYork, the sum of $200,000 on the contract for building the steam sloop-of-war Idaho. Mr. SHERMAN asked unanimous consent to call up the bill to encourage emigration, which was not granted. Mr. WILSON introduced a bill for the protection of travelers, which provides, among other things, that no person shall be excluded from travel upon any railroad or navigable water of the United States on account of color, or by reason of any State law or municipal ordinances, or of any rule, regulation or of any corporation, company or person whatever. Mr. WILSON also introduced a bill, which was ordered to be printed, to prevent the sale of notes, scrip, bonds, or other evidence of debt, issued by the rebel authorities, &c. A resolution was introduced, and laid over till to-day, declaring that the President's approval is not necessary to give validity to the Article of Amendment to the Constitution proposed by Congress. Mr. SUMNER introduced a series of resolutions, which were ordered to be printed, declaring that the rebel States should not be allowed to participate in the ratification of the Constitutional Amendment. Consideration of the joint resolution declaring certain States not entitled to representation in the Electoral College, was then renewed. After the rejection of several amendments, the resolution was passed.

abstract: FREEMAN's GREATEST BOON. -- We would advise a man to forego a thresher and thresh wheat with a flail rather than to see the wife wear her health, vigor and life away in the everlasting "stitch, stitch, stitch," when a sewing machine can be obtained. The Wheeler & Wilson is an invaluable aid in every household. We have had several different kinds on trial, and after six years' service, the Wheeler & Wilson has taken the precedence as the best, where all kinds of sewing are to be done in a family. -- American Agriculturist, January, 1865.

The Wheeler & Wilson is an invaluable aid in every household. We have had several different kinds on trial, and after six years' service, the Wheeler & Wilson has taken the precedence as the best, where all kinds of sewing are to be done in a family. -- American Agriculturist, January, 1865.

abstract: -- GUSTAVE FERDINAND VORGTMAN, otherwise known as HELLE, late of Chicago, and formerly of the Berlin and Hamburgh Railway, was taken before United States Commissioner WHITE on Saturday, by Mr. JOHN WILLIAM SMITH, Consul-General for the Prussian Government, and required to show why he should not be surrendered to Prussia to answer for forging a draft upon the Prussian Military Treasury for fourteen thousand thalers. The accused was fully identified as the man who had confessed the forgery, and told Mr. H. CLAUSSENIS, the Prussian Consul at Chicago, that he had lost the money in speculation in New-York. The hearing is to be resumed to-morrow.

abstract: The good people of Brooklyn who did not attend the Concert at the Academy of Music on Friday evening last -- at least those of them who have an eye as well as an ear for the beautiful -- missed a great treat. The young ladies of the Packer Institute, assisted by Mrs. WILLIAMS, the soprano of Grace Church, and that little "host in herself," CAMILLA VERSO, filled the Academy to overflowing. The sight that met the eye as the curtain rose, was most beautiful. Between five and six hundred young misses dressed in pure white, were arranged in rows occupying the whole width of the stage, and extending from the proscenium, at a slight angle upward, to the extreme rear. The singing by the young ladies was very good. Chorus singing is something not to be passionately fond of when executed by immature female voices, but this certainly was very good indeed. The voices were in such perfect harmony, many times, as to seem like one; in "Fesca's Wenderer," especially, although a poor selection for chorus singing, the fact was particularly noticeable. The instrumental part of the programme was equally as good as the vocal, and in one note-worthy instance far excelled it. Miss DE WITT, having seated herself at the piano, gave with the utmost naivete, GOTTSCHALK's "Le Bannier" in a very fine style; and in one evidently not borrowed. Power only was lacking in her performance; time, taste and touch were almost unexceptionable. It was regretted that the was not permitted to respond to the encore which was so vigorously called for by the audience.

abstract: 12 years in Kentucky Jail
snippet: 12 years in Kentucky Jail
lead_paragraph: Rev. CALVIN FAIRBANK, who was for more than twelve years confined in the Kentucky State Penitentiary for the crime of assisting a slave woman to escape from bondage, delivered a very interesting lecture last evening in Shiloh Church. Mr. FAIRBANK commenced by relating the circumstances under which he was arrested. He said that his father died in Lexington, Ky., in 1849, and that he visited that State in the Fall of 1851, for the purpose of removing the remains. On the 2d of November a young slave woman appealed to him for help to escape from her master, which he granted by secreting her, and at night removing her beyond the reach of her enemies. On the 9th of November, while on his way in church in Jeffersonville, Indiana, he was assaulted by three irresponsible persons from Kentucky, one being the owner of the fugitive, and without requisition from the Executive of Kentucky, was forcibly taken from Indiana to Louisville, Ky. On the 24th of November, he was arraigned before a police court on a charge of aiding a slave to escape to a free State, and held to bail in the sum of $5,000, in default of which he was thrown into jail, where he was heavily ironed. On the 21st of December Attorney ROSSEAU (now General) made affidavit before the Circuit Court concerning the absence of witnesses, and the case was postponed to the 23d of February, when an attempt was made to further postpone the case until May. The postponement being resisted by the District-Attorney, the court ordered a hearing for the 25th. On the day of trial the case was called, and no witnesses appearing for the defence, the accused was compelled to go to trial without them, though legal summons had been issued to rescue their attendance. Mr. FAIRBANKS was summarily tried and convicted, and sentenced to a term of fifteen years' hard labor in the penitentiary. On the 9th day of March he was incarcerated, and remained in confinement until the 15th day of April last, a period of over twelve years, when he was pardoned by Lieut.-Gov. R.T. JACOB, then acting as Governor, in absence of Gov. BRAMLETTE. The lecturer spoke of his treatment while in prison, and gave a vivid description of his privations and sufferings. He stated that during his confinement he was put to tasks beyond his ability, and for failure to perform them was frequently whipped, receiving during his imprisonment over thirty-five thousand stripes. The speaker concluded by saying that "the force of public sentiment in dissolving the bonds of the slave has dissolved mine."
headline: {'main': 'LOCAL INTELLIGENCE; Twelve Years in a Kentucky Jail Sufferings for the Slave.LECTURE BY REV. CALVIN FAIRBANK.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'LOCAL INTELLIGENCE; Twelve Years in a Kentucky Jail Sufferings for the Slave.LECTURE BY REV. CALVIN FAIRBANK.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: Princess Mary of Cambridge and Royal Marriage Act; Royal Marriage Act and Princess Mary
snippet: Princess Mary of Cambridge and Royal Marriage Act; Royal Marriage Act and Princess Mary
lead_paragraph: It has been well known for many months, that the Princess MARY of England, sister to the Duke of CAMBRIDGE, and cousin to the Queen, had consented to accept the hand of a gallant guardsman, Viscount HOOD, lineal representative of the Admiral, and that the only obstacle in the way of the marriage of the illustrious personages was the withheld assent of the Sovereign -- that assent being required under a very foolish act of the British Parliament, passed at the instance of GEORGE III., in the twelfth year of his reign. The act in question, so far from having been desired by the thinking Statesman of England at the time, was passed through Parliament with the greatest difficulty; the King in his usual peremptory way ordering Lord NORTH to have the measure become law at all hazards, and to have care taken that those who voted against it should be specially marked for exclusion from the Royal Drawing Rooms. The bill was passed under this pressure, as many other bills were passed at the time, in defiance of whatever liberal opinion had a voice in Parliament. There was, however, one mitigating clause in the Act. The Prince or Princess desiring to marry had a right of appeal from the disapproval of the Sovereign to the Privy Council On giving this notice of appeal the royal person interested might marry twelve months thereafter, unless Parliament in the interim passed a law expressly prohibiting the proposed alliance.

abstract: 30th ult., two families, at No. 464 Washington-street, were prostrated by sudden and mysterious sickness, which was supposed to be the result of poisoning. They lay at the point of death until about noon, when one of the children -- MARY MORRISON -- died. Coroner GAMBLE summoned a jury; but as the case was enveloped in mystery, the inquest was adjoured, and the stomach of the child was given to Drs. JOSEPH G. SHAW, THOMAS C. FINNELL and HAZLETT for chemical analyzation. No mineral poison was found. The physicians believe the sickness and death to have been caused by miasm in the apartments which the families occupied. Both families have recovered....Corner COLLIN held an inquest, yesterday, at the New-Haven Railroad station in Eighty-sixth-street, upon the body of THOMAS A. WALLACE, one of the company's employes, who was run over and killed by a locomotive while loading a freight car. Mr. WALLACE was a native of Maryland, aged 23 years. ...Coroner GOVER was summoned to hold an inquest upon the body of an infant that had been found frozen in an open lot near the Thirty-first Precinct Police Station....CATHARINE COULTER, aged 17 months, was fatally scalded by overturning a pan of scalding water.....Coroner GOVER held an inquest at the Fifth-avenue Hotel, upon the body of JOHN BRADY, one of the attaches of the hotel, who fell and expired, on Sunday evening, in Broadway, near Twenty-fourth-street. He was 60 years of age....Mr. HARDY, a night watchman, employed at pier No. 21 East River, fell into the dock yesterday morning, and was drowned.

abstract: Policy now Treason; and the Peace Conference; Peace Policy; Conference has Defined the Situation
snippet: Policy now Treason; and the Peace Conference; Peace Policy; Conference has Defined the Situation
lead_paragraph: We have now a right to look for a consolidated support of this war by men of all parties in the North. The peace conference has confirmed beyond all question that there is no alternative to war but disunion. The commissioners of the rebel Government demanded the recognition of its independence as an indispensable preliminary to any negotiation for peace. President LINCOLN in vain exhausted every inducement to bring them to ground where compromise was possible. They would not swerve one hair's-breadth -- in fact could not so move without violating their trust, and at once evoking a repudiation from Richmond. Their directness was honorable. They practiced no reserve or equivocation. They confronted us on their real position at the outset. So far from attempting to deceive, they, from the very beginning, made mistake impossible. No sine qua non was ever more sharply defined, or more positively claimed. It must be met in the same manly spirit. It cannot be yielded to without treason. It cannot be paltered with without imbecility.
headline: {'main': 'A Peace Policy now Treason.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'A Peace Policy now Treason.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: In the Senate yesterday the credentials of Mr. LANE, Senator from Kansas, and those of Mr. FARWELL, Senator from Maine, were presented. An act for the benefit of army officers in the field, regulating the commutation price of rations, was reported. A resolution was adopted calling upon the President for information in regard to permits to trade in cotton. A resolution was offered, and will be taken up to-day, calling for information relative to the late peace mission. Mr. WILSON then called up the bill in relation to the enrollment, as reported by the Military Committee. Section fifth, providing that State and local bounties to volunteers be paid in installments, was stricken out. An amendment to repeal that section of the Enrollment bill which permits Governors of States to send agents to States in rebellion to recruit and fill quotas was proposed and adopted. Further consideration of the bill was referred till to-day. A joint resolution proposing an amendment to the Constitution, in relation to the apportionment of representatives among the several States. Mr. WADE made a report in relation to the attack on Petersburgh in June last. Five thousand copies of the report were ordered to be printed.

abstract: Conference; Foolish Gossip About
snippet: Conference; Foolish Gossip About
lead_paragraph: It is as well to say that the fictions put in circulation by a portion of the press, with regard to the result of the peace conference, such as that "it is far from a failure;" that "the door is opened to reconciliation;" that "an answer is expected from JEFF. DAVIS which will decide whether it is a failure or not;" that "the Government gives out that it has been a failure for reasons of its own;" that "the meeting at Fortress Monroe has materially hastened the day of reunion," must work mischief and only mischief if the public pays the slightest heed to them. They are evidently manufactured in the hotels and bar-rooms of Washington -are the veriest tattle of the most scatterbrained and untrustworthy loungers served up as startling political news. The currency which this sort of stuff has had now for some days has already had a most unfortunate effect on the public mind. It has excited false hopes, spread apathy about the war, paralyzed the work of recruiting, and, in fact, accomplished in a limited degree the very object which, in our opinion, DAVIS desired that the peace movement should accomplish, viz: the slackening of those exertions on our part to prosecute military operations through the Winter, from which the Confederacy has so much to fear, and which it now witnesses for the first time. Anything which promises to impede SHERMAN's movements -- and our failure to send him forward reinforcements will seriously impede them -- is, of course, a great gain to the desperadoes, who now find the circle in which they are to meet their doom contracting round them at Richmond. And nothing could do more to keep back reinforcements than the diffusion through the North of those mendacious accounts of the results of the late conference which some of our cotemporaries have been so industrious in concocting, and which the public has displayed such greediness in swallowing.

lead_paragraph: The deaths in this city during the week ending on the 5th inst., numbered 473 -- being 22 less than occurred during the corresponding week of last year, and 23 less than occurred in the week ending on the 1st inst. Of the deceased, 103 were men, 92 women, 144 boys and 134 girls. The mortality from the principal diseases was as folllows: Apoplexy, 13; bronchitis, 16; convulsions, 36; croup, 12; diphtheria, 17; scarlet fever, 18; typhus, 18; inflammation of the lungs, 45; inflammation of bowels, 14; consumption, 70; small-pox, 28. The deaths of children under 5 years of age numbered 216. The mortality from small-pox during the previous three weeks has been as follows: Week ending Jan. 15, 40; Jan. 22, 26; Jan. 29, 26.

abstract: Claim to extend Fair
snippet: Claim to extend Fair
lead_paragraph: family of the late CHARLES GOODYEAR have petitioned Congress for a further extension of the celebrated patent for vulcanizing india-rubber. The grounds upon which this extension is asked, we are informed, are the following: Mr. GOODYEAR devoted twenty-seven years to the investigation of the properties of india-rubber, during which, he made the discovery from which the greater part of the india-rubber manufactured in the civilized world is now founded. The business employs, in the United States alone, about fifty thousand persons, and yields an annual revenue to the Government, in duties and taxes, of about three quarters of a million. But, while creating this vast and important business, GOODYEAR was involved in immense expenses in defending his rights against infringement, and in applying the material to new uses. Consequently, he died insolvent, leaving a wife and six children without provision. His heirs represent that it was his devotion to the development of his discovery, from which the public derive great advantages, that prevented his reaping the pecuniary reward which the patent law was designed to secure to inventors. The claim of this family to a fair hearing seems unquestionable, and, we trust, they will have it.

abstract: Important news from Gen. SHERMAN comes to us through rebel sources. A dispatch dated Charleston. Feb. 2, printed in Richmond papers of Saturday, announces that SHERMAN's left wing, which had moved up the Savannah River fifty miles, had struck off in a northerly direction and had, on the 1st, crossed Whipply Swamp, and secured one of the bridges over the Saltketchie River, only thirty miles from Branchville, upon which point this force was undoubtedly moving. Another dispatch, of the same date announces the appearance of a fleet of transports and barges with troops in the vicinity of Young's Island, which is only 20 miles southeast of Charleston. SHERMAN is evidently moving in two columns, and demonstrating in earnest against both Charleston and Branchville.

abstract: ORPHAM CHILDREN OF SOLDIERS. -- The fact may not be greatly known that an institutional has been started by Col. YOUNG of Niagara, for the military education of the orphan and destitute children of soldiers. The charity is a most worthy one, and should meet with very general support -- as it is designed to conduct and sustain the institution by voluntary contributions. A detachment of the soldiers, whose admirable training is really surprising, is now in the city. and has quarters at the State Soldier's Home on Howard-street. It is designed to give an exhibition on Thursday evening next at the Howard-street House, (Soldier's Depot,) commencing at 7 o'clock P.M., for the benefit of the charity. No charge will be made for admission -- but a subscription will be taken up among the visitors -- and the amount collected will be applied to the purpose of the charity. The exhibition will be a most entertaining one, and the public generally, ladies and gentlemen are invited to attend.

abstract: -- The crowds which enjoyed themselves on this select pond, yesterday, showed their full appreciation of the excellent condition in which they found the ice by arriving earlier and remaining later in the day than is their usual custom. The finely executed music from a full band added another attraction during the afternoon and evening. To-day is apart for the third grand gala-day of the season, and if the weather should continue favorable throughout the week another skating carnival will be held on Thursday, on the evening of which every opportunity will be afforded for a grand fancy dress masquerade, beside, the magnificent and brilliant pyrotechnic display and illumination, which will continue from 8 to 11 o'clook P.M. Due notice of the carnival will be given on the day previous.

abstract: Paid and Volunteer
snippet: Paid and Volunteer
lead_paragraph: statement is to be laid before the Legislature at Albany, in which a pointed comparison is drawn between the economy of our Fire Department and those of other American and European cities. We cannot, at the moment, vouch for every one of the "facts" advanced in this memorial, but such as they are, they demand the attention of every tax-payer of the city. It is alleged in the memorial that we have here in New-York one hundred and twenty-five houses to maintain for the accommodation of the engines, hose-carriages, and men belonging to the Fire Department; that these houses are kept up at an annual expense of $10,000 each, making an investment in the first instance of $1,250,000. The annual interest and taxes on this make up a sum of $112,500, to which has to be added the annual appropriation for repairs and so forth, making in all an expenditure of $628,000. Even with all this outlay, we are told, the rates of insurance are far higher here than in Cincinnati, where the expenses of the Fire department, even taking population into account, are barely one-third those of New-York. Compared with Boston, our rates of insurance are found to be double what they ought to be, and four times greater than those of London, which has a population four times that of New-York, crowded mostly into narrow streets, and covering an area of about sixty square miles. But the contrast becomes still more startling as between London and New-York, when we find that the cost of the Fire Department of London is little more than one-eighth that of this city, or about $75,000 annually.

abstract: To Richmond; Futility of; and Peace Negotiations
snippet: To Richmond; Futility of; and Peace Negotiations
lead_paragraph: We trust that Senator WADE will sleep better now that the attempt to negotiate a peace has utterly failed. His general temper, never, perhaps, too sweet and gentle, ought to be considerably mollified by the assurance that the war must still go on. In common with a good many other opponents of the Administration, he seems to have been greatly exasperated of late by the efforts of the President to ascertain whether peace was possible without sacrificing the object for which the war is waged -- the integrity of the Union. We do not suppose that the result of these endeavors will soften his indignation against Mr. LINCOLN for having made them, but it may do something toward healing the wound which the possibility of peace was likely to make incurable. Mr. WADE, and those who sympathize with him, can rest easy in their minds. There is no immediate danger of peace. It is now quite certain that the rebels are not prepared to surrender. They are preparing to fight with new vigor and to make fresh sacrifices in the attempt to destroy the Union. We shall have more battles, more taxes, more drafts, -- quite enough of all, we are sorry to believe, to satisfy the patriotic rapacity even of those who have come to love war for its own sake, because it gratifies certain resentments and hatreds in their natures, which have long since overborne their love of the Union and their regard for the Constitution of our common country.

abstract: QUERA, Ex-President of the United States of Colombia, who arrived in this city on Sunday, by the Costa Rica, is now stopping at the Clarendon Hotel. The General will visit England, Prussia, Italy and several of the German States, on a diplomatic mission from his Government. In December, 1863, while Provisional President of Colombia, Gen. MOSQUERA, with three thousand men, defeated an army of twice its strength, and dictated terms of peace to the Government of Ecuador. On the 30th of December a treaty was signed by commissioners, and afterward ratified by President GARCIA MORENO, of Ecuador, and President MOSQUERA, of Colombia. In April, 1864, Senor MURILLO, formerly Minister to Washington, was inaugurated President of Colombia, Gen. MOSQUERA's term having expired. The latter is now intrusted with an important mission to Europe. He is accompanied by Capt. C. ARBOLADA, Lieut. C. MOSQUERA and THOMAS D. MOSQUERA. It is expected that the General and suite will leave this city on Wednesday.

abstract: at the Church of the Holy Trinity, Brooklyn, in aid of the fund for the completion of the church spire. Notwithstanding the severe storm, the church was well filled. Mr. GEORGE WILLIAM WARREN acted as organist and conductor, and the chorus comprised twenty selected voices from Holy Trinity choir. The programme was made up of choice selections from HAYDN, MOZART, HANDEL, ROSSINI, ADAM and MENDELSSOHN. The "Cantique del Noel," of ADOLPH ADAM, the "Ave Maria," of HANDEL, and the "Stabat Mater," of ROSSINI, were finely rendered by Mrs. COMSTOCK. The aria from HANDEL's "Messiah" -- "He was Despised," -- was sung by Mrs. STETSON with great feeling. Messrs. WOODMAN, COMSTOCK and HUNTINGTON rendered the Rev. J.H. HOPKINS' quaint but pleasing carol, "Three Kings of Orient," very effectively. Rev. A.F. TOULMIN, harpist, accompanied Mrs. COMSTOCK in an obligato of the "Cantique de Noel," and added effect to that beautiful hymn. The chorus from the "Creation" -- "The Heavens are Telling," was spiritedly rendered by the entire choir, and the audience then dispersed, evidently highly pleased with the evening's entertainment.

abstract: A sudden and unexpected demonstration by the Army of the Potomac was begun on Sunday last. On the morning of that day the Fifth Corps, preceded by Gen. GREGG'S cavalry division, took up its line of march for Reams' Station and by noon. had reached Rowanty Creek, over which a bridge was construted.
lead_paragraph: A sudden and unexpected demonstration by the Army of the Potomac was begun on Sunday last. On the morning of that day the Fifth Corps, preceded by Gen. GREGG'S cavalry division, took up its line of march for Reams' Station and by noon. had reached Rowanty Creek, over which a bridge was construted. The Second Corps took up its line of march in a westerly direction, on the Vaughan road, to a point about a mile across Hatcher's Run, the scene of several former engagements, where a strong line of the enemy's breastworks was developed. The Second Division of the Second Corps, under Gen. SMYTHE, before reaching Hatcher's Ran, turned to the right, advanced in a northwesterly direction, but before going more than three-quarters of a mile, the enemy were discovered in a strong position and in considerable force, four divisions of Gen. GORDON's corps bring reported in the vicinity. Our troops threw up some slight breastworks, and at 11 o'clock P.M. the rebel la [???]ies opened for the purpose of feeling our lines. Soon afterward the rebels advanced their infantry to the attack in regular line of battle, with a heavy skirmish line, and charged across the fields in the style, but were at once driven back by a galling fire of musketry from our men. The attack was renewed several times, but the enemy suffered a severe repulse with every attack. An effort was then made to turn our right flank, but it was completely foiled by Col. MURPHY's brigade of Gen. SMYTHE's division, who caused the rebels to suffer severely, and finally compelled them to abandon the attempt to break our lines. During the day the Fifth Corps captured a large rebel commissary train. Our entire loss for the day did not exceed one hundred. Further fighting was expected on Monday.

abstract: The bark Leroy, of Montreal, EVANS, from Portland for Havana, with a cargo of shooks, sailed Dec. 18, and for several days had a succession of westerly gales. On the 25th was struck by a heavy sea, which stove in the quarter, and carried away the house, filling the vessel with water. Dec. 28, lat. 34° 30′, lon. 65° 35′, was fallen in with by brig J.W. Johnson, FOSTER, from New-York for Barbados, and, as the Leroy was water-logged, and the men completely worn out at the pumps, concluded to abandon her, and were taken off by Capt. FOSTER, and landed in Barbados.

abstract: PROPOSED PLAN FOR RAISING RECRUITS. -- His Honor Mayor CLEVELAND, of Jersey City, yesterday addressed a circular to the citizens of that city, proposing a plan by which to fill the quota. He says it has become apparent that the quota cannot be filled by paying bounties in bonds, as cash only will bring the recruits. The city pays a bounty of $500, in bonds, to recruits for one year, and he has known cases where the broker paid the recruit but $300 to $350 -- the latter preferring to receive that amount rather than take the bonds. He is confident that more men could be procured at a bounty of $400 cash than for $500 in bonds. In order to enable the Committee on Enlistments to procure the recruits, and save the people from a draft, and to save the city not less than $50,000 on the present call, he proposes that citizens shall loan the money to the city and take the bonds at par -- the loan to be divided into forty parts of $5,000 each, making $200,000. The Mayor announces that he will be at his office in the City Hall, every day, at 11 o'clock A.M., to give information in regard to the matter and receive subscriptions to the loan.

abstract: The Report on; Colored Troops; Troops and the Petersburg Mine
snippet: The Report on; Colored Troops; Troops and the Petersburg Mine
lead_paragraph: We venture to say that the authorized abstract of the Congressional report on the Petersburgh Mine disaster, sent yesterday to the Associated Press, will challenge no common share of attention hereafter in the history of the war. What the report itself, in the fullness of its wisdom may be, we cannot presume to say, until we are favored with a complete copy of it. But the sum of the story, as it comes to us by telegraph, demands attention. The mine in question was due to the genius of Lieut.-Col. PLEASANTS, of the Forty-eighth Pennsylvania Volunteers -- the mining being mainly done by this regiment. The enterprise had the express approval of Gen. BURNSIDE, from which it is to be inferred that, in entering on his task, Col. PLEASANTS acted under the direct authority of the officer in question. The work took a little more than a month for its completion. It was then submitted to the judgment of Gen. MEADE, with a recommendation from Gen. BURNSIDE that an enterprise of so daring and hazardous a character ought to be intrusted to colored troops. Gen. MEADE, no doubt remembering that from Blenheim to Bunker Hill the white race had now and again distinguished itself by considerable prowess, suggested to his subordinate that the negroes had never been under fire, and that if there was danger of an extraordinary character to be gone through, it would be only fair to put the experienced white soldier in the forefront, so that the Commanding-General might not be liable to the charge of indifference to the lives of the black soldiers. In this view the Lieutenant-General, as might be expected, at once concurred. It seems, however, that Gen. GRANT subsequently expressed the opinion, that as the project was Gen. BURNSIDE's, and as he had drilled certain colored regiments for the special purpose of carrying it out, it might have been better if that officer had been allowed to take his own way in matters of detail as well as in the general scope of his enterprise.

abstract: Cost. >amp;c.
snippet: Cost. >amp;c.
lead_paragraph: Not the least interesting of the annual reports ordered by Congress is that which has just been issued from the Washington Printing Bureau. The rebellion had been conceived, but scarcely brought forth, when the joint resolution of Congress was passed which authorized the establishment of a public printing-office and bindery; and since then the influences operating toward the derangement of all sorts of industrial enterprise have necessarily been felt, in as great a degree in this department of public labor as elsewhere. Indeed, it may be doubted whether, looking to the scope of business, which the public printing has embraced during the past four years, as compared with that of the fat contract era, there is yet room to form an entirely satisfactory comparison between the system now in operation, and that which has been abolished. This, we assume, would hold good, even if all the material that enters into the furnishing and working of a complete public printing office and bindery had not changed its value to such a degree as it has.

abstract: Cannonading During Peace Conference
snippet: Cannonading During Peace Conference
lead_paragraph: While the peace conference was in progress on Friday last at Fortress Monroe, Gen. GRANT was keeping up an active cannonading upon the extreme right of his position, which was still in progress on Saturday as STEPHENS, HUNTER and CAMPBELL passed through the lines; and these three rebel notables had hardly got into Richmond on Sunday when Gen. GRANT began an imposing movement on the left, the precise character and purpose of which are not yet apparent. There was marching in large bodies, there was skirmishing, and we learn by the dispatches that something of a much greater character was anticipated speedily.

abstract: In the Senate, yesterday, Mr. HARRIS presented the petition of PETER COOPER and others, of New-York, in favor of a ship canal from Lake Erie to Lake Ontario. A resolution was adopted declaring that the action of the Secretary of the Senate, in submitting the Constitutional Amendment to the President for his approval, was unnecessary, and should not be taken as a precedent for the future Mr. SUMNER's resolution, calling on the President for information in regard to the late peace conference was not taken up. The enrollment bill was then taken up. The pending question was the adoption of the amendment to make the third section read so that substitute-brokers, recruiting agents, or other persons who shall, for pay or profit, enlist insane persons, or persons in a state of intoxication, shall he punished. This amendment was adopted. Mr. CLARK moved to amend the first section so as to make it read that any person drafted may furnish as a substitute a person liable to draft in the same town, city or ward. This amendment was also adopted. Several of the amendments were rejected, when the bill was passed. Mr. POWELL moved the postponement of all prior orders for the purpose of considering the bill to authorize the construction of a bridge over the Ohio River at Zanesville. Pending the consideration of this question the Senate adjourned.

abstract: Letter on Arkansas and Constitutional Amendment; Constitutional Amendment in New-Jersey; The Anti-Slavery Constitutional Amendment in; Constitutional Amendment; Senator Snow's Letter
snippet: Letter on Arkansas and Constitutional Amendment; Constitutional Amendment in New-Jersey; The Anti-Slavery Constitutional Amendment in; Constitutional Amendment; Senator Snow's Letter
lead_paragraph: It is a matter of no surprise that the passage of the Constitutional Amendment calls forth such unbounded enthusiasm from the people of the free States, and that cannon answers to cannon from the shores of Maine to the Pacific coast, saluting this great event. The convictions and instincts of the nation but foretell the decision of history, that the day on which that great act of emancipation becomes law, is only second to one other day -- the birth-day of the Republic. For, when that new provision is incorporated in the Constitution, the proclamation of human rights contained in our Declaration of Independence has become embodied utterly in our organic law. All men under the American flag are then "free" and "equal" in the sight of the law. A race is forever emancipated. The last stain on our political Constitution is wiped away. Freedom under the great Republic means freedom for all races, colors and classes. The ideas which inspired our heroic Fathers have at length borne their full fruit, and universal liberty is installed under the Constitution. Indeed, we may, without exaggeration, say more, that that day or that year when slavery is forever abolished by the highest law on American soil, is, like the era of Magna Charta, or of the Reformation, or the emancipation in the West Indies, one of the great epochs in human history, to which the respect and admiration of mankind will return for many centuries to come. It will be looked upon like the destruction of serfdom, and many other public evils in Europe, as the highest working out in the nineteenth century of the principle of CHRISTIANITY itself.

abstract: The New-York Historical Society held its February meeting last evening, which was well attended, notwithstanding the inclemency of the weather. The minutes of the last monthly and the annual meetings were read and approved, when the President, FREDERICE DE PEYSTER, said Lieut.-Gen. WINFIELD SCOTT had presented the society with a copy of his autobiography. Mr. DE PEYSTER accompanied the announcement with a few interesting remarks upon the life and character of the donor. The thanks of the society were voted to Gen. SCOTT for his gift.

abstract: W. L. McDonald; a Newark Rebel
snippet: W. L. McDonald; a Newark Rebel
lead_paragraph: WILLIAM LAWRENCE MCDONALD, who figures in the papers as the rebel agent in Canada, and the leading spirit in the Chesapeake, St. Albans, and New-York hotel-burning affairs, was formerly a resident of this city and of Orange, where he has relatives and is well known. He was a steamboat Captain on the Mississippi River for ten years, and became largely acquainted with Southern people. In 1860, he associated with Mr. B.M. WHITLOCK, (his brother-in-law,) in the carriage business, and opened a Southern repository at No. 514 Broadway, in New-York City. His trade, which had been almost exclusively with the South, having been shut off by the war, he became a most bitter and consistent partisan of the rebels. Having become heavily indebted to Mr. GREEN, carriage-maker in this city, "Larry," as he is familiarly called, tendered his services to him to pay his obligations, and on the former gentleman being appointed sutler to the Twenty-sixth Regiment, he accompanied him to Virginia. After the first stock of goods had been sold, LARRY came North and purchased $2,000 worth of goods for Mr. GREEN, and, on his return to Virginia, deliberately drove them into the rebel lines, where they were, of course, confiscated. While in Richmond, as is since ascertained, he lived in luxury, affiliating with all the rebel leaders, giving them information as to the number and position of our forces, and other valuable facts. He was then released on a pretended parole, and came to this city, and while visiting his wife at Westchester, New-York, learned that his exploits had been divulged to the War Department, and detectives were after him. He immediately shipped as a sailor on a schooner for New-Brunswick, Nova Scotia, and succeeded in eluding the vigilance of the authorities. MCDONALD is about forty years of age, and a native of Canada, but came to Orange when very young, "GUS" MCDONALD, a brother of the above, who also lived in Orange, but recently a resident of New-York, is in custody on a charge of harboring the incendiaries while they were in that city. -- Newark Advertiser.

abstract: St. Louis; Coleman's Grocery, >amp;c--$20,000; Bounty-brokers' Astounding Frauds
snippet: St. Louis; Coleman's Grocery, >amp;c--$20,000; Bounty-brokers' Astounding Frauds
lead_paragraph: While a committee of the Board of Supervisors of this county are striving to show the Washington authorities that we have nearly filled our quota, a number of Government officers are in our midst, ferreting out a system of gigantic frauds, the exposure of which, it is alleged, will show that we are not entitled to more than two-thirds of the credits which we received on the call for men in July last. Col. BAKER, Chief of Government Detective Police, has succeeded in showing Gov. CURTIN, of Pennsylvania, how it happened that notwithstanding the payment of thousands on thousands of dollars in bounties, by towns and counties, they had failed to place men in the field; and now the Colonel intends to solve a like problem for us. He will show us that not a dozen of the many men who are engaged in the business of recruiting in New-York, are honest, and that nearly all of the bounty-brokers' crew are the most arrant scoundrels that ever went unpunished.

abstract: BURGLARY AND SHOOTING -- About 1 30, yesterday morning, CHAS. ENGLISH and a confederate, who had burglariously entered Mr. DENNIS DOWLING's boot and shoe store, at No. 726 Broadway, and stolen therefrom $550 worth of goods, were making their escape through Broadway, when they were apprehended by Policeman CONNOLLY, of the Fifteenth Precinct. They replied evasively when questioned by the officer concerning the contents of their carpetbags, and when he attempted to take them to the station-house they fought him, and ENGLISH, releasing himself, fired upon Officer CONNOLLY, but missed aim. He then fled, firing as he retreated. The officer, pursuing ENGLISH, was fired upon by the burglar's confederate, but was not harmed. ENGLISH was captured and taken before Justice DODGE, and committed without ball, and a warrant was issued for the arrest of his associate.
