abstract: ACADEMY OF MUSIC. -- The weather, this season, at least, does not favor Mr. MARETZEK, but the audience last night was superb, and, as on Saturday, the result of a general appreciation of the opera produced, and of confidence in the singers who took part in it. The attendance in consequence was in the highest degree satisfactory. "Faust" was given with complete success; the cast being mainly the same as last season The notable exception was in the representative of Mephistopheles, who was Signor BELLINI. Hitherto the role has been sustained by the voice for which it was written, namely, the basso. In London, however, the partition was subsequently changed for the baritone, and Mr. MARETZEK, conscious of a fine artist with this voice, has given it, for the sake of novelty, to Signor BELLINI. The energy, conscientious study, and vigorous vitality of this thorough artist, combined with the clear intelligence which he throws into every part, render him desirable in any and all parts. As Mephistopheles he is really excellent, giving to the part a degree of pointedness and diablerie which has not been achieved. We regard it in fact as a new feature of attraction to a work which has already become somewhat familiar to our public.

abstract: Luther C. Tibbetts vs. Horatio N. Twombley.  Sidney Sanderson, one of the brokers for the plaintiff, testified that he talked with plaintiff and took orders which were reasonable from Mr. Tibbetts after the fracas at the Corn Exchange, and saw no marks of insanity either on the 9th or 10th after the affair which happened on the 8th; agreed to raise money for plaintiff.
lead_paragraph: Luther C. Tibbetts vs. Horatio N. Twombley. -- Sidney Sanderson, one of the brokers for the plaintiff, testified that he talked with plaintiff and took orders which were reasonable from Mr. Tibbetts after the fracas at the Corn Exchange, and saw no marks of insanity either on the 9th or 10th after the affair which happened on the 8th; agreed to raise money for plaintiff. Defendant's counsel objected to the admission of any evidence as to the plaintiff's business. Mr. Tibbetts stated that it was the purpose of the question to show loss of credit. After some discussion between the Judge and the plaintiff, the court refused to allow any question as to the witness' having applied for the money, until first it was shown that their refusal resulted from Mr. Twombley's remarks. Question repeated. Objection sustained. Exception. The question was repeated in different forms tending to show loss of credit and objected to, and the objection sustained. Witness resumes. Mr. Twombley asked for a statement of Mr. Tibbett's affairs from witness, which witness could not give. Mr. Twombley wished to see whether it would be advisable to carry out certain contracts, as in that case no would be willing to advance money; Mr. Twombley did talk of plaintiff's insanity in connection with his affairs and imprisonment in the Tombs; defendant did not say anything in regard to plaintiff's unfitness to do business. On a cross-examination he gave an account of the fracas at the Corn Exchange; that he saw the plaintiff at the Tombs on the 10th of February.

abstract: In the Senate, yesterday, a bill was reported for a tunnel railroad under Broadway. Bills were introduced to incorporate the New-York. Underground Railroad Company, and for the improvement of that portion of New-York lying between One Hundred and Tenth-street and Harlem River; to incorporate the Merchants' Exchange and News-room, and to authorize Supervisors of New-York to raise money for certain county purposes.
lead_paragraph: In the Senate, yesterday, a bill was reported for a tunnel railroad under Broadway. Bills were introduced to incorporate the New-York. Underground Railroad Company, and for the improvement of that portion of New-York lying between One Hundred and Tenth-street and Harlem River; to incorporate the Merchants' Exchange and News-room, and to authorize Supervisors of New-York to raise money for certain county purposes. Among the bills passed was one to prevent encroachments upon the harbor of New-York, and for the completion of the Battery extension. In the Assembly -- The bill legalizing the ordinance of the Supervisors of New-York, passed June, 1864, relative to bounties, was passed. The bills to enable the State Banks to organize as National Banks; to extend the time for the construction of the Adirondack Railroad, and to increase the capital stock of the company; and for the improvement and government of Central Park, were ordered to a third reading. The Assembly held an evening session and considered the State Bounty Bill.

lead_paragraph: The United States double-ender Chenango, nine guns and 974 tons burden, sails to-day for Port Royal, to perform blockade duty. abstract: The news from the Army of the Potomac is not yet definite as to the object or results of the new movement. The Second and Fifth Corps obtained a well-advanced position on Sunday, and held it, despite the efforts of the enemy to dislodge them.
lead_paragraph: The news from the Army of the Potomac is not yet definite as to the object or results of the new movement. The Second and Fifth Corps obtained a well-advanced position on Sunday, and held it, despite the efforts of the enemy to dislodge them. The greater part of the Sixth and Ninth Corps arrived on the ground Sunday night. On Monday afternoon CRAWFORD's division of the Fifth Corps was pushed forward, and drove the rebels from a point known as Dabney's Mills, about two miles beyond Hatcher's Run. Here the rebels made a determined stand, and about 5 o'clock made an attack in front and on the flank of the division, and caused it to fall back some distance to a line of works thrown up by the Second Corps on Sunday, where our men reformed, and aided by the Third Division of the Sixth Corps, the enemy were in turn driven back. The fighting was quite severe while it lasted, and the enemy being the attacking party suffered severely. Our loss was from 300 to 500. About 120 prisoners were captured, among whom was one rebel Colonel.

abstract: The declaration of the Richmond papers to the effect that the South is ready to become abolitionist, as well as the North, has been seized upon with eagerness by the French rebel press, as a pretext for urging recognition. Even the official journal prints prominently and menacingly in its columns, at least sufficiently so to give great courage to the Secessionists here, this declaration of the Richmond journals about abolition for recognition.
lead_paragraph: PARIS, Friday, Jan. 20, 1865.

abstract: In the Senate, yesterday, bills were reported ratifying the amendment to the National Constitution, to create a new ward in New-York, and to incorporate the Merchants' Exchange and News Room of the City of New-York. Notice was given of a bill to repeal the charter of the Union Trust Company; for a Police Court in New-York, and for a railroad in Eleventh-avenue. Bills were introduced for the completion of Harlem Bridge, and for widening Sixth-avenue, New-York. The bill incorporating the Arion Society of New-York and the Poughkeepsie Bounty Bill were passed.

abstract: Brooklyn, Sackett-street; Dwelling House--$2,000
snippet: Brooklyn, Sackett-street; Dwelling House--$2,000
lead_paragraph: THE SUFFOCATION CASE. -- Coroner LYNCH held an inquest on the body of the infant. MYRON VAN BUREN, who died on the 3d inst., in consequence of inhaling gas at No. 228 Washington-street. The evidence showed that the room was without ventilation, and that the damper of the stove had been turned off, thus forcing the gas into the room. A verdict in accordance was rendered. The remainder of the family are getting well.

abstract: Freedmen's Bureau Bill; The
snippet: Freedmen's Bureau Bill; The
lead_paragraph: A measure of far-reaching influence and importance to the colored race and to the country comes up before Congress to-day -- Mr. ELIOT'S bill for the establishment of a "Freedmen's Bureau," or, in other words, of a separate department of Government, controlling the interests of millions of human beings in the future. The new bill is a compound of the two bills -- the House and the Senate -- which have been up before for the settlement of this difficult matter. It has been framed mainly by Senators HOWARD and SUMNER, and Messrs. ELIOT and KELLEY, of the House.

abstract: CHARGE OF CONSPIRACY AND ROBBERY. -About a week since a German named ISAAC STAMFILS, a resident of Morristown, N.J., was arrested and taken before Justice POPE, of Hoboken, charged with having attempted to commit an outrage on the person of BARBARA WEIN, whose husband keeps a lager-beer saloon at No. 139 Washington-street. Subsequently STAMFILS went before Justice WHITE and charged WEIN, his wife, and a man named HERMAN FECHT with conspiracy and assault and battery, and with having robbed him of two gold watches and $145 in money, together with a wallet and some papers. A warrant was issued upon which the parties were arrested, and the examination was to have taken place yesterday, but was postponed in consequence of the illness of STAMFILS, produced by violence, as is alleged, received at the hands of the accused parties at the time the robbery is said to have been committed.
lead_paragraph: CHARGE OF CONSPIRACY AND ROBBERY. -About a week since a German named ISAAC STAMFILS, a resident of Morristown, N.J., was arrested and taken before Justice POPE, of Hoboken, charged with having attempted to commit an outrage on the person of BARBARA WEIN, whose husband keeps a lager-beer saloon at No. 139 Washington-street. Subsequently STAMFILS went before Justice WHITE and charged WEIN, his wife, and a man named HERMAN FECHT with conspiracy and assault and battery, and with having robbed him of two gold watches and $145 in money, together with a wallet and some papers. A warrant was issued upon which the parties were arrested, and the examination was to have taken place yesterday, but was postponed in consequence of the illness of STAMFILS, produced by violence, as is alleged, received at the hands of the accused parties at the time the robbery is said to have been committed.

abstract: Political and Social
snippet: Political and Social
lead_paragraph: Is there anything wonderful to which our people would not become accustomed in almost as little time as it takes to express the wonder? Only think what things are now accepted as matters of every day, which but a short time ago would have stirred the whole country. Look at the military displays which now pass through the streets, almost unnoticed, which a short time ago would have brought every one to the windows and doorways. The skirmish at Great Bethel, with its two dozen of killed and wounded, made far more sensation throughout the country than would a battle now, in which as many hundred fell. Long marches and victorious campaigns, seiges and captures, have palled upon us, and we only pay momentary attention to the guns which announce some victory which will take its place among the great victories of the world's history.

abstract: and Drafted; rights and wrongs, Sumner's Amendment; Debate--Unjust to Drafted Men; Injustice to Drafted Men
snippet: and Drafted; rights and wrongs, Sumner's Amendment; Debate--Unjust to Drafted Men; Injustice to Drafted Men
lead_paragraph: There appears, from the debates in Congress on the Enrollment Act, as well as from much of the discussion which takes place out of doors, to be a strong disposition prevalent to look upon a man who chances to be drafted, as something very like a criminal, and treat him accordingly. That portion of the public, whose names have not been drawn, is very indignant with him, if he displays the slightest unwillingness to serve in person, or the slightest anxiety to procure a substitute, He is not only expected to march off, but to do so with great satisfaction and enthusiasm; and the least indication of a desire to get some one else to go in his place, raises a presumption that he is a meanspirited or disloyal person.

lead_paragraph: The Senate yesterday took up a bill relating to postal laws. The bill contains seventeen sec tions, a full summary of which will be found in the proceedings of Congress. It is said to have the approval of the Postmaster-General. At 1 o'clock the Senate received a message from the House, that that body was really to proceed with the counting of the Presidential vote. The Senate then repaired to the House of Representatives and assisted at this ceremony, retiring at 2 o'clock to their own room. Mr. SUMNER's resolution requesting the President to furnish information in relation to the peace conference was taken up and passed, after a somewhat protracted debate. The bill to establish a bridge over the Ohio at Louisville, was taken up and passed. Pending the consideration of a bill to define the boundaries of the State of Nevada, the Senate adjourned.

abstract: Emigration of English; Affidavits
snippet: Emigration of English; Affidavits
lead_paragraph: Although for several years it has been known to our State authorities, that the British Government have been surreptitiously sending paupers to this country, still it has been very difficult to fasten the misdemeanors upon that Government, and in but few instances have the facts been sufficiently plain to warrant the Commissioners of Emigration in sending well-known paupers back to the port of their embarkation. Recently, however, the proceedings of the prison officials of London have become more open, and the jails of that metropolis are frequently cleared, and the convicts sent to our shores. The following affidavits of four emigrants by the ship Cornelius Grinnell, which landed her passengers at Castle Garden on Tuesday ought to receive the attentions of the Police Commissioners:

abstract: The State Senate have called on the Croton Aqueduct Department for information relative to the sewerage system of this city. Mr. A.W. CRAVEN, chief engineer of the department, says, in reply:
lead_paragraph: The State Senate have called on the Croton Aqueduct Department for information relative to the sewerage system of this city. Mr. A.W. CRAVEN, chief engineer of the department, says, in reply: "The condition of the sewerage of the city is not creditable to those having control over the matter, and that there is no system governing the construction of sewers. Municipal ordinances are passed only on the application of parties suffering for the want of drainage in their immediate individual localities, and by the operation of these ordinances sewers are built in detached pieces, and to make them immediately available their outlets are forced into either the nearest existing sewer, or the head of some dock, or slip, without regard to the teachings of experience, or to any scientific, calculation as to size, grade or direction. The result of a long-continued persistence in this disregard of system is, that for miles along the river front of the city almost every dock has become a vast recess-pool of sewerage matter, without the reach of tidal currents; noxious exhalations occur, poisoning the atmosphere, and breeding the elements of disease. The docks or slips rapidly fill up, the water becomes too shallow for vessels in berth, and the expense of dredging out follows.
headline: {'main': 'Our Sewerage System.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'Our Sewerage System.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: CITY NOTES. -- The ball of the German Lieder kranz will take place at the Academy of Music, on Thursday, the 16th inst. The preparations are on an extensive scale, one hundred musicians having been engaged....Mr. DE CORDOVA will deliver his celebrated humorous lecture, "Mrs. Smith's Surprise Party" at Cooper Institute, on Saturday next. The proceeds of the lecture will be devoted to printing it and sending copies to our soldiers in the field....Prof. JOHN W. DRAPER's course of lectures before the Historical Society will commence this evening at the Society's Library, corner of Second-avenue and Eleventh-street. The subject of this evening's lecture is "The Influence of Climate."....There will be a meeting at Union Headquarters in Fourth-avenue, near Thirtieth-street, on Friday, night next, when resolutions will be adopted in relation to the death of WILLIAM CURTIS NOYES.

abstract: Convicts Shipped to New-York; Ticket-of-Leave Men in New-York
snippet: Convicts Shipped to New-York; Ticket-of-Leave Men in New-York
lead_paragraph: It is over a year ago that we called attention to the fact that English " ticket-of-leave men," or convicts let out of the English prisons before the expiration of their term, were being shipped to this city by the " Prisoners' Aid Society" of London, an association acting under the auspices of the British authorities. At that time, some of these beautieswho had then just landed on our shores, were got hold of by the police, taken to headquarters for inspection and drill, and then shipped back to their own, their native land. Those of our citizens who then had an opportunity of seeing them will not soon forget their appearance. They were the final and perfect type of that hideous order of human brutishness which grows in such gross luxuriance on the soil of England. Had they been permitted to remain among us, we should soon have heard of them as burglars or murderers, and they would doubtless finally have ended their days at the public expense, in the penitentiary or on the gallows tree.

abstract: Our Peace Commissioners have returned. They were not allowed to enter the enemy's capital. No commissioners on the part of the enemy were appointed to meet them but LINCOLN, after the manner of ancient potentates, himself gave audience in person and listened to their errand in his own backwoods style. He was civil, and, as he never fails to be jocose and anecdotical, he assured our commissioners that he has no terms to offer or listen to that did not rest upon our submission to the Federal authority and a return of our States to the Union. Such, we have reason to believe, was the result of the interview between LINCOLN and SEWARD on one side, and STEPHENS, HUNTER and CAMPBELL on the other, at Fortress Monroe last week.
lead_paragraph: Our Peace Commissioners have returned. They were not allowed to enter the enemy's capital. No commissioners on the part of the enemy were appointed to meet them but LINCOLN, after the manner of ancient potentates, himself gave audience in person and listened to their errand in his own backwoods style. He was civil, and, as he never fails to be jocose and anecdotical, he assured our commissioners that he has no terms to offer or listen to that did not rest upon our submission to the Federal authority and a return of our States to the Union. Such, we have reason to believe, was the result of the interview between LINCOLN and SEWARD on one side, and STEPHENS, HUNTER and CAMPBELL on the other, at Fortress Monroe last week.

lead_paragraph: A special meeting of the Chamber of Commerce, President A.A. LOW, presiding, was held yesterday afternoon, to hear the report of the Committees on the Battery Extension and on Piers, Wharves and Slips. Mr. GEORGE W. BLUNT, Chairman of the Committee on Battery Extension, submitted a report which embraced a memorial to the Legislature in favor of the passage of a bill now before the Senate to place the alteration in the water-front in the hands of the Pilot Commissioners. The memorial briefly recapitulates the facts concerning the history of the extension, and gives the opinions of distinguished engineers who have been consulted respecting the same. The committee state that in 1853 the original contract for the Battery Extension was transferred by Mr. CONKLING to GEORGE LAW, "since which period it has been prosecuted slowly until now, when labor upon it is wholly suspended.

abstract: In the Senate bills were introduced requiring Registers throughout the State to provide an official seal; for a railroad in Eleventh-avenue, NewYork; relative to Life and Health Insurance Companies.
lead_paragraph: In the Senate bills were introduced requiring Registers throughout the State to provide an official seal; for a railroad in Eleventh-avenue, NewYork; relative to Life and Health Insurance Companies. The following bills were advanced to a third reading: To facilitate the acquisition of lands for the Croton Aqueduct Reservoir; fixing the compensation of members of the New-York Common Council at $2,000 per annum, to take effect next January; to enable husband and wife to be witnesses for and against each other in certain cases. In the Assembly a bill was reported ratifying the amendment to the Constitution abolishing slavery, which was made the special order for Wednesday evening. The following bills were passed: The State Bounty and Loan Bill; to provide a military parade-ground in Hamilton-square, New-York; for the improvement and maintenance of the Central Park; to close Obserfatory-place in the City of New-York.

abstract: Bounty-jumpers;>amp;c.
snippet: Bounty-jumpers;>amp;c.
lead_paragraph: The strong prospect of another draft, causing in any event another drain on the blond and purses of the population, makes everything relating to the economy of men of the highest importance. We have already spoken in strong terms in these columns of the shocking abuses perpetrated in the supply of substitutes, of the moral depravity and physical decrepitude and inferiority of a large proportion of the men furnished to the army as volunteers under our present system of high bounties. The greater part of these abuses are undoubtedly the fault of Boards of Enrollment, Examining Surgeons and Provost-Marshals. It is impossible to acquit these officials of a large portion of the blame of sending to the army the cripples and imbeciles, the blind and deaf, of whom a large number make their appearance in the field, as part of the quota, over the filling of which towns and cities so often ring their bells and fire their guns.

abstract: Speech on Hampton Roads Conference; Conference; Rebel Official Reports
snippet: Speech on Hampton Roads Conference; Conference; Rebel Official Reports
lead_paragraph: The message of President LINCOLN, giving the details of the peace conference, was not sent in to Congreess yesterday, as was generally expected. It will probably be sent in to-day. The Richmond papers of Tuesday contain a message from JEFF. DAVIS, communicating to the rebel Congress the report of the rebel commissioners, which we give elsewhere. On Monday evening there was a large public meeting in Richmond, to hear and discuss the result of the peace conference, at which JEFF. DAVIS and A.H. STEPHENS spoke. DAVIS uttered the most ultra war sentiments, declaring he would never give up the fight, would lose everything he had, and if he possessed them would sacrifice a thousand lives rather than that the country should be reunited. We make copious extracts from the Richmond papers, all of which are in perfect paroxysms of rage over what they term the "insulting propositions" of Mr. LINCOLN. They howl, groan and swear, alternately, and then bid defiance to everything and everybody, and then -- subside into a decent quiet, at the soothing sound of GRANT's cannon in the suburbs.

abstract: At a sitting of the Finance Committee of the Lower House of the Reichsrath, the Minister of Police declared, in the name of the Cabinet, that the Government was willing to consent to reductions in the budget of expenditure, under the twofold condition that the Government should have the right to distribute the funds voted by the Chamber indiscriminately amongst the different branches of the public service; and also that the budget of 1866 should be voted during the present session of the Reichsrath, with similar power of distribution on the part of the Government. The Minister further declared that unless these two conditions should be previously accented, the Government [???]ould not state precisely the exact amounts of which the new modifications of the budget would consist. Hereupon the finance committes resolved not to accept these conditions so long as the Cabinet declined distinctly to point out the amount of reductions to be introduced.

abstract: Bartlett, Washington A, of "Diamond Wedding" Fame
snippet: Bartlett, Washington A, of "Diamond Wedding" Fame
lead_paragraph: United States Marshal MURRAY received a telegram yesterday morning, directing him to proceed to Montreal, Canada, and take charge of the St. Albans raiders, who are to be delivered up by the Canadian authorities. The Marshal and his assistants left this city last evening....WASHINGTON A. BARTLETT, formerly an officer in the United States navy, and father of the young lady whose marriage a few years ago to Senor OVIEDO, of Cuba, was known as the "diamond wedding," died on Monday, aged 49 years. Col. BARTLETT was well known in this city....The Senate Investigating Committee will resume its sessions on Thursday, the 16th inst....An advertisement in another column calls for information in relation to the City Inspector's Department, and the labors of the committee will be greatly lightened by active cooperation on the part of citizens. Communications should be addressed to Mr. DOTY, No. 70 William-street....The attention of brokers, lawyers and others, desiring eligible offices convenient to the Stock Exchange, Custom-house, United States Treasury, &c., is directed to the advertisement of Mr. E. MATTHEWS in another column.....The Fifth-avenue Skating Pond, yesterday afternoon and evening, presented a very gay and animated appearance, there being a very large attendance of the beau monde, who enjoyed themselves to the fullest extent. The ice was in a remarkably fine condition, and a fine band added to the pleasure of the company. A large concourse may be expected, to-day.

abstract: Wednesday afternoon Officer DODGE, of the Broadway Police, arrested CORNELIUS VANDERBILT for driving over Mrs. CAROLINE WALTER in Broadway, corner of Fulton-street. The Commodore was taken to the Tombs Police Court, but no complainant appearing, Justice HOGAN dismissed him. Mrs. WALTER, whose abode is in Sheriff-street, was taken thither. She was not seriously injured.

abstract: The steamer Australasian, from Liverpool on the 28th and Queenstown on the 29th of January, arrived at this port last evening. She brings also
lead_paragraph: The steamer Australasian, from Liverpool on the 28th and Queenstown on the 29th of January, arrived at this port last evening. She brings also a summary of the news sent out by the St. David, now due at Portland. The English papers have little to say on American affairs. A London merchant, who was in Savannah two days prior to its occupation by our troops, expresses his belief that the amount of cotton captured could not exceed 5,000 or 6,000 bales. The British public is very sensitive on this point, and would be very glad to have the statement that 32,000 bales were captured prove untrue. The case of Capt. CORBETT, of the pirate Shenandoah, has been removed from the Central Criminal Court to the Queen's Bench, and the amount of bail doubled. The Right Honorable FREDERICK PEEL, Under Secretary of Treasury, had addressed his constituents in favor of peace and neutrality. Mr. MILNOR GIBSON, Chairman of the Board of Trade, had made a speech in which he asserted that his sympathies were wholly with the North, and expressed the belief that the war would extinguish slavery in this country. The advices from the continent are of minor importance.

abstract: THE NEW-YORK SEMI-WEEKLY TIMES is published THIS MORNING, and may be had at the counter of the publication office in wrappers ready for mailing. Price FIVE CENTS.
lead_paragraph: THE NEW-YORK SEMI-WEEKLY TIMES is published THIS MORNING, and may be had at the counter of the publication office in wrappers ready for mailing. Price FIVE CENTS. In addition to the latest intelligence by telegraph up to the moment of going to press, there will be found in the current number full details of all military movements in the different departments from the pens of our special correspondents. Also, all official orders, reports and documents, and the latest and fullest Washington news, European news, with graphic letters from our correspondents in London and Paris, giving the tone of public feeling abroad, is made a special and permanent feature. In addition to Editorials on all the current topics of the day, the SEMI-WEEKLY TIMES has a page of carefully prepared commercial matter, giving the latest financial news and market reports; items of agricultural and domestic interest, compiled from sources many of which are otherwise inaccessible to the American reader; and marriages and deaths of the week.

abstract: Yesterday Mr. CLARK, of New-Hampshire, was elected temporary Chairman of the Senate during the absence of the Vice-President. A bill was reported back from the Military Committee for the better organization of the Army Pay Department.
lead_paragraph: Yesterday Mr. CLARK, of New-Hampshire, was elected temporary Chairman of the Senate during the absence of the Vice-President. A bill was reported back from the Military Committee for the better organization of the Army Pay Department. The bill to regulate commerce between the several States was made the special order for next Monday. The bill to reimburse Missouri for the expenses incurred by that State in calling out the militia was passed. A bill was introduced, and referred to the Committee on Commerce, concerning intercourse between loyal and rebel States. Mr. WILSON introduced a bill more effectually to provide for the nation's defence, by establishing a uniform militia throughout the United States, which was referred to the Military Committee. After an Executive session, the Senate adjourned.

abstract: They can at any moment have peace, simply by laying down their arms, and submitting to the national authority under the Constitution. After so much, the Government could not, if it would, maintain war against them. * * * The executive power itself would be greatly diminished by the cessation of actual war. Pardons and remissions of forfeiture, however, would still be within Executive control. In what spirit and temper this control would be exercised can be fairly judged of by the past. A year ago, general pardon and amnesty, upon specified terms, were offered to all, except certain designated classes; and it was at the same time made known that the excepted classes were still within contemplation of special clemency.

abstract: Those who have been credulous as to the rumors about peace through negotiation, will not find much basis for their faith in the official rebel documents, the speeches and action of rebel officials, the popular rebel manifestations, and the rebel newspaper articles, which we are enabled to furnish to-day. And, if it were not adding a comic feature to a grim fact, we might also add that the appreciation in the value of gold in Richmond shows a depreciation of rebel faith in the peace negotiations, and will not increase ours.

abstract: RUFFIANLY RECRUITING AGENT. -- Mr. JAMES CONOVER, of Keyport, N.J., appeared before Justice DODGE, and complained that, on Wednesday evening LEONARD J. SEELY seized him by the collar, and, personating a United States detective, threatened to take him to the Tombs at once, if he refused to accompany him to a recruiting office, and enlist. Mr. CONOVER declined, and SEELY was arrested by Officer ROBINSON, of the Eighth Precinct. He was committed in default of $1,000 bail.

abstract: ACADEMY OF MUSIC. -- VERDI's opera of "La Traviata" was given here last evening to an exceedingly good house. Mme. ZUCCHI was the Violetta, and sang with great dramatic breadth, but with less than her usual vocal clearness. Signor MASSIMILIANI was admirable, fine in voice, and -- we may say it -- animated in manner. Of Signor BELLINI we have nothing at any time to say except in the way of praise. He was in fine voice last evening, and contributed very largely to the general excellence of the performance.

abstract: The and Law of Recognition; New Story of; The Law of
snippet: The and Law of Recognition; New Story of; The Law of
lead_paragraph: It is safe to say that a day has not passed since the outbreak of the war, on which a rumor has not been afloat of the impending recognition of the Confederacy by France or by England, or by both. There has always been somebody who had it "on the best authority," that it had been fully decided on, and generally he has been able to fix the precise number of days, inside which it would happen, and it is somewhat remarkable that this has generally been thirty or a multiple of thirty, say sixty or ninety. There has, however, from the outset, never been the slightest warrant, beyond the suspicion of people who knew nothing of the policy of either of these Powers, and were incapable of framing any rational calculation about it, for the supposition that either France or England would depart in this matter from the established usage. What that usage is was very clearly set forth in the letters of "Historicus," and his statement of it is very well known to meet with the entire concurrence of the English cabinet, and, we have very little doubt, with that of France also. It is simply this, that no rebels are entitled to recognition as a separate and established nation, no matter how strong the probability may appear of their final triumph, as long as the Government against which they have risen continues to make serious efforts for their subjugation. This rule has grown up in the interest of peace and order, and its observance is urged by considerations of the same nature. Every Power owes it to its neighbors, as a matter of courtesy, to regard every revolt against its authority as likely to fail, until it has itself admitted its success by the abandonment of all attempts to suppress it.

The bill in relation to collecting dues from defaulting agents or employes...
lead_paragraph: In the Senate yesterday, a message was received from the President in relation to the exclusion of certain States from the Electoral College. A resolution was offered, and objected to, instructing the Committee on Military Affairs to inquire into the expediency of appropriating the cotton captured at Savannah for the manufacture of tents for the army. The bill in relation to collecting dues from defaulting agents or employes of the Post-office Department, was taken up and passed. The President's message concerning the late Peace Conference was read and ordered to be printed. The Senate then resumed the consideration of the Appropriation Bill, to which, by amendment, the Deficiency Bill was attached. Among other amendments proposed was a section increasing the compensation of Congressmen to $10,000 per Congress. The amendment was rejected.

abstract: The Inman steamer City of London, Capt. PETRIE, which left Liverpool at 3 o'clock on the afternoon of the 25th, and Queenstown on the 26th of January, arrived here yesterday morning. Her news is anticipated mainly by the Australasian. It was reported that the steamer Ajax, with seven guns on board, had effected her escape from the Clyde, bound for a port in the West Indies. The vessel afterward called at Kingston, Dublin, and received various supplies there. A mutiny also took place among her crew. She was regarded as a mere blockade-runner at Kingston.

abstract: Bounty-jumpers; Col Baker's Further Discoveries
snippet: Bounty-jumpers; Col Baker's Further Discoveries
lead_paragraph: Col. BAKER's parlors, at the Astor, was literally overrun, yesterday, by Boards of Supervisors from the rural districts, who had come hither to ascertain what action the Government will probably take in regard to their respective quotas. They were not the best-humored multitude that ever gathered under the Astor's hospitable roof; they had been outrageously cheated, and they did not care to conceal their feelings; but as nothing was to be gained by reiterating curses upon the heads of the bounty-brokerage banditti, and as Col. BAKER had done them a favor rather than otherwise, in exposing and exploding the enlistment frauds, they were disposed to treat him quite courteously. He, however, could do nothing for them; he could exhibit the official records of the York-street Naval Rendezvous and of the Governor's Island office, showing what enlistment papers were genuine and what fictitious, and that was all. He dared not undertake to say whether the Government would require them to supply soldiers in lieu of the thousands that its agents on Governor's Island have aided in deserting; but he felt assured that Gen. FRY and Secretary STANTON would regard as so much waste paper every certificate of enlistment for which a name is not to be found on the War Department records.

abstract: We have no confirmation to-day of the rebel intelligence published yesterday, and doubted in Richmond, that Gen. SHERMAN had captured Branchville; but the rebel papers and dispatches give good reason to believe that this important centre is in our possession by this time. Of the recent movements of his right wing, which they reported advancing in the direction of Charleston, they are silent.
lead_paragraph: We have no confirmation to-day of the rebel intelligence published yesterday, and doubted in Richmond, that Gen. SHERMAN had captured Branchville; but the rebel papers and dispatches give good reason to believe that this important centre is in our possession by this time. Of the recent movements of his right wing, which they reported advancing in the direction of Charleston, they are silent. But as SHERMAN has been nearly a fortnight on the march, and as the rebels have reported no frustration of his plans, no disaster to his army, we may conclude certainly that he is meeting with all possible success. His present march, however, is topographically much more difficult than his Georgia march; and the great caution with which he has moved over the limited space between Savannah and Charleston, has increased largely our confidence in his military genius. If he gives the nation Charleston for its "Valentine" as he gave it Savannah for a "Christmas" gift, the country will be satisfied.

abstract: THOS. J. BROWN, Deputy Surveyor of Customs, for the past 16 years, having resigned, was the recipient, last Saturday evening week, of a purse of $5,000 as a testimonial of respect from the merchants, shippers, members of the bar, &c., the subscription being headed by such names as A.T. STEWART, PAUL SPOFFORD, MOSES TAYLOR, MOSES H. GRINNELL, A.A. LOW, HOWLAND, ASPINWALL, CYDERS, WETMORES, OLIPHANT and many other substantial men. Mr. BROWN resigned to take the superintendency of the Fourth-avenue Railroad. A committee waited upon him at his home, in Thirty-first-street, and Mr. BROWN was presented with the money by Hon. RUFUS F. ANDREWS in a happy speech, and was replied to by Mr. BROWN, after which he invited the committee to a collation, which all did ample justice, wishing Mr. BROWN health, happiness and success in the new enterprise he has entered upon.

abstract: Draper, Prof, on Historical Influence of Natural Causes
snippet: Draper, Prof, on Historical Influence of Natural Causes
lead_paragraph: Prof. JOHN W. DRAPER delivered an instructive lecture on Thursday evening at the rooms of the Historical Society -- the first of a series on "The Historical Influence of Natural Causes." The subject of last evening's address was "The influence of Climate." The lecturer introduced his subject by a comprehensive review of the steady advancement of civilization. He said that everything is influenced by physical agents, and the progress of humanity is guided by immutable laws. The laws of nature, acting under physical influence, hold a dominating control over all living things. HUMBOLDT's essay on plants first drew the attention of the world to the influence of climate over vegetables. The climate regulates the nature of the plants and trees, and if anything should occur to change the climate of the zones, the vegetable life would likewise change. The influence of changes of temperature is seen when we examine plants of the same species in different climates. Instead of offering any resistance to change, the vegetable creation hopelessly yields. The lecturer said the color and form of man oscillates between two extremes, the effect of climate. The one extreme is dark, the other fair, with intermediate grades. The form of the skull also changes. No race will hold its own and experience changes of climate but will descend or advance. That climate does change men is seen in the Jews, who come of a common stock. In northern Europe they are fair, with blue eyes, while in Palestine they are tawney, and in Malaga, almost black.
headline: {'main': 'The Historical Influence of Natural Causes.; LECTURE BY PROF. DRAPER.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'The Historical Influence of Natural Causes.; LECTURE BY PROF. DRAPER.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: The Committee on Wharves, Piers and Slips, of the Board of Aldermen, consisting of Aldermen KELLY, RYERS and NORTON, held an adjourned meeting on Friday to consider the petition of a number of oyster dealers of this city, who transact business on the pier at the foot of Spring-street, and who are afraid of losing their location on the expiration of their lease in May next. On the other hand, a portion of the trade are in favor of removing to Piers Nos. 51,52 and 53, where better accommodation can be obtained, the location at the foot of Spring-street being somewhat limited. The committee informed those present that the Comptroller had the power to dispose of the leases of all wharves, piers and slips at public auction to the highest bidder, and suggested that the proper way would be for the trade to be present and bid on such piers as they desired to have. They stated, however, that they would report to the Board of Aldermen, recommending the reservation of Piers Nos. 51, 52 and 53 for the use of the oyster trade, a fair rental being paid for the same. The committee then adjourned.

They stated, however, that they would report to the Board of Aldermen, recommending the reservation of Piers Nos. 51, 52 and 53 for the use of the oyster trade, a fair rental being paid for the same. The committee then adjourned.

abstract: Camper, John, Notorious Counterfeiter, Arrested
snippet: Camper, John, Notorious Counterfeiter, Arrested
lead_paragraph: On Friday night, Officer RYDER, of the Twentieth Precinct, arrested JOHN CAMPER, of Fifty-fourth-street, near Ninth-avenue, and Marshal GIRVAN, accompanied by Mr. JEFFERSON STOUT, of No. 229 West Fourteenth-street, searched CAMPER's house, and found therein nearly $20,000 in spurious bank-notes and fractional currency, several printing presses, and a quantity of paper, inks, &c,, all of which they seized. CAMPER, who is said to have served twenty-seven years in State Prison, and to have acquired the grammar of several spoken languages while there, is described as one of the most accomplished counterfeiters in the country. His workmanship is really excellent -- so fine that it has yielded him a considerable fortune. The new counterfeits of the fifty-cent fractional currency, which were seized in his house, are very close imitations of the genuine. CAMPER was caught by stratagem. Mr. MARTIN WOLFERT, an acquaintance, introduced Mr. STOUT as a Sutler for a New-Jersey regiment in the field, and STOUT bargained for a quantity of counterfeit money. CAMPER agreed to supply bogus ten-dollar notes on the Mechanics' Bank, of New-Haven, at the rate of $100 for $20; fives on the Northfield Bank, of Vermont, for $3, or in sums of $5,000 at $12 per hundred; and fractional currency at the rate of five spurious for one genuine. STOUT ordered $100 in counterfeit United States currency, $5,000 in fives on the Northfield Bank, and $1,000 in tens on the Mechanics' Bank, of New-Haven, to be delivered on Friday night, in a porter-house in Eighth-avenue, near Fifty-first-street. CAMPER appeared, according to agreement, and was arrested as above, and the counterfeits were found on his person. He was taken before Justice DODGE, yesterday morning, and committed for trial.

abstract: Col. BAKER'S men discovered a large number of spurious certificate of enlistment, yesterday, on board the steamer North Carolina. These they seized, and took to the Astor House, and there they way be examined by any supervisor or other person who may had been cheated by the bounty-brokers.
lead_paragraph: Col. BAKER's men discovered a large number of spurious certificate of enlistment, yesterday, on board the steamer North Carolina. These they seized, and took to the Astor House, and there they way be examined by any supervisor or other person who may had been cheated by the bounty-brokers. Yesterday afternoon, Capt. MCMAHON, Capt. MOONEY's partner, whom the detective officers had been seeking, was found concealed in a house far up town. He was briefly questioned by Col. BAKER, and then sent off to prison. One ISAACS, who combines fashionable millinery with bounty-brokerage, was apprehended for defrauding a recruit of $100. The money having been recovered, Col. BAKER sent ISAACS back to his store, in Canal-street. Other arrests were made yesterday; but to publish the prisoners' names would serve no useful purpose, and might put rogues on their guard.

abstract: Grabow's Reply to King's Speech
snippet: Grabow's Reply to King's Speech
lead_paragraph: The political campaign has fairly opened in Prussia. The President of the Second Chamber, Herr GRABOW, has replied to the King's speech, not by reciprocating his Majesty's expression of desire for a settlement of the dif ferences existing between the Ministers and the Deputies, but by entering into a detailed enumeration of the Government's aggressions on the liberties of the country since the dissolution of the former Diet. He howed that even while the King and VON BISMARK were winning glory in foreign war, the work of oppression at home never ceased. The Liberal press was persecuted; Liberal officials were "disciplined;" the Royal assent was refused to the election of men of Liberal opinions to municipal dignities; Liberal sentiments were placed under a ban; and Liberal citizens were continually abused, insulted and calumniated by the servile journals of the Court. This pointed censure of the Government was received with storms of cheering by the Chamber, and so irritated Ministers that Count ENLENBURG, in the name of his colleagues, reprimanded the President, and told the Deputies that their plaudits could have no effect on the Government. "We stand," said he, "on the rock of right, and shall not let ourselves be forced from our position."

abstract: The heaviest snow-storm of the season commenced this morning, and continued throughout the day without interruption. As the sun went down the storm ceased, with an average depth of two feet of snow upon the ground. In all probability, railway traveling in this section will be interrupted for several days to come, as well as all military movements.
lead_paragraph: WINCHESTER, Tuesday, Feb. 7, 1865.

abstract: Items
snippet: Items
lead_paragraph: -- "Flaneur" writes in the London Morning Star: "The news of the death of Mr. James Wallack -- 'handsome Jim Wallack' -- arrived too late for me to comment upon last week, and has since been almost sufficiently noticed. I think, however, that nearly every commentator has been wrong in one important fact. It was in America, on his first visit, that he broke his leg, and hence his appearance there on crutches. What a noble head he had, and what a rollicking humor! How splendidly he told a story, and how he brought the house down in delight as, with uplifted eyebrows, and a swing of his lame leg, he would exclaim in 'The Brigand,' 'Why, now I look at it again, 'tis more like me than Massaroni!" He was one of the best stage-managers of the day, and he knew thoroughly all stage requirements. He never grasped the higher flights of tragedy, but in melodrama was unrivaled; in what are technically known as 'character parts,' excellent. Mr. Fechter reminds one more of James Wallack than any other actor now on the stage."

abstract: Superintendent's Report
snippet: Superintendent's Report
lead_paragraph: The annual report of the State Superintendent of Education presents many noteworthy features. The amount realized from the school tax reached the sum of $2,663,097, two-thirds of which was raised in the cities. The amount paid for teachers' salaries alone exceeded this sum by over four hundred thousand dollars -- a result, no doubt, due in great part to the advance in the scale of remuneration, rendered necessary by the depreciation of the currency. Thus, while the number of public schools kept open during 1864 was less by seventeen than in 1863, the amount paid for teachers was greater, in the first-named year, by the sum of $367,573.

abstract: American Confederation; Progress of
snippet: American Confederation; Progress of
lead_paragraph: Since the Alien Bill was passed by the Legislature at Quebec, the Crown Ministers have directed their utmost energy to bring their confederation scheme to a vote. The signs are that they will be supported by overwhelming majorities in both Houses. The difficulties of the case will not, however be entirely surmounted when these anticipated results are reached. There is a strong feeling of opposition to federation in the maritime colonies. Prince Edward's Island andNewfoundland will almost certainly reject the scheme. Its acceptance by Nova-Scotia and New-Brunswick is by no means assured, and although such an issue in the Eastern colonies would not prevent Upper and Lower Canada from establishing a federal system of their own, it would leave the separate provinces practically in the same isolated co[???] in which they are now. All the anticipations of forming a powerful maritime State would be at an end. All the fine promises on which the English Government have been lain to rely in the matter of transferring the burdens of colonial defence from the Imperial shoulders, would fall to the ground. A mutually hostile system of tariff would still prevail along all the inter-provincial frontier lines; and the building of the inter-colonial railroad would be indefinitely postponed. All this, and worse, will come of a non-agreement between the maritime provinces and the West. If the present coalition Government is thwarted in the prime object for which it was formed, it is improbable that another can ever be brought together of sufficient strength to carry such a scheme hereafter. Party lines in Canada would be reestablished at once. Sectionalism and sectarian strife would resume their sway, and the old commercial rivalry between the East and the West become ten-fold more bitter than ever.
headline: {'main': 'The Progress of Confederation in Canada.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'The Progress of Confederation in Canada.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: The second annual ball of the Italian Benevolent Society, held at Irving Hall on last Friday evening, was one of the most brilliant and fashionable of the season. The decorations were beautiful, and in excellent taste. On the stage was an arch, bearing the name of the society, on the right of which hung in graceful folds the Stars and Stripes, and on the left the national colors of Italy green, white and red.
lead_paragraph: The second annual ball of the Italian Benevolent Society, held at Irving Hall on last Friday evening, was one of the most brilliant and fashionable of the season. The decorations were beautiful, and in excellent taste. On the stage was an arch, bearing the name of the society, on the right of which hung in graceful folds the Stars and Stripes, and on the left the national colors of Italy -- green, white and red. he stage was also trimmed with wreaths and bouquets, while the gallery was decorated with festoons of flowers, presenting a most pleasing effect. The attendance was large, and was composed of the fairest daughters and most accomplished sons of Italy residing in the city. The toilettes of the ladies were rich and tasty. Music was furnished by Grafulla's Promenade and Dodworth's Orchestra Bands. The arrangements were admirable, and the merry dancers kept time to the sweet music until the early hours of morning.

abstract: THOMAS HEFFERN, of Minnesota, entered a lager-beer saloon at No. 55 Christye-street, and was robbed of his wallet containing $527. He summoned Officer PLACE, of the Tenth Precinct, and while the bystanders were being searched, CHARLES STRAUB pretended o find the wallet on the floor. STRAUB was taken to the Essex Market Police Court, and there committed by Justice SHANDLEY....The same justice committed EDWARD MORRIS for entering Mrs. HANNAH NEWMAN's apartments. No. 23 Eldridge-street, and stealing, it is alleged, $280 in money and jewelry therefrom....ANN RAY and JANE GRAHAM were arrested by Officer LEWIS, of the Tenth Ward, and committed for tendering a counterfeit $2 note on the Clifton Bank, of Canada, to Mr. WILLIAM KORNER, of No. 127 Bowery, in payment for refreshments. Other spurious bills were found in their possession....MATILDA HADDON was committed for stealing $250 in Treasury notes and a watch and breastpin from private EMORY F. PINCKARD, of the Seventieth United States Infantry now stationed at Fort Schuyler.

abstract: A bill has been introduced into the Legislature providing that each gas company in this State shall, on or before Dec. 1 in each year, make and file in the office of the Superintendent of the Insurance Department, a report setting forth the quantity and value of real and personal estate then possessed by the said corporations, the amount of expenditures, and the purposes for which made; the amount of stock of the corporation, and the increase or decrease during the year; the net profits of the business, the amount paid in dividends, the debts, the surplus on hand; the quantity of coal or material for making gas, and the cost thereof; the amount of same purchased during the year; the quantity consumed during same period; the average cost of gas, the quantity of coke, coal tar and other residum sold, and the price charged for same. The report to be verified under oath.

abstract: THE ARION BALL. -- The annual fancy dress ball of the Arion Society took place at the Academy of Music on Thursday last. The attendance was unusually large; so large indeed that the convivality, good will, and jollity hitherto characteristic of these anniversaries were on this occasion impossible. The policy of aiming for an increased attendance each year is a questionable one. It seems to us indeed that the time has already come when the excessive hospitality of the society is likely to work its ruin. After all, the most liberal of hosts must regulate his invitations by the capacity of the building in which he hopes to entertain his guests. To be jolly under difficulties is to be miserable under compulsion. These facts were amply demonstrated on Thursday. The Academy was crowded to suffocation, and we take this opportunity of saying, with a mixed but unusually good attendance. We have never seen so many first-class people at a public entertainment of the kind. The effect, of course, was extremely animated and delightful -- to the eye. Seen from the dancing-floor it was really a suggestion of Paris, and had with it a brighter gaiety in the upper regions than can be found there. But to see is not the sole object of a visitor to a masquerade ball -- and even if it were, the average visitor had but a small chance of gratifying that object. Inconvenience, amounting to absolute annoyance, prevailed from floor to roof. Dancing was out of the question; even the debatable ground of the promenade -- that compromise which the uninitiated rejoice in -- was impossible. Impossible! why, at one period of the evening, even movement was out of the question. It is ungraceful, we know, to quarrel with success, but we may at least object to the way that a particular kind of success has been obtained. A society whose reputation insures a public response to any notice of its intentions, ought, it seems to us, to pay some kind of respect to that public. To sell every ticket that can be sold, with the absolute knowledge that the majority who buy them will never receive their money's worth, is, to speak mildly, not politic. Nor do we derive consolation from the knowledge that, in the end, the society will suffer by such grasping avarice. We do not wish the society to suffer. All that can be expected, in morals or in life, is to put a proper restraint upon excess. We have nothing to say in praise of the Arion Ball, except that it was overcrowed with maskers whose dresses would have done credit to the French opera itself. The wearers were unusually dismal, but they were justified in being so. The inconveniences to which they were subjected were enough to make Rome howl. The accommodations in the hat-room were exasperating to a degree which led to many personal altercations; in the supper-room they were mediocre. During the night several rencontres took place of an utterly disgraceful character. Indeed, a species of fistic skirmishing was going on all the time, rising sometimes into the dignity of a fight, but resulting always in the humiliation of the society. The Academy was not constructed for ball purposes, and its accommodations for any purpose are of the worst. When it comes to a question of providing for six or seven thousand people, it is of course helplessly inadequate. Still, the fault lay with the society, not the house.

abstract: Flushing, L I; Indignation Meeting on
snippet: Flushing, L I; Indignation Meeting on
lead_paragraph: The inhabitants of Flushing, Long Island having become indignant at the mismanagement of the railroad, the filthy condition of the cars, the great want of punctuality in the running of the trains, the wretched and hazardous condition of the road, the withdrawal of the privilege of commutation, the insufficient protection from the inclemency of the weather at the terminus, and the general want of a spirit of accommodation on the part of those who have, or ought to have, its general superintendence, met at the Town Hall a few sights ago and adopted resolutions protesting against the abuses complained of, and urging the directors of the Woodside and Flushing Railroad to hasten the completion of that road, promising, as soon as it is in running order, to give it the preference over the present road. They also resolved, if the directors of the present road do not provide increased accommodations, to present the matter before the Grand Inquest of the county.

abstract: The recent frightful conflagration in Philadelphia ought to warn our authorities of the imminent danger this city is in from the promiscuous storage of petroleum. There is no material in use so inflammable, and, with the exception of powder, none so explosive. A fire originating from petroleum cannot be quenched by water so long as the oil remains unconsumed; in fact, it is asserted, by those who witnessed the conflagration in Philadelphia, that water thrown on the rivers of fire flooding Washington-street, seemed to "add fuel to the flames."

abstract: Senate and House, Arming Slaves Debate; Arming Slaves at the South
snippet: Senate and House, Arming Slaves Debate; Arming Slaves at the South
lead_paragraph: While the President, and the Secretary of State were discussing with the "Southern Commissioners" the question of peace, the "Confederate Senate and House of Representatives at Richmond were debating the grave question of putting arms in the hands of the Southern slaves to aid in accomplishing what has otherwise proved a failure -- the subversion of the national authority by an armed conspiracy of white men. The subject having been simultaneously discussed in the two Houses, we get from the concurrent sentiment of the rebel Representatives something like a fair notion of the progress which the movement has made.

abstract: Philadelphia; Great Loss; Caused by Petroleum; Historical Examples; Historical Examples of Danger of
snippet: Philadelphia; Great Loss; Caused by Petroleum; Historical Examples; Historical Examples of Danger of
lead_paragraph: Deluded and self-deceived people have been [???]ing for the past year about an armistice, as if a suspension of arms was as resultless as a peace party project, or a panacea for all our national difficulties. In a ring-fight, time and a breathing spell is allowed to the combatants to recuperate, and renew and prolong a struggle of its moment to the nation, however interesting to that nation's refuse. The savage, wiser, because natural -- (the soldier as well as the sailor must act instinctively, naturally, as it were) -- concedes no such pauses in the conflict. He knows it is slay or be slain, and so, when his adversary is down, he leaps upon him, kills him, if necessary, or makes him a captive, a spoil, or a prey, enmeshing him in bonds. The fate of the hunter, in the very claws of the cougar, if he refrains from using his revolver or hunting-knife before his strength and courage fails, is exactly the fate of the North, if we make any terms with the South short of the absolute submission of the seceded states. Our fight with them is the struggle of the Templar with the Saracen, truceless and inevitable until the great end is accomplished, the liberation of our own patrimony -- that soil purchased with Northern blood and the whole nation's money -- from the yoke of a military despotism, founded upon a slaveholding oligarchy. The whole South may be styled the patrimony of the North. How few know that Great Britain had almost, if not altogether, reconquered, in September, 1780, what now constitutes the basis of the seceding States. GEORGE III. was ready to offer peace and independence to the Northern Provinces if they would abandon the Southern. They refused; and it was Northern cool valor and Northern indomitable energy, the capture of BURGOYNE, and the revival of confidence at the North, which enabled the South, with Northern aid, under a Northern General, GREENE, first to hold their own, and then, united with the North, to achieve their ultimate liberation. Outsiders, as regards the army, should recollect, before they clamor for an armistice, that countries, causes and commanders have been lost, ruined and compromised by such indiscretions.

abstract: Peruvian Question
snippet: Peruvian Question
lead_paragraph: According to the Correspondencia, of Madrid, Spain means to impose humiliating terms on Peru, or to compel her to fight. "It Peru," says that journal, "has consented to enter into negotiations with Admiral PAREJA, if she fully ratifies all the demands of Spain, is she relinquishes to us, as a guarantee for the payment of our war expenses, the guano of her islands, and if she has accepted all these conditions within the period of one week, then we may hope that the Spanish squadron of the Pacific is on its way home. But if, on the contrary, Peru still defers the payment of her debts, if she still refuses to pay the expenses of Spain, why, even in that case, we may expect that our vessels of the Pacific will return to Europe about the 1st of March -- but not till after having taken as a guarantee the equivalent of all the sums due, -- suck that Peruvian squadron which has been so much vaunted," and "left in the ports of Peru the marks of the indignation of Spain." From this same official statement we may judge of the animus of Spain toward her former dependency.

abstract: Atrocious misrepresentations on Peace Conference; Conference and Rebel Leaders
snippet: Atrocious misrepresentations on Peace Conference; Conference and Rebel Leaders
lead_paragraph: Two distinct things are to be learned from the language with which the rebel leaders follow up the failure of the Peace Conference. First, that their spirit of rebellion is as stubborn as ever; and, second, that they are conscious that popular support would fail them without grossest deception. In other words,that what really took place in the conference did not change their own purpose a jot, but that this reality must be perverted and disavowed in order to keep the people satisfied.

lead_paragraph: CITY NOTES. -- The match game of billiards between MELVIN FOSTER of this city, and JOHN DFERY of Washington, played at Irving Hall on Saturday evening, resulted in favor of the former, who led his opponent at the close of the game 382 points....Col. BAKER'S men discovered a large number of spurious certificates of enlistment, Saturday, on board the steamer North Carolina. These they seized, and took to the Astor House, where they may be examined by any supervisor or other person who may have been cheated by the bounty-brokers....A concert will be given at the Academy of Music, Brooklyn, on to-morrow, for the benefit of the Five Points House of Industry, by the pupils of the institution....The fifth promenade concert of the Twenty-second Regiment, which took place at the armory, on Fourteenth-street, near Sixth-avenue, Saturday evening was a most delightful affair.... A second grand concert, under the direction of Professor J.M.F.V. BUSCH, will be given at Cooper Institute this evening.... A large and select audience assembled at the Academy of Music Saturday evening, to listen to a concert of the pupils of the Primary Department of the Twelfth-street school, under the direction of Mr. G.F. BRISTOW. Nearly two hundred girls, tastefully dressed, occupied the stage, and presented a beautiful appearance. The performance reflected credit upon the instructor, and was frequently applauded.

abstract: War Demonstrations in
snippet: War Demonstrations in
lead_paragraph: We are enabled to give this morning, from the Richmond papers of Saturday, a full report of the speeches delivered at the great war meeting at the rebel capital on the previous day. It was a pendant of the meeting of Monday last, at which JEFFERSO DAVIS was the chief orator. On this occasion also the speakers were the most notable rebel leaders -- the rebel Secretary of State BENJAMIN, the late Peace Commissioner HUNTER, the Speaker of the Virginia House of Delegates, senators GILMER of North Carolina, SEMMES of Louisiana, and HENRY of Tennessee. More instructive reading as to the present condition of the South, the prospect of the rebellion, the state of public opinion, and the object of the late negotiations, could not possibly be found than is contained in these remarkable speeches of high rebel officials.

abstract: Thomas, Samuel Alden
snippet: Thomas, Samuel Alden
lead_paragraph: Our readers may recollect that more than a year and a half since, we published information concerning the death of Sergt. ROBT. M. THOMAS, Fifth New-Jersey Volunteers, who nobly fell whilst engaged with his regiment at the battle of Chancellorsville. At that time the brave boy's father was doing valiant service in the First New-Jersey Cavalry; but, after nearly a score of battles, his naturally robust constitution gave way, and he is now at home lingering in the last stages of consumption. After the death of his elder brother, and discharge of his father, the only remaining member of the family old enough to bear arms, resolved that at least one of the family should be represented in the Union Army. Accordingly, he entered his father's old regiment, and served faithfully for more than a year, setting a good example to many an older soldier. But he was naturally delicate, and finally was stricken down by disease, when he was conveyed to a hospital in Washington, where an affectionate mother watched his bedside until he expired, when she had his remains brought to his home (Jersey City) for interment. Upon some Christian lady expressing sympathy with the bereaved mother in her application, she resignedly remarked: "Dear boy! he died for his country." And thus has passed away the last fighting representative of a patriotic family -- SAMUEL ALDEN THOMAS, aged nineteen years.

abstract: His Peace Mission Cured; Internal Dissensions; Conference; Rebel Object
snippet: His Peace Mission Cured; Internal Dissensions; Conference; Rebel Object
lead_paragraph: The object of the rebel Government in sending Peace Commissioners is now evident. They had no intention of offering terms or of accepting such as we could offer. They made no propositions of any sort, nor did they either assent to or dissent from any made by Mr. LINCOLN. They came simply to find out, distinctly and officially, what our demands were. They were in pursuit of information, and they got all they came for. They found out exactly, from the highest authority, the indispensable conditions of peace. They learned again that submission to the authority of the Government was the sine qua non to all negotiations on the subject.

abstract: The only excitement for the moment in France is the Encyclical letter of the Pope. But even this is rapidly passing from the stage of excitement into that of a bore, and the gamins in the street instead of saying, "Tu m'ennure!" now say, "Tu m'encycliques!" Such a phrase is enough to kill even a more vital question than this, and we may hope soon to hear no more of it.
lead_paragraph: PARIS, Friday, Jan. 27, 1865.

abstract: The past week was an exceedingly prosperous one at the Academy of Musle. We have rarely witnessed a succession of finer houses, or heard more general expressions of satisfaction. It was essentially a week of revivals. Beginning with "H. Trevatore" on Monday last, it ended with "La Traviata" on Friday.
lead_paragraph: The past week was an exceedingly prosperous one at the Academy of Musle. We have rarely witnessed a succession of finer houses, or heard more general expressions of satisfaction. It was essentially a week of revivals. Beginning with "H. Trevatore" on Monday last, it ended with "La Traviata" on Friday. On the other two nights (for the company played but four times) "Norma" and "Faust" were given. These works, we will venture to say, have been heard by every grown and half-grown person in New-York. But there is a country beyond New-York City, and a stream of strangers -- called the floating population, because it keeps the heads of our managers, hotel-keepers and dry goods purveyors above water -- sets in from it. Italian opera is the great treat which our country cousins propose to themselves. The operas of which they have heard the most are those which they prefer and desire. Hence "Il Trovatore"' is a never-falling attraction, and "Norma" and "Lucia" and "Lucieda" are sure to fill the house. Mr. MARETZEK, in fact, is compelled to repeat himself in order that he may satisfy the country as well as the town. He is now about to do something for both. The programme for the present week is unusually interesting; to-night we are to have "Ernani;" to-morrow night "Fra Diavolo," and on Wednesday "Lucia di Lammermoor," in which work Mme. VAN ZANDT will appeal to the public in her second role. This is decidedly a musical event; for the lady's success in "Rigoletto," although not complete, was of a character to justify the brightest anticipations for the future....VARDI's opera "La Folza del Destino" is in active rehearsal, and will be produced in grand style on Monday next. The scenery and dresses are both new, and the cast introduces the best members of the company.

abstract: Both Houses were in session on Saturday. In the Senate, the joint resolution of thanks to MarGen. THOMAS was favorably reported. The Freedman's Bill was made the special order for Monday. Gen. GRANT appeared on the floor of the Senate, and was introduced to the members generally.
lead_paragraph: Both Houses were in session on Saturday. In the Senate, the joint resolution of thanks to MarGen. THOMAS was favorably reported. The Freedman's Bill was made the special order for Monday. Gen. GRANT appeared on the floor of the Senate, and was introduced to the members generally. The creddentials of Mr. CRAGIN, the new Senator from New-Hampshire, were presented and referred. The Appropriation Bill was taken up and an amendment adopted increasing the salaries of the Assistant Secretaries of departments to $3,500 per year. An amendment appropriating $60,000 for the enlargement of the Congressional Library was adopted, and the bill is amended, was then passed. Adjourned.

abstract: Richmond papers of Friday, the 10th inst., admit that the forces of Gen. SHERMAN were dangerously near Branchville, and it is understood that Richmond papers of Saturday contain the definite statement of the capture of that important position. The fall of Branchville involves the evacuation of Charleston as a military necessity on the part of the rebels. The Richmond Whig of Friday mentions a rumor, which then had received no official confirmation, that the Confederate forces had already been withdrawn from that city.

abstract: Although in a pecuniary sense the petroleum interest in this city is greater than in all other localities combined, still among owners of the article there seems to be an indifference approaching almost to recklessness concerning the manner in which the oil shall be stored.
lead_paragraph: Although in a pecuniary sense the petroleum interest in this city is greater than in all other localities combined, still among owners of the article there seems to be an indifference approaching almost to recklessness concerning the manner in which the oil shall be stored. There are more than 40,000 barrels of petroleum publicly exhibited for sale below Fiftieth-street and yet little more precaution is used to provide a[???]t accident than is commonly displayed at marble yards.

abstract: It is generally understood here that the country is indebted, primarily and mainly, to HORACE GREBLEY for the recent peace demonstration. It was at his instance and solicitation that Mr. BLAIR went to Richmond, and set on foot the machinery which made the conference necessary.
lead_paragraph: It is generally understood here that the country is indebted, primarily and mainly, to HORACE GREBLEY for the recent peace demonstration. It was at his instance and solicitation that Mr. BLAIR went to Richmond, and set on foot the machinery which made the conference necessary. It is evident, also, that in consenting to BLAIR's proposals, the rebel authorities consulted their own interests a good deal more than ours. They were becoming very much embarassed by croakers and men clamorous for peace among themselves, and they saw in this movement the means of squelching them. It looks very much as if they had succeeded, at least for the present. It is stated on authority that DAVIS distinctly informed the commissioners that no thought of peace could be entertained, except on the basis of independence. What they said to Gen. GRANT about desiring peace and a return to the Union was evidently a diplomatic dodge; but it succeeded in securing them a meeting with the President.

abstract: End and Result of; Question; Freedmen's Labor, >amp;c.
snippet: End and Result of; Question; Freedmen's Labor, >amp;c.
lead_paragraph: creating a Freedmen's Bureau is now before the Senate -- Mr. ELIOT's bill having passed the House on Wednesday last. We have favored putting the matter in charge of the War Department for the present, or as long as the military power is the supreme and dominant law in the rebel States. It was as military commander that Gen. BANKS instituted the negro-labor system in Louisiana, which has worked so beneficently for both blacks and whites in that locality, while in other parts of the Mississippi Valley, where other systems have been adopted, there has been an appalling amount of suffering among the emancipated blacks. In our issue of yesterday, there were two letters -- one from Winchester, in the Shenandoah Valley, and the other from New-Orleans -- containing statements incidentally made as to the results of the different modes of dealing with the blacks adopted in these widely-separated regions, to which legislators would do well to take heed. Our correspondent at Winchester, (Va.,) wrote:

abstract: PROBABLE MURDER. -- About 2 o'clock yesterday morning a shooting affair occurred in Green-point, which will probably prove fatal. It is alleged that a man named FRANCIS HILL, residing corner of Eagle-street and Union-avenue, had a difficulty with a young German named HENRY JURGEN, in consequence of a confession by the dying wife of the former of an improper intimacy of long standing with the latter. As soon as JURSON found his conduct was known by HILL, he absented himself from his home, and could not be found, although a warrant was issued for his apprehension. Some time after 9 o'clock Saturday night, however, it is said, friends of the absent man called upon HILL and entered into an agreement with him to give a certain sum of money to prevent further proceedings, which he expressed a willingness to accept. A meeting between the two men was then agreed upon, and they met with some friends, at a grocery store at the hour above named, After everything appeared to be amicably settled, HILL suddenly drew a horse-pistol, heavily loaded with shot, and discharged the contents into the head of JURGEN and then beat him over the head with the stock of the weapon. The injured man was conveyed to the City Hospital, where he lies in a senseless condition. He was visited yesterday by Coroner BARRETT, who had HILL committed for the offence. It is further alleged that the assailant, some time since, had his wife taken from her sick bed and removed to Bellevue Hospital, New-York, and that she has since died.
lead_paragraph: PROBABLE MURDER. -- About 2 o'clock yesterday morning a shooting affair occurred in Green-point, which will probably prove fatal. It is alleged that a man named FRANCIS HILL, residing corner of Eagle-street and Union-avenue, had a difficulty with a young German named HENRY JURGEN, in consequence of a confession by the dying wife of the former of an improper intimacy of long standing with the latter. As soon as JURSON found his conduct was known by HILL, he absented himself from his home, and could not be found, although a warrant was issued for his apprehension. Some time after 9 o'clock Saturday night, however, it is said, friends of the absent man called upon HILL and entered into an agreement with him to give a certain sum of money to prevent further proceedings, which he expressed a willingness to accept. A meeting between the two men was then agreed upon, and they met with some friends, at a grocery store at the hour above named, After everything appeared to be amicably settled, HILL suddenly drew a horse-pistol, heavily loaded with shot, and discharged the contents into the head of JURGEN and then beat him over the head with the stock of the weapon. The injured man was conveyed to the City Hospital, where he lies in a senseless condition. He was visited yesterday by Coroner BARRETT, who had HILL committed for the offence. It is further alleged that the assailant, some time since, had his wife taken from her sick bed and removed to Bellevue Hospital, New-York, and that she has since died.
