abstract: Exchange of Prisoners; on; Gen Grant on
snippet: Exchange of Prisoners; on; Gen Grant on
lead_paragraph: We expressed our conviction a few days since, when it was authentically annnounced that the matter of exchange had been put into the hands of Lieut.-Gen. GRANT, that this most intricate question, which the efforts of years had failed to solve, would soon find a a practicable solution. Certainly no more gratifying official news has reached the public for many days, than that conveyed in the testimony given by Gen. GRANT in Washington on Saturday, as to the prospects of an immediate general exchange.

abstract: ACADEMY OF MUSIC. The indisposition of Milo. ZUCCHI compelled Mr. MARETZEK to change the opera last evening. Instead of "Ernani," which was announced, the acceptable substitute of "Faust" was given. The house was very good, and the pleasure of those who were in it seemed to be undisturbed. It is unnecessary to speak of the performance. To-night " Fra Diavolo" will be given for the last time.
lead_paragraph: ACADEMY OF MUSIC. -- The indisposition of Milo. ZUCCHI compelled Mr. MARETZEK to change the opera last evening. Instead of "Ernani," which was announced, the acceptable substitute of "Faust" was given. The house was very good, and the pleasure of those who were in it seemed to be undisturbed. It is unnecessary to speak of the performance. To-night " Fra Diavolo" will be given for the last time.

abstract: From information received through a high official source, it may be safely announced that the draft, which was to have taken place to-morrow, will probably be postponed. The reasons for the change in the governmental programme are such as have been recently developed, and have no reference to the original plan for filling the ranks of depleted regiments, or the President's proclamation for a draft.
lead_paragraph: From information received through a high official source, it may be safely announced that the draft, which was to have taken place to-morrow, will probably be postponed. The reasons for the change in the governmental programme are such as have been recently developed, and have no reference to the original plan for filling the ranks of depleted regiments, or the President's proclamation for a draft. It has been determined to postpone the draft solely on the ground of expediency. The disposition so recently expressed by our Supervisors to meet the exigencies of the Government by offering extraordinary inducements to enlist, has convinced the authorities at Washington that the quota of this county will be filled, if the present arrangements are permitted to continue, sooner than the number of men required of the city could be raised by draft. It has also been argued that the time which would be required of Provost-Marshals to carry into effect the draft, if employed in active efforts to recruit, would result in securing the men necessary to fill our quota. Unwillingly many of our citizens, most anxious to assist the Government in filling the ranks of our armies, have been indirectly the means or encouraging a spirit of dissatisfaction among a class of people ignorant of the law. This has been specially the case in the disposition manifested, sometimes even in official circles, respecting the correctness of our enrollment lists. It would be difficult to find a man, however loyal, who has not his doubts that more men are required of New-York than of any other city of the Union, in proportion to its population. This arises more from a disposition to find fault than from a knowledge of the facts. It is possible the new enrollment lists now being prepared by Supervisor BLUNT may tend to reduce our quota considerably, but this will be done only because of the new enrollment and not in consequence of imperfections in the old lists. That class of people who engage in riots delight to have some excuse, however poor, to disturb the quiet of the city by resisting the law, and the statement that our quota is oppressive and unfair is quite sufficient for them to base an argument in favor of the "rights of the individual." It should be remembered but seventy-five per cent. of the present call for troops will be required of this city under the President's proclamation, and that the remaining twenty-five per cent. will be held in reserve to provide for the loss of men from sickness in hospitals, fraudulent enlistments, desertions, &c.

abstract: Tremaine, Lieut-Col; Killed in Battle
snippet: Tremaine, Lieut-Col; Killed in Battle
lead_paragraph: Among the killed at the battle of Hatcher's Run, last week, was FREDERICK L. TREMAINE, eldest son of Hon. LYMAN TREMAINE, of Albany, aud at the time of his death Lieut.-Col. of the Tenth New-York Cavalry. He was born in Greene County, in this State, in June, 1843, His character as a boy was distinguished by those qualities of generosity, firmness and courage, that marked him as a man, and endeared him to all who knew him. After careful preparation at the school of Dr. REED, at Geneva, in the Fall of 1860 he entered Hobart College, with the highest hopes and the highest prospects. There he remained until the Summer of 1862, when, unable longer to resist the promptings of patriotism, he was made Adjutant of the Seventh Regiment of New-York Heavy Artillery. He accompanied the regiment to Washington, where, much to his regret, it was detailed for the defences of that city. Although constantly engaged in his duties as Adjutant, and in the acquisition of military knowledge, Col. TREMAINE was ever eager for active service in the field. At last, in September, 1863, he was appointed by the President Assistant Adjutant-General, with the rank of Captain, with orders to report to Gen. DAVIES, of the cavalry, of the Potomac army. He was assigned to the staff of that officer, then commanding a brigade in KILPATRICK's division. He was transferred to the staff of the First Brigade, Second Division, then under the command of Col. TAYLOR, after, and now by Gen. DAVIES. He remained on this staff, distinguished himself by his bravery in many engagements, by the courtesy of his manner, and the prompt and intelligent discharge of every duty until December last, when he was commissioned as Lieutenant-Colonel of the Tenth New-York Cavalry. He ever won the affectionate regard, as he always secured the respect of his superior officers, and the warm friendship of his companions in arms.

abstract: BROOKLYN COMMON COUNCIL. At a meeting of the board last evening, the committee on renaming and renumbering streets, reported on the necessity of the measure under consideration.
lead_paragraph: BROOKLYN COMMON COUNCIL. -- At a meeting of the board last evening, the committee on renaming and renumbering streets, reported on the necessity of the measure under consideration. They state that there are as many as three streets bearing the same name, and in many of the streets the numbers commence in two places. A resolution was appended authorizing the committee to prepare an ordinance, subject to the approval of the board, by which streets and avenues requiring renaming shall be determined, and the numbers of houses and lots designated so as to conform to a general plan. A surveyor is also to be appointed to survey the streets and make maps. The resolution was adopted by a vote of 13 ayes to 7 nays.

abstract: Infatuation of the South; Disasters and Infatuation
snippet: Infatuation of the South; Disasters and Infatuation
lead_paragraph: Was there ever such infatuation as that which now possesses the South? Did any people, on the face of the earth, ever show such an utter lack of reason and of self-respect? In the other years of the war, they could be admired for much; and with all their errors, we were not ashamed to claim them as our fellow-countrymen. It was a crime in them to lend themselves to the treason of their leaders; but nobody can deny that once having committed themselves to this bad cause, they have fought for it with a gallantry seldom exceeded in human history. Nor have we, heretofore, been able to charge them with the folly of struggling for the impossible. There were, at the commencement of the war, large chances that it would end in Southern triumph and independence. Even the most sagacious men could reckon with much confidence on foreign intervention in favor of the South; or on a North so divided that President LINCOLN's administration would be paralyzed, and be succeeded by another which would take peace from the South at any price. There was during the first three years of the war no time in which the patriot had not reason to tremble for the final result; and no time in which the rebels could not reasonably look forward with at least some degree of hope. But the period in which it was possible for the higher qualities of manhood to serve the rebellion has passed. It now lives only through the absurd and contemptible.
headline: {'main': 'The Present Fatuity of the South.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'The Present Fatuity of the South.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: Relief for; Relief for
snippet: Relief for; Relief for
lead_paragraph: There are several applications pending in Congress from contractors, for relief from the ruinous consequences of fulfilling the engagements into which they have entered with the Government. The enormous amount of contracts and, the certainty that many such applications will be made, if any of them are favorably entertained, induces many persons to oppose them indiscriminately. If the door is once opened, it is said, to such claims, there will be no end to them, and the Treasury will be drained in the attempt to satisfy the demands that will be made upon it. The country cannot afford, it is urged, to enter upon such a work, and the only thing for Congress to do, therefore, is to refuse all applications of the kind, and hold every contractor to the strict performance of his engagements with the Government. If they had made money by their contracts, they would never have refunded it. Why should they be reimbursed in case they lose?

abstract: Bounty-brokers' Frauds; Col Baker's Investigations
snippet: Bounty-brokers' Frauds; Col Baker's Investigations
lead_paragraph: Our readers will be pleased to know that Col. BAKER remains in the city, and does not propose to return to Washington until he has thoroughly exposed, shown up and broken down the infernal system of bounty swindling, which seems to have entered into the very heart of the service, affecting not only the men who make rascality a trade, but also our most respected and reputable citizens. The developments already before the public are enough to disgust our honest people, but we are pained to assure them that as yet they know comparatively nothing of the extent to which the frauds have succeeded. Thus far but few names of note have figured in the list of rascals detected by the shrewd management of Col. BAKER, but a discerning public has doubtless ere this concluded that bounty-brokers, bounty-jumpers, recruit-runners and professional rogues could not alone compass so great a villainy. The cooperation of officials, the sanction of men in power, and the connivance of those whose duty is the detection of crime, rather than its shielding, was needed, and we are convinced by the most tangible demonstration that nothing of the sort has failed the villains in their hour of need. The scenes at Col. BAKER's rooms, yesterday, were most exciting; were it not so mortifying an exhibition of the worst side of human nature, they would have been amusing. All day long Supervisors from interior counties of this and other States jostled against the scallywags who swindled them, and with tearful eyes watched the unfolding of the villainous schemes by which they had been defrauded of men, money and time; all day long fiercely moustached individuals, with diamond pins and jeweled hands, hung nervously about the Colonel's apartments waiting their turn for examination; Captains in the regular and volunteer services obeyed the beck and call of the "Special Agent;" Provost-Marshals, divested for the nonce of pomp and power, excused their little irregularities or meekly submitted to the "parole to city limits," which was the alternative to the "old Capitol" -while ever and anon a subordinate would come in with his head full of new points and his pockets full of forged papers. One of the most interesting cases was the following, which in its developments exhibits a well-known city Provost-Marshal in a light at once unpleasant and disgraceful: It seems that some months ago a fine stalwart young Englishman named M, came to this city from Liverpool with the intention of entering the army. He had served his time in the regular British service, and brought with him official testimonials and certificates as to good conduct and general efficiency, which he thought would aid him in securing a commission in our service. After weeks of unsuccessful endeavor, he made up his mind to enlist as a volunteer and take his chance for promotion. In pursuit of this he fell into the hands of a bounty brokerage firm, in this city, who took him at once to the office of the Provost-Marshal above-mentioned, an officer of prominence, politically and socially, and presented him as a recruit. The Provost-Marshal examined and passed him, made out the necessary papers, and desired him to sign them. M. perceived by the wording of the papers that he was placed as a substitute, and to this he objected, saying he didn't care "to sell himself; he wished to enter the service as a volunteer." The Marshal told him it was" all right; it was only a matter of form, and something which all recruits were obliged to sign." This satisfied the man, who signed the papers, took his $400, put on his uniform, and was sent to the rendezvous at Governor's Island. The Provost-Marshal being fold of filthy lucre, posted at once to the store of a merchant in Beaver street, who a day or two previous had requested him to find a substitute for him. The merchant listened with pleasure to the glowing account of M.'sphysique, and jumped at the chance of securing him for the moderate sum of $900. The bargain was arranged, and on the following day the merchant called on the Marshal with nine $100 bills, for which he obtained a receipt and the necessary exemption papers. Of this $900 the recruit had already received $400, and was, of course, entitled to the remaining $500. Of course he didn't get it. A few days thereafter he was in the city, and, meeting the Provost-Marshal, asked him for whom he was a substitute. The Marshal thoughtlessly told him: the two met, and the recruit found he had been cheated out of $300, while the merchant concluded he had been badly sold. The matter was brought to the attention of Gen. HAYES, who at first noticed it, but, for some reason, subsequently rebuffed the friend who attempted to arrange it for M.M. then called on the Marshal, but received not only no satisfaction, but was disgraced and returned to the Island. There the matter dropped until Col. BAKER came. The friend called on him, and told the story. He sent for the merchant and the soldier, got all the affidavits necessary to prove the case, and then sent for the Provost-Marshal. At first this officer was disposed to stand on his dignity and all that sort of thing, but facts and papers soon convinced him that it was easier to cheat a poor soldier than to confront the "Special Agent" He denied having received the money, but his own signature condemned him; he then said it was all given to the brokers, This they denied, and their books corroborated their assertion. At last, it turned out that he had kept $200, his clerk had kept $100, and the two brokers had received the other $200. When the gallant Captain saw that he was found out, and that there was literally no escape for him, he did the best thing he could, and said nothing. He was then permitted to return to his work, which will probably be under his control but temporarily, however. The brokers who also were brought before Col. BAKER are held for other charges, of which, however, we can say nothing to-day.

abstract: Journal publishes a long list of rebel prisoners who have died at Camp Douglas near that city. It says; There are not far from 12,000 prisoners how confined at Camp Douglas, though the recent order for exchange, together with frequent cases where the oath of allegiance is administered, it rapidly decreasing that number. Among those held as prisoners there are representatives of every rebel State and every arm of the rebel service. Every Western battle field is represented there, from Fort Donelson to Franklin and Nashville. The prisoners are for the most part fat and hearty. They are well fed, well clothed, and have a sufficiency of fuel. Hospital accommodations are ample and perfect. Deceased prisoners are burled in the city cemetry, where every grave is marked, while a record is kept of each interment, so that relatives can, without difficulty, find and remove the remains.

abstract: In the Senate, yesterday, after a number of petitions for various objects had been presented, the bill to establish a steamship line between the United States and China was taken up and passed. The report of the Conference Committee on the Freedman's Bureau Bill was then received, but no action was taken on the bill, its consideration being postponed to give way for Mr. SHERMAN's motion to take up the House joint resolution, reducing the duty on imported paper. A motion to postpone the subject indefinitely was defeated, and the amendment to make the duty 15 per cent., instead of 3 per cent., was passed. The question was then taken on the final passage of the resolution as amended, and it was decided in the affirmative.

abstract: His History and Opinions; History and Opinions
snippet: His History and Opinions; History and Opinions
lead_paragraph: Mr. H.S. FOOTE, late member of the rebel Congress, and who came through our lines in the Shenandoah Valley, left on Saturday in the City of Cork for Liverpool. He was sent here under guard from Gen. SHERIDAN'S command, to report to Major-Gen. DIX, and was most of the time during his sojourn in this city the guest of Col. WM. H. LUDLOW, of Gen. DIX'S Staff. It is understood that the alternative was presented by our authorities to Mr. FOOTE of returning to Richmond, or of going abroad, and he chose the latter. Mr. FOOTE represents the "Confederacy" to be on the eye of disruption, and that the struggle on the part of the rebels is nearly over. High military authority in Richmond admits that the capture of Branchville must compel the evacuation of Charleston, Wilmington, and even of Richmond itself. Desperate battles would probably be fought before this latter evacuation takes place; but if GRANT and SHERMAN were successful in them, LEE, with his army, would fall back to Lynchburgh, and there endeavor to make a stand. His army, however, would in such case become demoralized, could not be held together, and could not be supplied.

abstract: Memminger's Deficiency of $400,000,000
snippet: Memminger's Deficiency of $400,000,000
lead_paragraph: -- The rebel authorities have lately made an unpleasant discovery. They have just found out that Mr. MEMMINGER, when going out of the Treasury Department, neglected to mention to his successor a little debt of four hundred millions which he happened to have on hand. The Government has been going on ever since in blissful ignorance of the existence of such a debt; but they happened a few days since to stumble over it by accident, and they didn't like it. Their Congress has been holding secret sessions on the subject, but they have not succeded, up to the latest dates, either in blotting it out or in providing for its payment. The probability is that it will have to swell the sum total which JEFF. DAVIS bye-and-bye will repudiate. His early exploits in that line will fade into insignificance beside the gigantic achievements of his later years.

abstract: A correspondent of the Philadelphia Press, writing from Eastport, Miss., under date of Feb. 3, says: "Last night a large number of transports arrived. The whole number here now is about twenty-five or thirty. The troops are already embarking; grain is being shipped, and wagons and mules taken on board. Everything indicates a general move of THOMAS' whole army. It is supposed he is going down the Mississippi.
lead_paragraph: A correspondent of the Philadelphia Press, writing from Eastport, Miss., under date of Feb. 3, says: "Last night a large number of transports arrived. The whole number here now is about twenty-five or thirty. The troops are already embarking; grain is being shipped, and wagons and mules taken on board. Everything indicates a general move of THOMAS' whole army. It is supposed he is going down the Mississippi. This is the only way the army could possibly make a move (we mean on boats,) for the roads are in the worst possible condition. The weather, for the past two weeks, has been very disagreeable and unfavorable for the army. First we had snow to the depth of two inches, then rain on that, storming for days together. At one time, and that when it was very cold weather, the troops had nothing in the way of bread but corn. This they boiled and parched, and had nothing else for a week. Their hard tack finally arrived, and they are now living very well. The health of the army is regarded as very good. The extreme right of the army is at this point: the left wing at or near Florence. HOOD, at last accounts, was moving south. His men were deserting by hundreds.

abstract: Hicks, T H, Ex-Governor and United States Senator
snippet: Hicks, T H, Ex-Governor and United States Senator
lead_paragraph: Hon. THOS. HOLLIDAY HICKS, United States Senator from Maryland, and Ex-Governor of that State, died yesterday, at Washington. He was born in Dorchester County, Maryland, and passed his boyhood in his native place. He evinced great force of character in his early days, and took a special interest in politics. While still young he was elected Mayor of the county seat, and soon after was sent to the State Legislature, where his talents and character soon won for him a distinguished name. In 1857 he contested the Governorship with Gov. GROOME, of Cecil County, and was elected by a handsome majority. He held office during the exciting events attending the secession movement, and but for his unyielding firmness and loyalty his State would probably have been dragged into the vortex of treason.

abstract: leaving us almost as much in the dark about SHERMAN's campaign through South Carolina, as formerly they did in the case of his march through Georgia. Perhaps they are not to be much blamed for this, as they seem to find it very hard to learn anything themselves about SHERMAN's purpose, or his line of march, or the point he is aiming at, or any other point. One of his two great columns is evidently near the coast, not far from Charleston; the other has already got beyond Branchville, and seems to be striking for Columbia, the capital of the State, and located in its geographical centre; while still other bodies of troops are discovered here, there and manywheres. But does he actually mean to take Charleston? Does he really purpose capturing Columbia? These are truly solemn questions, and cannot at this moment be answered by us any more than by the rebels.

abstract: Fractional Currency, ingenious Counterfeit
snippet: Fractional Currency, ingenious Counterfeit
lead_paragraph: An interesting case was brought before the Commissioner yesterday. It appears that some weeks ago some workmen, who were engaged in removing the ruins of a building in Fulton-street, destroyed last Summer by fire, discovered some copper-plates of the United States postal currency, of the denomination of 25 cents. At first they seemed fac-similes of the genuine, but closer inspection showed that at the bottom of the plates, separated a little from them, was an additional line, containing the words: "Postal Currency Liniment;" and on the plates for the back of the notes the line: "None genuine unless signed." These extra lines were so situated that when the notes were struck off the additions could be cut off, leaving the note the exact size of the genuine, and an excellent counterfeit of the twenty-five cent postal currency notes. The matter was placed in the hands of Government detectives to work up, and they found that a portion of the burned premises had been occupied by an engraver. The engraver being found, made a statement to the effect that some time last Spring a man had called on him and given him an order to engrave these plates, claiming that he wished to use the impressions as labels for a newly-invented nostrum to be called the Postal Currency Liniment. The engraver being a highly respectable party and perfectly innocent, application was made to the commissioner for the arrest of the man who employed him, and who evidently intended by this ingenious method to obtain the plates for a good counterfeit on the Postal Currency. The commissioner, however, held that under the act of Congress he could not issue a warrant in a case where the party had never had the counterfeit plates in his possession or issued any of the spurious currency.

abstract: THE PAID FIRE DEPARTMENT. -- The Board of Representatives of the Eastern District Fire Department about a week ago held a meeting to consult upon the merits of the paid system, and authorized its members to obtain the names of those who were opposed to the measure. At a meeting held on Monday evening it was found that the names of only 150 remonstrants were obtained. Considerable discussion ensued, during which it was noticed that more anxiety was displayed in regard to the disposition of the Charity Fund, now about $21,000, than anything else. Much diversity of opinion exists among the members with regard to the movement, but the leading members of the board express a decided preference for the original bill introduced by Senator LAIMBEER than for its substitute, and they claim that two-thirds of the members are of the same opinion.

At a meeting held on Monday evening it was found that the names of only 150 remonstrants were obtained. Considerable discussion ensued, during which it was noticed that more anxiety was displayed in regard to the disposition of the Charity Fund, now about $21,000, than anything else. Much diversity of opinion exists among the members with regard to the movement, but the leading members of the board express a decided preference for the original bill introduced by Senator LAIMBEER than for its substitute, and they claim that two-thirds of the members are of the same opinion.

abstract: Cotton Fleet for New-York
snippet: Cotton Fleet for New-York
lead_paragraph: The United States gunboat Flag and steam cutter Wyandah, which started from Port Royal on the 8th inst., to convoy the fleet having on board the cotton captured at Savannah by Gen. SHERMAN, arrived here this morning. The entire fleet went ahead out of sight on the night of the 8th, except the bark Savannah, which dropped behind. They were last seen on the 10th inst. off Hatteras. The following is a correct list of the fleet: Bark Savannah, schooners Lottie, Kirk, Minerva, Marshal Perrin, Henry Hobart, Neptune's Bride, L.B. Cowperthwaite, Gifford, Aid, Helene, W.B. Thomas, Nautilus, C.P. Williams, L.S. Davis, Mary Stedman, John Freeman, E.R. Bennett, Ann & Susan, Lovett Peacock, N.W. Smith, P. Boice. The gunboat Flag parted company with the fleet off Charleston on the night of the 8th.

abstract: In the Senate, yesterday, Mr. WILSON of Massachusetts reported from the Military Committee a joint resolution recommending the appointment of honorably discharged soldiers and sailors to remunerative positions under Government, in preference to other persons. It was ordered to be printed. A resolution was adopted to in-...
lead_paragraph: In the Senate, yesterday, Mr. WILSON of Massachusetts reported from the Military Committee a joint resolution recommending the appointment of honorably discharged soldiers and sailors to remunerative positions under Government, in preference to other persons. It was ordered to be printed. A resolution was adopted to inquire what increase of the army ration is necessary for the comfort of the soldier and the good of the service. A resolution was adopted calling upon the President for a report of the Court of Inquiry upon the subject of the explosion of the Petersburgh mine. The vote granting authority for the construction of a bridge across the Ohio at Louisville was reconsidered, and Mr. COWAN moved to amend by striking out "two hundred and forty feet span," and inserting "three hundred feet span." This was disagreed to. The bill was passed as it stood originally. The bill to regulate commerce between the several States was then taken up, and after some discussion was postponed till Thursday. The Senate then adjourned, to meet in the evening for Executive business.

abstract: Would end the Rebellion with 100,000 more men
snippet: Would end the Rebellion with 100,000 more men
lead_paragraph: Lieut.-Gen. GRANT, in his recent visit to Washington, did not hesitate to say publicly that if a hundred thousand more men were given him, he would, within three months, wipe out all that is left of the rebellion. Our highest military authority thus confirms what was already believed not only by the Administration, but by all civilians best acquainted with the actual condition of the South. This fact ought now to take its place in the public mind as something settled.

abstract: and Abraham Lincoln Contrasted; Dignity aad patience of, and Davis' vulgarity
snippet: and Abraham Lincoln Contrasted; Dignity aad patience of, and Davis' vulgarity
lead_paragraph: The contrast between JEFFERSON DAVIS' speeches and his written papers is so great that we cannot help feeling astonished that his admirers -- for we presume even he has them -- do not prevent his appearing on the platform as often as he does. His State papers, as a general thing, have been very creditable productions -- clear, terse, pointed and admirably adapted to produce the intended effect. They have all been marked by an air of dignity, self-restraint and moderation, which, as they have mainly been written for the European public, even when nominally addressed to bodies or individuals in the Confederacy have been just what was wanted to win confidence and respect for their author. The speeches, however, are mostly delivered for home use, and in them the real man shows himself; the real, thoroughbred Mississippian is seen in every sentence, without any of the gloss of civilization. He is exceedingly boastful, of course, and full of promise; disposes of whole Federal armies with a few phrases; sketches out great campaigns with a confidence worthy of NAPOLEON, and not a little comical in the mouth of a warrior whose short term of active service was passed as a Colonel of militia. He inflicts (on the stump) the most disastrous defeats on Union Generals; sends SHERMAN and GRANT reeling like drunken men hither and thither over the continent, and is always able to tell his audience all but exactly what will be the military situation three months afterward. We don't believe he will again resort to this species of rhetoric, tempting though it be, after the recent terrible falsifications of his predictions.

abstract: Beall John Y, Lake Pirate; Trial and Sentence
snippet: Beall John Y, Lake Pirate; Trial and Sentence
lead_paragraph: A few days since we mentioned the arrest at Suspension Bridge, by Chief Detective YOUNG, of the police, of JOHN Y. BEALL, the leader of the piratical crew who, in September last, seized the unarmed passenger steamers Philo Parsons and Island Queen, on Lake Erie, and in December following attempted to inaugurate a system of guerrilla warfare on the norther border of the State of New-York. We mentioned, also, that the prisoner had been sent to Fort Lafayette, for the purpose of being tried before a court-martial for the high crimes laid to his charge. It now appears from the following general orders which were promulgated yesterday by Gen. DIX, from Headquarters of the Department of the East, that BEALL has been found guilty of violating the laws of war and acting as a spy, and has been condemned to death by hanging, at Governor's Island, on Saturday next. The sentence will be carried into execution unless the President shall interpose a reprieve.

abstract: The news from Gen. SHERMAN, though coming exclusively through rebel channels, is highly encouraging, and shows that he is making as rapid progress in his present advance as in his Georgia campaign. The Richmond papers of Monday an-...
lead_paragraph: The news from Gen. SHERMAN, though coming exclusively through rebel channels, is highly encouraging, and shows that he is making as rapid progress in his present advance as in his Georgia campaign. The Richmond papers of Monday announce that his army had crossed the Edisto River, which was the line held by Gen. HARDEE, at last accounts, and which defended Branchville. The Richmond papers had previously admitted that if SHERMAN accomplished this, their troops must necessarily evacuate Branchville, which is undoubtedly in our possession by this time. The papers of the 13th also assert that a portion of SHERMAN's forces, probably his cavalry, are two thirds of the way from the Edisto to Columbia, an important point forming the junction of the Charlotte and South Carolina and the Greenville and Columbia Railroads, which connect with the railroads to Richmond. A large number of our prisoners, mostly officers, were confined at Columbia.

abstract: The Edisto River rises in the southwestern portion of South Carolina, and flowing southwestwardly, empties into the Atlantic forty miles southwest of Charleston. Branchville is on the Augusta branch of the South Carolina Railroad, a mile east of the point at which the railroad crosses the Edisto. This river is now the line held by Gen. HARDEE, in the neighborhood of Branchville. Nearer the coast, we hold the line of the Combahee River, in the vicinity of the Charleston and Savannah Railroad.

abstract: CITY NOTES. -- The payments at the New-York Post-office on money orders sent from various parts of the country average $1,500 per day. Arrangements will soon be made for the establishment of a money-order office at City Point, Va., for the accommodation of our soldiers....Mr. P.T. BARNUM will deliver his celebrated lecture on "The Art of Money Getting," in Prof. MATTISON's Church, in Forty-first-street, this evening, at 8 o'clock....Mr. JAMES L. STEARNS will deliver a lecture this evening, at the rooms of the Young Men's Christian Association, No. 161 Fifth-avenue. Subject, "Sir Samuel Romilly....The annual celebration of WASHINGTON's birthday by the pupils of the Cooper Union, will take place at the hall of the Union on the 20th inst., at 8 P.M....The first of a series of addresses instituted by the Union League Councils, was delivered before the Eleventh Ward Union League on Thursday evening last, by DEXTER A. HAWKINS, Esq. The addresses are all on national subjects and promise to be attractive....The Union General Committee are making arrangements for the delivery before them of an oration, by a distinguished speaker, on the Constitutional Amendment prohibiting slavery. The time and place will be announced hereafter....Mr. CHARLES L. WHITING, manager of the Western Union Line of telegraph, was presented yesterday by the operators of the line with a magnificent quarto Photographic Album, gold mounted and suitably inscribed, containing the likenesses of his late associates, and a letter expressive of their appreciation of his many gentlemanly qualities. Mr. WHITING retires from his position as manager of the New-York office of the Western Union Line, to assume a responsible position in another business in the city of Buffalo.

abstract: Muller's, Max, Lectures on Language; Perpetual Curate, The; Lange's, J P, Gospel according to Matthew
snippet: Muller's, Max, Lectures on Language; Perpetual Curate, The; Lange's, J P, Gospel according to Matthew
lead_paragraph: The authors of the Perpetual Curate, Mrs. OLYPHANT and Mrs. GASKELL, are almost the last of the old classical school of novelists who continue the traditions of the days of Miss EDGEWORTH and Miss AUSTIN. Mrs. OLYPHANT's novels, in particular, are remarkable for their careful painting of English rural life, and the skill that composes an interesting story out of the ordinary incidents of ever-day existence. She appears to have made a minute study of the clerical profession, and to be perfectly at home in the various relations of the pastor and his flock, as displayed in the humble walks of dissent, or in the more assuming precincts of the National Church establishment. The prominence given to clergymen in late English novels is a remarkable proof how strongly the clerical character exercises an influence in every branch of society, from the lordly Bishops and Deans that ANTHONY TROLLOPE has made us all familiar with, to the independent minister of the "Little Bethel" Chapel, badgered to death by the leading butcher or baker of his congregation, such as we find portrayed in the "Chronicles of Carlingford." All who delight in a healthy novel, when the interest is legitimately created by the play of character brought out by a natural succession of events, instead of startling incidents by fire or flood, will follow with attention and sympathy the fortunes of the bachelor "Perpetual Curate" until he exchanges that title for a charming wife and a benefice of his own. The three maiden aunts who exercise an important influence on the story, are fine specimens of portraiture, elaborated with the skill of a practiced artist. The whole work, indeed, will add to Mrs. OLYPHANT's well-earned reputation.

abstract: In the Senate to-day Mr. SCOVEL offered a resolution and advocated it, as also did Mr. BUCKLEY, requesting the Committee on Federal Relations to report on Wednesday their action on the Constitutional Amendment against slavery. Mr. HOLEMAN resigned his position on the Committee on Federal Relations, and it was accepted.

abstract: a State Capital not Proper for; Supervisor's Gift of Courthouse
snippet: a State Capital not Proper for; Supervisor's Gift of Courthouse
lead_paragraph: Our Board of Supervisors means to keep up its reputation for liberality. Their donation of $50,000 to Mr. BLUNT "for saving the City from the draft" seems to have acted like an inspiration, They are now inclined to take still higher flights, and have unanimously voted to make the State a present of the New Court-House, when completed, for the purposes of a State Capitol! This is magnificent. "These be imperial acts, and worthy thee!" No Emperor or "King barbaric" could scatter gifts with a more royal recklessness or a more lavish hand. And why should they not? Of all branches and departments of our local government, the Board of Supervisors is the only one that is utterly irresponsible. It has nothing to fear from the popular judgment, for it does not depend in the least on popular favor. By a happy device of political ingenuity, that candidate whom the people reject stands just as well as his rival whom the people elect. The majority candidate is elected, -- the minority candidate is appointed, to be Supervisor. All that is required is to secure the party nomination: accession to office follows as a matter of course.

abstract: MYSTERIOUS ROBBERY. -- Mr. JOSEPH COLTON, a resident of Waterbury, Conn., appeared at police headquarters in Jersey City, yesterday forenoon, and stated that he had been robbed the night before of a wallet containing $95 in bills, and a carpet-bag and bundle containing clothing. He stated that he spent the fore part, of the night with a friend in New-York, during which they imbibed two or three times, after which he went over to Jersey City for the purpose of taking the midnight train for Washington. He did not recollect what happened after arriving on the Jersey City side, but thinks he fell into the hands of some of the sharpers that infest the public houses in the vicinity of the depot. At a late hour in the night Mr. COLTON was found wandering in the streets, minus his money, carpet-bag and bundle, and there is little probability that he will ever set eves on it again. It wont do to mix Jersey lightning with benzine.

abstract: Proposes to Settle with Lee this Summer
snippet: Proposes to Settle with Lee this Summer
lead_paragraph: The various Live Stock markets have received only a very limited supply of animals this week, especially of beef cattle; those reported a week ago at Buffalo and Suspension Bridge have failed to arrive for this market, but are yet back, having made but little progress. Most of the bullocks on hand were from the Eastern and New-England States, only about 500 being reported from the West, and these have been nearly four weeks on the way. The scarcity of animals this week is caused by the cold and snow almost putting a stop to railroad transportation. Great numbers of animals are detained all along the railroad between Dunkirk and Buffalo. Wholly on account of this short supply prices of beef cattle have reached a height never known before in this city. These high prices are only for this market, however, as under favorable circumstances an ample supply must reach this place for the next market. Prices of Beeves run from 18c.@28c. lb., fully 2c. lb., net weight, higher than last week. The receipts of Sheep are also very light, and those in market sold at 12c.@15c. lb. -- an advance of about 1 3/4c. lb. The demand for Milch Cows is very light, and prices remain about the same. Veal Calves sell at 11c.@15c. lb., -- about 1c. lb. above the rates a week ago. The arrivals of Live Hogs are not in sufficient numbers to supply the demand, at an advance of 1/4c. lb. live weight.

abstract: Brooklyn; Judge Garrison's Office Robbed of $9,000
snippet: Brooklyn; Judge Garrison's Office Robbed of $9,000
lead_paragraph: LARGE ROBBERY OF KlNGS COUNTY BONDS. -- The law office of Ex-Judge SAMUEL GARRISON, No. 22 Court-street, Brooklyn, was entered on Monday afternoon, and robbed of Kings County Bonds and Certificates, in all valued at $9,000. The Judge and his partner, THOS. PEARSALL, Esq., had been in and out of the office several times, and the door meantime was left unlocked. At one period the office was closed for about half an hour. The Judge came in about 6 P.M. to get his valuable papers for the purpose of taking them to his house and found them gone. The key had been left in the safe where his document were deposited, and it was an easy matter for any one so inclined to take any thing he wanted. The bonds stolen are described as follows: Kings County Bonds (three) Nos. 646, 647, 648, each for $1,000; coupons attached, dated Aug. 1, 1864, 6 per cent. These bonds are payable to bearer and can therefore be disposed of without difficulty. Kings County Treasurer's certificate dated June 29, 1864. No. 158, for $6,000, 7 per cent. This note is payable to SAMUEL GARRISON, but is not payable before the County Treasurer has prepared the necessary plates, which are not yet ready. It will therefore be useless to the thief. Information of the theft was given to the police yesterday morning, but as yet no clue of the thief has been obtained.

abstract: Duty of Recruiting; Firing the Southern Heart
snippet: Duty of Recruiting; Firing the Southern Heart
lead_paragraph: The view expressed in these columns from the beginning, that the peace negotiations were devices of DAVIS to strengthen his position with the disaffected in the confederacy, are fully confirmed by events. We doubted the expediency of such individual missions as BLAIR'S, and anticipated their natural results. They commit the Government at least to the appearance of negotiation with the Confederate authorities, they weaken the probability of separate State action, and give DAVIS material for "firing the Southern heart." He is able now to say to the whole Southern people that he had made the most humane and Christian efforts for peace, but that all were ignominiously rejected, and that nothing is left but fighting to the last. And this "firing the Southern heart" is a thing by no means to be laughed at, as we learned in 1861. The Southern masses are ignorant, and capable of being deceived to an unlimited degree. They are now doubtless fully instructed by their leaders that LINCOLN will hear to nothing but the absolute spoliation, banishment or death of every rebel. They will hear that war with all its horrors cannot bring them more damage and loss than peace would; that they will be, after fighting is over, the servants of slaves, and their wives and daughters given up to the lusts of a brutal soldiery, and their children exposed to every insult and injury.
headline: {'main': 'Firing the Southern Heart."', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'Firing the Southern Heart."', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: County Clerk's Office, Reorganization of
snippet: County Clerk's Office, Reorganization of
lead_paragraph: The complaints made as to the management of the County Clerk's office during the past three or four years have been both loud and frequent. Those who have had business to transact with the department have experienced delays and obstacles which showed plainly enough that the County Clerk's office stood sadly in need of a managing head. All this, however, has been entirely changed since the commencement of the present year, when Mr. WILLIAM C. CONNER entered upon the duties of his office. Mr. CONNER, being a man of business and accustomed to the control of a large establishment, saw the necessity of reform, and, assisted by his cashier, Capt. JOSEPH H. TOONE, instituted radical changes in the administration of the affairs of the department, important alike to the public and to those employed in the office. It was found that many of the books were in arrears, the records of lispendens being three years behind, and other records for even a longer period. Mr. CONNER at once employed, at his own expense, three clerks and an extra messenger, to write up the books in arrears, much to the satisfaction of those who found it necessary to consult them. The whole of the offices were repainted and thoroughly cleaned. The basement in which papers had been allowed to accumulate for years in most admired disorder was emptied of its contents. Valuable papers were there found which were fast passing into a state of decay. These were cleaned, copied if necessary, and filed away under the superintendence of Mr. WILLIAM WILKS, and the same gentleman was placed in charge of a Repository Department where all the old writs, executions and documents dating as far back as 1750, are kept in a systematic manner. Among the new regulations introduced by Mr. CONNER are the following:

abstract: Chris. Lorrey and Others vs. Omar Kingsley and Others. -- This is a suit against Mr. Kingsley, the former equestrienne, Ella Zoyara, but who has now assumed male attire, to recover salaries of members of the Stokes Circus Company. The defence is that Mr. Stokes was the sole proprietor and hirer of the troupe, and that Mr. Kingsley was not liable as a partner or otherwise. The jury rendered a verdict for the plaintiffs for $1,550.

abstract: The conscription which was appointed to take place to-morrow, will doubtless be postponed, in accordance with the promise of Gen. FRY, that he would defer the craft if the Provost-Marshals of each district were kept busily engaged in mustering men into the service. Gen. HINKS has as yet received no orders to enforce the draft, and, in the meantime, the work of recruiting goes briskly on. The County Volunteer Committee have about as much work as they can attend to, the increase of bounties and hand-money having stimulated recruiting wonderfully. Nearly 100 men per day have been enlisted during the last two days, there being an increase in favor of yesterday; and the inquiries in regard to the amount of bounties, time and manner of payment, &c., keep the committee and their clerks busily employed.

abstract: Little can be added at present to the statements which we have published concerning the arrests that Col. BAKER'S detective officer have recently made among the bounty-brokers. Further arrests...
lead_paragraph: Little can be added at present to the statements which we have published concerning the arrests that Col. BAKER'S detective officer have recently made among the bounty-brokers. Further arrests were made yesterday; but in the Colonel's absence his subordinates do not feel at liberty to disclose names; and the public must, therefore, wait patiently until the detective officers think it prudent to make a complete revelation. This time may not come until the accused are brought to trial. We have, however, the gratifying assurance that there is to be no unnecessary delay in arraigning the prisoners, it being Col. BAKER's desire to finish his work at the earliest period possible; and with this view he has gone to Washington to make arrangements for the speedy assembling of a court-martial for the trial of the persons whom he has sent to the Old Capitol prison.

abstract: The People vs. Bernard Friary. -- The court was engaged all day yesterday in endeavors to obtain a jury in this case. The proceedings are necessarily tedious, as the qualifications of each juror have to be tried by the court and the sworn tryers; so far it has been shown that only one out of one hundred is the average obtained from the new panel drawn especially for this case. Friary appears to be much paler and thinner than when he was first brought into court, and looks uneasy. At 5:30 o'clock a full panel had been obtained, and the court adjourned until this morning.

abstract: The closing exercises of the Fifth Ward Evening school, which took place at the North Moore-street School-house last evening, were witnessed by a large number of the parents and friends of the scholars, and the exhibition of attainments by the pupils reflected great credit on their teachers, Mr. THOMAS W. CONKLIN, of the Male Department, and Misses MARGARET C. CONNEL and ELIZABETH B. DENTON, of the female department. Mr. FRANCIS R. TILLOU presided, and the varied programme was given with complete satisfaction to all. Among the more noticable declamations was "Horatti Curatti," by Master SMITH, which was received with much applause; also solo, "Beautiful Dreamer," by Master CHARLES HILL, which was very finely rendered, and fully merited the hearty appreciation manifested by the audience. In speaking of these selections there is no desire to be invidious, for the entire exercises, from the commencement to the close, gave evidence of a high order of talent on the part of the scholars and the careful cultivation bestowed by their teachers. The term, which closed with last evening's exhibition, commenced on the 18th of October, and the whole number taught during the season was -- males, 684; females, 456. Of these the former received 104 diplomas, the latter 102. School Commissioners JAMES DUPIGNAC and JAMES M. TUTHILL were present, and expressed their delight at the progress attained by the scholars and the happy manner in which the entertainment was given.

abstract: Astoria; U S Laboratory, at $50,000
snippet: Astoria; U S Laboratory, at $50,000
lead_paragraph: The United States Army Laboratory, located at Astoria, L.I., was consumed by fire on Monday morning last. The fire commenced about 9 A.M., in the ceiling over the drying-room, and so rapidly did the flames spread, that all efforts to stay their progress were of no avail. The medicines furnished by this Laboratory are for the army. The premises are leased for seven years, commencing on the 12th of February, 1864. The dwelling apartments of J.H. BILL, Assistant Surgeon United States Army and Director, connected with the Laboratory, were consumed. From the first alarm no time was lost in getting a stream on with apparatus attached to the engine of the establishment. The employes worked faithfully to save the various articles, and by their efforts much that was explosive was removed. To the engineer, Mr. GEO. VERITZAN, great praise is due for his precaution in opening the valves of the engine, thereby preventing the bursting of the two large boilers.
headline: {'main': 'Burning of the United States Laboratory at Astoria Loss $60,000 Large Quality of Drugs Destroyed.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'Burning of the United States Laboratory at Astoria Loss $60,000 Large Quality of Drugs Destroyed.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

lead_paragraph: In the Senate, yesterday, a petition was presented praving that the Constitution be so amended that justices and judges might be appointed and not elected. A bill was reported extending the time for the completion of the Adirondack Railroad. Notice was given of a bill to prohibit the erection of public nuisances in New-York. Among the bills passed was one amending the charter of Syracuse; also incorporating the New-York Yacht Club. Mr. BELL offered a resolution approving of the terms of peace offered by the President in the late conference, which was laid over.

lead_paragraph: CITY NOTES. -- The Savannah cotton fleet has not arrived, though the steamers that should have convoyed the fleet are here....Miss SUSANNAH EVANS will deliver a lecture on temperance, this evening, at the Free Will Baptist Church, in Twenty-eighth-street, near Broadway....The annual celebration of the birthday of WASHINGTON, by the pupils of the Cooper Union, will take place at the hall of the Union on Monday evening.... A meeting of loyal Georgians will take place to-night, at 7 1/2 o'clock, at Cooper Institute.... The Annual Coterie of Company K, Thirty-seventh Regiment, takes place at the Everett Rooms, Tuesday evening, Feb. 21.... The Twenty-fourth Anniversary of Mercantile Lodge, No. 47, I.O.O.F., will be celebrated by a ball, at the City Assembly Rooms, this evening.... The Liederkranz masquerade ball takes place at the Academy of Music to-night.... Professor DRAPEE lectures on "The Effects of Emigration" at the hall of the Historical Society to-night.... F.E. ENGLEHARDT will deliver a lecture on petroleum this evening at St. Francis Xavier's College in Sixteenth-street, near Fifth-avenue.... The Senate Investigating Committee will resume its sessions at 10 o'clock this morning.

abstract: The Board of Managers of this excellent institution appeal to the public for assistance. They say: "Our various expenses during the year ending May 1, 1864, amounted to $7,651 42; while the whole amount received by annual subscription was $1,088 75; from parents of children for their board, $859 84, and from interest on investments, $442 81. These were all our reliable income; while over $5,000 in donations must be obtained by laborious efforts on our part. What we desire now to accomplish is, to secure a list of subscribers of $10, $25, $50 or upward, upon whom we may annually call, with the certainty of receiving at least the amount subscribed -- an amount trifling to a man of wealth, but important to a poor institution like our own."

abstract: The news of Gen. SHERMAN'S Successful progress continues to reach us through rebel sources, and though not full, either in fact or in detail, it is evident that no impediment has yet been or is likely to be thrown in his path that will seriously obstruct his march.
lead_paragraph: The news of Gen. SHERMAN's successful progress continues to reach us through rebel sources, and though not full, either in fact or in detail, it is evident that no impediment has yet been or is likely to be thrown in his path that will seriously obstruct his march. The operations of the right wing, of which we have not heard much lately, are becoming of vital importance in view of its near approach to the city of Charleston. The rebels announce that on the 9th a strong force of Union troops was landed at Grimball's Plantation, on the Stone River, James Island, within two miles of the city of Charleston. Another force had gone up Edisto Inlet, and reached the main land, with the evident design of connecting with the maiu body of the right wing which was advancing toward Charleston along the line of the Savannah railroad. This column had crossed the Salkehatchie, driven the rebels from a strong line of works, and advanced as far as Blue House, a station on the railroad less than thirty miles from Charleston. The progress of the left wing under Gen. SLOCUM, in the interior of the State, is likewise rapid and successful. On the 8th inst. his forces crossed the Edisto River about twenty miles west of Branchville, pushed on and struck the railroad to Columbia at Orangeburgh, sixteen miles northwest of Branchville, which puts the entire system of railroads in the State completely in SHERMAN's possession, isolates Branchville, and compels its evacuation without the necessity of occupying it.

abstract: Trouble between
snippet: Trouble between
lead_paragraph: Advices from San Salvador state that as soon as the arrival of Gen. BARRIOS at Costa Rica became known, the President of San Salvador issued a decree declaring that all relations between the two Republics were at an end. No persons coming from Costa Rica will be allowed to enter the ports, or cross the frontier of San Salvador without submitting to a thorough examination. Any citizen of the latter Republic who is caught communicating in any way with BARRIOS or his agents, will be sentenced to six months' imprisonment at hard labor; if a foreigner, he will be at once exiled from the Republic.

abstract: ACADEMY OF MUSIC. -- "Lucia di Lammermoor" was given here last evening, with Mme.VAN ZANDT in the part of the heroine. The lady's voice is fresh and delightful. It possesses more body and strength than can be found in any other American prima-donna's voice. It is, however, an inexperienced organ, and except in cavatinas that have become familiar and facile, is inadequate to the labor of sustaining an important role. Mme.VAN ZANDT needs practice on the stage, and, with this, will, we doubt not, arrive at a brilliant future. Her Lucia, however, is more immature than her Gilda, in which character it will be remembered she made her debut. The performance was cold, unimpassioned and amateurish.

abstract: A serious accident occurred at an early hour yesterday morning on the New-York and New-Haven Railroad, near Westport, about two miles beyond Norwalk. Three passenger cars were thrown from the track by the breaking of a defective rail, and hurled together on one side in a heap of ruin. One car was flung over a stone fence, and turning a complete somerset, came down on its roof. Strange to say no person in the train was killed, and only one, a soldier, was so seriously injured as to be unable to come on to this city by the next train. The name of this unfortunate passenger is JAMES DONOVAN. He was removed to a hotel in Norwalk, where he lies in a very critical condition. His injuries are mostly internal. He belongs to the Second Massachusetts Cavalry.

abstract: South Carolina Great Campaign
snippet: South Carolina Great Campaign
lead_paragraph: Now that every merchant, mechanic and clerk in the city, every farmer and laborer in the country, every bull and bear in Wallstreet, and indeed every intelligent man and woman who reads a newspaper, is a military strategist, we advise them all to procure a correct and minute map of the State of South Carolina, and carefully trace out and study out the superb and altogether artistic movements of Gen. SHERMAN, of the two main columns, and the minor movable bodies into which his army is now divided. It is true there is nothing to guide us but the rebel newspapers; and though they tell us as little as they can, and not near as much as we would like, yet we are enabled, by the places they mention as being visited by the Union troops, to form an idea of the great features of this great campaign.

abstract: The steamship North American, from Liverpool on the 2d, via Greencastle on the 3d, arrived at Portland yesterday, with four days later news. The intelligence of the fall of Fort Fisher depressed the rebel sympathizers in England very much, and elated the friends of the North. The rebel loan suffered another decline, and American securities again advanced. The brokers reported an active and excited market for American securities. Cotton was flat and depressed, in consequence of the continued Federal successes. News of the conditional cession of Sonora to France, as payment of the French war debt, had reached England from Mexico. Minister ADAMS had a long interview with Earl RUSSELL on the 28th ult., and the fact attracted comment. The stormy weather continued around the English coast, and had caused many additional wrecks. No American vessels are among the number.

abstract: On Saturday evening next, a public meeting will be held at Cooper Institute, in aid of the Patriot Orphan Home, when the claims of the Institution on the public will be presented by several eloquent speakers. The Home has been organized but a short time, yet it has now more than one hundred children within its walls, whose parents have been either killed or permanently disabled in the service of their country during the present war. The Institution has been the means of saving many orphans from starvation, and others from a life destitute of the blessed influences of education and religion. The Home is under the care of a number of ladies of this city, whose names are a sufficient guarantee that the object with which they are associated is worthy of the sympathy and support of the public. Associated with these ladies is a Board of Counsellors, consisting of the Rev. Stephen H. Tyng, Drs. Griscom, Willard Parker, C.R. Agnem, and James Warren, with many other prominent gentlemen. Mrs. Wm. Topping is the President of the Home; Mrs. C.L. Monell, Vice-President; Mrs. H. Zabriskie, Recording Secretary; Mrs. Edward Fitch and G.W. Huntsman, Corresponding Secretaries; and Mrs. Wm.J. Haddock, Treasurer.

abstract: Petroleum History and Statistics
snippet: Petroleum History and Statistics
lead_paragraph: The historian hereafter of this great struggle will record with wonder how nature herself seemed to try to heal the fearful waste and loss of the war, so that the most profitable natural discoveries of the century occurred between 1860 and 1865. While pouring out our means in the costly effort for upholding liberty and law on this continent forever, the mountains and the oil wells have opened their treasures to restore the national wealth.

abstract: In the Senate yesterday, the Committee on Cities and Towns made a majority report in favor of a paid Fire Department in New-York. Senators SHAFER and SMITH dissented from the report. The Metropolitan Health Bill was reported, and also bills to fix the compenastion of members of the New-York Common Council, and to prevent animals from running at large in cities, Notice was given of a ...
lead_paragraph: In the Senate yesterday, the Committee on Cities and Towns made a majority report in favor of a paid Fire Department in New-York. Senators SHAFER and SMITH dissented from the report. The Metropolitan Health Bill was reported, and also bills to fix the compenastion of members of the New-York Common Council, and to prevent animals from running at large in cities, Notice was given of a bill to increase the tax on salt, and to authorize certain horse-railroad companies to increase their fares. A bill was introduced providing for the review of Supreme Court decisions in the Court of Appeals. A resolution was offered by Mr. FIELDS, and finally passed, asking of the Comptroller of the City of New-York a statement of the accounts of the several District Attorney's since 1845. The Assembly resolution for a recess from the 17th to the 23d inst. was passed.

abstract: Mill, John Stuart, Dissertations, >amp;c.
snippet: Mill, John Stuart, Dissertations, >amp;c.
lead_paragraph: The name of the publisher of these handsome volumes is new to us. If they are the commencement of his literary enterprises, we can sincerely congratulate him on a first start that would do credit to our oldest and most experienced houses. The mechanical execution of the work is perfect, its form convenient, and its contents more ample than those of tho English edition, the cooperation of the author, with whose "express sanction and approval" it is issued, enabling the publishers to offer it as a complete collection of Mr. MILL's miscellaneous writings to the present time.

abstract: In the Senate, yesterday, Mr. JOHNSON, of Maryland, announced the death of Senator Hicks, and concluded his remarks by offering the customary resolutions of respect, which were adopted and sent to the House. Eulogies on the deceased were also delivered by Mr. WILLEY, of West Virginia, and Mr. HALE, of New-Hampshire.
lead_paragraph: In the Senate, yesterday, Mr. JOHNSON, of Maryland, announced the death of Senator HICKS, and concluded his remarks by offering the customary resolutions of respect, which were adopted and sent to the House. Eulogies on the deceased were also delivered by Mr. WILLEY, of West Virginia, and Mr. HALE, of New-Hampshire. At 2 o'clock the body of the diseased was brought into the Senate Chamber, and after the funeral services of the Masonic Order had been performed, Rev. Dr. NADAL delivered an eloquent discourse on the character of the deceased. President LINCOLN, several members of the Cabinet, and many other distinguished gentlemen were present. At 3:30 o'clock the body of the deceased Senator was conveyed to the Congressional Cemetery. On the return of the Senators to the Chamber, the Senate adjourned.

abstract: Hop Culture; Agricultural Report
snippet: Hop Culture; Agricultural Report
lead_paragraph: A large portion of the Monthly Report issued by the Agricultural Department at Washington, is devoted to the question of the best means of cultivating the hop plant; and, yet, there is no agricultural production which so little invites the notice of the American practical agriculturist. There is no product of our soil so entirely capricious in its character. Fifteen years ago the price of hops here varied from twenty to sixty cents a pound. The price last year was almost half a dollar. Yet, within the period intervening, the price has been marked as low as from four to ten cents.

abstract: Postal System Broken Down
snippet: Postal System Broken Down
lead_paragraph: -Some idea of the broken and dislocated condition of the Southern Confederacy may be obtained from a news item in the Richmond Whig of the 13th inst., which says: "Our latest exchanges from the South embrace the following dates: Columbia, 7th; Charleston, 4th; Augusta, 5th; Macon, 2d; Columbus, 1st; Atlanta, 1st; Montgomery, 31st ult; Selma, 29th; Mobile, 28th." "The Confederate postal system, (adds the Whig) is a great institution -- worthy of the days of Noah."

abstract: Semi-annual Exhibition
snippet: Semi-annual Exhibition
lead_paragraph: The students of Columbia College held their semi-annual yesterday, at 11 A.M., at Wallack's Theatre. The large and brilliant audience which usually attends all the public exercises of this time-honored institution of learning was not wanting upon this occasion. Upon the stage we noticed among other distinguished gentlemen, President BARNARD, of Columbia College, and Professors PECK, JOY, NAIRNE and SCHMIDT. The music, under direction of Mr. HELMSMULLER, was, as usual, faultless. After a prayer by President BARNARD, Mr. CHARLES KING GRACIE, the presiding officer, delivered an interesting address, in which was convincingly set forth the great and good results to grow from the establishment of the School of Mines of Columbia College. Mr. JAMES M. BRADY followed in an oration on "Liberty," which he treated in a masterly manner, his reward being a shower of bouquets and a tumult of applause. He was followed by Mr. GEO. L. RIVES, on the "Island of the Scots." Next in order, Mr. HENRY A. BARCLAY delivered, in a very able manner, a poem entitled "Farewell to Earth." which elicited the hearty applause of the audience. These pieces were then delivered, as follows: "King Rampsinitus," by Mr. H. CRAIG, F. RANDOLPH; "Pausanias," by Mr. JAMES M. BRUCE; "About Four Years Ago," by Mr. WM. E. SMALLEY; "The Ages," by Mr. JULIAN JAMES, and "The Era of Progress." by Mr. WM. B. WALKER. Mr. H.R. BEEKMAN, the representative of the Philolexian Society, then delivered an oration eulogizing that association. But, by all means, the speech of the day, both as to composition and delivery, was delivered by Mr. RANDOLPH B. MARTINE. The exercises closed with a benediction.

abstract: Scarcely a day passes that an accident, resulting in the loss of life or limb, does not occur on the city railroads. Only a few of these casualties come under the cognizance of the police, and not a tithe of them find their way into the public journals; but a fearful record might be made of those who are suffering from broken bones and crushed limbs, These accidents are especially common during the Winter season, when the iron steps of the cars are slippery, and are attributable in part to overcrowding, and in part to the carelessness of passengers in getting on and off the platforms while the vehicles are in motion. Granting that railroad companies always will be rapacious, and that citizens always will be careless, the practical question presents itself of finding a remedy. We are supposed to be an inventive people, yet, through all the years that our city railroads have been in operation, no person so far as we remember, has offered a suggestion for preventing these far too common accidents, which often result in death, or else leave the victim to go maimed and crippled through life. It certainly must be an easy matter to provide against these casualties. Cannot they be effectually avoided by placing a screen or guard along the sides af the cars, completely shielding the ponderous wheels, and reaching so close to the ground as to make it impossible for a body, or even a limb, to slip under the vehicle? Even should a person be run down and fall before the wheels, this curtain or shield might be so constructed as to act like the cow-catcher of a locomotive, throwing the obstruction from the track, not, perhaps, escaping bruises, but obviating broken bones. One of these railroad accidents has been brought painfully to the notice of the writer during the past few days, in the case of a noble lad, the only son of his parents, who was crowded off the front platform of a car in University-place, and, slipping under the wheels, suffered such injury that his right leg had to be amputated. The suggestion we have made is a practical one, and it can be put in operation at a very trifling cost. Which of our railroad companies will snow that its officers are humanitarians by trying the experiment?

abstract: Yesterday the schooners Lota and Neptune's Bride, of the Savannah cotton fleet, arrived at this port. Capt. STILLMAN KENT of the Lota, reports that the fleet were dispersed by the gale of the 12th inst; and that, for severity, he has never witnessed one to equal it in his whole seafaring experience on the Atlantic coast, of 25 years. The Lota lost her jibboom, mainboom, all the topsails and gearing. She was towed to the Atlantic Duck, Brooklyn, where she will unload her cargo, consisting of 425 bales of cotton.

abstract: State Capital; Mayor Gunther's Advice
snippet: State Capital; Mayor Gunther's Advice
lead_paragraph: -- Mayor GUNTHER recommends the Common Council to offer the State the Battery, the Park, Union-square, the Central Park, or any other little tract of territory that may induce the Legislature to remove the Capital to this city. The offer of the New Court-house does not seem to be sufficient. It is not likely to cost over five or six millions, and that is thought to be quite too small a sum to tempt our State law-makers to the metropolis.

abstract: Letter to Gov of Vermont on Drafts; Lincoln, President; Views on Quotas; Letter to Governor of Vermont
snippet: Letter to Gov of Vermont on Drafts; Lincoln, President; Views on Quotas; Letter to Governor of Vermont
lead_paragraph: In common with nearly all the other States, Rhode Island has been making complaints at Washington of the assignment of her quota to the draft. A committee from the Legislature went to the capital to remonstrate, and try to have the State quota reduced, and the time for the draft extended. They made their report on Tuesday last. They say that they had an interview with the President, who told them, after stating their case, that so many complaints had reached him from various quarters of the assignment of quotes, that he had personally taken the pains to examine the formula adopted by the Provost-Marshal-General for the calculation and distribution of the quotas for the several States, had arrived at the conclusion that no candid mind could doubt its fairness and equity. The President also gave them a copy of the following letter on the same subject, which he had written to Gov. SMITH of Vermont:

abstract: Question; The, at Savannah
snippet: Question; The, at Savannah
lead_paragraph: A brief letter from Savannah, in another column, makes some interesting and important suggestions concerning, the policy which is pursued at Savannah in regard to the cotton found there upon the entrance of our army. Gen. SHERMAN, at the outset, gave orders that an exact account should be kept of all the cotton there -- that a description of each lot should be recorded, and the marks upon it preserved, in order that full facilities might be given to private loyal owners to reclaim it if they could show a title which our Government could recognize. But a different policy seems to have been afterward adopted, and now the whole is seized for the Government, -- no receipts are given to private owners, the private marks are effaced, and all facilities for subsequently testing its ownership are refused.
headline: {'main': 'The Cotton Question.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'The Cotton Question.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: Official dispatches from Gen. SHERMAN were received in Washington yesterday, and though announcing the successful inauguration of the South Carolina campaign, they do not contain news so late as that received through the Richmond papers, which report that on the 11th inst. a column of SHERMAN'S infantry and cavalry crossed the Edisto to the west of and above Branchville, and advanced on the Columbia Branch Railroad.
lead_paragraph: Official dispatches from Gen. SHERMAN were received in Washington yesterday, and though announcing the successful inauguration of the South Carolina campaign, they do not contain news so late as that received through the Richmond papers, which report that on the 11th inst. a column of SHERMAN's infantry and cavalry crossed the Edisto to the west of and above Branchville, and advanced on the Columbia Branch Railroad. The rebels at Branchville withdrew toward Columbia. According to the last official accounts our troops were at Orangeburgh, some twenty miles north of Branchville, and on the road to Columbia. BEAUREGARD was in command, and it was thought he would fall back to the Santee, and attempt to defend that line. HARDEE is in command at Charleston, and claims to have repulsed the advance of our troops on the Salkehatchie.

lead_paragraph: The Quebec Mercury gives currency to the following: -- "The rumor still prevails in military circles here and westward, that five regiments, which are ordered home from India, are to be sent out to Canada on the opening of the navigation. It is also believed that the regiments now stationed in British North America are to be increased to twelve hundred strong each, and to be placed on a war footing. A letter from England by the last mails mentions that arrangements were then being made for the the transport of three full regiments of cavalry to Canada in the Spring. It is thought that the Crystal Palace at Toronto will be shortly occupied as a barracks by troops of the line. There is some talk also of the Forty-seventh being relieved at Hamilton and sent westward."

abstract: Fire Department Question
snippet: Fire Department Question
lead_paragraph: The Board of the City Fire Department held a meeting on Tuesday evening, to protest against the movement now in progress at Albany for the abolition of the existing organization, and the substitution of a small paid department. The speakers were very energetic in their defence of the present system, and declared it to be their intention to contest the passage of the bill now before the Legislature to the last. What strikes us as singular about all this is, that the firemen should be so dreadfully reluctant to go out, when nobody wants them. They are all volunteers, the services they render to the public are of a very trying and arduous nature, and they receive no compensation. The sole basis of their organization is in fact the desire of the public for their assistance. They have no divine right to extinguish fires any more than anybody else. Those who live in houses and are liable to be burnt up, are the only persons who have the right to decide what should be the nature of the measures taken for their protection. It is neither very dignified nor very civil, therefore, for the Fire Department to persist in forcing their good offices on people who have, as distinctly as good manners and gratitude for past favors will permit, signified their desire to be rid of them.
headline: {'main': 'The Fire Department Question.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'The Fire Department Question.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: Cotton; Government and Rebel Action About
snippet: Cotton; Government and Rebel Action About
lead_paragraph: The steamship Europa arrived at Halifax, yesterday, from Liverpool on the 4th and Queenstown on the 5th, bringing one day's later news. GOLDWIN SMITH argues a peace in America through the separate action of the rebel States. The alarm of the rebels in England at the continued misfortunes of their cause, was increasing, and their organ was uttering sensational stories about war with England and France in case the rebellion failed. The trial of RUMBLE, for obtaining enlistments for the rebel steamer Rappahannock, had resulted in his acquittal. The news received from America on the 4th, per steamship China, indicating a continued war in the United States, imparted a decided improvement to the cotton market, and rather unfavorably affected United States Securities. The rebel loan is reported unchanged. VICTOR EMANUEL had paid a visit to Florence, where he was enthusiastically received.
