abstract: and Rebel Raiders
snippet: and Rebel Raiders
lead_paragraph: -- The rebel raiders in Canada are endeavoring to prove to the satisfaction of the Canadian courts that they acted under regular Confederate authority in their demonstrations upon St. Albans and other towns in Vermont. They have produced their commissions, issued in due form by C.C. CLAY, who was in Canada last Summer as a regularly authorized Confederate agent, appointed for the special purpose of directing military movements upon the Northern frontier. As will be seen by the report in another column, bands of men were organized and directed to burn St. Albans and other towns in Vermont, and on this around the courts of Canada are asked to discharge the prisoners.

lead_paragraph: The committee appointed by the State Senate to investigate the workings of the City Departments, reassembled at No. 75 Duane-street, yesterday morning. The examination of the City Inspectors Department was postponed until Monday morning, Mr. GRAHAM, counsel for Mr. BOOLE, having an engagement at court. This morning the Comptroller's Department will be taken up. Mr. MCKEON will appear for the citizens, and conduct the investigation.

abstract: At the opening of the court, this morning, the District-Attorney stated that the witness Connell, who was very sick, had been sent to the New-York Hospital in accordance with a suggestion from the court, but they had refused to receive him on the ground that the District-Attorney had once had them fined for heaping snow and ice on the sidewalk. He supposed it must have been the Corporation Attorney that they meant, and was glad to bear that he had enforced the law. However, he would suggest to the Governors of the hospital that they get a new Superintendent. The first witness called was Christopher Richards whose examination began on Wednesday. He testified:

abstract: Carolina Campaign; Union Troops at
snippet: Carolina Campaign; Union Troops at
lead_paragraph: The news from the South indicates that the army of Gen. SHERMAN, which is marching through the central part of South Carolina, is meeting with nothing but success. It is quite a week since he reached Orangeburgh, and as the capital of the State is but two days' march from that point, it was doubtless entered the early part of this week. It is now clear that SHERMAN's line of conquest is to be across Middle South Carolina, demolishing the Confederate power in the State as he proceeds, and then continuing his advance. It was reported yesterday that his cavalry had reached Florence, some eighty miles northeast of Orangeburgh, and not far from the North Carolina line. If he should at once hold Columbia and Florence, HARDEE's army at Charleston, as well as the city itself, would be in a predicament, and HARDEE would certainly have to take to the swamps. He could not go southward, for we hold the railroad; nor northward, for the same reason; and the only other, railroad, that easterly to Florence, would also be useless to him. So that, beside the army and navy menacing Charleston in front, it and the Confederate forces are in imminent danger otherwise.
headline: {'main': 'The Carolina Campaign New Combinations in Progress.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'The Carolina Campaign New Combinations in Progress.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: In the Senate, yesterday, the report of Gen. HERRON on the condition of the Department of Arkansas was received. A bill was passed to authorize the settlement of claims of the American Colonization Society for the support of recaptured Africans in Liberia. A bill was passed extending the boundaries of the port of entry and delivery of Philadelphia. A bill was introduced and referred to the Military Committee to increase the efficiency of the staff of the army. The Naval Appropriation Bill was taken up, and all the amendments of the Finance Committee, affecting appropriations, were concurred in. An amendment to postpone the time for the restoration of the Naval Academy was voted down. An amendment was adopted appropriating $100,000 for additions and improvements to the Naval Asylum at Philadelphia. An amendment creating a Board of Admiralty was proposed. Pending the discussion of this question, the Senate adjourned.

abstract: The, Rhode Island, Tribune, Evening Post, Gen. Fry; Tribune Hard On
snippet: The, Rhode Island, Tribune, Evening Post, Gen. Fry; Tribune Hard On
lead_paragraph: and mystery in which the matter of the draft has been enveloped is dispelled by a report, which we publish in another column, from a committee of the Rhode Island Legislature. Like nearly all the other States, Rhode Island felt aggrieved at the large quota assigned to them, and sent a committee to Washington to remonstrate. They urged that as their State had always kept ahead of the calls made upon them, it seemed hard that they should now be required to make up the deficiencies of other States.

abstract: The Richmond papers of the 15th contain very little additional intelligence from Gen. SHERMAN's army. The Dispatch says that official dispatches received at the rebel War Department, that on the 10th Gen. WHEELER attacked KIDPATRICK at Aiken, on the Charleston and Augusta road, twenty miles northeast of Augusta, and after a considerable engagement, drove him five miles in the direction of Branchville. It also says that their troops have by this time, no doubt, fallen back to the Congaree River, and that SHERMAN will be able to shell the Columbia from the south bank. The Congaree and its tributary, Saluda, are both easily fordable above the city.
lead_paragraph: The Richmond papers of the 15th contain very little additional intelligence from Gen. SHERMAN's army. abstract: Insane Talk of Rebels about A bject Submission, >amp;c.; Lee and Richmond Whig on
snippet: Insane Talk of Rebels about A bject Submission, >amp;c.; Lee and Richmond Whig on
lead_paragraph: We may as well set it down, once for all, that the South has lost its reason, and that it must be treated like all other lunatics -- first mastered, then soothed. The philosopher BERKELEY maintained that a people, as well as an individual, might go deranged. If derangement consists of such a confusion of the faculties that things can no longer be regarded in their just relations, and of such an exaltation of the imagination that fancies sway the mind and the will instead of facts, there can be no doubt that, so far as regards this case, at least, BERKELEY was right. Ninetenths of the inmates of Bloomingdale are there to-day on less conclusive evidence that they are out of their senses, than what daily comes to us in respect to the people in rebeldom. They to-day have a greater capacity of suitably managing their own concerns than that people exhibit. They think less loosely, talk less incoherently, are disposed to act with less damage to themselves and the public.

abstract: Barbarity; Com. Mason on; Commissioner, on Rebel Barbarity
snippet: Barbarity; Com. Mason on; Commissioner, on Rebel Barbarity
lead_paragraph: -- The "Confederate Commissioner" in London, Mr. MASON, of Virginia, has published in the English papers a very long letter about the barbarous treatment of Union prisoners in the South. The facts are too patent and too well authenticated to be directly denied by Mr. MASON; but he attempts to palliate some of the rebel atrocities, such as starving our prisoners, by asserting that our armies have devastated the South and destroyed the supplies. Now, the point where the worst treatment of this kind was visited most extensively upon our prisoners was at Andersonville, in Georgia -- the very region which SHERMAN's army traversed two months ago, and found to be abounding in all the necessaries of life to such an extent that it furnished supplies on the line of march for an army of fifty thousand men. MASON also tries to excuse the rebels for their savagery, by asserting that Confederate prisoners are maltreated and starved in the North. This will be news to the rebel prisoners at Point Lookout, Columbus, Chicago, Rock Island, Indianapolis, Johnson's Island, and Elmira. The rebel prisoners, when exchanged, have invariably been in far better physical condition than when they fell into our hands, and the rations daily meted to them are both good and abundant.
headline: {'main': 'COMMISSIONER MASON ON REBEL BARBARITY.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'COMMISSIONER MASON ON REBEL BARBARITY.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: ACADEMY OF MUSIC. -- VERDI's early, but mature opera of "Ernani," a work which reveals all the best characteristics of the composer, and abounds in strong dramatic and melodic effects, was received here last evening. The house was exceedingly brilliant, and received Mad. CAROZZI ZUCCHI -- who was dressed with rare good taste -- most cordially. The part of Elvira is admirably suited to the powers of the lady, and the role has rarely been so well interpreted, either vocally or in its dramatic bearings. Signor MACCAFERRI was the Ernani. It is one of his best parts. The gentleman possesses a powerful voice, rather rough, but capable of movements of great brilliancy. Signor BELLINI was admirable as the King. He has rarely been heard to better advantage. We cannot, unfortunately, say the same of Signor SUSINI, who was once more hoarse, and blurred and spoilt the music of the role of Silva. To-day there will be a grand matinee when DONIZETTI's opera of "Lucia di Lammermoor" will be repeated with Mme. VAN ZANDT as the heroine.
lead_paragraph: ACADEMY OF MUSIC. -- VERDI's early, but mature opera of "Ernani," a work which reveals all the best characteristics of the composer, and abounds in strong dramatic and melodic effects, was received here last evening. The house was exceedingly brilliant, and received Mad. CAROZZI ZUCCHI -- who was dressed with rare good taste -- most cordially. The part of Elvira is admirably suited to the powers of the lady, and the role has rarely been so well interpreted, either vocally or in its dramatic bearings. Signor MACCAFERRI was the Ernani. It is one of his best parts. The gentleman possesses a powerful voice, rather rough, but capable of movements of great brilliancy. Signor BELLINI was admirable as the King. He has rarely been heard to better advantage. We cannot, unfortunately, say the same of Signor SUSINI, who was once more hoarse, and blurred and spoilt the music of the role of Silva. To-day there will be a grand matinee when DONIZETTI's opera of "Lucia di Lammermoor" will be repeated with Mme. VAN ZANDT as the heroine.

abstract: Proposed Steamship Line to; San Francisco and China S S Lina
snippet: Proposed Steamship Line to; San Francisco and China S S Lina
lead_paragraph: Both Houses of Congress have passed the bill providing for the establishment of a steamship line across the North Pacific Ocean, from San Francisco to China. They have done well in so doing. The necessity of the line as a means of postal and commercial intercourse, is apparent; and the terms on which it has been established are eminently favorable at once to the enterprise and to the Government.

abstract: It is not positively known whether the strong array of influence which has been brought to bear in behalf of Capt. BEALL, now under sentence of death, will induce the President to grant a reprieve; but last evening unofficial reports were abroad, setting forth that the execution had been stayed. Gen. DIX was unable to give the reporters any definite information yesterday afternoon.

abstract: The steamship City of Dublin, from Liverpool on the 1st, and Queenstown on the 2d, arrived at this port yesterday. A summary of her news was brought by the North American at Portland. The files by the North American, covering dates to the 2d inst. were also received. They contain little of interest. The energy evinced in the capture of Fort Fisher, upon the heels of a failure, extorted praises from even the rebel organs.

abstract: Col. BAKER returned yesterday from Washington, where he has been to make arrangements for the speedy trial of the bounty-brokers whom he has in confinement in the Old Capitol Prison. At the Federal City he was heartily thanked for his timely and important services here, and assured that he should not need aid from the War Department; and as an earnest of their words the department officers promptly named a military commission, which, at Col. BAKER's suggestion, will immediately enter upon the trial of his prisoners.

abstract: Count Johannes vs Greeley; Verdict for Defendant
snippet: Count Johannes vs Greeley; Verdict for Defendant
lead_paragraph: Judging from the crowded attendance in this court yesterday, the public interest in the libel suit brought by GEORGE, the Count JOANNES, against Mr. HORACE GREELEY, for an alleged libel published in the Tribune, seems to be very great. Long before the hour of opening the court -- 11 A.M., -- the room was crowded to suffocation. Many persons were no doubt induced to come there under the impression that they would hear the Count JOANNES sum up the case to the jury in his own behalf. Among the spectators were quite a number of prominent citizens. Professors THEODORE DWIGHT and FRANCIS LIEBER, Mr. P.T. BARNUM and FREDERICK KAPP, Esq., were examined as witnesses:

abstract: The great military problem is hastening day by day to its solution. The toils are slowly, but inextricably tightening about the rebel General and his array in Virginia. Gen. SHERMAN is cutting his distant line of supplies, and, when Charleston is reduced, will be steadily advancing toward the grand concentration of the National armies in Virginia, and destroying as he marches the very sources of LEE's commissariat.

abstract: What will he do if Defeated; Sumner, C.; Resolution Against Recognizing Rebel Debt, (Senate)
snippet: What will he do if Defeated; Sumner, C.; Resolution Against Recognizing Rebel Debt, (Senate)
lead_paragraph: In the Senate, yesterday, the credentials of Mr. JOSEPH LEGAR, Senator elect from the old State of Virginia, were presented, and in the debate which arose, the whole question of Virginia's status in the Union was discussed by Messrs. SUMNER, FOSTER, TRUMBULL, HOWARD, WILLEY, WILSON and SHERMAN, when the credentials were laid on the table. Mr. SUMNER introduced a concurrent resolution declaring the rebel debt or loan simply an agent of the rebellion, which can never in any way be recognized by the United States. The introduction of the resolution was objected to. The Naval Appropriation bill was taken up when another long discussion occurred between Messrs. HALE, GRIMES, DOOLITTLE and SAULSBURY. At the evening session of the Senate Mr. SUMNER's resolution on the rebel debt was passed. The Naval Appropriation Bill came up and Mr. NYF made a long speech in reply to Mr. SAULSBURY's remarks of the afternoon. Messrs. SAULSBURY, GRIMES and WADE also participated in the debate, when several minor amendments were made, and the bill passed.

abstract: House, Rise of and Remedy
snippet: House, Rise of and Remedy
lead_paragraph: One of the time-honored customs of our city requires both landlord and tenant to "declare their intentions" on the 1st of February, in relation to the rental year commencing the 1st of May. The house-owners have made their declaration, and, to the horror of pater families, struggling to keep himself and babies from the contamination of a "low neighborhood," his landlord demands an increase of rent fully averaging 25 per cent. above the rates of last year. The intentions of the tenant becomes, therefore, the question of vital importance in the family circle; they agitate the breakfast table and disturb the serenity of the bedroom confab; they penetrate even to the nursery. Especially is this the case in the middle stratum of humanity, where the entire social economy now turns upon this all-absorbing matter -- the rate of the yearly rental. The salaried man, whose annual income is a fixed quantity, looks despairingly toward Brooklyn or to the shores of New-Jersey, and presents to himself the alternative of emigration or a boarding-house. And it is upon this class that the rise in rents is about to press most heavily. By means of trade associations, combinations, strikes, &c., mechanics and craftmen have brought about a rate of increased remuneration for their labor proportionate to the increased cost of living, but no regular or commensurate rise in the salaries of clerks. Government employes and others receiving fixed wages, has taken place, and to them the rent question is of absorbing interest. Even emigration offers but little relief to the harried clerk, for the rush to Brooklyn and Williamsburgh, Hoboken and Jersey City, is so great, that rents which are, of course, dependent on demand, have risen more than fifty per cent. in all accessible suburbs of New-York.

abstract: Our Position at Home and Abroad
snippet: Our Position at Home and Abroad
lead_paragraph: The late arrivals from Europe bring intelligence of a great revolution in public opinion favorable to this country, and, as a consequence, of a very large advance in American securities. The condition of affairs here is getting to be understood. So far, it has been entirely misunderstood. Statesmen and journalists abroad have been possessed with the idea that the condition of this country repeated that of Europe -- that our States stood upon their nationalities, and that a wide expanse must necessarily produce an irreconcilable antagonism, both of interest and feeling. They regarded the rebellion as the commencement of the natural disintegration of the country into numerous communities, to ripen in time into distinct nationalities, and that it was the height of folly even for our own Government to resist a tendency so inevitable and irresistible. The conviction and wish of Europe against our success was almost universal. The only thing that prevented interference, probably, was the belief that we should soon be so completely exhausted that we would be only too glad to give up a hopeless contest.

abstract: On Friday evening the patients in the "Ladies' Home" U.S. General Hospital, corner of Lexington-Avenue and Fifty-first street, testified their gratitude to Dr. ALEXANDER B. MOTT, the surgeon in charge, for his kindness and attention, by presenting him with a beautiful silver vase and salver. The hall of the institution was tastefully decorated with the national colors, while on the four sides of the room were the following inscriptions: "The Union must and shall be Preserved;" "God bless our Soldiers;" "Our absent Ones;" and "Our fallen Heroes." The room was filled by patients and the friends of the Institution, among whom were many ladies. The proceedings were enlivened by an excellent musical entertainment, given under the direction of Mr. ALFRED H. PEASE, assisted by an excellent amateur quartette, consisting of Mrs. MORRIS, MISS RUSHLY, Mr. LEGGAT and Mr. CHAPMAN. MISS BRUMAN presided at the piano.

abstract: Dr Von Vleck's Exposures of
snippet: Dr Von Vleck's Exposures of
lead_paragraph: Within the last few years, a number of persons calling themselves "mediums," have attracted public attention, by professing to be the means through which disembodied spirits communicate with the material world. At the seances given by these mediums, a regular course of performances is gone through. Musical instruments are played, bells are rung, tables are uplifted and overturned, the most intricate knots are untied; and articles of furniture go gyrating round the room, and all this, apparently, without the aid of the physical forces. As these manifestations invariably take place in a dark or dimly lighted room, and as the mediums always insist on certain conditions being observed, the spectators, (if they can be so called,) finding it impossible to detect any artifice or deception, naturally become impressed with the idea that the mediums are really endowed with more than mortal powers. Of course, among the investigators, are many hard of belief, who feel unwilling to ascribe the manifestations to spiritual agency, merely because they cannot detect the physical means employed. Yet there are others, who are so firmly convinced of the truth of all they hear and see that they have given up both friends and fortune to aid in disseminating the peculiar doctrines of the Spiritualists. These unfortunate victims of the dela[???] [???] may be counted by thousands. The Spiritual Telegraph and other organs of the Spiritualists affirm that there are some sixty or eighty thousand believers in spiritualism in Europe alone, and that the number is daily increasing. Lunacy, suicide and the disruption of family ties are some of the common results of a belief in the doctrines of the Spiritualists. A jargon has been adopted by their lecturers and writers, solely, it would seem, for the purpose of confusing ordinary intellects and "making the wrong appear the better reason." The evil is wide-spreading, and those who undertake its exposure should receive encouragement. There is now in this city a Dr. N.F. VON VLECK, who professes to have made the exposure of the trickery practiced by the "mediums" his study for the last ten years. He believes that he has discovered the means by which all the manifestations are made, and that the whole thing is a deception from beginning to end. The writer, with several other representatives of the press was invited to be present, Thursday, at a private seance given by Dr. VON VLECK in his apartments at the Astor House. The Doctor clearly demonstrated in what manner four or even five musical instruments could be played upon at once, how the tightest and apparently most inextricable knots could be slipped, iron rings placed on a person's arm, while his hands were retained in those of the medium, rappings produced, and in short, fully exposed the hundred and one tricks familiar to all who have attended spiritual seances. The writer was requested to take a seat at the table, on which were a number of musical instruments, to close his eyes and to place his hands on the doctor's head. Dr. VON VLECK, being seated before him, then clasped both his hands round the writer's arm. While in this position, no one else being within ten feet of the table, the musical instruments were played on, sailed over the writer's head, struck him on the face, and, in fact, made themselves felt in a manner more forcible than pleasant. The writer was somewhat astonished by the demonstrations until the modus operandi was explained to him, when the only wonder he felt was that he had never thought of so simple an explanation before. Dr. VON VLECK also explained the method adopted by mediums in answering sealed letters and in producing spirit writing, and convinced all present that a little skillful manipulation would account for all the wonders the clairvoyant and writing mediums profess to perform.

abstract: Empire of; The Second; Sonora, Cession and Gwin, Stories not True
snippet: Empire of; The Second; Sonora, Cession and Gwin, Stories not True
lead_paragraph: The second Mexican Empire promises to prove as ephemeral as the first was durable. That of the Montezumas, which CORTEZ overthrew, had existed for centuries, but the empire which the Third NAPOLEON has founded for the benefit of the Hapsburgs, already totters. On every side of MAXIMILIAN, the storm-clouds are looming above the horizon. His determination to confirm the law secularizing ecclesiastical property, has converted the Church party, once his most steadfast supporters, into his most bitter enemies. True, their late attempt at insurrection has failed, VALDEZ, who had placed himself at the head of the movement having been defeated by a division of French troops near Texcatitlan. This discomfiture has not, however, in the least disheartened them, or caused them to desist from essaying to undermine the throne which they contributed to effectually to set up. If the champions of the priesthood cannot encounter the mercenaries of MAXIMILIAN in the field, their emisaries can traverse the country and prepare the way for that universal uprising which bids fair to overwhelm the usurper, by sowing the seeds of disaffection in the minds of the people. VALDEZ may not prove a very formidable antagonist to the French Generals, but VICARIO and his columns riding over the land and disseminating proclamations, which "attack the Emperor, accuse him of having broken faith with the nation, and call on all Mexicans to take up arms against the foreign dynasty," are opponents whom the Austrian and his Gallic friends may well dread.

abstract: the Incendiary of 1777; Trial of Jas Hill; Incendiaries now and in 1777
snippet: the Incendiary of 1777; Trial of Jas Hill; Incendiaries now and in 1777
lead_paragraph: In the year 1777 there was put on trial at he assizes in London, a man known as JAMES HILL, otherwise called "John the Painter," under an indictment for setting fire to what was called the rope-house in the dockyards in Portsmouth. From the opening speech of the counsel for the Crown, it appeared that at the time of the fire, which was a very destructive one, no suspicion was raised as to its origin, but that a short time after, there was discovered in the hemp-house in the same dockyard, a machine containing combustibles, which showed that an attempt had been made to fire this house also. Suspicion being then excited; it was remembered that this HILL, who had been in the yard, was found locked up in the hemp-house the day before the fire. Other circumstances combining to strengthen the suspicion thus directed against him, a reward was offered, and the man was at last arrested. As it was understood that he had been in America, it was surmised that the Colonies, which were then in rebellion, and interested in the destruction of the English navy, were in some way concerned in the affair, and another man, named BALDWIN, who had been in Philadelphia, was called in to prove that he had seen HILL there, but was unable to identify him. HILL, however, as BALDWIN was going out, called him up, and, after some talk, requested a visit from him. BALDWIN visited HILL in prison, and an intimacy sprang up between them, until HILL took BALDWIN entirely into his confidence, admitted that he set fire to the rope-house, and gave a full account of his coming over from France under a French passport, for the purpose of firing the dockyards, and of all the steps which he took to make his infernal machines and to fire the buildings. BALDWIN thereupon made the matter known to the Government Officers, who were enabled to verify the story by the evidence of the man who made the machines, the women with whom he had boarded, and other witnesses, making out a full chain of proof against the accused, and corroborating to the full his confession to BALDWIN. He was convicted and executed, having confessed his guilt. The case is reported in full in Howell's State Trials, vol. 20, p. 1,318.

abstract: His Personal Characteristics
snippet: His Personal Characteristics
lead_paragraph: It is now a little more than six years ago that I first saw Mr. JEFFERSON DAVIS, then United States Senator from Mississippi, now the head and leader of this great rebellion. We were fellow-passengers on one of those magnificent packets that, in the palmy days of union and peace, plied a lucraitve trade between New-Orleans and the towns on the Mississippi River. His time was apparently unoccupied, and after dinner we fell into conversation on the state of the nation and general politics, which lasted, with great interest to me, till sundown. In conversation, JEFF. DAVIS is the most engaging and instructive of all rebels. Upon introduction his manners have a tinge of military exactness and formal courtesy, but once engaged in talk upon his favorite themes, no public man could be more lavish of his mental wealth, or more agreeable in his mode of displaying it. It was plain even then, in a time of profound peace and great national prosperity, the South never so flourishing, and his own party in undisputed power, that his heart was set on the establishment of a separate republic, and that he had contemplated and loved to contemplate all the advantages which the South might hope to derive from such a step, and anticipated all the difficulties in the way of successful secession.

abstract: for Rebel Service; Arming by Rebels
snippet: for Rebel Service; Arming by Rebels
lead_paragraph: It seems to be more than probable that the rebels will make the experiment of arming at least a small number of their slaves. BENJAMIN publicly confesses that the able-bodied white population is used up, and that Richmond must be evacuated unless the negroes be conscripted. Gen. LEE favors the measure the army calls for it, as we may see from the letters from the camps in the Richmond papers; DAVIS has long been an advocate of it. The strong aristocratic slaveholding caste must at length yield, and all its slaves, as well as its children, must be offered a sacrifice to the ambition of DAVIS and the pride of LEE. The so-called Congress, it is true, rejects any comprehensive measures for arming great numbers of slaves; but it allows twenty or thirty thousand to be employed as "pioneers and teamsters." How long will it take Gen. LEE to make passable soldiers of these pioneers and put them in garrison or on guard at bridges in his rear? Still time flies, and SHERMAN presses steadily on. Whatever regiments are to be drilled for the Spring and Summer campaign, must be drilled now. The area for conscripting the black population diminishes every day; the time for arming and exercising and organizing such a mass of raw troops grows continually shorter. It is not improbable that approaching ruin and the feeling of desperation will finally drive the rebel administration into the forcible conscription of masses of blacks, and the insurgent armies will be reinforced with these unwilling Sepoys.

abstract: The question of most interest on the subject of fashion for this month is the style in vogue for ball and evening dress. abstract: Maiden-lane; Byrne's Cotton-store--$6,000
snippet: Maiden-lane; Byrne's Cotton-store--$6,000
lead_paragraph: ing, a fire occurred in Mr. MATTHEW J. BYRNE's cotton warehouse, on the second, third, and fourth floors of No. 100 Maiden-lane, and the building and stock were damaged to the extent of about $6,000. Mr. BYRNE has $9,500 insurance in the Albany City, Norwich, Firemen's Fund and Grocers' offices. Mr. WM. TERWILLIGER, dealer in iron safes, on the first floor, lost $100 from damage by water. He is insured for $9,000 by the Park, Globe and Star Companies. The fire originated from a scrap of lighted paper which fell from the hands of a girl who was passing through the cotton room.

abstract: FICERS. -- John MCNEILL and CHARLES GARVIN, were apprehended, yesterday, and taken before Col. BAKER, where also appeared Mr. JOHN H. HARRIS, of No. 156 West Thirty-fifth-street, a stage-driver, who made affidavit that the prisoners had defrauded him of a small sum of money by representing that they were United States detective officers, and had a warrant for his arrest as a deserter. The evidence against the accused being conclusive, they were sent in irons to Fort Lafayette.

abstract: Brooklyn; Michael Burke Beats his Wife to Death
snippet: Brooklyn; Michael Burke Beats his Wife to Death
lead_paragraph: OF HIS WIFE. -- MICHAEL BURKE, charged with beating his wife with such severity that she died, was arrested at the house of his uncle, PATRICK BURKE, No. 405 Columbia-street, yesterday morning. When questioned by the officers in regard to the affair, be acknowledged that he had beaten her because he found her drunk when he got home, but that the injury above the left eye was caused by falling upon the edge of the stove. The accused was committed to await the result of the Coroner's investigation.

abstract: Grand Trunk, Canada; Train over Embankment
snippet: Grand Trunk, Canada; Train over Embankment
lead_paragraph: -- An accident of a very serious character occurred on the Western division of the Grand Trunk, one mile east of Guelph, yesterday morning, about 10:30 o'clock, by which a passenger car, containing some thirty five persons, was precipitated down an embankment about thirty feet high, and where it now lies bottom upwards. It appears the morning train from London to Toronto left Guelph at its usual time, but had got only a mile below that station when the engine, by means of the ice and snow at a crossing, got off the track, and in doing so broke a rail. It dragged the train about twenty rods, when the passenger car was thrown off the track, and hurled down the embankment. Information was immediately sent to Guelph Station, and in the meantime the persons who were on the baggage car and engine used every exertion to rescue the inmates of the passenger car, who miraculously escaped with their lives, although about six of them were seriously injured. The names of some of the injured are: Hon. M.H. Foley, bruised and injured in chest and shoulders, but not considered dangerous by his medical advisers; Conductor Robert Johnston, (formerly a member of the Toronto City Police Force) seriously injured, his collar bone being broken in three places and his skull fractured. Johnston was conveyed to this city by train yesterday, and sent to his house on Camden-street, where he was placed under the care of Dr. Russell, W. Phin, J.P., Eram[???]sa; J. McNab, Knox College, hands and face burnt by overturning of stove; Wm. Carson, A[???]blon, badly cut on the leg; A. Thompson, Toronto, hands burnt by the stove; -- Rowe, C. Chadwick and A. Lemon, Guelph, the latter two slightly injured; Miss Thompson, Esquesing, shoulder hurt; James French, Hamilton, side and shoulder bruised. The baggage car was thrown off the track, but did not go down the embankment. The wheels and axles of the passenger car were broken to pieces. A special train was dispatched from Toronto at once to render assistance and to bring away the passengers, all of whom, with the exception of Mr. Foley and Mr. Thompson, resumed their journey to their several destinations. A passenger describes the scene in the car at the time of the accident as frightful. One was thrown on top of another, and for the moment all were in perfect terror. -- Toronto Globe, Feb. 14.

abstract: The Post-Office Department has developed a most useful branch of the money-order system in designating the post-office at City Point, Va., as a "money-order office." Absolute safety is thus secured in sending money to the Army of the Potomac by mail, and soldiers wishing to send home a portion of their pay can obtain money-orders at City Point, payable at the regular offices in any part of the country. The establishment of this system, in connection with the army post-offices, at all our great military depots, will he a great blessing to soldiers and to their families. With convenient facilities for the safe transportation of their money the greater portion of our volunteers would send their pay home, either to be used presently in the support of their wives and children, or to be laid by against the day when their warlike occupation shall cease.

abstract: Dispatches form Gen. GRANT to Secretary STANTON containing extracts from the Richmond papers of yesterday give the cheering news that SHERMAN has captured Columbia, South Carolina, and is there with his whole army. The probably immediate evacuation of Charleston is announced, and a dispatch from the Charleston Mercury states that the publication of that paper will be suspended for a short time, until the office can
lead_paragraph: Dispatches form Gen. GRANT to Secretary STANTON containing extracts from the Richmond papers of yesterday give the cheering news that SHERMAN has captured Columbia, South Carolina, and is there with his whole army. The probably immediate evacuation of Charleston is announced, and a dispatch from the Charleston Mercury states that the publication of that paper will be suspended for a short time, until the office can be removed to another place. The Richmond papers seem to be in the dark as to the future movements of SHERMAN's army, but think that he may go to Charlotte, N.C. They say that he may possibly establish a new base at Charleston, but think it is needless for him to have any base, as he is living on the country, and has fought no battle that would diminish his supply of ammunition. The "brag" appears to have been entirely taken but of the Southern journals, their tone being despondent, and conveying the impression that they believe SHERMAN can go where he chooses, consulting only his own convenience. BEAUREGARD had retreated before the advance of SHERMAN, destroying large quantities of medical stores; but no intimations are given as to the direction taken by his forces. It is evident that SHERMAN will now sweep through the States of South and North Carolina unopposed, completely destroying the main lines of communication with the beleaguered capital of Virginia, and join GRANT by Spring in the final struggle with the only organized rebel force on the face of the earth.

abstract: Morris, Richard, of Butternuts, N Y.
snippet: Morris, Richard, of Butternuts, N Y.
lead_paragraph: son of the late Gen. JACOB MORRIS and eldest grandson of LEWIS MORRIS, one of the signers of the Declaration of Independence, died at his residence, Upton Park, in the town of Butternuts, this county, on the 2d of February, aged 82 years. He was born in Philadelphia, on the 18th of September, 1782, receiving baptism from the venerable Bishop WHITE, Chaplain of the first Congress. JACOB MORRIS, his father, was a prominent officer in the Revolutionary army, serving as Aid to General CHARLES LEE. He was an active participant in most of the battles of the Revolution, taking a distinguished part in the gallant defence of Fort Moultrie. In the year 1787 he moved to Orsego county with his family, and settled on a tract of land given him by his father, LEWIS MORRIS, and now known as the Morris Land Patent. RICHARD MORRIS was an unambitious man, caring more for the endearments of domestic life, and agricultural pursuits, than for empty honors. He was known and beloved by his neighbors and tenants, for his many unobtrusive acts of benevolence, and his spirit of enterprise in every good work. -- Cooperstown Republican, Feb. 16.

abstract: Wooster-street; Cabinet Factories--$75,000
snippet: Wooster-street; Cabinet Factories--$75,000
lead_paragraph: Last evening, the two great cabinet and piano manufactories, Nos. 176 and 178 Wooster-street, were destroyed by fire, the upper portion of Public School building No. 10, at No. 180 Wooster-street, was considerably damaged, and the roof of Mrs. MONROE's dwelling, at No. 174, was crushed in by falling walls. The fire was first discovered in Messrs. DROUHARD & ROY's French cabinet warehouse, No. 176, and thence the flames leaped through the combustible material on the upper and lower floors, and into the adjoining building, and in less than half an hour from the time of the first alarm the two buildings were a sheet of flame. The firemen now turned their attention to saving properity in the immediate neighborhood of the conflagration; but no withstanding the floods of water which they poured into the schoolhouse adjoining No. 178 and into Mrs. MONROE's house, No. 174, both buildings were materially damaged before the firemen gained mastery of the fiery element. At one time several dwellings on the west side of Wooster-street were in imminent danger of destruction; but they were, happily saved with little damage beyond a slight searching. At about 10:30 the lofty walls of Nos. 176 and 178 fell and sent up dense volumes of sparks and cinders, which, being swept on the wind far over eastward, threatened Greene-street, Broadway, and Elm-street; but they kindled fire on only one roof -- that of the Jewish Synogogue, in Greene-street. The flame was speedily extinguished by firemen, who clambered to the roof and applied their axes.

abstract: Ack's Gift "Waiting for the Hour"; Carlton's Waiting for the Hour; President's Acknowledgment of Gift
snippet: Ack's Gift "Waiting for the Hour"; Carlton's Waiting for the Hour; President's Acknowledgment of Gift
lead_paragraph: ter the public exhibition in this city of Mr. W.T. CARLTON's very merritorious painting, entitled "Watch-Meeting, Dec. 31, 1862 -- or, Waiting for the Hour of Emancipation under the President's Proclamation of Jan. 1, 1865 -- It was deemed eminently fitting that it should be purchased by subscription, and presented to President LINCOLN, as a mark of personal respect, and warm appreciation of his act, whereby more than three millions of fetters were broken, and a death dealing blow was virtually given to the entire system of chattel slavery. The list of subscribers was headed by Gov. ANDREW, and composed of some of our most respected citizens -- the sum raised amounted to $500. The painting was duly forwarded to Washington, accompanied by an explanatory and congratulatory letter to the President; but, though the safe arrival of it at the White House was ascertained, its receipt has remained unacknowledged till now. The reason for this is satisfactorily given in the following ingenuous and appreciative letter just received by us from Mr. LINCOLN.

abstract: On Historical Influence of Natural Causes
snippet: On Historical Influence of Natural Causes
lead_paragraph: Thursday evening Prof. JOHN W. DRAPER, gave the second of a series of lectures before the Historical Society, on the "Historical Influence of Natural Causes." The subject treated was the "Effects of Emigration." Prof. DRAPER, in beginning his address, said he would treat late subject as compactly as possible, and therefore classified it under two heads: First, the effect on the coun- try left; and Secondly, the effect on the country joined. In considering the effect upon the country left, we must bear in mind that in every country the people are made up of three distinct classes: First, a superior order, who, by their talents, rule with unresisted power; second, an intermediate class, which understands what is explained; and thirdly, the lower orders, who do not understand at all. If the class which leaves a country belongs to the lower order, the effect is not serious. The places of the ignorant are easily supplied, and no material strength is lost. Should the migrating body, however, seriously diminish the higher class, it is a more serious matter, as it is impossible to recruit that class at will. The discovery of America by COLUMBUS agitated Europe to its deepest foundations; the people went wild for the lust of gold, the excitement extending from the prisoner's cell to the throne. In Spain, the men of influence -- civil, military and ecclesiastical -- all rushed across the ocean, the thirst for gold becoming too strong for family pride. The melancholy Peruvian Inca, when he placed his finger on the prison wall, and offered to give gold to that height for his freedom, only added to the fierce thirst. Spain acted with the greatest atrocity toward the natives, treating them as though they did not belong to the human race. It was an unutterable outrage, producing universal ruin. Whole races, numbering millions of people, were remorselessly exterminated. From Mexico and Peru, a civilization that might have instructed Europe was blotted out. The crime of Spain, the speaker said, became her punishment. Her intelligence was swamped in American wilds, and the emigration of her best and bravest blood wrought her ruin. The Mexican and Peruvian are terribly revenged. In Europe, there is another class of emigrants that is worth our study. For three centuries a large portion of the world has been peopled by the English, principally from the second and third classes. The first order has emigrated to but a limited extent. In the colonization of North America and Australia, there has been but little inducement for those who desired a life of learned ease or social distinction. The removal of forests and building of cities presented but few temptations for the aristocracy. In a double manner, these circumstances tended to restrain the upper class, and the intrinsic strength of that nation has not declined. On speaking of the second point -- the effect of emigration on the country joined -- the lecturer said that when a people is suddenly transported from its original seat to some new abode, in a different climate, it involuntarily commences a movement to come into harmony with its new estate. There is an increased risk of life, but the change once perfected, everything moves forward harmoniously. The result may be expedited by mixture of blood. A small tribe intermingling with a large one becomes absorbed by the greater. This is illustrated by the history of the Romans. That people spread around the Mediterranian Sea, conquered Greece, Egypt, Spain, and other countries, only to be themselves contaminated and conquered by intermingling. The blood of the Romans was transferred into all, and that people was literally dissolved and lost in the nations. With them went down all their ideas and institutions; the thoughts of the conquered people conquered the thoughts of the Romans. The lecturer spoke at much length of the dissipation attending the adulteration of the Roman blood, and the extraordinary prevalence of crime, especially in relation to the conjugal relations of the people. The middle class, in which the worth and virtue of nations exist, became extinct. History proves, the speaker said, that nations cannot be continually modified without changing their natures. The extinction of races is never consummated by force, but by insidious influences, which gradually wean them away. Blood-degeneration implies thought-degeneration. These principles are illustrated with equal emphasis in Asiatic history. The Mahomedans overran Asia so rapidly, and their mass was so small, that instant extinction appeared to await them; yet for centuries they held the conquered country. The explanation of this surprising political result turns on the position of the female race in Asia. There woman is a slave, while in Europe she is a companion. The political pewer of the polygamic system is prodigious. The lecturer spoke of the greater power, which a large family of children gave, especially when the women are excluded from the public. In Europe, the area of influence is in society, while in Asia it is in the person. The sword made the conquest of the Mohommedans, and polygamy secured it. The speaker next illustrated his subject by referring to the history of this country. From the Atlantic States the West has been peopled. The emigration has been in equal proportions from the then social grades, and the social state has remained comparatively permanent. The speaker said we lost much by the extent of territory; if the area was smaller, and the population more condensed, the intellectual competition would be greater, and the advancement proportionate. The lecturer said our faculties were turned to the development of machinery rather than the science of agriculture, because land was so much cheaper than labor. If emigration should set toward the South, the effect would be different. The blood admixture with the white people of the South will make itself powerfully felt in the consequences that will ensue. There is a great difference between a civil and foreign war. The feuds of civil war, the speaker said, rapidly disappear. The vanquished in a civil strife avoids a recurrence to his failure, while the victor abstains from a contemplation of his success. The memory of such things speedily pass away, and society stands one new basis. The lecturer said it took but little time to heal the bonds of Rome and England, and it would take still less in the activity of human life in America.

abstract: The Eighth Ward Pioneer Clay Club held its twenty-sixth annual ball Friday evening at the City Assembly Rooms. The hall was thronged by a brilliant assemblage, not less than one thousand people
lead_paragraph: The Eighth Ward Pioneer Clay Club held its twenty-sixth annual ball Friday evening at the City Assembly Rooms. The hall was thronged by a brilliant assemblage, not less than one thousand people being present. Among the distinguished guests were Mayor GUNTHER, THURLOW WEED, ANDREW BLAKELY Supervisor SHOOK, Alderman GEDNEY and Councilman LENT. At an early hour the guests began to arrive and at 9 o'clock the floor was filled by dancers, who, to the music of WALLACE's full band, began to while the evening away in the delightful recreations of the dance. At 12 o'clock the guests adjourned to the supper room, where a sumptuous repast was partaken of. After supper, dancing was resumed, which continued until a late hour, when the guests dispersed, much pleased with the evening's entertainment.

abstract: Po sible Strategy of; How to Make the Campaign Decisive
snippet: Po sible Strategy of; How to Make the Campaign Decisive
lead_paragraph: We have seen no admission of the enemy, not even JUDAH BENJAMIN's speech at the African Church, in Richmond, that argued so much for the speedy issue of this struggle as a letter recently published, from a Georgian to his South Carolina friend, giving an account of Gen. SHERMAN's march through the former State. It contains a candidly, though reluctant admission, that along the line of that victorious General's march private property was generally respected; that few dwelling-houses, and not many factories were burned; that, except for the deep ruts in the highways, one could hardly know, from anything on the face of the country, that a hostile force of sixty thousand veteran troops had recently taken their line of march from the railroad and military centre of the State to its commercial city. He says the poor were generally unmolested, and whenever necessary supplies were taken, care was always shown to leave at least a year's supply on the farm.

abstract: A great trotting-match took place on the 1st in the Bois de Boulog[???]e between the famous American trotter Shepherd and French horse Express, for Â£400. The Parisian sporting world was on the spot in great force. The horses looked in first-rate condition. Shepherd was driven by the owner's groom, and Express by ALFRED MOYES. The course was two miles and a half. Shepherd took the lead, and maintained it to the last, winning by about 160 yards. The American trotter was the favorite; betting, three to one on Shepherd.

abstract: Murder of British Officers
snippet: Murder of British Officers
lead_paragraph: The nobles of Japan make it a point to evince the intensity of the hatred which they bear toward foreigners, by the periodical sacrifice of one or more of the obnoxious race. Their latest victims have been two British officers, Maj. BALDWIN and Lieut. BIRD, who had started from Yokohama on horseback, on the morning of the 21st of November, for a pleasure excursion to a place about sixteen miles distant. But they never returned alive, and in the evening of the same day, information reached the Governor of Yokohama that two foreigners were lying dead near the temple gardens of Kamakura. This intelligence, of course, caused great excitement and consternation among the European residents, and immediately a troop of mounted artillery, accompanied by a number of civilians and several Consuls, set out for the locality indicated, where they found the corpses of Messrs. BALDWIN and BIRD horribly mutilated -- the neck of the former half severed, and his cheek cut off; the arm and cervical vertebrae of the latter cut through in two or three different places, and his body disfigured all over with gashes. The killing was evidently the work of some of those armed bravos whom the Damios keep in their service for purposes of violence and assassination, and must have been perpetrated with no lees of treachery than of ferocity, since the revolvers of the murdered officers were undischarged, and no sign of a struggle anywhere to be seen.
headline: {'main': 'Another Japanese Trouble.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'Another Japanese Trouble.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: Released from Fort Warren
snippet: Released from Fort Warren
lead_paragraph: The Boston Transcript says: "The late GEORGE P. BOND, Director of the Observatory of Harvard College, was a graduate of the institution in the class of 1845, and was one of the most gifted and accomplished scientific men in the country. His death is a loss to the cause of science, as few astronomers have brought to their profession such eminent qualifications as the deceased. Since the death of his father, the late WILLIAM CRANCH BOND, in 1859, he has been at the head of the Observatory. The father and son have occupied this high position since the establishment of the Observatory, twenty five years."

abstract: Funds, Large sums Deposited in Canada
snippet: Funds, Large sums Deposited in Canada
lead_paragraph: One of the Montreal papers, which boasts itself the organ of the Southern Confederacy, states that two gentlemen of the rebel "persuasion," now in Montreal, have on deposit in the banks of that place no less a sum than $2,300,000. It calls to mind the fact also that the money belonging to the refugees, which they have with them in Canada, amounts in the aggregate to a large amount. From which truth it would apparenty have us come to the conclusion; first, that the sudden withdrawal of the money on deposit would probable "use up" every banking institution in the land; and secondly, that to avoid such a catastrophe we must carefully abstain from doing anything likely to hurt the feelings of the refugees here, lest they should in revenge bring our house down about our heads. If we Canadians will behave like good children, allow the refugees to violate the neutrality of our soil, to organize within the Province plundering expeditious upon our neighbors, and to drag us into a war with the United States, while we stand quietly by, or say nothing but by way of encouragement, then they may kindly continue their deposits; but otherwise we had better beware!

abstract: Preparations were in progress at Governor's Island on Friday afternoon for the execution of BEALL, the spy and pirate, according to the order issued by Gen. DIX. The execution was to have taken place at noon yesterday, but on Friday evening Col. BOMFORD, commandant at Governor's Island, received a second order directing a postponement until some day this week. It is understood that the order for a respite was issued at the request of the President, upon the urgent solicitation of the convict's mother, who came through our lines at Charleston, Va., on Wednesday last, for the purpose of being with her son in his last moments. Mrs. BEALL, who is a fine-looking lady, about fifty years of age, has obtained permission to visit her misguided son, and was with him the greater part of yesterday.

abstract: Brooklyn; Navy-yard, Metal at
snippet: Brooklyn; Navy-yard, Metal at
lead_paragraph: other alleged robbery has just been discovered at the Navy-Yard in this city. It is alleged that there were stolen one hundred and eight tank plates, made of a composition of brass, and other metals, weighing about fourteen pounds each. Also about four hundred pounds of the best block tin, the whole valued at about seven hundred dollars. The alleged robbery is said to have taken place on Wednesday evening.The day watchman attached to the plumber shop left the premises at 6 o'clock. His relief did not take charge until 8 o'clock.

abstract: The managers of the Lyceum of Natural History, which was incorporated in 1818, appeal to the public for assistance in obtaining funds to the amount of from $50,000 to $75,000, the interest of which would enable them to hire a building suitable for the display of the vast collection of objects of natural history, &c., which they possess. The managers say: "The establishment hero of a Museum of Natural History would attract to New-York many persons of cultivation who are driven to other cities, where a wise liberality has made ample provision for scientific pursuits. Moreover, many valuable objects, and often entire collections, which now find their way elsewhere, would naturally fail to us. We beg leave to press upon your attention the fact, that while the citizens of this great metropolis have lavished enormous sums upon enterprises and institutions of every kind, both of a public and private nature, no sufficient effort has ever been made toward establishing in New-York a Museum of Natural History." The Treasurer is Mr. GEORGE N. LAWRENCE, of No. 172 Pearl-street.

abstract: The House of Representatives yesterday passed the amended Internal Revenue Act, embodying some very important changes in the tax laws. The amendment taxing sales one and a half per centum was stricken out by a vote of 65 in favor of the tax to 75 against it. The House refused to increase the tax on beer and ale from $1 to $1.50 per barrel. Among the amendments adopted were the following in
lead_paragraph: The House of Representatives yesterday passed the amended Internal Revenue Act, embodying some very important changes in the tax laws. The amendment taxing sales one and a half per centum was stricken out by a vote of 65 in favor of the tax to 75 against it. The House refused to increase the tax on beer and ale from $1 to $1 50 per barrel. Among the amendments adopted were the following: imposing a tax of two and a half per centum on the net receipts of railroads, steamboats, ferryboats, stages, bridges, &c., when the receipts are under $3,000, and five per centum where they are over that sum. The tax under the old law was two and a half per cent. on the gross receipts. On diamonds, emeralds, precious stones and imitations thereof, and all other jewelry, the duty is reduced to five per centum ad valorem. Another amendment provides that no man not enabled for military duty, excepting in cases of physical disability, shall be entitled to take out a license as a peddler.

abstract: the late Mrs. MARY HYDE was attended yesterday from the residence of her husband's father, ROSWELL HYDE in Hubbard-street. It was a large funeral. Rev. Mr. STRONG and Rev. Mr. LAMPHEAR conducted the exercises. Her remains were buried in the family lot in Evergreen Cemetery. Among the persons present on the mournful occasion, were the near relatives and friends of the deceased and of her unfortunate husband; her father, who came from Milford, the Provost-Marshal of the Second Congressional District. Deputy-Marshal AUGUSTUS PUTNAM, and all the clerks and employes attached to the office of the Board of Enrollment in this city, and other persons officially connected with the recruiting service. Much sympathy was expressed for Mr. HYDE, who, while beating himself with moderation, appears to be fully sensible of his loss, and the peculiarly painful position in which he is placed. Toward evening -- some time after the funeral -- Constable JOHN MCGEE arrested Mr. HYDE, on a document issued by the Grand Juror, Col. GEORGE M. GARDINER, and in about an hour Mr. HYDE gave bonds -- or a friend did for him -- in the sum of $1,000, to appear this morning, at 6 o'clock, before Judge HOLLISTER, to answer to whatever complaint or charge might be brought against him. It is not probable that there will be any hearing of this sad affair to-day, as in case the State shall wish an investigation, witnesses will have to be summoned, which will take time. We saw Mr. HYDE at the office of the Chief of Police. He expressed a desire to have all the facts of his melancholy story laid before the officers of justice, and has no doubt of establishing the truth of his statements as he made them to the police on the night of the death of Mrs. HYDE. We understand that T.E. DOOLITTLE, Esq., is acting as HYDE's counsel. -- New-Haven Journal, Feb. 17.

abstract: Would it not be a good idea for all our managers to reverse the order of their performances; to begin, for instance, at 1 o'clock in the afternoon instead of 8 o'clock in the evening? The critics, who always place themselves first because every one else places them last, will not object; and the public, if we may judge by the experiment of Saturday, would be delighted. On that day matinee performances
lead_paragraph: Would it not be a good idea for all our managers to reverse the order of their performances; to begin, for instance, at 1 o'clock in the afternoon instead of 8 o'clock in the evening? The critics, who always place themselves first because every one else places them last, will not object; and the public, if we may judge by the experiment of Saturday, would be delighted. On that day matinee performances were given at the Academy of Music, at the Winter Garden, at ROBERT HELLER's "Salle Diabolique," at the Hippotheatron, at the Menagerie, at Barnum's Museum, and at various other places. In every in stance the attendance was overwhelming. Fully twenty-five hundred people were present at the Academy -- attracted perhaps by the promise of "Fra Diavols," but equally content with the performance of "Lucia di Lammermoor." At the Winter Garden, the house was literally filled to overflowing, and the same accurate statement may be made of the other places we have named. Everywhere the majority was composed of ladies, and it was certainly the prettiest, jauntiest, and chattiest majority ever seen. Clearly our managers would do well to devote several days of each week to a sex that exhibits such liberality and anxiety in the matter of amusements.

abstract: Paris Letter, Jan 20
snippet: Paris Letter, Jan 20
lead_paragraph: We have what may properly be called three day's later news from Europe by the arrival of the Saxonia from Southampton, Feb. 8. We have also fuller details of the news by the Europa. The principal item of British domestic intelligence is the assembling of Parliament, which took place on the 7th. The Queen's speech, which is of little general interest, will be found elsewhere, as also a portion of the debate thereon in the House of Lords. The Queen did not appear in person at the opening. We have additional particulars in the summary by the Saxonia, as well as in our Paris letter, relative to the strange proceedings by which the so called Danish ram Olinda has passed, presumably, into the handsof the rebels, and received an English outfit as a pirate. The "peace rumors" appear to have caused an extraordinary excitement in Germany, and United States securities at Hamburg advanced to 53 1/2, which is about 5 per cent. higher than their selling price here, was at the date of the Hamburg report. The London press is occupied more than ever with American continental affairs. The Army and Navy Gazette points to the rapid decline in the rebel cause -- looking solely to the military situation. The foreign enlistment case -- that of one RUMBLE, a British naval officer, engaged in fitting up a British gunboat as a rebel ram (the Rappahannock,) had been disposed of by the acquittal of the accused, although all the evidence went to establish his guilt. The news of the cession of the Mexican Provinces of Lower California, Sonora, &c., to France, had caused much comment. The British press seemed disposed to credit the report, although it was plumply denied by the French organ. We read in the Le Noid a story about a French Cabinet Council having been held, at which a grave discussion took place relative to the interests of France in Mexico, and the attitude in that regard of the Government of the United States.

abstract: The  British Parliament met on the 7th inst., and we publish the Queen's Speech elsewhere in full, as also the comments on American affairs elicited by the Address in the House of Lords. The Speech itself is utterly lacking
lead_paragraph: -- The British Parliament met on the 7th inst., and we publish the Queen's Speech elsewhere in full, as also the comments on American affairs elicited by the Address in the House of Lords. The Speech itself is utterly lacking in interest on any single question of foreign or domestic policy. Respecting ourselves we have the stereotyped phrase repeated, that we are to continue to be the subjects of a strict neutrality. To this is added an expression of hope that there may be a friendly reconciliation between "the contending parties." The speeches subsequently made by Lord DERBY and Lord RUSSELL, as far as they relate to the United States, are not at all different from those uttered by these statesmen on other occasions. Lord DERBY frankly confesses that he is not disposed to quarrel with the Government over its theory of neutrality -- a remark susceptible of a double interpretation. Lord RUSSELL, in his turn, is neither particularly gracious, nor specially belligerent.

abstract: Justice and Foreign Enlistments; Rumble case; Rumble Trial in England
snippet: Justice and Foreign Enlistments; Rumble case; Rumble Trial in England
lead_paragraph: The European mail last night brought us the conclusion of the trial of one RUMBLE, an officer in the British naval service, for a violation of the Foreign Enlistment act of the United Kingdom. The result of the trial is not different from what we had expected, but the shameless manner in which the jurors refused even to allow the law to be expounded to them, before rendering their verdict of acquittal, has, happily, we believe, few, if any, parallels in the judicial records of civilized communities.

abstract: Windsor, Charles; Mercantile Bank forger; arrested in England
snippet: Windsor, Charles; Mercantile Bank forger; arrested in England
lead_paragraph: CHARLES WINDSOR, late paying teller in the Mercantile Bank of this city, who absconded on the 28th of October last, and sailed for Europe the day following, was arrested last December by the Sheriff of Middlesex, England, and on the 3d last, was brought up at Bow-street, London, on a writ of habers corpus, directed to the governor of Whitecross Prison, to answer to a charge of forgery.

abstract: The steamer Ariadne arrived here to-day from Fort Fisher. The Captain of the steamer reports that our forces had expected to make an attack upon Fort Anderson on the 13th instant, but failed for some cauee unknown to him. Before he left Fort Fisher he saw a bright light in the direction of Fort Anderson, and the supposition was that it had been abandoned and burnt by the rebels.

abstract: In the United States Senate on Saturday, Mr. MORGAN introduced a bill authorizing the giving of bounties to honorably discharged soldiers, who have already served two years, the same as are now allowed for three years' service, and entitles the heirs of such soldiers, if dead, to the same bounty.
lead_paragraph: In the United States Senate on Saturday, Mr. MORGAN introduced a bill authorizing the giving of bounties to honorably discharged soldiers, who have already served two years, the same as are now allowed for three years' service, and entitles the heirs of such soldiers, if dead, to the same bounty. It also gives the same bounty to those who would have been entitled to discharge, by reason of wounds, but whose terms of service had expired within two years from the date of enlistment. Mr. SHERMAN, of Ohio, offered a joint resolution, providing for the appointment, by the Secretary of the Treasury, of a commission of three persons, to enamine into and report upon the subject of raising revenue by taxation, and the articles most fit for taxation. After some debate, the resolution was laid over. 2,000 copies of the report of the Naval Commission, in reference to the establishment of a Naval Depot in the Western waters, were ordered printed. The Army Appropriation Bill was taken up, and the recommendation of the Finance Committee to strike the proviso in the House bill, that no money shall be paid to land-grant railroads for transportation of troops and munitions of war for the United States, was adopted. An amendment making an appropriation of $7,000,000 to supply deficiencies in the appropriations for the present fiscal year, was adopted. Mr. WILSON offered amendments increasing the commutation price of rations to officers on duty in the field, below the rank of Brigadier-General, to fifty cents per ration. Also, that all officers of volunteers below the rank of Brigadier-General now in commission, who shall continue in the military service to the close of the war, shall be entitled to receive three months' pay, the provisions of this section not to apply to officers not on duty. That commissioned officers serving in the field shall be permitted, hereafter to purchase rations for their own use on credit from the Commissary Department, and the amount due for rations so purchased shall be reported monthly to the Paymaster-General to be deducted from the payment next following such purchase, which were adopted. Mr. WILSON also offered an amendment which was adopted, that the Secretary of War be directed to furnish, at cost, not exceeding 16 ounces of tobacco per month to each soldier who may deserve it, the cost to be deducted from their pay. The bill as amended was then passed. Mr. TURNBULL, from the Committee on the Judiciary, reported a resolution recognizing the State Government of Louisiana and the right of that State to Senators in Congress. Mr. SAULSBURY, of Delaware, offered a resolution proposing a committee to investigate charges of disloyalty against Secretary STANTON, the basis of said charges being a speech recently made in the rebel Congress by ex-Senator BROWN, of Mississippi, in which he asserted that Mr. STANTON once said the South was right. The resolution was laid over.

abstract: HELD FOR GRAND LARCENY. -- CHRIST MEYER, coppersmith, of No. 188 Second-avenue, was apprehended by Officer HAY, of the Twenty-seventh Precinct, and taken to the Halls of Justice, and EDWARD MEHDING, of No. 128 Greenwich-street, appeared and complained that the prisoner had stolen from him a spurious hundred-dollar bank-note. MEYER had passed the bogus note upon MEHDING, and the latter had returned it, when MEYER, instead of giving MEHDING good money for it, snatched the bill and fled. The prisoner having possession of the bill, there was no evidence that he had attempted to pass counterfeit money, and Justice HOGAN had no option but to entertain a complaint against him for grand larceny. He was committed in default of $1,000 bail.

abstract: the Franco-Danish Rebel Ram
snippet: the Franco-Danish Rebel Ram
lead_paragraph: -- Our Paris correspondent supplies us to-day with sundry particulars of great interest relative to the agency employed to smuggle the iron-clad ram Olinda within reach of the clutches of rebel agents, while the craft was, ostensibly, being transferred from the hands of her French builder into those of her so-called Danish owners. It seems the enterprising person to whom this task was intrusted by M. ARMAN, the builder of the ram, was M. DE LA RIVIERE, who was formerly known here in connection with ship-building contracts for the Italian Government. He is known in Paris now as one of the shrewdest as well as the most ardent sympathizers with the rebellion in Europe. And his game, in this instance, lay mainly in having the vessel land at Copenhagen in such a condition that it should at once be rejected by the Danish Government. Whether he has so managed matters that neither the Government of France nor that of Denmark can be held to accountability for the appearance of this new scourge, we shall learn anon.

abstract: -- At about 11 o'clock on Saturday night PHILIP HANOVAN was shot in the abdomen by JOHN MCCARTHY, in a quarrel in Grand-street, near Elm. MCCARTHY fled, and HANOVAN was taken by the Fourteenth Precinct police to the New-York Hospital, where he died early yesterday morning. MCCARTHY was apprehended yesterday by Officers MCGLOIN and CAMPBELL, and surrendered to Coroner WILDEY, who held an inquest last evening. He was formerly a member of Fire Engine Company No. 40, a company which was recently disbanded for rioting.

abstract: Swindling his Government
snippet: Swindling his Government
lead_paragraph: Dispatches from Gen. GRANT to Secretary STANTON, containing extracts from the Richmond papers of Saturday, give the cheering news that SHERMAN has captured Columbia, South Carolina, and is there with his whole army. The probably immediate evacuation of Charleston is announced, and a dispatch from the Charleston Mercury states that the publication of that paper will be suspended for a short time, until the office can be removed to another place. The Richmond papers seem to be in the dark as to the future movements of SHERMAN's army, but think that he may go to Charlotte, N.C. They say that he may possibly establish a new base at Charleston, but think it is needless for him to have any base, as he is living on the country, and has fought no battle that would diminish his supply of ammunition. The "brag" appears to have been entirely taken out of the Southern journals, their tone being despondent, and conveying the impression that they believe SHERMAN can go where he chooses, consuiting only his own convenience. BEAUREGARD had retreated before the advance of SHERMAN, destroying large quantities of medical stores; but no intimations are given as to the direction taken by his forces. It is evident that SHERMAN will now sweep through the States of South and North Carolina unopposed, completely destroying the main lines of communication with the beleaguered capital of Virginia, and join GRANT by Spring in the final struggle with the only organized rebel force in the whole South.

abstract: The Phare de la Loire says, that the suspicious of the French Government has been excited as to the real character of the steam ram Olinde, which recently arrived at the Isle of Houat, under the Danish flag, and left again after receiving a quantity of coals from the French tug Expeditif, and transferring to the latter the Danish crew of forty-two persons.
lead_paragraph: The Phare de la Loire says, that the suspicious of the French Government has been excited as to the real character of the steam ram Olinde, which recently arrived at the Isle of Houat, under the Danish flag, and left again after receiving a quantity of coals from the French tug Expeditif, and transferring to the latter the Danish crew of forty-two persons. Some of the crew recognized the Olinde as an iron-clad ram recently constructed at Bordeaux for Denmark, and they state that soon after leaving the Olinde they saw an English steamer approach her and transfer on board a great number of large cases and barrels. One of the officers on board the Olinde offered the crew of the Expeditif 175f. per month to serve on board the ram, first to Lisbon and thence for a five-month's voyage. The stoker and a sailor accepted the offer, but when the latter found the Olinde was a a war vessel, and that all the men on board were armed with revolvers, cutlasses, &c., he jumped into a boat and succeeded in getting back to the Expeditif. The real character of the Olinde will, no doubt, soon be ascertained. The crew of the Olinde are generally of opinion that she is a Confederate cruiser.

abstract: Fall of; Hanavan Shot by McCarthy in Self-defence; Campaign--Columbia fall off
snippet: Fall of; Hanavan Shot by McCarthy in Self-defence; Campaign--Columbia fall off
lead_paragraph: South Carolina lies at the feet of Gen. SHERMAN, and at the mercy of the victorious army of the Union. Our invincible soldiers are encamped in its capital, after having overcome its hideous swamps and morasses, traversed and laid under contribution its richest and most populous districts, seized its railroad centres and destroyed its railroads, driven and dispersed its blustering defenders led by the prince of blusterers, freed its slaves and doubtless armed thousands of them, and borne the flag through every obstruction, till at last they planted it on the top of the State House, where treason wae first formulated into law. It was on Friday last that BEAUREGARD marched out of Columbia and SHERMAN marched in. No defence whatever was made of the Capital, although only a few days before the official organ of the State had promised us that it should be the last ditch.

abstract: The United States steam-frigate Wabash, recently arrived from the bombardment of Fort Fisher, has been taken to the upper shears and wharf for a thorough overhauling. The Connecticut, Capt. BOGGS, is ready for service. The Dacotah, Paul Jones, Kearsarge and National Guard are undergoing repairs. The Wachusett has just coaled. The bark Kemlin is loading shot and shell for Fortress Monroe and Charleston Bar. The Niphon is ready for sea. The United States ship Nightingale sold at auction to the highest bidder, a week ago Saturday, for $10,000. The yard employs 4,821 artisans, who received for the month of January $312 817 82. The total expenditures of the yard for that month were $319,721 32.

abstract: In the Senate, yesterday, a resolution was introduced, and ordered to be printed, to regulate and equalize the expenses of assessors of internal revenue for clerks and stationery. The resolution of thanks to Gen. THOMAS with an amend-...
lead_paragraph: In the Senate, yesterday, a resolution was introduced, and ordered to be printed, to regulate and equalize the expenses of assessors of internal revenue for clerks and stationery. The resolution of thanks to Gen. THOMAS with an amendment giving thanks also to Admiral LEE, was reported from the Military Committee. A reconsideration of the vote on the Army Appropriation Bill was moved for the purpose of reconsidering the vote by which Mr. TRUMBULL's amendment, removing all distinctions of rank and pay between regular and volunteer officers, was passed. After considerable discussion, Mr. TRUMBULL's amendment, as originally incorporated in the bill, was rejected. An amendment to increase the pay of officers and soldiers twenty per cent. was also rejected. Another amendment as an additional section to give the service-ration to volunteer as well as regular officers, which was rejected, and the bill was then passed.

abstract: and Harbor Defences
snippet: and Harbor Defences
lead_paragraph: When the news of BUTLER's defeat at Fort Fisher reached England, it was very scientifically proved that no bombardment of a fleet could seriously damage an earthwork well built and well armed. The capture of the fort, by showing the actual work done by PORTER's second bombardment, has dissipated another of the fallacies of European theories of war, and taught us and them a new lesson of the prodigious power and accuracy of our new artillery. All the guns but one on the sea face of Fort Fisher, it is now ascertained, were either disabled or dismounted by the heavy and accurate fire of the fleet. This is a lesson which we should apply in our harbor defences. We have been busy in this war attacking harbors, but in any war other than this the defence of our coast will be a point of considerable importance -- and the lesson of Fort Fisher must not be lost upon us.
