abstract: The system of bounty brokerage inaugurated in this city in 1863 has grown to be a business of no mean magnitude. In the Summer of that year parties bringing recruits received but $10 hand money. They are now getting $100. Under the palmy reign of Gen. SPINOLA, when it was only a question of bargain and sales between the broker and recruit, it was not a difficult thing for the former to so arrange matters as to send the latter penniless into the ranks. Although it cannot be said with truth that Gen. SPINOLA had anything to do with the "arrangement," still he proved a means to the end, and hundreds of poor fellows were swindled out of their just dues without his knowledge or consent. So flagrant became the abuse that the authorities at Washington were led to investigate the official transactions of the General, who, upon trial by court-martial, was acquitted of all complicity. The investigation, however, developed the fact that there were a number of men in the city who had banded themselves together for the purpose of wronging volunteers out of their bounties, and it was determined to stop further nefarious transactions by introducing stringent local measures. The State Legislature passed an act prohibiting brokers, in fact, any person, under a heavy fine, from taking men from this State to another for the purpose of enlistment, and the Common Council passed an ordinance prohibiting recruiting in the city for other localities. Unfortunately, so stringent were the provisions under the new law that honest brokers were included with the dishonest, and this class of people who had acted as semi Provost-Marshals, were thrown out of business. The result was trickery and complete dishonesty on the part of the brokers. They were under the suspicion of United States officials and the County Volunteer Committee, and in a short time became to be regarded as thieves and swindlers. Under such circumstances, it was not at all strange that the bounty brokers should band themselves together for the purpose of "running" men out of the State to localities where they could receive some compensation for their services. How well the combination succeeded, the efforts made by Supervisor BLUNT to fill our quota under the last call, before increased bounties were offered, will attest. When it is remembered that there are over two hundred "private recruiting establishments in the city in charge of brokers whose aggregate number is not less than three thousand, it can easily be seen what a powerful element the County Volunteer Committee had to contend with. Now, however, Supervisor BLUNT has partially modified his plan of attack on the brokers, and an honest man of that class is permitted to receive the premium due him for bringing a recruit. If Mr. BLUNT had been wise enough to have adopted this course three months ago our quota would have been filled. The moral of this story is that there is a difference between an honest man and a thief, and that Supervisor BLUNT heretofore has failed to observe the distinction.

abstract: Great Triumph of
snippet: Great Triumph of
lead_paragraph: SHERMAN marches like an Emperor. All the adverse elements and rebellious powers fly in confusion before him. After conquering the bogs of the State and outmanoeuvering the forces of the enemy, he planted his troops in the capital of South Carolina on Friday last; but he seems to have remained there only long enough to complete his work, and perhaps to offer up a Te Deum early on Sunday morning. For Lieut.-Gen. GRANT forwards to the War Department official rebel intelligence, published in the Richmond papers of yesterday, that upon Sunday SHERMAN's main force was striking north from Columbia, and was advancing toward Winnsboro, and toward Charlotte, in North Carolina, whither BEAUREGARD had fled. Another force had been also moved down the Charleston road, probably to threaten HARDEE, so as to hasten his evacuation of that city; and we have a brief but thrilling official dispatch from Admiral DAHLGREN, dated on Saturday last, that Charleston was then abandoned by the rebels, and that our forces were then on their way up to and into the city. Thus BEAUREGARD fled one direction and HARDEE in another; while the Southern papers show that those of the Palmetto chivalry who are not clad in gray, are fleeing westward into Georgia and eastward into North Carolina.

abstract: and Mining States of Mexico; Mining States; The French Designs on
snippet: and Mining States of Mexico; Mining States; The French Designs on
lead_paragraph: All that one can gather from the French and British press on the subject of the reduction of certain States of Mexico to French Provinces, is inconclusive, if not entirely bewildering. It seems that the first telegraphic statement of the case from this side of the Atlantic represented the negociations for the reported "cession" as having been made through a "Mr. GWIN," and the unknown agent at first made the story assume the character of a canard. The French official journal, after waiting the proper time for its cue, undertook to say that "all reports which have been circulated in regard to a cession made to France by Mexico, of Sonora and the other provinces, are absolute fabrications.
headline: {'main': 'France and the Mining States of Mexico.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'France and the Mining States of Mexico.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: Importation of
snippet: Importation of
lead_paragraph: The importation Of criminals to this country in the guise of emigrants, by the English authorities, or with their connivance, led us to call the attention of Congress to the necessity of legislation on this subject. We have reason to believe that beside the "ticket-of-leave" men imported to New-York, from time to time, from the prisons of London and Liverpool, there are large numbers of the criminal population of England and Ireland, not to speak of the continent of Europe, who yearly find their way to our shores, and swell the grand aggregate of vice and crime which exists among us. Now, though emigration is desirable, emigrants of this kind are not. If the criminal character was transformed by its transference to America, we might permit it to come here; but unfortunately it is not, as the records of our courts and prisoners prove. The permitting of these criminal emigrants to come among us, is, moreover, of damage to the large body of emigrants of the respectable classes.
headline: {'main': 'IMPORTATION OF CRIMINALS', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'IMPORTATION OF CRIMINALS', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: THE NEW-YORK SEMI-WEEKLY TIMES is published THIS MORNING, and may be had at the counter of the publication office in wrappers ready for mailing. Price FIVE CENTS. In addition to the latest intelligence by telegraph up to the moment of going to press, there will be found in the current number full details of all military movements in the different departments from the pens of our special correspondents. Also, all official orders, reports and documents, and the latest and fullest Washington news, European news, with graphic letters from our correspondents in London and Paris, giving the tone of public feeling abroad, is made a special and permanent feature. In addition to Editorials on all the current topics of the day, the SEMI-WEEKLY TIMES has a page of carefully prepared commercial matter, giving the latest financial news and market reports: items of agricultural and domestic interest, compiled from sources many of which are otherwise inaccessible to the American reader; and marriages and deaths of the week.

snippet: Forty-ninth-street, Incendiary--$400; Howe, J B, Arrested for Breaking Agreement with Lingard; East Houston-street--$1,000; What are the only Legal
lead_paragraph: ARREST OF AN ACTOR. -- Mr. J.B. HOWE, the leading business actor attached to the New Bowery Theatre, was arrested on Saturday noon, while stepping on board the steamer City of London, just as it was about to leave for England, on a warrant issued by Judge MCCUNN, upon complaint of J.W. LINGARD, Esq., proprietor of the theatre, with whom Mr. HOWE had entered into a written agreement for three years. It is charged that the latter had become involved in debt to Mr. LINGARD. He was completely taken by surprise when arrested on the steamer by Mr. LINGARD, who accompanied the officer, and at first, stoutly refused to leave the ship, but subsequently allowed himself to be placed in Ludlow-street Jail, where he is now confined. Mr. HOWE was accompanied by his lady, who has postponed her return to England for the present. Mr. LINGARD has commenced a suit for $6,000 damages for breach of agreement.

abstract: The vessels composing this immense fleet, transporting 31,000 bales of Upland and Sea Island cotton from Savannah to this port, are arriving daily. Mr. SIMEON DRAPER, of this city, is the Government consignee of the cotton, which is being stored at the two large Government storehouses at Quarantine, and also in a large number of sheds which are being erected temporarily for that purpose at the same place. Three more vessels arrived yesterday, the bark Savannah, and the steamers May Flower and Commander. It is ascertained that the schooner Boyce, one of the fleet, is ashore off Cape Henlopen, having been driven there by the gale of the 12th inst., which it will be remembered scattered the entire fleet. The following is a correct list of the vessels of the cotton fleet arrived up to date:

abstract: The plaintiff in this action claimed to recover damages against the city to the amount of $5,000 for the destruction of his property, consisting of an extensive tenement-house, situated on Thirty-second-street, between Sixth and Seventh avenues. The testimony given in the case tended to show that the mob, on the second day of the riots, entered the premises and destroyed gas fixtures, Croton water fixtures, a quantity of furniture, and then set fire to the buildings. A part of the tenement house was occupied by colored persons, and it was the determination of the rioters to destroy all that portion of the premises occupied by that class of people. One witness testified that on the morning of the day in question, a colored person was hanged in the neighborhood, and that the excitement was such that it was not safe to remain anywhere in the vicinity unless a person joined the rioters.

abstract: DIED IN THE CELLS.--Coroner FARREBL, of Jersey City, held an inquest yesterday on the body of a man named JAMES O'NEIL, who was found in the streets suffering from delirium tremens. He was taken to the Station-house and medical aid was procured: but he died soon after being admitted.
lead_paragraph: DIED IN THE CELLS. -- Coroner FARREBL, of Jersey City, held an inquest yesterday on the body of a man named JAMES O'NEIL, who was found in the streets suffering from delirium tremens. He was taken to the Station-house and medical aid was procured; but he died soon after being admitted.

abstract: The steamship China arrived at this port last evening. The steamship Nova Scotian arrived at Portland yesterday afternoon. The dates by the China are to the 12th -- four days later than those by the Saxonia. The Nova Scotian's dates are to the 10th. Interesting Parliamentary discussions -- though only of a brief character -- have taken place on American affairs, growing out of the relations of the United States and Canada. The tone adopted by Lord PALMERSTON is friendly to this country. An interesting series of State papers relative to the Canadian troublys had been laid before the British Parliament. Sensation rumors abounded in Paris relative to the nen-arrival here of a successor to M. MERCIER. These rumors, it will be seen, have found currency in England through the columns of the London Times and Globe. The steamship City of Boston had met with an accident to her machinery on the passage from Liverpool to Queenstown, and was compelled to put back. She would sail in a few days later than her advertised time, which was the 8th. Twenty-five guineas premium had been offered on the steamer United Kingdom, from the Clyde for this port. Some of the London papers indulge in curious speculations as to the probability of Mr. SEWARD taking the London mission. The Army and Navy Gazette believes that the appointment would aid the maintenance of a good understanding between the two countries; and pays a high tribute to the statesmanship of the Secretary. Cardinal WISEMAN by the latest report was still alive. Spain has forbidden the circulation of the Pope's Encyclical within her boundaries.

abstract: ED. -- A very unusual opportunity is presented to the citizens of New-York, and one that claims from all a mutual and hearty cooperation. To get one's coal at the actual cost of mining, transportation and delivery, will save at present prices, $3 50 to $4 50 per ton. by subscribing to the Consumer's Benefit Coal Company, No. 71 Broadway. This, as an investment, should not be overlooked, and then too the principle of thousands of people combining together on the mutual plan as joint partners, thereby becoming one great company of individuals in furnishing so indispensable an article as coal at cost, must make the enterprise what it deserves to be -- a great success. As this is the season of year when yearly supplies of coal are contracted for, for the coming year, we would advise all such consumers to unite with this company and secure their shares before it is too late. The coal is unsurpassed for manufacturing and domestic purposes. Its long use in our community proves that there is no better coal for making steam or for domestic use. Of the quality of the coal all who have used it agree that there is no better nor finer coal. The veins of coal lay between strata of rock (and not of dirt as is usually the case) and thereby comes out perfectly clean and pure. We welcome this movement as worthy the confidence and cooperation of all who desire a good investment, and believe that the cash dividends (after delivering the coal to the shareholders) on the sale of the remainder of the annual product of the colliery, will reimburse the original cost of subscription in less than two years. A word to the wise is sufficient. -- N.Y. World.

abstract: An official dispatch from Gen. GILLMORE states that Charleston fell into our possession on the morning of the 18th inst., with over two hundred pieces of artillery, (another account says that all the guns were spiked), and a supply of ammunition. The surrounding defences having been evacuated during the previous night by the rebel forces, the Mayor surrendered the city to the troops of Gen. SCHIMELFENING, who at once took possession.
lead_paragraph: An official dispatch from Gen. GILLMORE states that Charleston fell into our possession on the morning of the 18th inst., with over two hundred pieces of artillery, (another account says that all the guns were spiked), and a supply of ammunition. The surrounding defences having been evacuated during the previous night by the rebel forces, the Mayor surrendered the city to the troops of Gen. SCHIMELFENING, who at once took possession. The cotton warehouses, arsenal, Quartermaster's stores, railroad bridges, two iron-clads and several vessels in the ship-yard, were burned by the enemy. The railroad building contained 200 kegs of powder, which exploded with terrific effect, killing and wounding upwards of one hundred people. It is supposed that 6,000 bales of cotton were consumed in the warehouses. The dwelling houses in the lower part of the city were found to be completely riddled by our shot and shell. The wealthy part of the population had deserted the city, the poor who remained were suffering for want of food. The Stars and Stripes were raised over Fort Sumter by Capt. H.M. BRAGG.

lead_paragraph: we have used with such ability as we possessed the military and naval resources of the country in carrying this great war to the end, which we now appear to see shaping itself in no distant future, there have been many instances where the fate of the Republic has temporarily, at least, depended upon slight contingencies which could hardly have been foreseen -- much less prevented. When the Merrimac steamed out of Norfolk, the accidental presence of a small experimental vessel bound to Washington on a trial trip alone prevented a catastrophe, the extent and effect of which, at this period of time, we cannot possibly realize.

abstract: On War and Peace--His Letter on
snippet: On War and Peace--His Letter on
lead_paragraph: lish a letter written to a Baltimore lady, by Gen. SHERMAN, while he was conducting his great campaign in Georgia, last year. "Amid the sound of battle," he recalls to his correspondent the days long gone by, when he knew her as a school-girl playing on Sullivan's Island beach, near Charleston, and says that then he little dreamed that he should "control a vast army, pointing, like the swarm of Alaric, toward the plains of the South." "Why," he exclaims, "oh, why is this?" And he goes on to say that it is from no animosity toward the Southern people, though they call him "barbarian, vandal, monster, and all the epithets that language can invent, significant of malignity and hate." It is because of his devotion to the Government and to law -- because man must submit to some arbiter, and must not throw off his allegiance without just cause -- because the South bantered and bullied us to the conflict, and we were forced to accept battle, which, once begun, has gone on till the war has assumed proportions at which we stand aghast, but which, had we declined, America would have sunk back, coward and craven, meriting the contempt of all mankind. "God knows," he says, "how reluctantly we accepted the issue, but once the issue joined, like in other ages, the Northern race, though slow to anger, once aroused, are more terrible than the more inflammable of the South."

abstract: Testimony of his Death in Battle; Its Prestige,>amp;c.
snippet: Testimony of his Death in Battle; Its Prestige,>amp;c.
lead_paragraph: The Richmond journals recently made frequent quotation of a remark in our columns, that the greatest damage we could do to the rebel cause was a moral one, and as long as their "will was unbroken," our material successes could not subdue the country. They endeavored to strengthen the failing "will" of their people, and to demonstrate to them that while that remained impregnable all was not lost, and much might be regained. We still hold that the great power of a people is its moral power, and consists in "the mysterious and utterly immeasurable forces of the human will," rather than in population or wealth.

abstract: Cotton; Orders to Record Marks on
snippet: Cotton; Orders to Record Marks on
lead_paragraph: There are now in port twenty-one vessels of the first cotton fleet which sailed from Savannah, under the directions of Collector DRAPER. Most of them report having encountered severe storms, and none of them have arrived uninjured by the prevailing westerly gales. The value of cotton now in port and en route from Savannah will probably exceed $15,000,000. The vessels in the harbor have on board about 15,000 bales, valued at $5,000,000. The cotton arrived is being stored in the Government warehouses on Staten Island, and temporary buildings are being erected near Quarantine for the accommodation of cargoes not yet provided for. The revenue cutter Crawford, Capt. KELLOGG, will go down this morning, from the Navy-yard, to guard the cotton on Staten Island. No arrangements have been made for the sale of the article, and the probabilities are that the cotton now in store will remain in possession of the Government for several weeks. Many of the vessels recently arrived from Savannah, not being able to find dock accommodations at Staten Island, have anchored off Sandy Hook. Some are at Jersey City and others are lying in the stream. Although the weather since the sailing of the cotton fleet from Savannah has been the most severe experienced along the coast for years, still not one bale has been lost. It is stated in official circles that the Government is about to fit out another fleet, more extensive than the first, which will bring to this port all the cotton at the South now within our military lines.

abstract: In the Senate yesterday the committee to whom was referred the memorial of ANDREW J. WILCOX of Baltimore, asking that peace be made on the basis of the CRITTENDEN Compromise, requested to be relieved from further considieraton of the subject. A bill was reported amending the pension act so as to include within its provisions soldiers wounded while on picket-duty. A resolution was introduced creating the office of Solicitor and Naval Judge-Advocate-General. Other matters of minor importance occupied the attention of the Senate until the adjournment.

abstract: Three to four hundred Petroleum Bills (some days to 2400 a day) have passed, the Legislature reserving the power to amend or repeal the charters, limiting their existence to 30 years, and taxing each company $100 in advance. The corporations are no prohibited from running, after 30 years, railroads made by them under chartered grants; but nothing to prevent the Legislature's making railroads parallel with or crossing the corporations'.

abstract: Amos R. Willetts et al. vs. The Sun Mutual Insurance Company. -- This is an action to recover the sum of $1,480 damages, alleged to have been sustained by the plaintiffs on account of the injury done to 223 barrels of cider. The facts of the case are as follows: In December, 1863, the plaintiffs shipped at this port, for Washington, by the schooner Francis Satterly, the barrels of cider above mentioned. At the time of shipment, the plaintiff applied for and obtained from the Sun Mutual Insurance Company, a policy which guarantied all the risks incident to the sea. Before leaving the port of New York, and after the insurance was effected, the schooner Satterly became unseaworthy and the cider was transferred to the deck of the schooner Charles Demise. By the latter vessel the cider was conveyed to Washington. When it arrived there it was in a greatly damaged condition. The plaintiffs, by the advice of Mr. Whitehead, President of the Sun Mutual Insurance Company, had the cider gauged, inspected and sold upon its arrival in the City of Washington. There had been no notice given by the shippers or their agents of the transfer of the cargo. It was badly damaged and sold for much less than the value. The important question in the case is whether the plaintiffs can recover for partial loss of goods, insured on a specified vessel, when the goods were transferred to another vessel without the knowledge or consent of the insurers. The trial is exciting considerable interest and is not yet concluded.
lead_paragraph: Amos R. Willetts et al. vs. The Sun Mutual Insurance Company. -- This is an action to recover the sum of $1,480 damages, alleged to have been sustained by the plaintiffs on account of the injury done to 223 barrels of cider. The facts of the case are as follows: In December, 1863, the plaintiffs shipped at this port, for Washington, by the schooner Francis Satterly, the barrels of cider above mentioned. At the time of shipment, the plaintiff applied for and obtained from the Sun Mutual Insurance Company, a policy which guarantied all the risks incident to the sea. Before leaving the port of New York, and after the insurance was effected, the schooner Satterly became unseaworthy and the cider was transferred to the deck of the schooner Charles Demise. By the latter vessel the cider was conveyed to Washington. When it arrived there it was in a greatly damaged condition. The plaintiffs, by the advice of Mr. Whitehead, President of the Sun Mutual Insurance Company, had the cider gauged, inspected and sold upon its arrival in the City of Washington. There had been no notice given by the shippers or their agents of the transfer of the cargo. It was badly damaged and sold for much less than the value. The important question in the case is whether the plaintiffs can recover for partial loss of goods, insured on a specified vessel, when the goods were transferred to another vessel without the knowledge or consent of the insurers. The trial is exciting considerable interest and is not yet concluded.

abstract: The Memphis Bulletin learns from gentlemen who left Selma, Ala., on the 24th ult., and came through Meridian and Jackson, Miss., that DICK TAYLOR has a considerable force at Selma and also at Meridian. At Selma the rebels were manufacturing and turning out large quantities of munitions of war. Fortifications extend all around the place, but they are not very formidable. Most of HOOD's army had been sent to operate against SHERMAN. They were nearly naked and wholly dispirited, and had lost all hopes of successful resistance to the Federal troops. Large numbers were barefooted; and it is stated that ten thousand of HOOD's men had their feet frostbitten during their retreat from Nashville, in which they suffered more than during the previous three years. The slaveholders were greatly dissatisfied with the conscription of slaves and free negroes for service in the army; but the work was actively going on. Gen. FORREST was collecting a force at Jackson, Miss., for operations, it was said, against Vicksburgh. The Mississippi Legislature was to meet at Columbus on the 29th, and relieve the destitute people.

lead_paragraph: pondent of the Goldsboro (N.C.,) Journal has been getting information about the "Yankees" at Newbern, in a way that carries us back to the earlier part of the war, when "reliable gentlemen" saw the New-York "Fire Zouaves" spring like wildcats on the backs of the Virginia "Black Horse Cavalry," when the latter were going full speed, and cut the throats of the riders in a horrible manner. He says "he has just conversed with a reliable gentleman, who came in from the front yesterday, and who informs him that he had had an interview with a lady who was within the enemy's camp on Thursday, and from what she could learn while there, it is her opinion that the Yankees are preparing to move in force against Weldon," &c., &c.

abstract: Treatment of South Carolina by; Treason--Sherman's Treatment
snippet: Treatment of South Carolina by; Treason--Sherman's Treatment
lead_paragraph: The march of Gen. SHERMAN through South Carolina is attended with none of the ravage predicted by all the rebels, and hoped for by many loyal men. So far as can be gathered from the few general facts that have reached us, our army is displaying no vindictive spirit whatever. Moving without any base of supplies, it of course must, of necessity, live mainly upon the country it traverses, and this involves extensive seizures of food for man and beast. But even the rebel newspapers do not represent that there is any wanton destruction, or any attempt of any kind to make the scourge of war fall with needless severity. The army holds on its resistless way in order and sobriety, pervaded with no other than the military spirit, seeking no other than military ends. The soldierly discipline and the generous personal bearing which so marked it in Georgia, are again exhibited in the same high degree in South Carolina. So far as is yet developed, there is no distinction in the treatment of the two States.

abstract: Lazarus Murder; Friery Sentenced to be Hung
snippet: Lazarus Murder; Friery Sentenced to be Hung
lead_paragraph: The announcement that Bernard Friary would be sentenced yesterday attracted an immense crowd to the Court of Sessions. Every one who had influence enough to pass the stern guardians of the outer door crowded into the room, and gratified a morbid curiosity by staring at the prisoner. Friary was brought to the bar about 11 o'clock, and took a scat between Mr. Sedgwick and Judge Stewart, his counsel. The prisoner seemed to be nervous and somewhat affected by the imminent danger of his situation. Few friendly faces greeted him, out of all the dense mass that surrounded him. Although treated with the utmost kindness by the Sheriff and his deputies, he seemed to realize that he was a doomed man, whom the world looked upon as justly condemned to death.

abstract: The First and Greatest Victories; I propose to move immediately on your Works
snippet: The First and Greatest Victories; I propose to move immediately on your Works
lead_paragraph: Measured by its effect upon the heart and temper of the loyal people of these States, there is probably no victory of the war that can be compared with that which was won by the stubborn valor of our troops on the 16th day of February, 1862. That day, like many a preceding one in our experience of the war, had opened dark, gloomy, lowering. Many of the best and most devoted friends of the Republic had begun to despond over the reverses which seemed to have no turning tide. At home there was an apparent indigence in everything like skillful enterprise or thorough executive action in our military leaders. Abroad there were thrown at us, from every quarter, taunts and jeers which were altogether ill to be borne. On all sides the prospect was as cheerless for the national cause as it well could have been. How much more of misadventure, of ill-success, or of sluggish routine, the nation could have borne before giving up its title to existence, we cannot presume to conjecture. Happily, the test of endurance to be applied to loyal men had been reached before that gloomy 16th day of February had closed. It was on that memorable date that Brig.-Gen. U.S. GRANT sent from his headquarters the following dispatch addressed to Gen. BUCKNER, commanding the rebel forces holding Fort Donelson.

lead_paragraph: In compliance with the order of Assistant Provost-Marshal-General HINKS, the draft began yesterday morning in the Second and Third Congressional Districts. In the Second District Provost-Marshal WALDRON, at No. 29 Grand-street, E. D., set his wheel in motion at about 10 1/2 o'clock, in the presence of a large crowd who did not allow their fear of conscription to affect their good nature. The arrangements were excellent, and as the names were called, if the elected party happened to be present, as was the case in several instances, there was much mirth at his expense. From the town of New-Lotts, there were seventy-four conscripts taken, and from the Sixth Ward of Brooklyn, 450, being a number sufficient to fill all existing deficiencies on the basis of 75 per centum of the quota fixed on the 24th of January, ult., and 100 per centum in addition to the actual number of men required, so as to provide for contingencies of disability, absence and so forth.

abstract: the Last Humiliation of (Arming Slaves)
snippet: the Last Humiliation of (Arming Slaves)
lead_paragraph: The Richmond papers announce that Virginia has determined to give its able-bodied slaves to the military service of the Confederacy. It has cost the public mind of the State tremendous throes to come to this. Desperation alone has made it possible. A very peculiar desperation, too. It is not that sort which has a certain reason in it and would make the most of even the smallest chance to escape from an extremity, but the desperation of the scorpion girt with fire that turns and stings itself to death. It is no sublime audacity; it is insensate and abject despair.

abstract: A grand military and civil reunion, being the second annual ball of the New York Thirty-seventh National Guard, Company K, was given on Tuesday evening at the Everett Rooms, corner of Broadway and Thirty-fourth-street. There was a brilliant throng of ladies and gentlemen present, who joined in the dance until 12 o'clock, when an elegant supper was served in the dining-room adjoining the hall. At the conclusion of the repast, the company repaired to the ball-room, where the festivities of the occasion were kept up until a late hour. Among the distinguished guests present were Gen. HALL, Gen. SANFORD, Col. ASHLEY, Col. ROOME, Maj. CATLIN, Capt. BLAKE, Capt. ELLIS, and others.

abstract: George Steers, Pilot-boat; Apparent Loss of
snippet: George Steers, Pilot-boat; Apparent Loss of
lead_paragraph: The pilot-boat George Steers has been missing since the gale of the 12th inst., and information has lately been received in this city which renders her total loss almost a matter of certainty. The last pilot was put out from her on the 11th inst., off Cape May. During the gale of the 12th inst., a pilot[???]at was seen on the South Shoals near Barnegat. At daylight, the next morning, she appeared to be almost a wreck, all her masts having gone. On the 14th inst. a surf boat was enabled to get to her, but there was nothing of her left but a piece of the deck, some spars and rigging.

abstract: Admiral PORTER officially reports to the Navy Department, under date of Feb. 19, the evacuation of Fort Anderson on the night of the 18th, and its occupation by our troops on the morning of the 19th. On the 17th, Gen. SCHOFIELD, with a force of 8,000 men, moved up from Smithville and at the same time, Admiral PORTER attacked the fort with a portion of his fleet, the monitor Monadnock being placed closed to the works, and other vessels pouring in an enfilading fire. On the 18th, the fleet moved up still closer, and kept up a heavy fire during the day, silencing the fort by 3 o'clock. In the meantime Gen. SCHOFIELD moved around in the rear of the rebels, but they didn't wait to get caught, and hastily evacuated the fort during the night, leaving the heavy guns, mostly unspiked. Our troops entered at daylight on the morning of the 19th, and raised the Stars and Stripes over the works. Our loss was only three killed and four wounded. Lieut. CUSHING, bearer of dispatches to Washington, states that the army was moving on toward Wilmington. He also states that there is only one line of obstructions in the river above the fort, and that it is not defended by batteries.

abstract: Celebration and Municipal Faith; Filth of
snippet: Celebration and Municipal Faith; Filth of
lead_paragraph: The condition of the streets is simply horrible. We have had four or five days of as fine February weather as the present generation has seen. Yesterday, as far as a genial sunshine, and a healthy breeze go to constitute a luxury for holiday-makers, was one of the most charming days that imagination could well paint. And yet here, in New-York, with its expenditure of fifteen millions a year for cleanliness, safety, health and comfort, all that the smiling season had so bountifully contributed to the enjoyment of the day was marred and blurred by the foul surgings of corporation filth in every thoroughfare and alley-way of the city. Along the street-gutters, from river to river, and from the South Ferry to Harlem, composite piles of ice and muck, alternated with a blubbery stagnant Styx of liquid mud.
headline: {'main': 'National Celebrations and Municipal Filth.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'National Celebrations and Municipal Filth.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

BARNUM will repeat his lecture on the "Art of Money Getting," at Prof. MATTISON's Church, this evening....Dr. GARRISH will lecture on the all important subject of Vaccination, at the College of Physicians and Surgeons, corner of Fourth-avenue and Twenty-third street, on Friday evening, the 24th inst. Students of medicine, and all persons who take an interest in this subject, are invited to attend....Our readers who desire tickets for the Charity Ball, which takes place next Monday, will do well to apply at once to the managers, in whose hands they are, as, judging from the fabulous prices which are offered for the boxes, the tickets will be at a similar premium within a day or two....Dr. DRAPER will deliver the third of his series of lectures before the Historical Society this evening. abstract: Victories and Washington's Birthday Celebration of; Washington's Birthday and National Victories' Celebration; Celebrations
snippet: Victories and Washington's Birthday Celebration of; Washington's Birthday and National Victories' Celebration; Celebrations
lead_paragraph: Thunders of artillery, early yesterday morning, ushered in the One Hundred and Thirty-third Anniversary of the Birth of the Father of the Republic, and the echoes of these salutes, reverberating throughout the land, told to the listener a two-fold story -- the story of undiminished reverence and love still felt by a grateful nation for the memory of the pure patriot who guided it through the storms of the Revolution, and during the feebleness of infancy; and that other story of to-day, illustrious forever, of the triumph of those principles of patriotism and union inculcated by WASHINGTON, which we have been struggling to maintain. The manner in which the day was celebrated yesterday will long be remembered. The last four anniversaries of the event have been more or less overshadowed by gloom and doubts. The curse seemed to have fallen upon us; the blessings of peace, union and prosperity, which WASHINGTON left to us as an inheritance, seemed to have departed, and none could hopefully predict the time of their return. But the spirit of the people yesterday evinced a change, and, except among the few who wished it otherwise, the general opinion was that our days of trial were almost over. Four years ago Charleston resounded with noisy boasts that she would make herself the great commercial emporium of the American continent, and that her citizens, attracted by curiosity as tourists go to Rome, would come to New-York to see streets overgrown with grass and a city in ruins, bewailing the day when it offended South Carolina. Yesterday saw Charleston as black, desolate and uninhabitable a waste as the Cities of the Plain, and New-York one of the richest, most prosperous, gayest cities in the world, dressed out with streaming banners, pealing with joyous bells, brilliant with military pageants, commemorating the triumph of justice and truth over the miserably wicked folly of treason.

abstract: Enlistments in United States Army from
snippet: Enlistments in United States Army from
lead_paragraph: In the Senate, yesterday, a resolution was reported to increase the compensation of naval contractors. Mr. TRUMBULL, from the Committee on the Judiciary, asked to be relieved from further consideration of petitions asking for a recognition of the Supreme Being in the Constitution of the United States. Reports were received from the Naval Committee, adverse to propositions amending the Constitution so as to permit Congress to tax imports, and in regard to the basis of representation recently proposed by Mr. SUMNER. A joint resolution was reported from the Military Committee concerning the enlargement of the Illinois and Michigan Canal, and the improvement of the Upper and Lower Mississippi River, and that of the Fox and Wisconsin Rivers. A bill amendatory of the Copyright Law was passed. The bill to establish a uniform militia throughout the United States was reported back, with a recommendation that it be passed. The bill establishing an Eastern Judicial District in New-York was passed. The Freedman's Bureau was under consideration, and resulted in the rejection of the report of the Committee of Conference on that subject. The Senate insisted on its amendment to the original bill, and another Committee Conference was called for.

abstract: Last Ditchites at Charleston, >amp;c.; Letter to Chicago Lady Managers
snippet: Last Ditchites at Charleston, >amp;c.; Letter to Chicago Lady Managers
lead_paragraph: The celebration of WASHINGTON's Birthday was observed in this city yesterday with unusually imposing demonstrations. The fall of Charleston added to the enthusiasm of the people, which was expressed by one of the finest displays of bunting ever witnessed in this city. Flags were displayed from public and private buildings, and from the shipping in the harbor. Several regiments paraded, and in the evening fireworks were exhibited in several parts of the city. The streets were thronged by citizens, who congratulated each other upon the fall of Charleston, and spent the day in social enjoyments.

abstract: NIBLO's GARDEN. -- The "Belle's Stratagem" was produced here on Monday night with fair success. Mrs. LANDER is an admirable Letitia Hardy. The various phases of the character are interpreted by her with an earnest delicacy which no other actress now on the stage can even pretend to impart to them. Mrs. LANDER was substantially supported by Mr. WHEATLEY as Doricourt. The part requires a versatile artist, and one who is also volatile. Mr. WHEATLEY cannot be accused of possessing the latter quality, but he is certainly versatile, and his performance was artistic and good. The general distribution was excellent. We have seldom seen Messrs. POPE, BURNETT, COLLIER and BECKS to such advantage. The comedy was received with decided favor.
lead_paragraph: NIBLO's GARDEN. -- The "Belle's Stratagem" was produced here on Monday night with fair success. Mrs. LANDER is an admirable Letitia Hardy. The various phases of the character are interpreted by her with an earnest delicacy which no other actress now on the stage can even pretend to impart to them. Mrs. LANDER was substantially supported by Mr. WHEATLEY as Doricourt. The part requires a versatile artist, and one who is also volatile. Mr. WHEATLEY cannot be accused of possessing the latter quality, but he is certainly versatile, and his performance was artistic and good. The general distribution was excellent. We have seldom seen Messrs. POPE, BURNETT, COLLIER and BECKS to such advantage. The comedy was received with decided favor.

abstract: Lecture, "Our Country"
snippet: Lecture, "Our Country"
lead_paragraph: Although all the seats in the Brooklyn Academy of Music, excepting a few in the upper gallery, had been engaged in advance, the audience began to assemble a full hour before the appointed time, and very early the spacious hall was completely filled. Directly over the stage hung the glorious Stars and Stripes, bearing the words now beginning to have a vital meaning, "The Union," together with a portrait of the Father of his Country. Among the persons upon the platform were AARON M. POWELL, Rev. Dr. HATFIELD, Mayor WOOD, WENDELL PHILLIPS GARVIN, and others. At the appointed hour, the orator of the evening entered, accompanied by THEODORE TILTON, by whom he was introduced.

abstract: Gen Sherman
snippet: Gen Sherman
lead_paragraph: Gen. SHERMAN's army is now on the verge of North Carolina, if it is not already within the lines of the State. We hear of no frantic proclamations from the Governor, no "last ditch" resolutions from the Legislature which is in session, no wild appeals from popular leaders or from the press; but the whole people, as far as we have heard, seem to await the advance of SHERMAN's invincible army with perfect composure, if not with torpor. In the meantime a private letter has been received from Gen. SHERMAN himself, of which our Washington correspondent made mention yesterday, in which the General says that the people of the "Old North State" are prepared to hail the advent of his army among them, and promptly wheel the State into the Union. Gen. SHERMAN does not speak at random, nor without full and definite information concerning that of which he writes. He is not a sanguine man, nor one who is ever led away by his fancy. He knows the Southern people well from long residence in various parts of the South before the war, and from campaigning in nine of the Southern States during the past four years. He has never expressed himself in the same way about any other State.

abstract: -- What has become of those valiant South Carolina heroes who have been proclaiming their determination to die in the last ditch, and never, never, NEVER surrender to the Yankee invaders? We don't hear a syllable of one of them. None of our official bulletins make any mention of the discovery of their remains. The chivalry of Charleston seem to have shown quite as much alacrity in running away as any of the more ordinary and common-place specimens of the human race. They began to "evacuate," we are told, about three weeks before our army approached. This was discretion, -- decidedly the better part of their valor. There is a great deal of human nature in South Carolina, after all.

abstract: Praed, W M; Poems; Mattie--a Story
snippet: Praed, W M; Poems; Mattie--a Story
lead_paragraph: Twenty-five years after the death of the writer, appears the first authentic collection of his poetical remains. It seems to have been retarded by the illness and death of Mr. PRAED's widow, as well as by the desire to make the edition as perfect as existing materials would admit. It now appears, superintended by the daughters of the poet, and inscribed to the memory of his widow, by whom some of his most beautiful verses were inspired in the first buoyancy of happy wedded life. PRAED's friends and school-fellows have all done their part, not less by identifying fugitive pieces of his composition, than by clearing away a mass of poems, the production of an imitator, wrongly attributed to him. The memoir, written by DERWENT COLERIDGE, has the sole disadvantage of being too brief, when looked at as the only record we are likely to receive of one that the world would willingly know more of. It is a matter of notoriety, that while this English edition has been in preparation, five or six different impressions of the poems, selected on internal evidence only, from the periodical literature of the day, were published in America. That the wide circulation they met with has kept alive the poet's fame, and perhaps been the means of procuring us this edition of his authentic versions, it is impossible to doubt. The fact, indeed, is acknowledged in the editor's notice. The poems themselves are too familiar to the American public to need criticism here. Many of those, however, now first published, show the versatility of the writer, and his power over the elements of feeling and pathos, in a higher degree than would be supposed possible by readers acquainted only with the gaiety and brillancy of his more widely-known compositions. If ever there was a born poet, it was certainly PRAED. What such natural and instinctive gifts and graces might have ripened into with genial culture, it is now impossible to say. By a strange perversity of judgment, it seems to have been the sole aim of his family and friends to convert a heaven-born poet into a middling second or third-rate politician and orator. They succeeded, indeed, but at the expense of the life of PRAED, who died confessedly from the injurious effects of late Parliamentary hours and over-exertion in political and legal affairs, on a frame always weak and delicate. Never was there a more complete realization of RETSCHZ's drawing, "Pegasus in Harness," and there was the less excuse for it, because he belonged to a wealthy family, and was always amply provided for. It is a striking instance of the absolute want of any status in society conferred by literature in England -- the old complaint of men of letters, from POPE to THACKE[???]AY. It is easy to imagine how differently would have passed the poet's career in France There his exquisite talents, expanding in the warmth of genial appreciation, would have placed him on a height that politicians might in vain aspire to reach. Everything told us about the man is in keeping with his writings, and creates a desire for further revelations of his literary and social life. Prophecies are proverbially in safe, but it may be that when TENNYSON and BROWNING occupy the relative position to future generations that COWLEY and DONNE do to us, and are unintelligible without glossaries and commentators, thousands will delight in the sunny clearness and brilliancy, the airy fancy and unequaled felicity of diction, that distinguish the poems of WINTHROP MACKWORTH PRAED.

abstract: -- Probably no community in our land was ever in such wretched destitution as the people of Charleston. Plundered and oppressed by four years of rebel rule, their supplies exhausted, they have now been visited, through the cruelty of the rebel officers, by a devastating fire, which has laid waste the city. Enemies though they are, we cannot see them suffer. The aged and the helpless must not perish. The Union Commission takes the matter in hand, and its agent, MAHLON T. HEWITT, Esq., goes gratuitously on this errand of mercy on the first Government steamer. All who are disposed to aid this work of kindness may send money to A.V. STOUT, Esq.,Treasurer of the commission, at the Shoe and Leather Bank, No. 271 Broadway. Supplies of clothing, bedding, food and cooking utensils sent to the office of the commission, at No. 14 Bible-House, will be immediately forwarded.

abstract: Among the persons whom Col. BAKER has recently arrested is a young man of highly respectable connections in Brooklyn, whose name is at present withheld from the public. The accused, who is now an inmate of the Old Capitol Prison, never distinguished himself in any useful labor, and commonly associated with Brooklyn good-for-nothings, and expended ...
lead_paragraph: Among the persons whom Col. BAKER has recently arrested is a young man of highly respectable connections in Brooklyn, whose name is at present withheld from the public. The accused, who is now an inmate of the Old Capitol Prison, never distinguished himself in any useful labor, and commonly associated with Brooklyn good-for-nothings, and expended upon them the small sums which father gave him, until about eight months ago he struck a hidden and auriferous vein, and, Aladdin-like, suddenly leaped into a princely income. He forsook the Brooklyn bloods, betook himself to stylish teams, purchased an ambitious mansion on the aristocratic Heights, dressed elaborately, was lavish in gifts, particularly to his immediate relatives, giving his cousins of the fair sex hundred-dollar hats, and renting for them a costly pew in one of Brooklyn's most fashionable churches; briefly, be enacted the part of a prince to a charm. Last Saturday he became invisible to the public eye, and by to-morrow he may beast a wider notoriety than he could have gained if Col. BAKER's detective officers had permitted him longer to tarry among our neighbors over the river. Every dollar of his new-found riches came from bounty-brokerage frauds.

abstract: The Art National Association of New-York, No. 561 Broadway, have just published a very fine engraving of the celebrated Picture, "WASHINGTON Receiving a Salute on the Field of Trenton." The original picture is the joint production of Mr. J. FAHD, R.S.A., and R. ANSDELL, R.A., and represents the hero seated on his favorite charger, receiving the salute of the passing troops. The engraving, which is of large size, is the work of Mr. WILLIAM HOLL, who has been engaged upon it for several years. It is in the highest style of art, and Mr. HOLL has succeeded in transferring to his engraving all the spirit and beauty of the original picture. The directors of the association have received numerous testimonials to the beauty and fidelity of the work, and, among others, from EDWARD EVERETT, Prof. LONGFELLOW, Secretary SEWARD, Gen. SCOTT and FRED. E. CHURCH, the well-known artist. The painting can be seen at the rooms of the association. This is the first engraving issued by the association. It will be followed annually by others equal in merit.

abstract: -A contractor in Washington has just been giving a "splurgy" party, supposed to have cost $100,000. Some of our neighbors, we observe, are improving the occasion to denounce all contractors, and especially to protest against listening to their appeals to Congress for relief. This is unjust and foolish. Beyond all doubt, many contractors have made very large sums of money on their contracts. Those of them, especially, who had the monopoly of certain articles which the Government was compelled to purchase, such as certain patented cannon, for example, were in position to make enormous profits, and they have undoubtedly availed themselves of their opportunity. If they choose to spend their money in ridiculous displays and foolish entertainments, very well. That may be a most excellent reason against their being "relieved" by further grants of money from the public treasury.

abstract: Suggestions
snippet: Suggestions
lead_paragraph: -- The idea is well conceived to have the approaching 4th of March set apart as a day of national rejoicings. The recent victories achieved by the national army, and especially the surrender of Charleston, demand a celebration which shall be if possible, simultaneous, imposing and universal throughout the loyal States of the Union. It is to this end that the meeting of Wednesday and the adjourned meeting of yesterday in the Collector's office were summoned to deliberate, and we have no doubt that the influential committee named to carry out the objects of the meeting, will be able to report not only the hearty cooperation of all the loyal citizens of New-York, but a hearty sympathy and communion of purpose in all the great cities of the North.

abstract: Weeks and McKeever, in New-York, for $2,000; Connecticut Championship; Hubbell and Hunt
snippet: Weeks and McKeever, in New-York, for $2,000; Connecticut Championship; Hubbell and Hunt
lead_paragraph: One of the most interesting and exciting billiard matches that ever occurred in this city, came of in the new hall connected with Messrs. GOLDTHWAIT & CAHILL's establishment, Sixth-avenue and Thirteeth-street, commencing at 8 o'clock on Monday evening. The contestants were Messrs. WEEKS and MCKEEVER, two prominent members of base ball clubs, the former one of the best amateur billiard players in the country and the latter "no muff" in handling the cue. The match was as much a test of physical endurance as a contest at billiards, it being on thirty-seven games of one hundred points each. Mr. WEEKS giving the odds of "double discount." The game was around the table, viz.: The full game, except a ball, could be held once only from the spot.

LEE had attacked Gen. GRANT's army, and that our troops had met with a reverse. abstract: ACADEMY OF MUSIC. -- VERDI's latest Opera, "La Forza del Destino" will be produced here to-night for the first time in America. It has been in preparation for some time, and has been rehearsed with great care. Owing to Mr. MARETZEK's energy and enterprise, we have again an opportunity of hearing an important work prior to its production either in London or Paris. "La Forza del Destino" was written for St. Petersburgh, and was produced there with success. It was then given at Madrid, where a very favorable verdict was recorded in its avor. Both these cities are small compared with New-York, and the echoes which we catch from them are never of much importance. The career of VERDI's Opera begins from to-night. If "La Forza" is successful in New-York, its production in London and Paris will be vastly accelerated. We are at all events certain that the work will speedily occupy a prominent place in our reportoire.

abstract: In the Senate yesterday, an adverse report was made by the Committee on Naval Affairs on the petition for an increase in officers pay. A bill to extend to settlers on railroad ands the benefit of the Homestead Act, was reported on adversely.
lead_paragraph: In the Senate yesterday, an adverse report was made by the Committee on Naval Affairs on the petition for an increase in officers pay. A bill to extend to settlers on railroad ands the benefit of the Homestead Act, was reported on adversely. The bill was passed. A bill reorganizing the New-York Appraiser's Office was passed after some discussion. A number of bills were reported from the Committee on Commerce and were advanced a stage. Among others, one amendatory of the act to prevent frauds by false invoices, and relative to the verification of invoice by our consuls. Before the House rose, the Amendatory Enrollment Bill was taken up, and an amendment moved by Mr. BLAINE of Maine, providing that no credits shall be given except the men are actually furnished on present and future calls and mustered into the service of the United States, was ultimately passed by a vote of 83 to 64.

abstract: Capt. BEALL, the Lake Erie pirate, who is under sentence of death and would have been executed on Saturday, the 18th inst., but for informality in the warrant for execution, is to be hanged to-day, between twelve and two o'clock, on Governor's Island, provided the President does not grant a reprieve. The gallows to be used on the occasion is the same on which several criminals have been hanged, and upon which the slave-trader GORDON explated his crimes, was sent from the Tombs to the island yesterday. The execution will probably take place at high noon. Very few spectators, aside from the soldiery and representatives of the press, will be present.

abstract: The Decline in
snippet: The Decline in
lead_paragraph: -We trust our people will be under no unnecessary anxiety for a more speedy decline in the price of gold. It goes down regularly and steadily, just as public confidence in the overthrow of the rebellion goes up. Every Union victory puts down gold, -- every Union reverse puts it up. But it is going down now quite as rapidly as is consistent with the public welfare. It has fallen fifty per cent. within three or four months, and is now falling even more rapidly. To this rate of depreciation the business of the country can accommodate itself, but a more rapid fall would prove disastrous. A sudden decline of thirty or twenty per cent. would ruin thousands of our most thriving and substantial business men, -- not because they have speculated in gold, but because the price of the property they bought when gold was high, goes down with it. We hope that before many months gold will be nearly at par, -- but to be safe the decline must be gradual. A sudden and heavy fall would sweep the business of the country like a hurricane. Steady, but slow and sure, is the kind of progress that we require.
headline: {'main': 'THE DECLINE OF GOLD.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'THE DECLINE OF GOLD.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: Financiering; Extraordinary; Medical Director's Rank in the Army
snippet: Financiering; Extraordinary; Medical Director's Rank in the Army
lead_paragraph: One of the most serious obstacles to the economic employment of their resources in the field, felt by both armies during the present war, has been the want of a suitable staff organization. People speak of the military chaos of 1861; few yet appreciate how far or in what direction the army is organized at the present time. We exult with reason over the discipline of the line, and fire salutes for victories achieved by the valor and endurance of our brave soldiers, without once giving a thought to the magnitude of the labors of the Staff Departments, upon whose smooth and efficient working the success of the army absolutely depends.

abstract: The unpropitious weather yesterday had no effect on the business of the County Volunteer Committee. From ten o'clock in the morning until four o'clock in the afternoon, Supervisor BLUNT was busily engaged in receiving recruits and paying them their bounties. Under advice, most of the volunteers immediately upon receiving their money deposited it in some bank for the benfit of themselves or families, and the business of swindling recruits by brokers, who infest the enlisting stations, has almost entirely ceased. Yesterday one hundred and twenty-three men were sworn in by Supervisor BLUNT and the several Provost-Marshals; twenty-seven for one year, twelve for two years and eighty-four for three years. The men now being enlisted are immediately after receiving their bounties, furnished with uniforms, and their citizen's dresses are given to any person whom they may designate. This proceeding lends additional interest to the many queer scenes that happen daily at the City Hall Park recruiting stations. Waiting for old clothes has become one of the principal excuses of the hundreds lounging about Mr. BLUNT's office, and women are not unfrequently seen carrying off a man's entire wardrobe. The complaints made by friends of men who have been enlisted in this city and sent to other States still continue to be numerous, and more stringent measures are about being adopted by the Volunteer Committee to prevent our city being defrauded by unscrupulous brokers. It is understood that Mr. BLUNT intends to inaugurate a detective police, the men to be selected from the shrewdest brokers. If "setting a rogue to catch a rogue" be a true saying, the experiment will prove eminently successful. The only fear now entertained by the County Volunteer Committee is that they will soon be out of funds. It is to be hoped that the Bounty Fund Bonds will be liberally subscribed for by our capitalists.
lead_paragraph: The unpropitious weather yesterday had no effect on the business of the County Volunteer Committee. From ten o'clock in the morning until four o'clock in the afternoon, Supervisor BLUNT was busily engaged in receiving recruits and paying them their bounties. Under advice, most of the volunteers immediately upon receiving their money deposited it in some bank for the benfit of themselves or families, and the business of swindling recruits by brokers, who infest the enlisting stations, has almost entirely ceased. Yesterday one hundred and twenty-three men were sworn in by Supervisor BLUNT and the several Provost-Marshals; twenty-seven for one year, twelve for two years and eighty-four for three years. The men now being enlisted are immediately after receiving their bounties, furnished with uniforms, and their citizen's dresses are given to any person whom they may designate. This proceeding lends additional interest to the many queer scenes that happen daily at the City Hall Park recruiting stations. Waiting for old clothes has become one of the principal excuses of the hundreds lounging about Mr. BLUNT's office, and women are not unfrequently seen carrying off a man's entire wardrobe. The complaints made by friends of men who have been enlisted in this city and sent to other States still continue to be numerous, and more stringent measures are about being adopted by the Volunteer Committee to prevent our city being defrauded by unscrupulous brokers. It is understood that Mr. BLUNT intends to inaugurate a detective police, the men to be selected from the shrewdest brokers. If "setting a rogue to catch a rogue" be a true saying, the experiment will prove eminently successful. The only fear now entertained by the County Volunteer Committee is that they will soon be out of funds. It is to be hoped that the Bounty Fund Bonds will be liberally subscribed for by our capitalists.

abstract: Press on Military Affairs
snippet: Press on Military Affairs
lead_paragraph: The Richmond writers are of course casting their wits about them to discover how to defeat the armies that are gathering round LEE. They are sadly puzzled. They never have had anything so difficult in hand. When SHERMAN set out from Northern Georgia, HOOD tried to stop him by strategy, but failed; subsequently, the Georgians tried to stop him by militia, but failed; the South Carolinians then tried to stop him by bluster, but failed; now the North Carolinians exhibit nothing but torpor at his approach; and then what shall the Virginians do?

abstract: Female Employees Furloughed
snippet: Female Employees Furloughed
lead_paragraph: The Richmond papers announce that the female employes of the Treasury Department in that city have received a furlough for forty days. Is this the official mode of giving them notice that their services will no longer be required. Possibly other departments of the rebel Government may soon be furloughed also. We should not be at all surprised to hear that JEFF. DAVIS had received "leave of absence" for forty days -- more or less, as the case may be.

abstract: Now that our ports are hermetically sealed, it becomes a matter of necessity to develop our resources. The army must be fed, clothed and paid. How can this be done, since cotton is no longer an article of export and exchange? This is the great question to be solved by the ingenuity and the industry of our countrymen. We believe that it can be solved, and solved readily, if the proper impetus and encouragement be given by the authorities to those natural inventive gilts in which our citizens are no more deficient than those of the North. Look at the wonderfully ingenious and useful inventions of our prisoners in Northern camps, and it is impossible to doubt that, under the pressure of the mother of invention (necessity) the Southern man will prove fully the equal, if not the superior, of the Yankee. This necessity is now imposed upon us by the closure of our ports, and from it we augur the best consequences.

abstract: The Problem to Co e; Loyalty of Defeated Rebels
snippet: The Problem to Co e; Loyalty of Defeated Rebels
lead_paragraph: -- Many of our people have very unreasonable expectations in regard to the loyalty of the inhabitants in Savan nah and other recaptured cities of the South. They complain that these people at heart do not love the Union a whit better than they did before their towns were taken. Why should they? The mere fact of conquest cannot be expected to change the hearts of those who have been defeated. We should distrust all protestations of vehement love for the Union from those who have been fighting or aiding in the rebellion against it. All we can reasonably expect of these people at the outset is, that they should submit gracefully to their defeat, -- that they should acquiesce in the reestablishment of national authority, and obey the laws, promptly and peaceably, of the Federal Government. This, so far as we know, they are doing everywhere.

abstract: View of the Future
snippet: View of the Future
lead_paragraph: Some one was recently urging upon the President the adoption of some policy or measure which he deemed essential to the public good. "Well," said Mr. LINCOLN, "I doubt whether we can do that now -- but wait until the Fourth of March. I don't know how things will turn, but I rather think I shall have more influence with the next Administration than I have with this." The Fourth of March is close at hand.

abstract: The, a Warning against delay
snippet: The, a Warning against delay
lead_paragraph: The State Assembly, at its yesterday morning's session, passed the direct tax Bounty Bill. The bill is auxiliary to the Bounty Act which originated with the Senate. And it is now understood that all the necessary legislation has been secured to enable the Governor, in concert with the Comptroller and the banks, to obtain at once the necessary funds. This is satisfactory as far as most counties are concerned. As regards Kings County it is most unsatisfactory, simply because local effort seems to have been there suspended, in vain and delusive expectation of something turning up that would prevent the enforcement of the draft. Three days ago the Volunteer Committee of the Board of Supervisors presented their case to the Governor as one of hardship, and asked his influence to secure more time for volunteering, on the ground that the local bounty fund had given out just as the draft was upon the city. We have no doubt there is hardship in the case. But so far from the draft being a greater hardship on Brooklyn or New-York than on other cities or districts, we think it is far from creditable to either that their quotas should not now be full by volunteering.

abstract: Montgomery, Capt C S.
snippet: Montgomery, Capt C S.
lead_paragraph: Among the casualties occurring during the recent advance of the Army of the Potomac, on Hatcher's Run. I find the name of Capt. CHARLES S. MONTGOMERY, of the Fifth New-York Veterans, a very gallant officer, and who had for some time commanded the regiment to which he belonged. This is the second commander that regiment has lost during the present campaign. Capt. MONTGOMERY's military career extends through the entire war, and his record was a noble one. Enlisting as a private in the celebrated Duryee Zouaves (Fifth New-York Volunteers) in April, 1861, he carried his musket at the battle of Big Bethel, and subsequently became a corporal. In the fall of that year he was promoted to a Second Lieutenancy, and in that grade served with distinction with his gallant regiment during the Peninsular Campaign in 1862. Received a First Lieutenancy at Harrison's Landing and subsequently a Captaincy, and while in command of his company at the disastrous battle of Mannassas Plains, was wounded and taken prisoner. He was soon after exchanged, and rejoined his company after the battle of Antletam; served in the battles of Fredericksburgh and Chancellorsville, and in May, 1863, returned with the Fifth New-York, at the expiration of its term of service, as senior Captain. On the reorganization of the Zouaves as a veteran regiment, he returned to the field as Captain, and would have been made Major had the command reached the maximum number. The regiment went into battle for the first time in this campaign at the battle of Bethesda Church, and up to the present time Capt. MONTGOMERY has been constantly in active service. He was killed at the head of his regiment as its commanding officer, and his loss is deeply felt in the division of which he had so long been a member. Had he lived, speedy promotion awaited him, as his reputation was very high, and he had been complimented repeatedly by his superiors for gallant conduct. G.F.W.

abstract: The Express of yesterday says: Since our last report there has been no change in the situation around this city, nor even any event of sufficient importance to disturb the quiet that has prevailed since the encounter on Hatcher's Run. The enemy is busily employed in cutting and hauling wood from the vicinity of his new position, and his trains are running day and night to supply the army on the other positions of the lines. The woodland they have inclosed by their fortifications on our right, will prove an important acquisition, and furnish them with a large supply of wood, which, in order to put them to as much inconvenience as possible, it would have been desirable to have kept them from possessing.

abstract: We print this morning the gratifying intelligence that Wilmington, so long the grand entrepot of the rebels for foreign supplies of arms and stores, has fallen into our hands, having been evacuated by the rebels during the night of the 21st inst. The next day, at 9 o'clock in the morning, it was occupied by our forces under Gen. TERRY. According to one report, a considerable number of prisoners were captured with the place; and it is stated that a very large quantity of valuable stores, which the rebels left behind in their precipitate haste to get away, fell into our hands.

abstract: On the Political Force of Ideas
snippet: On the Political Force of Ideas
lead_paragraph: On Thursday evening Prof. DRAPER delivered the third of a series of lectures on "The Historical Influence of Natural Causes," at the hall of the Historical Society, in the presence of a large and select audience. FREDERICK DE PEYSTER, President of the society, presided. The subject of last evening's lecture was "The Political Force of Ideas." The speaker said that philosophical conceptions of the material progress of man must not be considered entirely from a physical point of view. He proposed to show the political force of an idea, and how a sentiment, expressed in a few words, break up religions venerable for their antiquity, rearrange the places of men and revolutionize the world. Rome would afford a text, but he would direct his attention to the eastern shore of the Red Sea. After giving an interesting sketch of Arabia and its products, the lecturer spoke of the birth of MOHAMMED, whose history was to illustrate his subject. He rapidly glanced at his life, his early penury, and his subsequent marriage to an opulent widow, which enabled him to abandon his mercantile pursuits. Subsequently he grew melancholy, and became the victim of mental illusions, unseen visions and phantoms, until he warned his wife that he might become insane. The lecturer gave the different causes which produce mental illusions, which are chiefly occasioned by disease, but art also frequently superinduced by the use of opium, as was the case with DE QUINCEY, who saw vast processions pass before him, which were immediately followed by the theatrical representations of more than earthly splendor. In one of his visions MOHAMMED became impressed with the idea that his mission was to preach. His wife became his first convert; she was soon followed by a small band of believers, and since that time nine thousand millions have become followers of MOHAMMED. His religion was simple, embracing the idea that there was but one God, and MOHAMMED was his prophet. The last sentiment was the one the speaker was to consider. He gave a brief review of the rapid growth of MOHAMMED's empire, and said there was nothing wonderful in the propagation of thought from man to man. The time was opportune, and the occasion was improved by MOHAMMED. There is no political force like an idea; it can shake humanity to its foundation, and governs the world. The sword can never affect the opinions of men. In conclusion, the speaker said that, in America, so great has been our national prosperity, that until the rebellion began, we thought gold, iron and cotton were all powerful, and would guide the opinions of the world. At last our soldiers, our merchants and the people have learned that there is something more powerful in this world than wealth. Of what avail are all national products, unless driven on their way by the impelling force of ideas? [Applause.]

abstract: Financial Schemes and Resources
snippet: Financial Schemes and Resources
lead_paragraph: Two schemes of revenue, taxation and currency are proposed in Congress. That of the Financial Committee of the House of Representatives was set forth with some detail in these columns the other day. It proposed to raise three hundred million of dollars by a tax in currency, equivalent to one and one-fifth per cent. in specie on the old assessments of general property; and also to raise one hundred and fifty millions of currency by a tax on incomes, trades and special subjects. It proposed in addition to continue the present tax of one-tenth in kind. It estimated that these three classes of taxation would produce an aggregate revenue, in currency or commodities, of five hundred and ninety millions of dollars; and that there would be needed, beside this sum, for the current calendar year, about four hundred and seventy millions of dollars. This deficit was expected to be supplied; First, from the sale of six per cent. non-taxable bonds; second, from the use of deposits and loans on call certificates, under a new plan of deposits about to be instituted; and third, from the sale of Government cotton on band for specie or foreign bills. This scheme of finance was based upon the present system of currency, and the present rule of values as measured by that currency. It is considered objectionable in the fact that it proposes to continue the sale of Government bonds for a currency which stands at a ruinous depreciation; and tends to perpetuate this depreciation by basing all public transactions on the existing prices.

abstract: Juvenile Crime Decrease of; Report, and Decrease of Crime
snippet: Juvenile Crime Decrease of; Report, and Decrease of Crime
lead_paragraph: Amid the sickening disclosures of the corruption of our City Administration, robbing our citizens to the extent of millions, and poisoning every spring of public life, it is refreshing to learn that in one great municipal concern there is no deterioration, but a signal improvement. Mr. BRACE, in his report of the Children's Aid Society just published, shows by the figures that juvenile delinquency is materially decreasing; and that, too, notwithstanding the vast increase of our city population, and the loss of natural protectors occasioned to thousands of young children by the war. Mr. BRACE goes back to the criminal records of 1855, and, comparing them with the last which are yet completed, he shows that, though the population of the city increased at least forty per cent. from 1855 to 1863, commitments for vagrancy decreased from 3,376 in the former year to 2,908 in the latter; commitments for petit larceny from 3,299 to 3,099; and that there was a decrease of twenty-five per cent. in commitments for pocket-picking. These comprise the principal offences that are committed by minors, though of course they are not committed by them exclusively. The increase occasioned by the orphanage and other unfavorable effects of the war, has been very slight. All the commitments to the City Prisons of those under twenty years of age, amounted in 1860 to 4,975; in 1863 to 4,998. Considering the great increase in population during those three years, this exhibits a very considerable reduction in the percentage.

abstract: The feeling of patriotic rejoicing which has pervaded the North during the past week has no where found more full and fitting expression than here at the capital of this State. I mention this as in some degree in contrast with the tone of feeling manifested in this city, one, and more especially, two Winters ago. No locality of the State is now apparently more loyal than its capital.
lead_paragraph: ALBANY, Friday, Feb. 24, 1865.

abstract: The bounty-brokers have begun to comprehend Col. BAKER'S mission here, and to understand that he is in receipt of information which is deeply interesting to them; and some of the gang, taking their illluck; philosophically, have prepared themselves to receive the Colonel's subordinates, and comply with their demands at a moment's notice.
lead_paragraph: The bounty-brokers have begun to comprehend Col. BAKER's mission here, and to understand that he is in receipt of information which is deeply interesting to them; and some of the gang, taking their ill-luck; philosophically, have prepared themselves to receive the Colonel's subordinates, and comply with their demands at a moment's notice. One broker who was visited yesterday bade the officers welcome, and without preliminary persiflage, hastened the business by producing a roll of Treasury notes, and merely asking how much money they required. Having disbursed the amount which they claimed for the soldier whose case the officers had in hand, the broker asked them to call again, assuring them that he would be ready; indeed, he said, he had been expecting a call ever since he first read the accounts of their doings.
