snippet: on number of States to Ratify; Doolittle, Senator, on Majority of all the States; Sumner and Doolittle
lead_paragraph: -- It used to be supposed that the meaning of the Constition was to be drawn from its language -- and that all public and private interests or wishes must be conformed thereto. That, to be sure, was in the days when the Constitution was the supreme law of the land; and when neither States, parties nor individuals felt themselves at liberty to override it for their own convenience. We trust that day has not yet gone by, though symptoms are not wanting of an effort to substitute other influences and views.

abstract: The Fall of
snippet: The Fall of
lead_paragraph: Had any one, at the time of the Presidential election in November last, predicted the military achievements of the three months of Winter, he would have been looked on as a lunatic. The fall of the great rebel strongholds of Wilmington, Charleston and Savannah, the occupation of the Capitals of South Carolina and Georgia, the march of SHERMAN from Chattahoochee to the ocean, and from the ocean to the Great Pedee, the rout and demolition of HOOD's army, the scatteration of COBB's forces, the double hegira of HARDEE, the flight of BEAUREGARD, the flight of BRAGG or HOKE, the advance into North Carolina and toward LEE's rear the possibility of such a speedy achievement of such vast labors -- the possibility of such a marvelous and unbroken series of successes, entered into no sane man's head. But this bold catalogue gives a faint idea of the greatness of the triumphs of the armies of the Union, and the staggering blows and irretrievable damage inflicted upon the rebellious South.

abstract: The Financial Committee of the rebel Congress has agreed upon a scheme of revenue and taxation which demands at least a passing notice. It is proposed to raise three hundred millions by a tax in currency equivalent to one and one-fifth per cent. in specie, on the old assessments of general property. Incomes and trades are to be taxed to the tune of one hundred and fifty million dollars. And, in addition to this, the present tithe on produce is to be continued. The gross totals from these imposts are computed at five hundred and ninety million dollars. But this falls altogether short still of the demands of DAVIS' Exchequer. Four hundred and seventy millions extra are needed to carry on the war for another year, and this is to be got at by the issue of non-taxable six per cent. bonds, and from the sale of Government cotton on hand!

abstract: Appointments; New U S District Judge
snippet: Appointments; New U S District Judge
lead_paragraph: a new judicial district in this State, comprising the counties on Long Island and Staten Island, has passed both houses of Congress, and yesterday the President nominated CHARLES L. BENEDICT for Judge, B.D. SILLIMAN for District Attorney and A.F. CAMPBELL for Marshal. These are all excellent appointments. Mr. BENEDICT is one of the junior partners in the firm of BENEDICT, BURR and BENEDICT, -- is about forty years of age, able, well-read, hardworking and inflexibly upright and straightforward. He has had a large practice in admiralty cases, and will make an efficient and popular judge. He was a member of the State Assembly in 1862, and though never an obtrusive politician, has always been active and effective in the Union cause. Mr. SILLIMAN is widely known and highly esteemed as a lawyer and a gentleman, and will give weight and character to the position he holds. Mr. CAMPBELL was formerly Sheriff of Kings County.

abstract: E H Ropes, U S Consul at; B???all J Y executed
snippet: E H Ropes, U S Consul at; B???all J Y executed
lead_paragraph: JOHN Y. BEALL, the rebel pirate and spy, was hanged yesterday afternoon at Governor's Island for the crimes against his country and the laws of nations of which he stood convicted. In the rigid enforcement of the sentence imposed by a military commission upon this man his confederates will see the determination of our Government to protect its citizens from plundering raids, its commerce from treacherous piratical attacks, and its ports and dockyards from prowling spies. The fate of this man and such of his fellows as may be similarly convicted will do more to relieve us from the incursions and annoyance of rebel thieves upon our frontiers and stowaway pirates on our merchant steamers, than the employment of an army of guards and detectives.

abstract: At the hour of opening, yesterday morning, Capt. O'DONNELL, of the court officers, entered the court-room with twenty-five persons in custody -- several of whom were witnesses; but who among them were indigent and friendless witnesses that, under our benign laws, had been imprisoned in the House of Detention, and which were prisoners from the Tombs, a casual observer would have been at a loss to determine. The attendance of spectators was large, and foreshadowed a busy day; but the array of counsel, on the contrary, being not striking as to number, indicated a short and uninteresting session.

lead_paragraph: LARCENIES. -- DAVID B. CADY was arrested by Detective Officer DEVOY for stealing from the rotunda of the Astor-house a carpet-bag belonging to EDWARD ULBRECHT, a lodger at HELD's hotel. The prisoner, having been caught in the act, was required to find $1,000 bail, and in default was committed by Justice DOWLING....Mr. THOMAS J. KIDD, of No. 538 Greenwich-street, appeared before Justice LEDWITH and made oath that ELLEN DUFFY, a nurse, had stolen $130 worth of his wife's wearing apparel, and handed the same over to JOHN LEWIN. The property was recovered, and the Justice committed the girl for examination.

abstract: Verdi's La Forza del Destino, at Academy of Music
snippet: Verdi's La Forza del Destino, at Academy of Music
lead_paragraph: ACADEMY OF MUSIC -- PRODUCTION OF "LA FORZA DEL DESTINO," -- Mr. MARETZEK fulfilled the most important promise of his early programme last evening, when he offered to his patrons the latest novelty from the pen of Signor VERDI, "La Forza del Destino." In this work, as in "Il Trovatore," "La Traviata," and "Un Ballo in Maschera," we anticipate the verdict of London and Paris; a fact of no importance, in itself, but tending, at all events, to show the practical advantage of having a liberal and enterprising musician at the head of our principal musical establishment, instead of an entrepreneur who must, necessarily, follow, not lead. "La Forza del Destino" was written for the Imperial Italian theatre of St. Petersburg, and it was produced there on the 10th November, 1862. It is difficult to estimate the success of a work by its reception at the Russian capital; but cotemporary criticism was rapturous on the subject of its merits. Subsequently the work was played at Madrid, and again glowing accounts were received of its excellence. Both cities are -- comparatively speaking -- small, and the work did not "run" as it would have done in London, Paris, or New-York. Doubts were even expressed as to the genuineness of the favor thus twice recorded, Mr. MARETZEK nevertheless obtained the score, and after a careful examination declared that, in some respects, it was the finest work in the modern Italian repertoire. We are entirely of his opinion.

abstract: In the Senate Mr. SPRAGUE offered a resolution, which was passed, instructing the Committee on Finance to inquire into the expediency of enlarging the powers of the Bureau of Emigration, so as to afford relief to Southern refugees in the Northern States. The Minnesota Railroad Grant Bill was passed. The bill to give a $300 pension to the revolutionary survivors was passed.
lead_paragraph: In the Senate Mr. SPRAGUE offered a resolution, which was passed, instructing the Committee on Finance to inquire into the expediency of enlarging the powers of the Bureau of Emigration, so as to afford relief to Southern refugees in the Northern States. The Minnesota Railroad Grant Bill was passed. The bill to give a $300 pension to the revolutionary survivors was passed. A resolution asking the President to call on the citizens to join in the Norwegian and Portuguese International Exhibitions of the current year, was awarded by a proviso that no expense should be incurred. The Fortification Bill, as reported by the Finance Committee makes appropriations for the completion, preservation and repair of such existing fortifications and other works of defences as in the opinion of the President are needed for the present war, and to preserve in repair existing fortifications and works of defence, $1,500,000; for field works and held operations, $1,000,000; for bridge trams and equipage for armies in the field, $300,000; for tools and siege trains for armies in the feild, $50,000; for surveys for military defences and for the purchase of campaign maps, $30,000; for surveys of the Northern and Northwestern lakes, including Lake Superior, $125,000; for engraving and printing charts of lake surveys, $15,000; for the purchase and repair of instruments, $200,000. The bill was taken up on motion of Mr. SHERMAN. Mr. WILSON moved an amendment, which was adopted, reducing the original appropriations one half, retaining all the provisions for expenditures to improve the forts on the North Atlantic and Pacific coasts. In the evening session the resolution in relation to the State Government of Louisiana was debated at some length by Messrs. SUMNER and HENDRICKS, but no action was taken on it.

abstract: For a long time, a home for discharged, disabled and furloughed soldiers has been needed in this city, and within the last six months several ineffectual efforts have been made by many of our patriotic citizens to establish a depot at which needy veterans could find at least temporary accommodations; but all attempts to carry into execution the noble object failed, until Col. BLISS, of the Union League, interested himself in the undertaking, and established at No. 385 Fourth-avenue the Soldiers' Rest. Previous to the opening of this institution there was, with the exception of the New-England Rooms on Broadway, and the Relief Association corner of Howard and Mercer streets, no place where discharged and furloughed soldiers could find a home except in the station-house or on the street. Hundreds of poor fellows, whose term of service had expired, found themselves suddenly turned adrift from a railroad train, and being penniless, were compelled to depend upon the charity of strangers or appeal to the Commissioners of Charities and Corrections. Strong men, unused to begging, who had fought for their country in many battles, reached New-York after being honorably discharged from the army, without sufficient means to buy food. They were consequently driven to beggary or starvation. The establishing of the Soldiers' Rest has resulted in the accomplishment of the long sought for object, and the weary soldier can now find a home until provided with employment or pensioned by the Government. At this new institution one thousand men can be fed and a large number lodged. The bill of fare is not uninviting. It consists of the best of meats, coffee, bread and butter and the ordinary table vegetables. The rooms have been open but two weeks, during which time, although the fact has not been generally advertised, many hundred soldiers have been fed. The several apartments of the institution are models of neatness, and the building, both in exterior and interior, presents an inviting appearance. The principal rooms are the reading-room, the dining-room, the baggage-room and the kitchen. The accommodations for sleeping are at present temporary, bnt permanent beds are soon to be arranged. A committee of ladies and gentlemen visit the establishment daily, and a most thorough system of discipline is observed. The reading-room is furnished with books and newspapers, and in all of the departments careful attention is paid to the wants of the soldier.
lead_paragraph: For a long time, a home for discharged, disabled and furloughed soldiers has been needed in this city, and within the last six months several ineffectual efforts have been made by many of our patriotic citizens to establish a depot at which needy veterans could find at least temporary accommodations; but all attempts to carry into execution the noble object failed, until Col. BLISS, of the Union League, interested himself in the undertaking, and established at No. 385 Fourth-avenue the Soldiers' Rest. Previous to the opening of this institution there was, with the exception of the New-England Rooms on Broadway, and the Relief Association corner of Howard and Mercer streets, no place where discharged and furloughed soldiers could find a home except in the station-house or on the street. Hundreds of poor fellows, whose term of service had expired, found themselves suddenly turned adrift from a railroad train, and being penniless, were compelled to depend upon the charity of strangers or appeal to the Commissioners of Charities and Corrections. Strong men, unused to begging, who had fought for their country in many battles, reached New-York after being honorably discharged from the army, without sufficient means to buy food. They were consequently driven to beggary or starvation. The establishing of the Soldiers' Rest has resulted in the accomplishment of the long sought for object, and the weary soldier can now find a home until provided with employment or pensioned by the Government. At this new institution one thousand men can be fed and a large number lodged. The bill of fare is not uninviting. It consists of the best of meats, coffee, bread and butter and the ordinary table vegetables. The rooms have been open but two weeks, during which time, although the fact has not been generally advertised, many hundred soldiers have been fed. The several apartments of the institution are models of neatness, and the building, both in exterior and interior, presents an inviting appearance. The principal rooms are the reading-room, the dining-room, the baggage-room and the kitchen. The accommodations for sleeping are at present temporary, bnt permanent beds are soon to be arranged. A committee of ladies and gentlemen visit the establishment daily, and a most thorough system of discipline is observed. The reading-room is furnished with books and newspapers, and in all of the departments careful attention is paid to the wants of the soldier.

abstract: Yesterday, during the consideration in secret session by the Confederate Senate of the bill to raise two hundred thousand negro soldiers, a motion was made for its indefinite postponement, and which was agreed to by a majority of one. This is equavalent to laving the bill upon the table, but it can be called up at any time; and we have reason to know that it will be again taken up within the next few days, when it will be passed. The measure is delayed not because of a want of strength on the part of its advocates, but for a specific purpose.

abstract: Goshen, N Y, Bank, $11,000; All Recovered; Savings Bank for Freedmen; Freedmen's Savings Bank
snippet: Goshen, N Y, Bank, $11,000; All Recovered; Savings Bank for Freedmen; Freedmen's Savings Bank
lead_paragraph: A bill is pending in Congress to incorporate a trust company to take charge of the money received by recently enfranchised slaves for bounties, wages, &c. It ought to be passed. We are told on good authority that over $70,000 thus accumulated are now in the hands of army officers and others at Port Royal alone, placed with and held by them simply for lack of other places of deposit. It is a responsibility which they do not seek and a risk to which the money of these poor people should not be exposed. The bill in question makes ample provision for the safe keeping of the money, -- the trustees are all men of standing, character and business experience, and the establishment of such a company would be a cheap, valuable and welcome boon to the freedmen for whose advantage it is designed. There ought to be no hesitation in Congress in the passage of this bill.

abstract: -- On Saturday afternoon last, a soldier, in company with some others, went into the Darcy House, near Market-street Depot, in order to obtain a "tipple." The soldier passed out into the rear of the hotel, and a short time afterward -- at about 5 P.M. -- was found suspended by his neck with a piece of sash cord, to the beam of a shed, his feet touching the ground and his body still warm. The body was taken down by Coronor SANDFORD; and papers, found upon his [???]son, proved him to be JAMES JOHNSON, of Company G, Eighth New-Jersey Volunteers, at the time an inmate of the Centre-street Hospital. He was about, 30 years of age, and, as will be seen from the following note written with a lead pencil and found in his pocket, was a married man:

abstract: The Wheeling Intelligencer, in speaking of the capture of Gens. CROOK and KELLEY, says: "A gallant and distinguished officer with whom we conversed yesterday, ventured the prediction, in the absence of any particulars that this capture was planned by rebels in the city of Cumberland, and that the rebels, upon entering the town, rode straight to the rooms occupied by the captured officers, and threw them upon horses brought for the purpose. Gen. CROOK occupied a room at the Revere House, and Gen. KELLEY occupied a room at the St. Nicholas. Capt. MELVIN occupied a room immediately adjoining, and opening into that of Gen. KELLEY, which circumstance our young friend is indebted to his capture, We learn that there was only one company of soldiers in the city at the time of the capture, and it is not likely that it could be rallied for any considerable resistance at 3 o'clock in the morning. Gen. DUVAL's brigade was encamped about two miles from the city. The rebels, it is said, were well mounted. Both men and horses were selected for this purpose. They no doubt put this little affair through with dispatch, and before the cavalry could be summoned from Gen. DUVAL's camp, which would require at least an hour, the rebels were, no doubt, far away. They have laid their plans well, and will strain every nerve to execute it successfully and thoroughly, and we shall be very agreeably surprised if our soldiers overtake them.

abstract: FEB. 25 -- William T. Wilkins vs. William P. Earle et al. -- This was an appeal from the verdict of a jury giving a verdict for $21,649 17 to plaintiff for money stolen from Earle's Hotel. The grounds relied on are, that defendant in law was not liable for the loss, as the money was considerably in excess of that required by travelers for ordinary expenses, and that was the extent to which they were liable. All sums above this, given to a servant of the defendant's, was at the risk of the traveler, and the innkeeper could not be held responsible.

abstract: Marriages by Mayor Gunther in 1864
snippet: Marriages by Mayor Gunther in 1864
lead_paragraph: -During the year 1864, fifty-three coupies were married by Mayor GUNTHER. Mayor OPDYKE united eleven couples only during his term of office. Of the marriages by Mayor GUNTHER, eight of the males and nine of the females were of native birth. Only one of the American males married a bride of foreign birth, and two of the native born females married husbands born in foreign countries. Five of the males were widowers, and seven of the females were widows. One male and two females were of such uncertain ages as to be classed "unknown." The average of the gentlemen was thirty years and seven months the oldest being sixty-nine, the youngest twenty-one years of age. The average of the brides was twenty-five years and eight months, the oldest a widow of forty-five, and the youngest three were each "sweet seventeen."

abstract: Africanization of the Gulf States; Order on Negro Labor in Gulf States; Evils to be Avoided; on Negro Labor and Lands
snippet: Africanization of the Gulf States; Order on Negro Labor in Gulf States; Evils to be Avoided; on Negro Labor and Lands
lead_paragraph: We remember of hearing, years before the present war, a distinguished statesman pre- dict that the time would come when "the Gulf States would become Africanized," or be entirely filled with black communities. The prediction was a scientific conclusion, based on the laws of population. In these semi-tropical regions, climate favors the negro, and in the course of centuries he must have the advantage over the white.

abstract: Price of; Price of Slaves in
snippet: Price of; Price of Slaves in
lead_paragraph: -- The local trade in slaves appears to be anything but flourishing, if we judge from some of the latest authentic reports. We find a healthy negro, thirty-six years of age, going off at Salisbury, N.C., for $4,900, which, at the latest quotations for Confederate money is about $200; a negro girl, fifteen years, at the same time was knocked down for four hundred dollars less. Hiring rates, according to the Salisbury Watchman, are much higher in proportion than the selling prices. Black mechanics go off by the year at two thousand dollars in Confederate notes, or eighty dollars in money. This would seem to indicate that buyers think the hire of a negro for a year worth about half as much as his purchase for life. There is much meaning in this new proportion established between the hiring and purchasing rates in the slave market. In a business point of view, we think, the Salisbury dealers show great shrewdness. Getting the lease of the negro for one year is probably just as valuable an investment as getting a lease of him for life. A still more advantageous arrangement might be to hire these black hands, say for three or six months, or even a shorter term. Salisbury lies in the line of Gen. SHERMAN's march -- doubtless.

abstract: Lecture in Hoboken
snippet: Lecture in Hoboken
lead_paragraph: FREDERICK DOUGLAS delivered a lecture, last evening, at the Odd Fellow's Hall, in Hoboken, before a large audience of ladies and gentlemen, who gave him a hearty reception. The speaker commenced by saying that the progress made and the charges wrought during the past four years were vast and wonderful. Great errors most hurtful to all parties, in respect to the character and possibilities of the colored race, had been swept away under the educating power of the rebellion. We had been living and moving at immense rate, and the work of an age had been compressed into a day. Millions of prayers had gone up to the Eternal Throne from bleeding hearts, desiring to see the day in which it was our privilege and our opportunity to live. Events had occurred so rapidly -- and overlapped -- and interlaced each other so thickly, that we are dazzled beyond the power of comprehending them. Only after coming generations, far remote from our stormy period of war, would we be able to appreciate and describe each separate event, and accord to each its true grandeur and importance. Four years ago we were upon our knees supplicating our Southern masters, blotting out with fears of penitence the most sacred laws upon our statute books -- laws for the protection of the hunted and helpless, innocent of crime. The lecturer thanked Heaven that we had lived to see the end at such humiliation. His object was to advocate the immediate and unconditional enfranchisement of the whole colored population of the United States, as an act of wise statesmanship and justice to the race. Time was precious and events were hastening. He would not waste time in the discussion of dead issues. To denounce the rebellion was cheap. To explain its causes was needless -- to eulogies our brave generals and our armies was unnecessary. The last rebel would soon be made to bite the dust or dance upon thin air.
headline: {'main': 'Frederick Douglas in Hoboken.; LECTURE ON PREJUDICE AND PROGRESS.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'Frederick Douglas in Hoboken.; LECTURE ON PREJUDICE AND PROGRESS.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: In the Senate, yesterday, notice was given of bills to incorporate the free Literary Association of New-York: legalizing certain resolutions of the Richmond County Supervisors; incorporating the Seventy-first Militia Regiment.
lead_paragraph: In the Senate, yesterday, notice was given of bills to incorporate the free Literary Association of New-York: legalizing certain resolutions of the Richmond County Supervisors; incorporating the Seventy-first Militia Regiment. Bills were passed increasing the rates of pilotage in the port of New-York; incorporating the Merchants' Exchange and News Room of the City of New-York; amending the act designating legal holidays; for the relief of holders of unsecured bonds of the New-York and Erie Railroad Company. The resolution calling for information as to to the amounts paid over by New-York City District Attornies on bail bonds, &c., since 1845, was adopted. The paid Fire Department bill was made the special order for next Thursday evening.

abstract: Wallack, J W, Will of; Wallack, J W, Will, Admitted to Probate
snippet: Wallack, J W, Will of; Wallack, J W, Will, Admitted to Probate
lead_paragraph: Yesterday the will of the late James W. Wallack was admitted to probate, before Surrogate Tucker. The principal provisions of the will are as follows: To his eldest son, Mr. John Lester Wallack, the testator bequeaths the lease, fixtures, properties, &c., of the theatre known as Wallack's Theatre, in this city, situated at the corner of Broadway and Thirteenth-street. This bequest is, however, subject to the continuous payment of £5 sterling per week to the testator's second son, Capt. Henry Wallack, of the British army. To Capt. Wallack he has bequeathed half his plate, and the rents, incomes and profits of his house in Fourteenth-street. His estates at Long Branch are to go to Mr. J. Lester Wallack, and his money, bank stock, &c., are to be equally divided between Capt. Henry Wallack and his brother, J. Lester Wallack.

abstract: -- The new issue of the fractional currency of the denomination of twenty-five cents is now ready for distribution. It is on thick paper, and the engraving gives it the appearance of one of the Government notes of greater value. abstract: Quotas Filled by Rogues and Disabled Men
snippet: Quotas Filled by Rogues and Disabled Men
lead_paragraph: Till recently, a great deal of the best material has gone into the army, even in our large cities. We all know what large numbers of the best young men of the country -- men often of position, wealth, and education, and those representing our best trades and most intelligent pursuits -- have joined even the rank and file in this struggle. But to a degree, this is now changing. The country towns and villages, not being obliged to fill their quotas from their own districts, and thus secure the best material for the army, resort to the cities with their high bounties and "hand-money," and take back to their own recruiting offices all that bad element which pours into such places, and which will do anything for money.

abstract: Gaultier, Rene; Remarkable Case
snippet: Gaultier, Rene; Remarkable Case
lead_paragraph: RENE GAUTIER, a Frenchman whose correspondence shows him to have been on intimate terms with rebels in Paris, if he was not one of their agents in this city, committed suicide, on Wednesday morning last, by shooting himself in the forehead, as has already been briefly stated in the TIMES. He was a boarder in the family of Mr. A.P. SMITH, at No. 219 West Forty-eighth-street; but as he had occupied apartments there only since about the 1st of December last, the family knew little more of him or his calling than if he had been an entire stranger. From his address, which was that of a young man of good breeding and considerable wealth, the family were led to offer him a parlor when he applied for board; but he chose a little chamber with ordinary furniture, and particularly desired seclusion. He appeared regularly at the family board at the usual hours, and was ever urbane and cheerful; but before the removal of the cloth he invariably sought his room, and spent nearly every evening therein, perfecting certain discoveries in window-glass staining. If he went abroad, he usually returned with a book or some other thing indicating that he had been at the Mercantile Library; but this seldom occurred. He seemed wedded to his room, and a light which nearly every evening shone thence far into the watches of midnight would indicate that he was busy therein. He never visited billiard-saloons, bar-rooms, or places of amusements, drank no wine, used no tobacco, and seemed altogether a gentleman whose tastes or pursuits led him to seek retirement.

abstract: A petition to the Legislature to create an efficient Board of Health for this city is now being tensively circulated, and already thousands of names have been appended to it. Dr. WILLARD PARKER and
lead_paragraph: A petition to the Legislature to create an efficient Board of Health for this city is now being extensively circulated, and already thousands of names have been appended to it. Dr. WILLARD PARKER and D.B. EATON, Esq., have been deputed to proceed to Albany to endeavor to obtain the passage of a Metropolitan Health Bill, which has been carefully prepared, and is believed to be well adapted to secure the end sought. The framers of the bill sa[???]. All citizens are urged at once to express their [???]ie[???]s upon the subject in a way that cannot be mistaken. The alarming fact of about ten thousand preventable deaths occurring annually in our city, and upwards of two hundred thousand cases of sickness, induced by causes which wise sanitary regulations might remove appeals to every heart. It is discovered by faithful and laborious investigation, that 1,500 cases of small-pox and 1,500 cases of typhoid fever, beside numerous and other diseases exist among the poorer classes of our population, induced more or less by living in crowded tenement houses poorly lighted and ventilated, and by the putrid atmosphere arising from streets filled with decaying garbage, offensive sinks and sewers, and other sources of sickness and mortality which proper sanitary laws would control.
headline: {'main': 'A Board of Health for New-York.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'A Board of Health for New-York.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: Taxation of Luxuries in England; Luxuries Taxed in
snippet: Taxation of Luxuries in England; Luxuries Taxed in
lead_paragraph: One of the periodical battles the British Chancellor of the Exchequer has to fight is that over the maintenance of the malt tax, a tax from which the Chancellor derives no less than six millions sterling a year, and which he is therefore naturally disinclined to relinquish. On purely fiscal grounds, no British Finance Minister would readily resign such a source of income, even if he had a considerable surplus on hand. And on grounds of sound financial economy, there is, we believe, no statesman of influence in England likely to surrender a tax which is so sure of realization, which is distributed so equally among every class of the community, and which, compared with the tax on tea, an article of equally general consumption, is found to be so entirely the reverse of excessive.
headline: {'main': 'How they Tax Common Luxuries in England.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'How they Tax Common Luxuries in England.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: Within the limits of the City Washington and the District of Columbia, thousands of women and children, whose husbands, fathers and brothers are in their graves, or far away at unknown places with our armies, are at present suffering for the want of clothing, food and fuel.
lead_paragraph: Within the limits of the City Washington and the District of Columbia, thousands of women and children, whose husbands, fathers and brothers are in their graves, or far away at unknown places with our armies, are at present suffering for the want of clothing, food and fuel. These poor people were driven hither by the inevitable necessities of the civil war, and came among us destitute and strangers. Yet with brave self-reliance and untiring toil, they have supported themselves and their families, with aged and infirm relatives dependent on them, through the Summer and Autumn weather.

abstract: DEATH OF JUDGE OGDEN. -- ELIAS B.D. OGDEN, one of the Justices of the Supreme Court of New-Jersey, died yesterday at his residence in Elizabeth. He was the senior Judge of that court, having entered upon his third term, and had been upon the bench more than fifteen years. He was one of the ablest among the judges of that tribunal, and was still in the vigor of a healthy old age.

abstract: Another Crisis in
snippet: Another Crisis in
lead_paragraph: Another Prussian crisis is at hand. The King is as obstinate, and as averse to compromise as ever, and the deputies will concede nothing -- will sanction no ministerial measure, while he remains in this mood. Under these circumstances, a reconciliation between the Lower Chamber and the Government need not be looked for, and, after another brief struggle, the fiat of dissolution is sure to be again pronounced.

lead_paragraph: Financial embarrassment is probably the rock on which the Narvaez Ministry will suffer shipwreck. Senor BARZANALLANA has about 2,000 millions of floating debt, and an annual expenditure far exceeding the national revenue, to deal with, while there are only three modes by which he can even attempt to raise the needful -- a forced loan, a voluntary subscription on the part of the people, or a foreign loan.

abstract: Crazy Nora, of Philadelphia
snippet: Crazy Nora, of Philadelphia
lead_paragraph: -- A few days since we were called upon to record the death of one of Philadelphia's eccentric characters, namely, the itinerant preacher and exhorter, GEORGE MUNDAY. On Wednesday last, another and more celebrated one passed from earth, after a singularly eventful and fitful career of nearly half a century. We alluce to "Crazy NORAH," whose strange street antics, fantastic dress, tall figurge, and peculiar, yet interesting expression of countenance, has made her name a sort of "house-hold word" for many years past, throughout the length and breadth of the city.

snippet: Stiger, Dr J W; Arrested for Frauds
lead_paragraph: COL. BAKER TO APPEAR BEFORE JUDGE BARNARD. -- Judge BARNARD issued a writ of habeas corpus, yesterday, commanding Col. BAKER, of the United States Detective service, to produce before him, on Monday morning, the 27th inst., the body of Col. ABRAHAM LYONS, one of the persons whom the Government detective officers have sent to the Old Capitol Prison, to await trial for alleged bounty-brokerage swindling. The TIMES has the best authority for saying that Col. BAKER will respond before His Honor of the Supreme Court to-morrow morning, probably in person, and that he will strive to show such accumulated proofs of villainy against LYONS as shall make the Judge blush for his countryman. Col. BAKER reported no further arrests yesterday in this city. We find the following in yesterday morning's Newark Advertiser: "Col. BAKER's detectives have been at work in the Fourth Congressional District in New-Jersey, and have arrested Dr. JOHN S. STIGER, of Mendham, the Examining Surgeon, and a broker named SAVIS, for defrauding the Government. It is alleged that STIGER was bribed to pass unfit persons as volunteers. One of Col. BAKER's detectives personated a broker, and giving the bribe to the Surgeon, caused his arrest, and the money was found on his person. The accused have been taken to New-York."

abstract: Fisher, London Times
snippet: Fisher, London Times
lead_paragraph: -The London Times is interested in the affair at Fort Fisher, because of its bearing upon the controversy of Ships vs. Guns, or, we should rather say, its possible bearing, for the Times is not clear that it has actually thrown any light upon the controversy. It says: "If the Confederate guns are capable of comparison with our own, the question of ships against forts may prove to have been considerably advanced by these experiments." Saying nothing about the quiet assumption in these words that that controversy can only be settled by English guns, we think the Times might have spoken more positively, for there was certainly one portion of the Confederate artillery as to which it ought to be satisfied beyond a doubt of the possibility of such comparison. We refer to the famous Armstrong guns, alleged to have been a present to JEFF. DAVIS, which were mounted in the forts, and which do not seem to have done much, if any, more execution than the others. But perhaps the attention of the Times had not been called to the presence of these cannon, and we may have yet from it further discussion of the question, with the new light of this fact thrown upon it.

abstract: Murray vs Vanderbilt, (Transit Co Receiver)
snippet: Murray vs Vanderbilt, (Transit Co Receiver)
lead_paragraph: D. Colden Murray, Receiver, &c., of the Accessory Transit Company, vs. Cornelius Vanderbilt. -- The plaintiff in this case was appointed Receiver for the benefit of the stockholders of the old Nicaraguan Transit Company, and brought this action to recover back from the former President of the company a large amount of valuable property, said to have been retained in his possession illegally. The case was heard at Special Term, and judgment given against the defendant. A reference was then ordered to Hon. John J. Hoffman, to ascertain the amount of the judgment and the value of the property, but the plaintiff objected to the referee on the ground of his intimate social and business relations with Horace F. Clark, Vanderbilt's son-in-law, one of the counsel, and also a witness in the case. The court then left it to the parties to select a referee, but, after trying in vain for two years to agree upon a suitable party, they were obliged to come into court again and ask for an appointment. Mr. Hoffman was reappointed, and plaintiff's counsel then addressed him a note, stating that while they had the highest confidence in his integrity and honor, their duty to their client compelled them to ask him to decline the appointment. In reply, Recorder Hoffman stated that he knew of no reason that should prevent him from acting as referee in the case, and, as he had been publicly appointed, his self-respect would not permit him to decline.

abstract: Montana, Pacific Mail Steamship Company, Launch
snippet: Montana, Pacific Mail Steamship Company, Launch
lead_paragraph: The fine steamship Montana, built for the Pacific Mail Steamship Company, was launched yesterday morning from the shipyard of WEBB & BELL, foot of G-street, Greenpoint. The Montana is of 4,000 tons burden and of the following dimensions; length, 330 feet; breadth of beam, 43 feet 6 inches; depth of hold, 27 feet. The materials usee in the construction of the vessel have been selected with the greatest care, and the workmanship is of the best kind. The engines will be furnished by the Novelty Works. This is the fourth steamship built by WEBB & BELL for the Pacific Mail Steamship Company within the last ten years. The company now own the following vessels: North Star, Costa Rica and Ocean Queen, which run to this side of the Isthmus and connect with the Sacramento, Golden City, Golden Age and Montana. The Montana will probably replace the Golden City.

abstract: In the Senate, yesterday, the bill to create the office of Solicitor and Judge-Advocate of the Navy Department, was passed. The House resolution to authorize Mr. POWELL to paint a picture for the Capitol, at a cost not exceeding $25,000, was strongly opposed by Mr. SUMNER, on the ground that our citizens were already taxed to the utmost to carry on the war. No action was taken.
lead_paragraph: In the Senate, yesterday, the bill to create the office of Solicitor and Judge-Advocate of the Navy Department, was passed. The House resolution to authorize Mr. POWELL to paint a picture for the Capitol, at a cost not exceeding $25,000, was strongly opposed by Mr. SUMNER, on the ground that our citizens were already taxed to the utmost to carry on the war. No action was taken. The Senate then took up the joint resolution recognizing the State Government of Louisiana. A substitute for the bill was offered by Mr. SUMNER, which was ordered to be printed. Mr. HOWARD spoke at length against the proposition of the Judiciary Committee, arguing that the State Government of Louisiana was but the government of a fraction of the people of that State. Mr. JOHNSON delivered a speech in favor of the resolution.

abstract: THE United States agt. George Barry. -- The accused was brought up yesterday morning on a charge of manslaughter, in causing the death of John Riley, by shooting aim with a pistol. It seems that, the defendant was mute of the schooner Minerva, and the deceased was a seaman on the vessel. On the 18th of December last, on a voyage from New-York to Hilton Head, South Carolina, the prisoner and the murdered man had a difficulty, in which Barry was struck in the face by deceased. They separated for a few moments, and the mate went to his cabin, procured a pistol, sought Riley out and shot him. The defence set up was that the mate's life was threatened, and in danger from the violence of Riley. After examining one witness, the case was adjourned.

abstract: We learn from Admiral PORTER'S official report to the Navy Department, that immediately after the evacuation of Fort Anderson, the fleet under his command pushed forward as rapidly as possible toward Wilmington.
lead_paragraph: We learn from Admiral PORTER's official report to the Navy Department, that immediately after the evacuation of Fort Anderson, the fleet under his command pushed forward as rapidly as possible toward Wilmington. After sounding and buoying out the middle ground at Big Island, he succeeded in getting two gunboats over, and opened fire on Fort Strong, the fort commanding the principal obstructious, where the rebels had also sunk a large steamer, the North Eastern. Our fire soon drove the rebels away from the fort. On the night of the 20th inst. the rebels sent down two hundred floating torpedoes; but the Admiral had a strong force of picket-boats out, and the torpedoes were sunk with musketry. One of them struck the Osceola, but did no serious damage. Further damage from this source was averted by stretching string-nets across the river. Fort Strong surrendered on the 22d inst.

abstract: Losses; The Confederacy Doomed; Family motto "Non incautus futuri"
snippet: Losses; The Confederacy Doomed; Family motto "Non incautus futuri"
lead_paragraph: On the scroll of the family arms of ROBERT E. LEE, General-in-Chief of the Southern Confederacy, is inscribed the motto "non incautus futuri" -- not unmindful of the future. If ever that General has needed to take heed to his armorial device, surely it is at this moment. Whichever way he turns, the sky lowers over him. His resources fail him in every quarter. The rebel army of the West has been beaten to chaff on the historic threshing-floor of Tennessee. One by one every port on the rebel coast falls into our hands -- Savannah, Charleston, Wilmington, Mobile. He sees the Confederacy absolutely inclosed. Which way shall he turn? Every exit is guarded -- by a fire of gunboats on the sea, and a cordon of glittering bayonets on the land.
headline: {'main': 'The Confederacy Doomed.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'The Confederacy Doomed.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

snippet: Imperfect Education of
lead_paragraph: It is an oft-repeated boast, that we are the best educated people in the world. To a certain extent only is this true. So far as a superficial knowledge of the great elementary branches is concerned, there is no nation so universally educated. Our young people of both sexes, both in the cities and in the country, generally receive a rudimentary education; but if they require any instruction beyond this, if either their necessities or their aspirations require a deeper or more scientific education, they are compelled to pay for such instruction from their own resources. The State gives no opportunities for prosecuting studies that will fit them to enter into any of the so-called learned professions. It is true that the Government gives a most complete and thorough special education to a few young men who wish to enter either the army or navy; but their services are afterward required by the Government, and they are confined to the professions for which they were trained. The State of New-York has, we believe, made one exception to the rule just spoken of, and that was in the granting of the charter of the New-York Medical College. Their charter required (and we have heard that they always fulfilled the requirement) that the faculty of the college should annually educate, free of all charge, five of the graduates of the New-York Free Academy. Upon inquiry of members of the faculty of this college, we learn that these young graduates from the Free Academy were nearly always the most promising and industrious members of their class.

abstract: N. Y., on Fall in Gold
snippet: N. Y., on Fall in Gold
lead_paragraph: -- In spite of protests from some of our cotemporaries we hold to the opinion that it will be much better for the country that the fall in the price of gold should be gradual rather than sudden. The Tribune cannot understand why any honest business man is to be injured by a precipitate fall of gold to par. Simply because business men have been compelled, if they would do business at all, to buy property at the high rates which the high price of gold has involved: -- and if they are compelled to sell it suddenly at very low rates, they are ruined by the operation. The Tribune, for example, may have bought printing paper at 20 cents a pound to last until July: -- if a sudden fall in gold and everything else compels it to reduce its price at once from four to two cents, it would lose very heavily by the operation. Now it may not have laid in any such stock of paper and so may escape; but merchants are compelled to buy very heavy quantities of goods at ruling rates, whatever those rates may be; and sudden changes, therefore, in the currency take them at a disadvantage. If gold were to fall instantly to par how many merchants or heavy business men in the country, would be solvent at the end of a fortnight?

abstract: Highway, Waters, H H, in N Y
snippet: Highway, Waters, H H, in N Y
lead_paragraph: ANOTHER ROBBERY BY THE THIEVES OF EAST HOUSTON-STREET. -- Mr. HENRY H. WATERS, of the firm of WATERS & THOMPSON, of Newark, was robbed by as East Houston-street gang of gamesters and thieves, at about 1 o'clock yesterday morning, in Houston-street, near Crosby, within a stone's throw of the Central Department of Metropolitan Police. The gang followed him from a saloon on the northeast corner of Broadway and Houston-street, and when they had gone far enough from Broadway to have a fair start if a Fourteenth Ward policeman should miraculously attempt to interfere, they surrounded him, and one of their number held him by the throat while the others "went through" him. They then dragged him into the den where HENRY LAZARUS was murdered -- No. 12 East Houston-street -- and attempted to rob him of a gold watch which they had failed to get in their attack on the highway; but in their attempt in this they were unsuccessful. Mr. WATERS at length escaped and sought an officer, but was unable to find one until he reached Mercer-street, and to him he related his adventure. The officer -- CONWAY, of the Eighth Precinct -- promptly went with Mr. WATERS to the groggery at No. 12 East Houston-street, and apprehended one HENRY ARCHER, and the prisoner was taken to the Jefferson Market Police Court, to the prison of which Justice DODGE committed him without bail. ARCHER, who is an Englishman, aged 25 years, is supposed to be one of a gang of English thieves and ticket-of-leave men that were imported two years ago. A census might be very interesting showing the occupation of the residents and visitors of East Houston-street from Broadway and Mulberry-street, and of Broadway on the cast side from Houston-street to Bleeker.

abstract: We have received Richmond papers of Friday last, but they contain very little war news. Gen. JOE JOHNSTON, whose appointment to active command we have already announced, has been with BEAUREGARD ever since the rebel forces returned from the line of the Edisto. abstract: THE DRAFT IN THE THIRD DISTRICT.--The draft in the Third District, Brooklyn, was completed on Friday, and on Saturday many of those drawn appeared at the office of the Provost-Marshal, for the purpose of being exempted, or to report with the view of procuring substitutes. Most of those drafted are poor men, with families dependent upon them for support. Those able have mostly procured representative substitutes, and their names were, therefore, not drawn.
lead_paragraph: THE DRAFT IN THE THIRD DISTRICT. -- The draft in the Third District, Brooklyn, was completed on Friday, and on Saturday many of those drawn appeared at the office of the Provost-Marshal, for the purpose of being exempted, or to report with the view of procuring substitutes. Most of those drafted are poor men, with families dependent upon them for support. Those able have mostly procured representative substitutes, and their names were, therefore, not drawn.

abstract: Lopez, Gen; Friendly Letter to Rebel Gen Pyron
snippet: Lopez, Gen; Friendly Letter to Rebel Gen Pyron
lead_paragraph: The Houston Telegraph, of Feb. 8, prints the correspondence which lately passed between Col. PYRON, commanding at San Antonio, and Gen. FLORENTINO LOPEZ, commanding MAXIMILIAN's troops on the borders of the Rio Grande. The former assures Gen. LOPEZ that it is the desire of his Government to cherish the most amiable relations with the Imperial Government of Mexico, and further that the entente cordiale existing shall not be disturbed. The Colonel also thanks the General for "protecting the interests" of the Confederates. The reply of Gen. LOPEZ is subjoined:

abstract: to be dropped
snippet: to be dropped
lead_paragraph: -- The Senate, on Saturday, refused to make the Bankrupt Bill the special order for the ensuing session. This is equivalent to an intimation that the measure is to be dropped. We cannot say that we had any great hopes of a different result. Nothing was ever more clearly shown than that the great body of our citizens desire and pray for this, or for some measure of commercial relief. We do not speak alone of the almost unanimous opinion of the public press, nor of the deluge of petitions poured into Congress from all quarters in favor of the measure. We refer especially to the promptitude and energy with which the bill of last year was revived in the House at the opening of the present session. Congress had barely been assembled a week when the measure was taken up and passed by a vote of 76 to 56. Since that time the only outside opposition offered to it has come from one or two second and third-rate Boards of Trade, that professed to find in the measure the appliances for a general whitewashing of rebel debtors. To meet these silly averments, more argument was wasted inside and outside of the House than they were worth. The measure had to be killed to gratify certain local cliques. It will be for the new Congress to revive it and give the relief prayed for.

abstract: -- If the celebration proposed by the leading merchants and other leading citizens of New-York is to prove a success, there must be thorough activity shown by the Committee of Arrangements. That committee, as far as its names are known to the public, appears to be an excellent one for work. The time, however, within which the work must be done, is short. There are but five days to count on, and every one of these will have to be thoroughly employed, if the celebration is to be worthy of the occasion.

abstract: Early Saturday forenoon, the splendid side wheel steamship Montana, built bY WEBB  BELL, for the Pacific Mail Steamship Company, was launched from the yard foot of G-street, Greenpoint. Her dimensions are: Length between perpendiculars, 330 feet; breadth of beam, 43 feet 6 inches; depth of hold, 27 feet; 4,100 tons burden. lead_paragraph: Early Saturday forenoon, the splendid side wheel steamship Montana, built bY WEBB & BELL, for the Pacific Mail Steamship Company, was launched from the yard foot of G-street, Greenpoint. Her dimensions are: Length between perpendiculars, 330 feet; breadth of beam, 43 feet 6 inches; depth of hold, 27 feet; 4,100 tons burden. The frame of the Montana is composed of white oak, chestnut and hackmetack; floor of oak, and solid the whole length of the vessel; futtocks of oak and chestnut, and top timbers of hackmetack. She is braced with diagonal iron straps 4 1/2 inches by 7/8 inches, running from heads of floors to heads of top timbers; longitudinal straps, 5 by 7/8 inches, runs completely around the vessel, at heads of timbers, connected with and thoroughly bolted and riveted to diagonal straps. She has nine tiers of keelsons running fore and aft, thoroughly bolted to the floors. The bed keelsons for engine are each 60 feet long, 6 feet 6 inches high, and 4 feet 9 inches wide. These bed keelsons contain about 45,000 superficial feet of timber, and the keelsons together contain nearly 100,000 superficial feet. The ceiling commences, at turn of bilge, 10 inches thick, and extends upward to upper deck-clamps, which are 8 inches thick. She has three complete decks, besides orlop decks. The beams of berth and main decks are of yellow pine, and the spar and orlop decks of white pine. The gallows frame is of yellow pine, with legs 22 inches square at head and 24 inches square at heels, built and fastened in the most complete manner, to support the engine. The outside planking of the ship is of oak; garboard streak 6 inches thick; thence to lower turn of bilge, 4 inches, and gradually increasing to wales, which are 6 inches thick. In order to increase her longitudinal strength, she has been double-planked from the flat of the floor to lower side of between-deck ports with oak planking 3 1/2 inches crossing the inner course, all strongly fastened with copper bolts and locust-tree nails, wedged both inside and outside. In point of workmanship, model and finish, this ship will compare favorably with any ever built at this port. Her engines, which are being constructed at the Novelty Iron Works, will be 105 inches cylinder, and 12 feet stroke of piston. This is the fourth steamship built by WEBB & BELL for the Pacific Mall Steamship Company during the past two years.

abstract: There will be no performance at the Academy of Music to-night -- the house being rented for the Charity Ball -- a benevolent enterprise, which we trust will realize all the expectations of its promoters. Profiting by the opportunity, Mme. ZUCCHI takes her first benefit in America, at the Brooklyn establishment, playing the part of Elvira, in VERDI's opera of "Ernani." Our friends in the neighboring city have thus the privilege of anticipating the general approval, which we know would be extended to our admirable and conscientious prima donna, if her appeal were made to New-York instead of Brooklyn. They will, we are sure, take advantage of it. _____ To-morrow evening Mr. MARETZEK will give his second performance of "La Forza del Destino." The work was received with unquestionable favor on Friday last. The critics are unanimous on the subject of its merits. We have rarely witnessed such unanimity of opinion. Only a few years ago it was considered good taste to cavil at, and take exceptions to the music of this great master. When "La Traviata" was produced, a writer on the weekly press stated -- after giving vent to all his contempt -- that if the management persisted in playing it he would not notice it again; so unworthy did it seem to him of any kind of distinction. After such a threat it was clearly VERDI's duty to have withdrawn from public life, or if he obstinately persisted in writing, to cancel the offending score in question. Instead of doing so, he has permitted "La Traviata" to become a favorite, and has given us "Un Balle in Maschera," -- a work which many competent judges regard his best -- and "La Forza del Destino." Concerning the last, we have no hesitation in predicting that it will take its place for many years to come as one of the best standard Italian operas. It may not reveal the freshness of "Ernani," or the exquisite feeling of "La Traviata," but it is a firmer and better made work than either. Youth is prodigal; age is thrifty, and in the end it is thrift that we admire. How to make a little go a long way is the science of life, and all true art is human in this respect. It was knowledge that made MEYERBEER, not inspiration. For the first time VERDI places a value upon his own ideas. Instead of scattering them with idle programmes he selects the best and elaborates them with conscientious regard to their varying phases. There is a degree of strong, healthy coherence about "La Forza del Destino" which we shall seek in vain in his other works. The melodies are reticent, not blatant; they are vitally connected with the orchestral tissue, not trumpery excresences that may be cut out at pleasure. The ensembles are dramatic, and occur naturally, not artificially, at the end of each act. In short, the work exhibits the ripened knowledge of a master -- the careful intention of one who knows what he is about, and the indispensable charm of a natural melodist. A single hearing may pique curiosity, but it takes many hearings to fully gratify it. There is so much that is exquisite and lovely, that weeks will be required before the measure of public appreciation will be filled. When familiarity has brought acceptance, we are certain that "La Forza" will be accepted as the great work of its composer.

abstract: In the Senate, on Saturday, notice was given of bills to incorporate the free Literary Association of New-York: legalizing certain resolutions of the Richmond County Supervisors; incorporating the Seventy-first Militia Regiment. Bills were passed increasing the rates of pilotage in the port of New-York; incorporating the Merchants' Exchange and News Room of the City of New-York; amending the act designating legal holidays; for the relief of holders of unsecured bonds of the New-York and Erie Railroad Company. The resolution calling for information as to the amounts paid over by New-York City District Attornies on bail bonds, &c., since 1845, was adopted. The paid Fire Department Bill was made the special order for next Thursday evening.
lead_paragraph: In the Senate, on Saturday, notice was given of bills to incorporate the free Literary Association of New-York: legalizing certain resolutions of the Richmond County Supervisors; incorporating the Seventy-first Militia Regiment. Bills were passed increasing the rates of pilotage in the port of New-York; incorporating the Merchants' Exchange and News Room of the City of New-York; amending the act designating legal holidays; for the relief of holders of unsecured bonds of the New-York and Erie Railroad Company. The resolution calling for information as to the amounts paid over by New-York City District Attornies on bail bonds, &c., since 1845, was adopted. The paid Fire Department Bill was made the special order for next Thursday evening.

abstract: On Effete Ministry and Public Morals
snippet: On Effete Ministry and Public Morals
lead_paragraph: Yesterday was a field day at Plymouth Church, whose spacious auditorium was densely thronged by thousands of citizens from this and the adjacent cities. Mr. BEECHER's opening services were marked by a significant emphasis on all points which could in any way be connected with the events of the day, and long before the evening's discourse was begun it was evident to the impatient audience that a sermon practical and pointed in reference to things of living interest was in store for them. Taking for his text the words: "For your field is the World," Mr. BEECHER commenced by defining his position in regard to creeds written and unwritten, to doctrines old and new, and to theology in general. He contended that creeds were of use, but were by no means sacred; that doctrines and forms were serviceable, and that liturgies and robes were not to be despised, for the very reason that plows, and hoes, and rakes are of use and service to the farmer, simply because he needs them; but further than this he could not admit. To him a gown would be an embarrassment physical, as a liturgy would be a hindrance mental, but so long as other people need them and enjoy them, it was not his business to ridicule or despise them. Branching from this, he alluded to the sacredness of days and ordinances, such as Sunday, fast days, peculiar modes of baptism, and so on, as of use simply to educate and assist Christians in their several lines of spiritual development, while mere is and should be no intelligent recognition of sacredness or holiness about them. "This," said he, "is an era of progress, and the church must be prepared for changes and improvements, as the body politic is, and as all human organizations have been since the dawn of Eden's sun. It has been customary for the great body of Christians to regard the church and its days and ordinances and its ministers as something different from everything and everybody. This is changing somewhat, and will change still more. Far be it from me to say a word or suggest a theory which can move one of Christ's littlest ones from the rock of ages or this firmest landmark of all time, the Bible; and I only fear lest I may be misunderstood when I say that from these old superstitions of our infancy, from this reverence of means, we must move, and that right speedily. Young men, you who are casting about for employment, and who seek to know by what avenue of life's labor you arc to become useful, avoid, I beseech of you, the overcrowded pursuits of the law, the bestuffed hospitals of medicine, the hot and dreary and unsatisfactory roads of merchandise. Remember that your "field is the world," and look with me for a moment at the grandeur of your opportunities. No place in life is so full of possibility, so rich in promise, so powerful, so full of liberty as the pulpit. "Oh," says some good, pious soul, "now you're going to advise preaching politics." Preaching politics! And why not? You have your little men in pulpits, who can preach of Moses and the prophets, who can show you the length and breadth of their creed, who can explain the meaning of this term, and of that text, who can talk learnedly of original sin, and of the wickedness of men who lived two thousand years ago; but where is the minister who teaches you of the duty of to-day -- who exposes the corruptions of the time in which you live -- who expounds the duty of the men before him? In what book or newspaper can you find aught concerning the manner of using a vote? With the exception of Dr. LIEBER, a man born in Germany, but bred in America, I know of no publicist who has taught the people understandingly on this vital question of American life. I have attended many councils where learned divines examined youthful candidates for orders, but I have never yet attended or heard one where a single question was put to test the fitness of the man as a teacher on the point most vital to his congregation. They ask him all about original sin, and the fall of Adam, and the superlapsus and the sublapsus, and test him as to whether he believes in natural grace or acquired grace, whether man is wholly depraved or only in part, and if the latter, where the depravity stops and what relation it bears to the rest of his nature -- but they never, never suggest a question which would indicate that the souls or bodies of the men of the nineteenth century are of the least possible moment. These ministers are easy made. The doctors take a little of the regulation dough, they mold it into a pretty little cake of exactly the right shape, pinhole it with the necessary number of orthodox holes, put it on a patty pan, shove it into a properly built oven, and, when it is baked, you have your pretty cracker ministers. Out on them, and out on such a system. We are living in a land and in a time of peculiar temptation. We are, as a people, given greatly to lying. Why, the range of white lies alone is wonderfully long, running not only through the highest octaves but way up into the harmonies, while the sub-base of black lies is simply tremendous. We must have a change in our public men, and not only in the lower classes of officials but even in the halls of our most exalted national council. I do not propose to make charges, but I cannot forbear saying that the tone of public morals is low indeed, when we hear glibly spoken of the bartering of votes on matters of great moral purport, making our legislatures literal shambles of infamy and disgrace.

abstract: Arming Defeated by the Vote of Gulf States; Enquirer on Desertion of Gulf States; Border States Deserted by Gulf States; Deserting the Confederacy, Richmond Enquirer; Free, Facilities Wanted; Gulf States Deserting Confederacy
snippet: Arming Defeated by the Vote of Gulf States; Enquirer on Desertion of Gulf States; Border States Deserted by Gulf States; Deserting the Confederacy, Richmond Enquirer; Free, Facilities Wanted; Gulf States Deserting Confederacy
lead_paragraph: We copy from the Richmond Enquirer, of the 23d, a very significant article, touching the political sentiment of the Southern States. It is a bitter complaint on behalf of the Border States, that they have been deserted by the Gulf States in their struggle for independence. Thus far, says this organ of the rebel Executive, Virginia and the other Border States have borne the whole brunt of the terrible war, into which they were pushed, against their judgment and will, by the Gulf States. They wanted to avoid the war; for they knew how much of misery and ruin it would involve, and upon whom that ruin would fall. They wanted to consult, to take advice, to concert for united and deliberate action. But they were not permitted to do so. "The States further South repelled advice, rejected concert, and cast Virginia and her children adrift amid terrific and increasing war." "Nothing," says the Enquirer, "could check the selfish impetuosity of those who risked little of disaster to be endured by others." The Border States were forced into a war which they did not seek, by which they were certain to be ravaged and ruined, for the benefit of States which counted on escaping most of its calamities.

abstract: In the Senate, on Saturday, the bill to create the office of Solicitor and Judge-Advocate of the Navy Department, was passed. The House resolution to authorize Mr. POWELL to paint a picture for the Capitol, at a cost not exceeding $25,000, was strongly opposed by Mr. SUMNER, on the ground that our citizens were already taxed to the utmost to carry on the war. No action was taken. The Senate then took up the joint resolution recognizing the State Government of Louisiana. A substitute for the bill was offered by Mr. SUMNER, which was ordered to be printed. Mr. HOWARD spoke at length against the proposition of the Judiciary Committee, arguing that the State Government of Louisiana was but the government of a fraction of the people of that State. Mr. JOHNSON delivered a speech in favor of the resolution.

abstract: New-York Central; F ightful Accident near Jordan
snippet: New-York Central; F ightful Accident near Jordan
lead_paragraph: A merchant of this city, who was on the express train from Buffalo for Albany, on Thursday evening last, describes a fearful accident which occurred about midnight near Jordan Station, west of Syracuse, on the New-York Central Railroad. The train, consisting of nine long passenger cars and the usual luggage and other cars, was running at high speed, when the locomotive struck a defective or broken rail on a culvert, and in a twinkling seven of the passenger cars were hurled down to the valley from an embankment of about twenty feet in height. The locomotive, tender, and luggage cars leaped the broken rail and ran on three-quarters of a mile before the engineer could check them. The gentleman who gives us the information was asleep in one of the sleeping cars at the time of the accident, and his first impression, on waking, was that the entire train had been crushed into one car; but upon extricating himself from the human mass that pressed on him in every direction, he plunged through a window and landed, cut and maimed, in his midnight attire, in a snow-bank, and then saw that the train had been turned bottom upward. Around him were throngs of unclad, shivering men and women, and before him were the overturned and shattered vehicles, whence the frightened travelers were escaping through the windows. The passengers had so crowded upon each other, that the work of extricating them -- the car doors being locked, as usual, and the only mode of egress being through the windows -- was exceedingly difficult. In one car they were heaped one upon another, and the vehicle had taken fire from the overturned stove, and several of the last who were dragged out were nearly exhausted from suffocation. In another car two women were suspended by the overturned seat, on which they had been reclining, and it was necessary to enter the car to drag them from their perilous position.

abstract: Street Cleaning and New Capitol
snippet: Street Cleaning and New Capitol
lead_paragraph: -- In putting forward the claims of New-York for the proposed new Capitol buildings, the Common Council neglected to present the recommendation of general cleanliness. Mr. Inspector BOOLE supplied the omission in his testimony before the Investigating Committee, on Saturday. He said, what every resident of ordinary intelligence knows tolerably well, that "there has been no street-cleaning since the 24th of December, 1864." A few more marble palaces among the fast-accumulating hills of dirt would improve the existing variety of our street-adornments wonderfully.

abstract: Removal of Lower Jaw by Dr. Raphael
snippet: Removal of Lower Jaw by Dr. Raphael
lead_paragraph: -- A remarkable surgical operation for necrosis of the lower jaw was performed in this city about a fortnight ago on a German boy twelve years of age, by the eminent surgeon, Dr. RAPHAEL, Professor of Surgery in the Thirteenth-street Medical College. This terrible and fortunately rare disease was induced by the fumes of phosphorus arising from lucifer matches -- the boy being a worker at the match-making business, and having had a tooth extracted over a year ago, which gave the malady the opportunity to gain a foothold in his system. The disease had been going on for thirteen months, until it involved nearly the whole of the lower jaw; and the external appearance of the boy was pitiful in the extreme, the face being swollen to greatly abnormal proportions, and pus exuding from large sinuses or openings along the line of the bone on the left side of the jaw. With difficulty the patient was gotten under the influence of chloroform, and when the bone was exposed from its upper left extremity to the middle of the chin, it was found that the whole mass was in the worst stage of disease. At the latter point the bone was severed with the saw, and a hope entertained of saving the right half of the jaw, or a part of it; but on examination, the disease was found to extend upward on that side also, and involved a farther removal of half of that half of the bone, which was also executed with masterly skill and great delicacy. The fleshy parts were then brought together with the suture, and tastefully dressed by the operating surgeon.
headline: {'main': 'REMOVAL OF THE LOWER JAW.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'REMOVAL OF THE LOWER JAW.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: Ogden, Judge, Supreme Court of New-Jersey; Hoboken, by Teresa Beiss
snippet: Ogden, Judge, Supreme Court of New-Jersey; Hoboken, by Teresa Beiss
lead_paragraph: CONSPIRACY. -- A German woman named TERESA BEISS was arrested on Saturday afternoon, by Constable WHITNEY, on a charge of having stolen a gold watch and chain, valued at $150, from GOTLEIB BREFUSS, a Swiss watchmaker, keeping a lager beer saloon in Washington-street, near the Post-office, Hoboken. It appears that Mrs. BEISS came to this country recently, bringing with her about $3,000, leaving her husband behind to dispose of some property. She engaged in the Prescott House, Broadway, as a domestic, where the complainant, who was acquainted with her in the old country, visited her, and becoming aware that she had means, desired her to take a partnership in his business. Mrs. BEISS accompanied the complainant to Hoboken, taking along her effects, but after arriving there, declined to enter into partnership until she had an opportunity to see how the business prospered. On Saturday, as is alleged, BREFUSS desired to borrow $100, offering as security eight watches, which she declined. He then went out and shortly after returned and accused her of having stolen his watch, which she denied, and he then locked her up in a room, procured a warrant from Judge POPE and caused her arrest. After the arrest, Constable WHITNEY searched the woman's trunks and bedding thoroughly, but was unable to find the property. Persons in the same house stated that the accused had not left the premises. BREFUSS finally offered to withdraw the charge on her agreeing not to prosecute for false imprisonment, and on his part he agreed to publish an advertisement in the German papers stating that she was innocent, and thus the matter ended.

abstract: Cheerfulness of Rebels under Disaster
snippet: Cheerfulness of Rebels under Disaster
lead_paragraph: -- It may not be generally known that Mark Tapley after his early adventures, returned to America and went South. But no one who reads the rebel newspapers can doubt that he "in spires" their ablest and most brilliant leading articles. Their determination to be "jolly" under all circumstances is thoroughly and unmistakably Taplei-an. Every seaport they lose is so much clear gain. Every defeat they suffer is an advantage. The loss of the seaboard relieves them from the necessity of defending it. The stoppage of blockade-running relieves them from the necessity of paying for foreign supplies. The failure to get recognized by foreign nations concentrates their energies by throwing them back on their own resources. The defeat of HOOD released what was left of his army from duty in Tennessee, and enabled it to go where it was wanted more. The general military disasters which the Confederacy has recently suffered are of immense service to the cause, because they have forced DAVIS to make LEE General-in-Chief.

abstract: Bankrupt Bill
snippet: Bankrupt Bill
lead_paragraph: -Many of our business citizens still refuse to believe that the Senate has finally decided the fate of the Bankrupt Bill. They are utterly at a loss to understand the grounds on which the opposition to the measure purports to be based. If we had any belief that the bill has not purposely been kept back in committee till this late hour, in order to make a disposition of it without bringing it to the test of a direct vote, we should make another appeal to the Senate on this all-important question. A measure of commercial relief, such as is prayed for, can only be temporarily defeated. Its refusal now is simply trifling with the clearly expressed wishes of the vast majority of our loyal citizens. At best the opponents of the measure can only delay it. They can neither stop the agitation, nor finally defeat the measure.

abstract: City Government, Reforms Needed
snippet: City Government, Reforms Needed
lead_paragraph: The committee appointed by the State Senate is pushing its inquiries into the management of our city affairs with ability, independence and success -- if that can be called success which simply convicts us of having no City Government that deserves the name. We have reported the testimony they have taken from day to day, and although it develops the mingled imbecility and corruption which pervade the whole machinery of our local rule, nobody seems to have been in the least surprised by its revelations. The only comment made is -- "Oh, we knew all that before."

abstract: -PROGRESS OF EXCHANGE. -- Under the judicious and energetic direction of Col. MULFORD, the exchange of prisoners goes on bravely. We publish to-day, a list of the names of the 500 officers who were received within our lines below City Point on the 21st and 22d inst., and since then, forwarded to Annapolis. With this last installment, the Richmond military prisons have all -- thank Heaven! -- been emptied of their loyal inmates. Col. MULFORD has also perfected his arrangements for the delivery of those who have been in prison at Columbia, Salisbury, and a part of those at Florence. The place named for this exchange is Wilmington. The Georgia and Alabama prisoners are to be delivered at Mobile; those west of the Mississippi at the mouth of Red River. Col. MULFORD, moreover, has not limited his exertions to the matter of an exchange of purely military prisoners. He has included in his arrangements the release of loyal masters and crews of vessels, and of not a few private citizens as well. The point at which Col. MULFORD has established his office on the James River (Varina) places him in easy communication with the Lieutenant-General, and the public need not be specially advised of the fact that Gen. GRANT extends the utmost facilities necessary to make the exchange as perfect and as speedy as the circumstances will admit.
lead_paragraph: -PROGRESS OF EXCHANGE. -- Under the judicious and energetic direction of Col. MULFORD, the exchange of prisoners goes on bravely. We publish to-day, a list of the names of the 500 officers who were received within our lines below City Point on the 21st and 22d inst., and since then, forwarded to Annapolis. With this last installment, the Richmond military prisons have all -- thank Heaven! -- been emptied of their loyal inmates. Col. MULFORD has also perfected his arrangements for the delivery of those who have been in prison at Columbia, Salisbury, and a part of those at Florence. The place named for this exchange is Wilmington. The Georgia and Alabama prisoners are to be delivered at Mobile; those west of the Mississippi at the mouth of Red River. Col. MULFORD, moreover, has not limited his exertions to the matter of an exchange of purely military prisoners. He has included in his arrangements the release of loyal masters and crews of vessels, and of not a few private citizens as well. The point at which Col. MULFORD has established his office on the James River (Varina) places him in easy communication with the Lieutenant-General, and the public need not be specially advised of the fact that Gen. GRANT extends the utmost facilities necessary to make the exchange as perfect and as speedy as the circumstances will admit.
