abstract: Rebel Gov N C, War Speech; Gov Vance's Speech
snippet: Rebel Gov N C, War Speech; Gov Vance's Speech
lead_paragraph: We remarked the other day that the authorities and people of North Carolina seemed to be awaiting the arrival of SHERMAN's army with perfect composure. Since then we have published a tepid proclamation from Gov. VANCE calling for assistance, and in this issue we give a chilly speech that the same functionary delivered at Goldsboro some ten days since. Gov. VANCE gave it as his unimpassioned opinion, that "he who submits is a mean dog," and then mildly declared that he "did not believe the people of North Carolina would submit." He at once guarded and qualified this remark, however, by adding that "when they understand the true issue, they will resist." He soon thought it necessary to further bolster up his assertion, for it would seem he saw incredulity in the faces of his listeners. "You think," said he, "that I am speaking now to encourage you, and not to tell you what I expect." He asserted, however, in the high-living style of Bunkum, that he did expect certain things, if certain things were so and so. The most decidedly cheerful part of this decidedly cheerless speech, is where, immediately after making the able remark that "the voice of the people is the voice of God," VANCE goes on to exclaim: "Four hundred thousand men -- living men -- were on the muster-rolls of the Confederacy, and almost one-half of them were absent." We cannot, of course, dispute the proposition as to the "voice of the people," but we would like to Know how we shall interpret the "voice" of the Southern people, if those of them who remain at home spend their time in dolefully repeating to each other "we are nearly whipped," -- if furthermore, the "women of the country" will not stop "writing letters to their husbands in the army, making them discontented;" and if, beside all this, two hundred thousand out of the four hundred thousand troops in the rebel armies are "absent" -- not in mind, but in body; in other words, are deserters, and that, too, at this Confederate crisis; we should certainly say that under such circumstances the Confederate "voice' is not as clear and harmonious in its tones as the occasion and the comparison demand.

abstract: Nursery and Child's Hospital Ball
snippet: Nursery and Child's Hospital Ball
lead_paragraph: The Academy of Music never looked gayer, and a more brilliant assemblage never gathered within its walls than on last evening, at the Charity Ball, given for the benefit of the Nursery and Child's Hospital. The flooring was extended over the orchestra seats, which, with the stage, gave ample space for dancing. In the rear of the stage was an Italian colonnade, in front of which were two terraces -- the upper one surmounted by gas lights, held by groups of children. In front were vases of green vines and gold fish, while in the centre was a posture of natural flowers. Over the stage was the word "Charity" formed by gas jets, in large letters, which was very beautiful. Around the boxes were festoons, vases of flowers. BRADY also adorned the house with many of his beautiful photographs, among which was a group of the lady managers of Sanitary Fair, many of whom are also managers of the Nursery and Child's Hospital. The guests began to assemble at an early hour, in full dress, and until 10:30 o'clock the line of coaches filled Fourteenth-street to Fourth-avenue. At that time the scone was most brilliant, the many gas-lights, rich decorations, and costly and magnificent toiletes of the lad[???] presenting a beautiful spectacle. The worth, the intelligence and the beauty of the great metropolis were ill well represented. The arrangements were excellent, carefully avoiding all confusion. The following were the executive committee: George Griswold Gray, Arthur Leery, Henry Clews, John Pyne, Daniel Kingsland, Peter Maric, Wm.P. Salboys, and James F. Ruggles.

abstract: Dispatch on Fall of Charleston
snippet: Dispatch on Fall of Charleston
lead_paragraph: -- The Richmond Dispatch does not see that the flight of the rebel troops from Charleston was a "blessing in diguise," or that it was a part of a brilliant plan concocted long ago. It had the courage to declare on Saturday last that Charleston fell "because our own (rebel) military blunders permitted him (SHERMAN) to make strategic combinations which rendered it inevitable."

abstract: Few incidents connected with, or springing from the action of the insurgent States, has created greater excitement, or caused more immediate fear than the well-remembered attempt to burn this great city on the night of Nov. 25, 1864. The terror of our citizens upon that night and the following morning evinced the vastness of the possible danger from similar causes, and stimulated the action of our authorities, national and local, in the laudable endeavor to detect and bring to justice the perpetrators of so vast an outrage. The theories advanced by certain semi-loyal journals as to the operators and motives of the same found but few adherents. The facts are so patently fiendish, the attempts so nearly successful, that the community scouted as one man, the idea that any resident of the metropolis was guilty of the offence. The keen eyed and experienced scouts of Chief YOUNG soon penetrated the mystery, and evidence clear to them as the noon-day sun, proved indisputably that no hand save that of a stranger and an enemy had applied the incendiary's torch to half a score of our hotels filled with women and children, and attempted the fearful destruction of several places of public amusement crowded with life and innocence. A clue singularly obtained was successfully followed, and in process of time the chief culprit was caught, brought to this city and arraigned for trial. A fairer court than that which has tried the pirate BEAL and the incendiary STANTON alias KENNEDY has never convened. Its President, Brig.-Gen. FITZ HENRY WARREN, brings to the discharge of his duties a clear head, a warm heart, a brilliant intellect and an experience varied in culture, as it is rich in honorable preferment, while the other members are recognized officers and gentlemen of mental, moral and professional worth, the Judge-Advocate ranking high among his legal cotemporaries and possessing equally the confidence of the Government and the respect of the men on whose cases he is compelled to pass. Some weeks since the court assembled at the Headquarters of the Department of the East, organized as follows: Brig.-Gen. Fitz Henry Warren, United States Volunteers -- President; Brig.-Gen. W.H. Morris, United States Volunteers; Col. M.S. Howe, Third United States Cavalry; Col. H. Day, United States Artillery; Brevet Lieut.-Col R.F. O'Bierne, Fourteenth United States Infantry; Maj. John A. Bolles, A.D.C. and Judge-Advocate of the Department.

abstract: Question in Present Congress; Amend. Consummation in no hurry
snippet: Question in Present Congress; Amend. Consummation in no hurry
lead_paragraph: ALEXANDER the Great apportioned his Empire on his death-bed; PETER the Great fixed Russian policy in his will. But this Thirty-eighth Congress is not Great. It will do well to finish its dying without any further attempt to dictate to the future. The restless craving to settle just how the Southern States shall be restored had better be composed into a serious and humble attention to its own final concerns. The country now asks nothing better of it than that it should die with decency.

abstract: The New-York Medical College for Women, will hold its first annual commencement on Wednesday evening, March 1, at the Broadway Athenaeum, (formerly Dr. OSGOOD's Church,) exercises to commence at 8 o'clock. Hon. Jas. T. Brady, Henry Ward Beecher, Theodore Tilton, and Rev. Drs. Crosby, Boole and Cox will be present to make addresses.....WILLIAM ROSS WALLACE delivers his discourse on Peter the Great, and recites some of his celebrated Union lyrics, next Wedesday evening, in the Cooper Institute, for the benefit of the Rose Hill Soldiers' Relief Association. The Harmonic Glee Club will be present, and the Hon. JAMES WADSWORTH will preside.....At a recent meeting of the Union League Club a following resolution was passed without a dissenting vote: "heartily approving of the attempt now being made for the establishment of a paid Fire Department in the City of New-York." At a subsequent meeting of the Club a special committee to bring the subject before the proper committee at Albany, was appointed consisting of SINCLAIR TOUSEY, THEO. ROOSEVELT Elliot C. Comdin, Stephen Hyatt, J.M. Cross, Jackson S. Schultz and Timothy G. Churchill ...A lecture will be given at Cooper Institute this evening by JOHN MERCER LANGSTON, for the Ladies' Union Bazaar Association, the proceeds to go for sick and wounded soldiers....The annual ball of the Seventy-ninth Regiment, Highlanders, takes place on Friday evening, March 3, at the City Assembly Rooms....The semi-annual exhibition of the pupils of St. Francis Xavier's College, will be given at the college, in Sixteenth-street, near Sixth-avenue, this evening....Col. CHARLES C. NOTT, of this city, well-known and highly esteemed as a learned lawyer, and a brave and skillful officer in our western armies during the earlier years of the war, has been appointed Judge of the United States Court of Claims.

abstract: In the Senate yesterday a note was read from the President, declining to furnish a statement of all the men raised by the several States during the war. A House bill to protect emigrants from being decoyed into the army or navy was reported favorably. It was voted that documents now accumulated in the storeroom be distributed among the members of the present Congress. Some discussion followed upon a resolution to purchase Mr. POWELL's historical picture for $25,000, but the matter was not settled. The question of the recognition of the Government of Louisiana coming up, a brief discussion ensued, in which several Senators spoke in opposition to the idea. Mr. SUMNER especially denouncing the so-called government in emphatic teams. On a million to postpone this (the Louisiana) question and take up the Tax Bill, the vote was yeas 24, nays 11. The Senate adopted the report of their Conference Committee on the Army and Navy appropriations, and other bills were passed. The Tax Bill then came up and and was denounced by GARRETT DAVIS, who moved its indefinite postponement. After his speech the Senate enjoyed their recess. In the evening the Tax Bill was taken up, and Er. SHERMAN made an elaborate speech.

abstract: -This association makes an appeal for aid. It has recently celebrated its fifty-first anniversary. During the past half century it has received within its doors many aged women, some of whom had once been in affluent circumstances. It has clothed, sheltered and fed them while living, and when dead has given them decent Christian burial. This work it is still doing. The asylum is always full, there being now ninety-three pensioners beneath its roof. Vacancies made by death are at once filled from the list of candidates for admission. There are also one hundred out-door pensioners ministered to abroad. All contributions will be thankfully received.

abstract: -On the 22d inst. the people of Tennessee voted on the Free Constitution adopted a few weeks since by the State Convention. Thus far the returns show no opposition. The Nashville Times estimates the vote in Middle Tennessee at 14,000 in favor to just about none against. In West Tennessee the rebel guerrillas will probably interfere materially with the voting, but of course there will be no nays. East of Knoxville the vote will be all in favor.

abstract: This board met at 2 P. M. yesterday, Mr. JAMES HAYES in the chair.  A communication was received from MOSES TAYLOR, Esq., Chairman of the committee of citizens appointed to make arrangements for celebrating our recent victories, inviting the board to join in the celebration.

abstract: THE NEW-YORK SEMI-WEEKLY TIMES is published THIS MORNING, and may be had at the counter of the publication office in wrappers ready for mailing. Price FIVE CENTS. In addition to the latest intelligence by telegraph up to the moment of going to press, there will be found in the current number full details of all military movements in the different departments from the pens of our special correspondents. Also, all official orders, reports and documents, and the latest and fullest Washington news, European news, with graphic letters from our correspondents in London and Paris, giving the tone of public feeling abroad, is made a special and permanent feature. In addition to Editorials on all the current topics of the day, the SEMI-WEEKLY TIMES has a page of carefully prepared commercial matter, giving the latest financial news and market reports; items of agricultural and domestic interest, compiled from sources many of which are otherwise inaccessible to the American readers and marriages and deaths of the week.

abstract: Common Council Decline to Celebrate Victories
snippet: Common Council Decline to Celebrate Victories
lead_paragraph: The Committee of Arrangements of the National Celebration of Union Victories, WILLIAM P. BLODGETT, Esq., Chairman, were in session the entire day yesterday at the Astor House, attending to the preliminaries for the great celebration on Saturday next. The committee is composed of the following citizens: Wm.P. Blodgett, Chairman; Thos. C. Acton, Elliott C. Cowdin, M. Cooper, Josiah Hadden, Hon. Chas. C. Cornell, Supervisor Wm.M. Tweed, and Hon. Douglass Taylor.

abstract: The deaths in this city during the past week numbered 554 -- 133 men, 137 women, 159 boys and 125 girls -- an increase of 57 upon the mortality of the previous week, and a decrease of 4 as compared with the corresponding week of the past year. Of the deceased, 262 were children under 5 years of age. The mortality by the principal diseases was as follows: Consumption, 99; marasmus, 28; infantile convulsions, 30; diphtheria, 14; scarlet lever, 16; typhus fever, 15; inflammation of the lungs, 50; small-pox, 30. The deaths from small-pox during the previous week were 35.

abstract: City Mortality
snippet: City Mortality
lead_paragraph: The weather during the past ten days has been altogether as seasonable as our experience would lead us to expect. Yet, the mortality of the past week, it will be seen, shows an increase of fifty-seven upon the mortality of the previous week. That increase is unquestionably due to the condition of the streets, wherein the daily accumulation of garbage and every sort of filth is altogether frightful. It is surely time that the Board of Health were convened, or the Mayor ought to give the citizens some reason for delaying a step which every succeeding day renders more imperatively necessary.
headline: {'main': 'THE CITY MORTALITY', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'THE CITY MORTALITY', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}
